PETITION.TITLE: Telecommunications: Future Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned shows that there is widespread community concern over the introduction of competition into Australia's telecommunications industry, and that ordinary consumers may be faced with higher prices and reduced services as a result. In particular, we are concerned about the impact on the affordability of telephone services for low income earners and rural consumers.
The petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
(a) protect ordinary consumers from increasing prices and decreasing service and to ensure that the telephone remains an affordable utility
(b) clearly define community service obligations of all telecommunications providers

(c) ensure that, regardless of the structural arrangements, a strong and viable government telecommunications carrier is maintained and continues to provide a universal, affordable service to all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and senators in the Senate assembled.

The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesmanlike leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:-

The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting, solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitions request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 78 I give notice that, at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting, I shall withdraw the notice of motion standing in my name for that day for disallowance of the Australian Horticultural Corporation (Export Control) Regulations as contained in Statutory Rules 1990 No. 422. SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 March I reported to the Senate on the concern of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances with this instrument, which related to the drafting, subdelegation and review of discretions exercisable by public officials. The Committee has received a reply from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) which undertakes to amend the regulations to meet two of these concerns and to review the legislation in respect of a third. SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
...21 February 1991
The Hon John Kerin MP
Minister for Primary Industries and Energy
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,
I refer to the Australian Horticultural Corporation (Export Control) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1990 No.422. The Committee considered the Regulations at its meeting of 21 February 1991.
The Committee would appreciate your advice on the following matters-

1. In regulation 4 (a) there is a typographical error, the word ``applies appearing in place of what obviously should be ``apples.'' The Committee normally does not expressly draw attention to such oversights, unless they affect the substance of a provision. However, this is such a case as regulation 4 is one of the most important provisions in the whole scheme. There is also a typographical error in r.16 (f), which misspells the name of a friendly Pacific region country.

2. Regulation 14 provides that ``The (Australian Horticultural) Corporation may charge such fees as it considers necessary to enable it to recover costs that it incurs in controlling the export of horticultural products.'' The Committee would appreciate your advice as to whether this provision is intended to sub-delegate the power in s.121(e) of the parent Act to make regulations imposing fees in relation to the registration of premises and other places. If so, your advice would be appreciated on the validity of such subdelegation. In this context the Committee notes that s.9(1) (e) of the parent Act refers to charges, which presumably are different to fees. There also appears to be no provision for the fees charged under r.14 to be subject to any kind of parliamentary scrutiny. They are apparently not required to be gazetted, tabled or subject to disallowance. The Committee would wish to know whether any of the fees contemplated by r.14 are mandatory imposts on any individual pursuing a livelihood in the horticultural industry.

3. Regulation 18 provides for rights of review to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of a number of decisions. However, unless they are seen as part of refusing to grant a licence, it does not seem that the determination of a financial rating for a licensee in r.9 or decisions on excuses for a licensee being unable to export horticultural products in r.10 (2) (b) are reviewable. Similarly, there does not appear to be a right of review of any failure of the Corporation to approve credit assessors under r.15 (2). All of these decisions appear to have important commercial and livelihood implications.

4. The Explanatory Statement is somewhat slight in that it does not give an explanation of the individual clauses in the regulations. This is not a minor point. For example, at the first dot point on page 1 the Explanatory Statement advises that the regulations may be extended to cover horticultural products which will be listed in a Schedule to the Regulations. In fact, this does not appear to be possible under the Regulations. Again, the first dot point on page 2 advises that licences are not required for some destinations (Antarctica, Christmas Island, Cocos Islands and various Pacific Islands) listed in a Schedule to the Regulations. There is no such Schedule.
Yours sincerely
Patricia Giles
Chair

Senate Standing Committee
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600

Senator P Giles...15 May 1991
Senate Standing Committee
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Giles
I refer to your letter of 21 February 1991 on the Australian Horticultural (Export Control) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1990 No. 422.

These Regulations were introduced to increase the simplicity and flexibility of the export control system operated for apples and pears under the now repealed Australian Horticultural Corporation (Apple and Pear Export Control) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1988 No. 187. The new Regulations also provide for the export licensing of other horticultural commodities, besides apples and pears, as are prescribed in the Regulations. Citrus is currently the only other commodity so prescribed.
My Department has sought the advice of the Attorney-General's Department on the matters you have raised and the potential impact they may have on the operation of the licensing system.

Firstly, in regard to the typographical errors, the Attorney-General's Department advises that it is the usual practice of the Courts to interpret legislation in accordance with its ordinary meaning. They believe the meaning of sub-clauses 4(a) and 16(f), in which these errors occur, is clear from the context and that these mistakes should therefore not affect the day to day operation of the Regulations.

Secondly, you ask whether Regulation 14 under which the Corporation is empowered to charge fees to recover the cost of controlling horticultural exports is an attempt to sub-delegate the power contained in section 121 of the Australian Horticultural Act 1987 (the Act). The legal authority for the wording of Regulation 14 is in fact sub-section 117(5) of the Act which states, inter alia,

``the regulations may empower the Corporation to charge such fees as it considers necessary to enable it to recover costs that it incurs in controlling the export from Australia of horticultural products''.
The question of delegation under section 121 does not therefore arise.

There are no arrangements in either the Act or the Regulations for the publication and Parliamentary review of the fees that the Corporation may charge for its services. However, the Attorney-General's Department advises that the wording of sub-section 117(5) of the Act in conjunction with the general law precludes the Corporation from charging more than a reasonable amount for costs reasonably incurred. These fees must be paid by all persons wishing to obtain a license to export prescribed horticultural products and the Corporation has advised that the fee for a license is currently $500 per annum.
Thirdly, you raise the rights of review by the Administrative Appeals Committee of Corporation decisions relating to the financial rating of licensees and the approval of credit assessors.

The Corporation is currently reviewing the export licensing system now it has been in operation for a period with a view to increasing its efficiency. Several areas have been identified which will require changes to the Regulations including, possibly, those sections dealing with the financial rating of exporters and the process of credit assessment. I therefore believe it is premature to consider amendment of the regulations at this time to provide for greater review rights in this area of the Corporation's decisionmaking, particularly as sub-clause 18(4) of the Regulations provides for Administrative Appeals Tribunal review of any conditions placed on an export license by the Corporation effecting the holder of a license.

The Corporation intends to put forward to my Department proposals for amendment of the Regulations by July 1991. I therefore propose that the matter of review of decisions and the typographical corrections suggested by your Committee be considered for inclusion as a package together with the changes requested by the Corporation at that time. The need for Parliamentary scrutiny of fees charged by the Corporation for administering the licensing system will also be considered at this time.
Finally, I have attached for your information a revised Explanatory Statement giving an explanation of all the individual clauses in the Regulations.
Yours fraternally
John Kerin

The speeches read as follows-
PETROLEUM (SUBMERGED LANDS) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

This Bill will make a number of miscellaneous amendments to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 to tidy up the legislation. Some of these will shorten the administrative decision process, consistent with the government's microeconomic reform initiative.

The Bill will enable the joint authorities to delegate jointly to Commonwealth and State or Northern Territory officials the more routine administrative decisions that they are required to make under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967.

It is intended that only decisions that do not diverge from established policy will be delegated. If there is any disagreement between the two officials involved on any matter to be decided, the matter must be referred back to Ministers for a decision. This amendment will streamline the administration of the offshore petroleum legislation without weakening ministerial authority over decisions made under the legislation.

The Bill will also replace the requirement for holders of offshore petroleum titles to lodge securities with a mandatory requirement for titleholders to take out insurance against potential liabilities arising from their operations. Currently, the requirements for insurance while usually attached as a condition of grant or renewal of a title are not mandatory.

The amendments will reduce the administration costs borne by industry while ensuring that the community is well protected against any liabilities arising out of offshore petroleum operations. While we never have had a major spill from petroleum exploitation operations in this country, this action will ensure that, in the unlikely case that an oil spill does occur, that environmental clean up costs will be fully met by the operators and their insurers.

Seismic surveying undertaken by contractors on a speculative basis over offshore areas not held under a petroleum title is a valuable means of encouraging exploration. It encourages exploration companies to express interest in, and to bid for, exploration permits over these vacant areas.

Such action can only enhance the offshore search for petroleum in Australia. This Bill will provide an additional incentive for such operations by giving the designated authority the discretion to extend the confidentiality period for the basic information collected in such operations to up to five years prior to providing public access to the information.

The Great Barrier Reef is a national treasure which all responsible Australian governments must manage and protect from damage for all time. This Government has made it clear that there will be no exploration for petroleum in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park or the coastal area extending up to the low water mark. Exploration in the five petroleum exploration permits, granted under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967, has been inactive since 1971 and operations were formally suspended in 1974.

Given the Government's commitment to a total ban on petroleum exploration in the park, continuation of the five permits was seen as anachronistic. The Government therefore announced its determination to terminate the permits on 26 July 1990.

One of the two companies with permits in the Great Barrier Reef region, Chevron, has favourably responded to our request and agreed to voluntarily surrender their four exploration permits in the area which were held by their subsidiary Keydrill Australia Incorporated. This action demonstrates Chevron's standing as an environmentally concerned corporate citizen.
This Bill will enable the Government to terminate the remaining permit in the region, Q/11P.

An amendment to section 130 of the Act is proposed to clarify an ambiguity that currently exists with respect to domestic gas phase royalties obtained from the North West Shelf project. The change is specifically intended to define that category of royalty that the Commonwealth agreed to transfer to Western Australia to ensure the long term viability of the liquefied natural gas (LNG) export phase of the North West Shelf project.

As it is currently drafted, no distinction is made in the legislation between Commonwealth royalties obtained from the domestic gas and LNG phases of the project. This ambiguity has been drawn to the attention of the Western Australian Government and they have indicated that they have no concerns in principle with the change.

The Bill also clarifies two minor possible ambiguities in the Act. First, a more precise definition of exploring for petroleum will ensure that all relevant operations are covered by the Act. Another amendment will clarify the obligations of a holder of an access authority to affected titleholders.
Finally the Bill will remove minor inconsistencies and overlap between the Act and the Crimes Act 1914 which have occurred because of amendments to the Crimes Act 1914.

Section 132 of the Act, which is now redundant because of recent amendments to the Crimes Act 1914, will be repealed. Other amendments will extend the scope of offences dealt with in sections 133 and 135 of the Act to cover inchoate offences. Another amendment to section 84 of the Act will remove an inconsistency with other parts of the Act by requiring that a person knowingly provides false or misleading information in the test for offences under the section.
None of the amendments have any significant financial impact although the amendment to section 130 of the Act may have the effect of deferring minimal payments of royalty to Western Australia.
I commend the Bill to the Senate, and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
PETROLEUM (SUBMERGED LANDS) (ROYALTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Royalty) Act 1967 to enable the efficient and correct determination of royalties from those areas subject to offshore petroleum royalties. Royalty is collected on a calendar month basis and is shared between the Commonwealth and the respective adjacent State.

As a result of the Government's decision last year to extend the coverage of the resource rent tax legislation to the Bass Strait region, the North West Shelf project, Australia's largest resource development, is the only producing region subject to the scope of this legislation. The Government's decision not to extend resource rent tax to the North West Shelf project was in recognition of the vast sums of financing involved in the infrastructure associated with the development, and the sensitivity surrounding the export phase of the project.

The proposed amendments are intended to clarify a number of matters of detail which are not specifically addressed by the legislation and give legislative support to administrative practices. They will, therefore, not add any further administrative burden on either government or the petroleum producers.

The amendment will allow for an interim royalty to be paid by the producers in circumstances where full agreement on royalty arrangements has yet to be finalised between the parties. On finalisation of the royalty agreement, adjustments to the interim royalty paid will be made.

The amendment will also enable any royalty payment that has been made by the producers to be considered as an interim payment until such time as the full details of the royalty calculation have been verified and accepted. The current provisions provide insufficient time to satisfactorily verify the information submitted by the producers, resulting in the potential for incorrect royalty payments to be made.

In addition, the amendments will facilitate the adjustment to royalty in cases of overpayment or underpayment arising from the incorrect application or interpretation of an agreed or determined procedure contained within a royalty agreement.

The amendments will not result in any additional administrative and compliance costs, but will provide added clarity of and certainty in the provisions. The impact of the proposed amendments are expected to be revenue neutral.
I commend the Bill to the Senate, and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last day or two we have focused on part of Estimates Committee A dealing with the question of the Clerks. Senators Coates and Short chose to take up the issue--
—Schacht.

—I sincerely beg your pardon; Senator Short did indeed take up the question in the Estimates hearing itself. He was equally deplored by the behaviour of Senator Coates and Senator Schacht on that occasion. The debate took a particular unpleasant turn when Senator Coates, having chosen to withdraw a motion which many of us found offensive, took the opportunity during the second reading debate to attack once again the institution of the Clerks in the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of that, Senator Schacht backed him up. He came along as a non-member of the Committee for the purpose of joining in the attack on the first day of the hearings. If one reads the Hansard one sees that Senator Coates did not make much of a contribution to the rest of the hearings after that attack. If one reads yesterday's Hansard one sees that the contribution made by both Senator Coates and Senator Schacht concerning the way the Opposition handled the issue amounted to rather gratuitous and offensive insults. This was about on par with the calibre of the attack made during the Estimates hearings.

For instance, a reading of the Hansard shows that Senator Coates asked the Clerk whether he would itemise what amount of time during his working hours was spent in putting together articles subsequently published. Senator Coates did not take into account the voluntary extra time and hours spent and not remunerated. The attack had a mean and nasty aspect to it. Anyone who reads the entire Hansard will see that the substance of what they argued was not worth while.

It was seen to be a personal and very particularised attack. There was no substance at all to the arguments they put forward. Subsequently, we have received more material dealing with allegations-if I can call them that. But all in all, last evening when either Senator Schacht or Senator Coates said that the Clerk ably defended himself and really required no defence as it were from anybody else, he was quite right.

I find it absolutely reprehensible that anyone should make these assertions because one speaks up in favour of the institution of the Senate and the important part that it plays within the parliamentary system as we understand it, because one defends the right of an individual to exercise freedom of speech-as we have seen, the Government pays only lip service to it; with its proposed banning legislation it would like to abolish and, indeed, seems hell-bent on abolishing it-and because somebody exercises the right to use expertise and place that expertise into the public arena for the purposes of enhancing debate and available information. I find it not only outrageous but also offensive when those two honourable senators simply say to an honourable senator on this side of the House that they are in favour of freedom of speech and the right to publish, and that they are somehow behaving in a partisan way and are trying to protect some privilege.

It is very important to place on the record that this whole incident and the way that this debate was raised were unseemly. The way it has been pursued is also unseemly. Any fair reading of the Hansard of the hearings and the debate that has taken place subsequently will show that two senators seem to be intent upon some sort of vendetta. This ought not reflect on the way that the rest of the Senate regards this institution. For instance, I note that last night Senator Schacht said that he would not weep any tears were the Senate to be abolished. Certainly the rest of Australia would not agree with that attitude.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of the role of the Clerks in this chamber is not a matter for government-and I am here as a government spokesman. It does not come, within our knowledge, as the first priority of 100,000 issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Individual senators are entitled to put their views both at the Estimates committees and in the Committee of the Whole; that is a simple right extended to all honourable senators. That entitlement takes a slightly different turn when Senator Bishop now says that the attacks on the Clerks were mean and nasty. That is an interesting comment coming from Senator Bishop, whom I watched on television in not this round of Estimates committees but the previous one. If I have ever seen crude, arrogant behaviour, I saw it then. Of my 10 years in the Senate watching Estimates committee interrogations, the treatment of public servants on that occasion was the worst performance ever.

I heard Senator Bishop demand to know the identity of a person who passed a note. I saw her harangue public servants, so much so that the Minister time and time again had to intervene. I regard it as a touch hypocritical that she should raise the question of interrogation being mean and nasty.

When I look at the Estimates committees as a whole, I am often surprised at how many Opposition senators just get the line right. They can draw the line between interrogation, pressing the point and trawling for information yet not trying to put public servants through an inquisition. I pay tribute to them today at how well they do that. They will go and have a cup of tea with the witnesses afterwards. It is not personal or anything else; it is a role of the Opposition at Estimates committees.

As we know, Estimates committees are primarily a vehicle for oppositions. They serve a tremendously great purpose in keeping government departments on the ball. I believe that, in my portfolio, everyone in the defence forces who serves under me has immense courage. However, the only thing I have ever found them afraid of is the Estimates committees.

Estimates committees are not just for honourable senators to exercise their magistrate court procedures and techniques. Fortunately or unfortunately, I was in a parallel Estimates committee and can neither confirm nor deny Senator Bishop's view of Senator Coates and Senator Schacht. I have also not read the Hansard subsequently; I do have slightly higher priorities. If Senator Bishop is pressing that point, as she is entitled to, she should have a look in the mirror and see whether she can see any of that meanness, nastiness and offensive behaviour reflected in her own behaviour at the previous Estimates committee. There have been many complaints about it. I did not raise it when that particular Estimates came up because Senator Bishop was absent and one does not raise such things in a person's absence. I would not have raised it today, but Senator Bishop has attacked people on our side of the chamber for their style. I am not talking about the substance of the questions because that is a matter--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am talking about substance.

—Senator Bishop talks about style and substance. Quite often Opposition senators suggest that I or someone else should be telling Government members what to do, yet in every other debate they get up and proclaim how free they are to express their views and how disciplined and Dalek-like we are.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bishop cannot have it both ways. She cannot say that Senator Schacht and Senator Coates approached a matter in a mean and nasty way- `reprehensible' was another word used-and then introduce the subsidiary argument that we are trying to cut off political debate. Seven years after she was found at Albury, she tries to ban a political party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) for his critique. I am interested to note that he has not read the Hansard and so is unable to comment upon the substance or the style of the remarks. I note that he says he was in a parallel committee and was unable to see it but nonetheless was able to comment upon what he had not seen.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said very often, I never have any complaint with public servants who come before a committee and are willing and eager to answer questions so that there may be proper accountability to the Parliament. It is very interesting that, when I have been invited to address seminars where public servants are in attendance, as I do from time to time, I have actually had the question asked: `To whom do I owe my responsibility-to the Executive, that is, to my Minister, or to the Parliament?'. The fact that there is doubt in the minds of public servants, that they have to ask that question, I find quite astounding. I think more and more people know that the responsibility and the process of accountability belongs with the Parliament.

Equally, on the question of cooperation, and indeed, cooperating with the committees and having respect for the Parliament, I have also said before that the way the Government treats the Parliament through its manner of disdain or sometimes contempt rubs off on the attitude of people who serve it. I ask the Minister never to say that at any stage I have not acknowledged that within the Public Service there is just as much talent and ability as lies within the private sector. The ability and willingness of public servants to carry out their functions well is about the same. But I have said that the system under which the Public Service works means that we do not get the best results from the best people.

If one reads the sort of evidence that is given by various public servants, whether or not it is under a cross-examination style of questioning, it becomes quite apparent who is on top of the material and who is not. Indeed, I think we will find that, more and more, the quality of information which is being proffered is improving.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise for a slightly lighter diversion in the form of an apology. Last night in the course of my remarks I made some disparaging comments about the journal the Parliamentarian. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I view the Parliamentarian with a somewhat jaundiced view, because I have been a member of this place for 15 years and it has not once decided to mention anything that I have either said, done or been involved with.

I apologise to the publishers of the Parliamentarian for saying that. I draw all honourable senators' attention to the April 1990 edition, which contains an edited version of a paper I presented to the Second Conference of Australian Delegated Legislation Committees. It has a good photograph of me in it, and a good photograph of Senator McMullan. It is an excellent article, and I recommend it to all honourable senators. I do apologise to the Parliamentarian. The magazine I had intended to refer to, which has never mentioned me in 15 years, is the House Magazine. So I transfer all of those criticisms from the Parliamentarian to the House Magazine.

The Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, made a few comments earlier which I feel that I must say something about. He mentioned the role of the Opposition in Estimates committees. With all due respect, surely that is also the role of government back bench senators. I am sure that Senator Ray remembers being on my Estimates Committee. I used to press very difficult questions to the public servants and to the Minister. I see that the Minister is shaking his head. He and I have different memories. I would not allow the nonsense to go on that is sometimes allowed to go on under certain other chairmen, as the Minister will recall, but if I thought a matter was genuinely being raised, I would allow it to be pressed to the limit.

It was always a pleasure to sit on an Estimates committee under Minister Walsh, as he then was, because he, as a Labor Minister, was delighted to have his public servants try to explain something which he thought was genuinely being raised. I think that is the role of the Ministers-to enable Estimates committees to raise difficult issues and either to have public servants explain them or to make a statement as to whether or not an issue is a policy matter. But to suggest that it is only the role of the Opposition to press the Public Service is failing to appreciate the benefit which Estimates committees can be to the Parliament and, indeed, to the administration of executive government in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me agree with Senator Lewis on that. I was talking more in the political sense when I said that the value and the joy of Estimates committees lies with the Opposition and not with the Government. That is by the nature of things. I am interested to hear him say that the Parliamentarian has covered him extensively. I must cancel my subscription, if that is the case. We are probably the only two who have never been mentioned in the House Magazine. That is deliberate policy on my behalf. I think we should have a cartoon of Senator Lewis on the front of that.
—I have been a member for 10 years and they have never done me.
—They must do it on ugliness; that is quite obvious.
—Thank you, Minister. I have been depicted.

—I meant, though, that they exclude the ugly, Mr Chairman. On the other point that Senator Lewis made about the good old days when he was so tough in Estimates committees, I do have a selected memory because one can only put so many things into it. My only enduring memory is when we forced Estimates Committee C to meet on nine occasions for a total of about nine hours a meeting. Senator Lewis in the old chamber stormed out of the Chair demanding to see Peter Rae and saying that he was never going to reconvene the Committee. Nevertheless, 10 minutes later he did. That is my only memory.

SPEECH.PARA: There is this other point about Estimates committees that I think Senator Lewis should acknowledge. Given the numbers in this chamber there are approximately 32 or 33 members of the Opposition who are either on Estimates committees or who float around whereas the Government can barely provide 18 to serve across them when the Whips are excluded. That has changed the nature of Estimates committees just a little. Also, I suppose that people are conscious of time. Priority, at least in questioning, should be given to the Opposition, but Government members should not be excluded from asking questions or being involved.

I get back to my previous remarks about where the political joy and political advantage is. It is quite often in Estimates committees. Whilst I am not an enthusiastic supporter of the current committee system as it exists in this Parliament, because I think we have too many, if we decided to reduce the number of them, the last ones we would ever touch are the Estimates committees. I know the effect that the Estimates committees have on my public servants. They strive to get the documents better and strive to get their answers in on time. Senator Newman probably wins one or two points concerning inaccuracies or misunderstandings, but the Senate Standing Committee of Privileges supports us on that. So the public servants are trying very hard to do those sorts of things.

I add another factor that, if we can get answers on notice given during the year answered as promptly as possible, it will relieve some of the pressure on Estimate committee questions on notice and other questions. We could have an ongoing process during the year getting answers in a lot quicker and that will relieve a bit of the pressure in Estimates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another form would be to bring forward other Ministers from the other place and make them answer questions.

—That is an interesting question. We have always had that as a trade-off position. I have been involved in trade-offs in this chamber over Standing Orders. Honourable senators will see in the next week how dudded I was because all sorts of total reservations were put in that were never intended by Senator Colston and his colleagues when they brought in that procedure report in December 1989. Funnily enough, the attitude of most of my House of Representatives colleagues in the Ministry is not to oppose that course. My predecessor, Mr Beazley, would have loved to come up to Estimates Committee B and do battle with Senator Newman, Senator MacGibbon and co. He would have loved that discussion but that particular Estimates Committee would probably have never concluded because he would want to keep it going rather than finish it off.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not say that every colleague of mine holds the same view. That position may come but I have to say that it may come with a rationalisation of committees. Why, apart from chauvinism, do we have a Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and a Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade? There are similar instances of duplication on the other side. If only we could get a rational role between the two chambers without infringing the rights of the two chambers as to where they concentrate.

The House of Representatives will never reintroduce Estimates committees. Mr Sinclair dumped them quite properly because they were becoming a farce in 1982 and we have never sought to resurrect them. This is the chamber for Estimates committees. If we get that rationalisation with committees between the two Houses at some stage, I think what Senator Lewis has asked for will follow.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Kemp, I remind honourable senators that we are considering the Estimates of the Department of the Senate and it would be good to get back to that subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to get back to the Estimates of the Department of the Senate. However, I welcome the comments made by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) about the Estimates committees. I have just been with a number of colleagues on the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration where we have dealt with the whole issue of the Estimates committees. It was good to hear the Minister's very strong endorsement with regard to those committees.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, I would like to return to the Department of the Senate and some of the matters which have been raised in this chamber by Senator Coates and Senator Schacht. Firstly, I will make some comments about some issues which were raised during the actual hearings of Estimates Committee A in relation to a number of activities which were put on by the Department of the Senate. I refer to the exhibitions and a series of lectures that were put on by the Department of the Senate.

I have been to two of the three lectures which have been held to mark the 1891 conference. I would like to say-and I think the President sought comments and reactions from senators at the Estimates Committee hearing-that this series is a very important one. It has been very well run. At the two lectures which I went to the speakers were Sir Zelman Cowan and Professor McMinn. In my view, the papers were extremely important ones and I am very proud, as a senator, to be in some way effectively associated with that lecture series.

The exhibition which was also referred to and which was questioned is the one which is currently in the public area of this Parliament House. Unfortunately, I missed the opening of that exhibition. However, I have had a chance to go over it quite carefully with two members of the Department of the Senate, Anne Millar and Rosemary Laing. I believe that is also an extremely important activity by the Department of the Senate and, again, I am proud to be associated with it. I am pleased to have the opportunity to give my congratulations to the Clerks and to all of those people who were associated with those exhibitions.

Another matter which was raised by Senator Coates related to the articles which have been published in a variety of journals and given at a number of sem- inars by the Clerk of the Senate and the Assistant Clerks. I have to say that, in some way, I am quite indebted to Senator Coates and Senator Schacht for drawing my attention to these articles. I have taken some time to gather what I believe to be a very large collection of this material and I have carefully read the articles, which I have in hand, so that I could make some careful assessment of the comments which have been raised by the honourable senators.

I have to say that the articles, generally, offer, I believe, great insights into the workings of this chamber and this Parliament. I believe some of the articles are quite brilliant. I particularly draw honourable senators' attention to an article entitled Parliament and Constitutional Design which was delivered by the Clerk of the Senate in February last year at a seminar at the Australian National University. I thought that was a particularly brilliant article and one which gave great insights into the way that this Parliament and this chamber work. Again, I think this type of work is important. I am pleased that the Clerks are taking the time to write these articles because I believe they make an important and effective contribution and enable the wider community to have a chance to understand the workings of this Parliament.

I was quite interested in one of the articles about which Senator Coates was particularly aggrieved. This was the article entitled Finally Bringing the Troops Home. This was a superb case study of the work of a former, and I am pleased to say a future, senator in bringing forward a private member's Bill to establish the end of the war list.

I am interested that Senator Coates was upset by this article because if anyone in this chamber should be upset by this article, I am that person. I will quote from the article which got Senator Coates so upset. Amongst other things, Peter O'Keeffe comments on:

. . . Senator McGauran's political future being sabotaged by an agreement between the Victorian Liberal and National Parties which resulted in his preselection for the essentially unwinnable third place on the Coalition Parties' 1990 half-Senate election ticket.
I am of course in this chamber because I was on the unwinnable--

TALK.START.PARA: —But when they did the deal it was Hamer who was going to get the spot.

—The Minister will have his chance. Every time I mention preselections in Victoria the Minister gets very excited. I do not know why that is. Maybe he is a bit nervous, but I am not nervous, and I am trying to deal with an issue that is before the Committee at the moment-so I hope he will just bear with me. I happen to be the person who won that unwinnable third spot on the ticket, and I am pleased to say that my future colleague, Senator McGauran, will be at the number two spot for the next Senate half election and that he will be back in this chamber. So, one would have to say that there was a slight error of fact in the article. However, I think it was a very important article. I would have to say to Senator Coates that it was not used in any election context. I noticed that the issue was raised in the Senate Estimates Committee. I have read it carefully and I think it is most unlikely that Senator McGauran would ever use that particular article in any election context whatever. To conclude comments on that matter, if any senator in this chamber could be slightly offended by that article it would probably be me-but I certainly am not.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to a matter that concerns the wider issue of the role of the Clerks in this chamber. I want to make a few brief comments on this. I can think of no other office in our Westminster system that is like the office of the Clerks, in the sense that they have to advise both sides of the Parliament. It is a very difficult and a very delicate role, and it is true that, in the past, it has been the Presiding Officer and Clerks who have been the great defenders of the institution of Parliament.

Unfortunately, in recent years a view has emerged in some chambers around this nation-and I stress that I do not make any reflection on the President of the Senate, because I believe he has the respect of all senators-that the office of Presiding Officer involves a party political role. I think that has been a most unfortunate development. Traditionally, the Presiding Officers and the Clerks have a very special role in our parliamentary system. It is a system that ensures that the chamber works well and is defended.

I point out to Senator Coates and his colleagues that I have no objection to senators having strong views on various topics, and I have always felt that this chamber should provide the widest ambit through which matters can be raised and discussed. In this case, though, I would like to have seen a degree of sensitivity from Senator Coates about the manner in which he went about this particular activity and the way that he chose to raise it.

No-one would deny that the Presiding Officer, the President, in this chamber must be impartial in his rulings. The President would say that, as would all honourable senators in this chamber. Everyone agrees that the President must be impartial in his rulings in this place. I happen to disagree with the President about the emphasis he gives to Standing Orders on relevance and length of answers which, in my view, enables some Ministers to speak at excessive length. I have put my view. Clearly, the President thinks I am wrong, and I think he is wrong. I note that this decision by the President has far greater political consequences than any article by any Clerk. However, I have spoken in this chamber about my concerns. I have avoided extreme language and personal reflections, and have left the matter at that. People of good will can differ about their respective roles without getting into slanging matches. I have not accused the President of being partisan in relation to any notice of motion-and I would not do so because I do not believe that that is the case. I have not sought to join Estimates Committee A so that I can involve myself in haranguing the President.

This goes to the nub of my concern about Senator Coates. Senator Coates is entitled to his views, although, from my point of view, I would hope that they were more soundly based in evidence. But what we can ask and should ask of Senator Coates is that he follow more appropriate procedures and exercise a degree of sensitivity in pursuing his concerns. He may believe that the Clerks are wrong, misguided or lacking in judgment, but he has gone a major step further and accused them of being partisan, and he has raised issues concerning pro-active advice given by the Clerks, which-I do not have time to go into this at length-on close examination, would show the nonsense of the matters that he raised in relation to that.

This issue could have been handled in a better and more effective way. I say that because, first, it relates to the respect that this chamber should have for the high office of Clerk and the recognition that the chamber should have of the restraints on the Clerk and his colleagues in responding to notices of motion. Secondly, when accusations of the type that are raised by Senator Coates are brought forward, it raises justifiable fears and opens the door to possible misunderstandings about the motives of the honourable senators involved.

Given the sensitivities involved, Senator Coates could, I believe, have raised his concerns initially with the Clerk. It is a great pity that he did not extend that courtesy. Failing that, I would have thought that Senator Coates should have taken up the invitation of the Clerk to discuss his concerns. Did Senator Coates ever reply to the letter that he received from the Clerk in relation to his notice of motion? Was this courtesy ignored as well?
Senator Coates said to the chamber on Tuesday night that he did not explain his complaints with the Clerk because:
I believed it was quite inappropriate for me to enter into political debate with the Clerk or other officers of the Senate.

The advantage of Senator Coates meeting with the Clerk is that it may have helped to resolve the matter or, failing that, have given the Clerk an opportunity to at least reply. That would have been a courtesy to a man who has served this chamber and senators of every political complexion. Regrettably, Senator Coates has chosen a forum-this chamber-to attack Clerks where they have no opportunity to reply. Senator Schacht, in his contribution last night, recognised that particular problem.

Many of the matters raised in Senator Coates's speech on the second reading debate have been well covered by my colleagues. There were just a few matters on which I would like to comment. Senator Coates said that it is he and the Government who are being attacked right now. He said that it was not the Clerks' duty to undermine, to continually attack and to oppose the Government. Senator Coates did not produce any substantive evidence for such a serious charge. He referred to three or four articles which, we should note, have very restricted circulation. It is Senator Coates who is doing the attacking.

The Clerks are attacked for being so proud of the Senate and all they believe it stands for-who so revere it that they have allowed themselves to overstep the mark in defending it and promoting it. What a dreadful thing it is that people have loyalty to an institution that employs them. Who else should they be loyal to? Why should they not defend and promote the Senate?

Senator Coates slides from defending and promoting the Senate to the next charge-that of manipulating the Senate. Where is the evidence for that serious charge? A few articles given to limited forums? Come on, Senator; you cannot be serious.

I have spoken earlier about the role of the President. As this matter seems to have got out of hand, I wonder whether the President cannot take a role in bringing about a resolution of the matter. Senator Coates has had his day. He ignored every common courtesy that should have occurred when he entered the chamber to deliver his attack on the Clerks. I think the President may well speak to his colleague Senator Coates and inform him of what the appropriate courtesies are and what evidence is required before extreme attacks are launched on individuals in the language that he has chosen. I hope that this sorry matter will be ended once and for all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make my final contribution on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2). I want to pick up on a few of the points made by Senator Kemp. Senator Kemp and I have probably disagreed before on Question Time. I have always said that it is a two-way street. I did endeavour, though, around that time, to press for shorter answers. Senator Kemp will notice that I have not done so this week-and I am not going to.

SPEECH.PARA: When we have about 20 people interjecting-a barrage of interjections right through Question Time-I am not going to ask my colleagues to cooperate; it is a two-way street. We did get up to 28 questions at some stage. That is without a flippant response, either, or counting one or two that we always get and put on notice, et cetera. The point about that timing is-there has got to be a two-way street-the behaviour of this chamber in Question Time, whilst not at the level of the House of Representatives, is drifting that way in terms of interjection and constant bellowing. In the end, that just denigrates us all in the eyes of the public. I do not distinguish between governments and oppositions or anything else. That is the first point I wanted to make.

Senator Kemp then went on to say that he does not think an honourable senator, in this chamber and through the Estimates process, should be raising issues such as Senator Schacht and Senator Coates have.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I said there was a better way.
—There are always better ways, I suppose.
—In the end, they can come in here.

—I have to say that no-one is exempt from Estimates committee procedures. Those who have promoted them over the years I am sure would be the last to complain that they should be exempt from the Estimate committee procedures. As Senator Kemp would appreciate, the role of the Clerks in this chamber is very much like the role of the Australian Football League umpire. If we do not notice them, they are doing a wonderful job. That is the particular procedure.
—Did you see the number of free kicks Essendon got last week against the West Coast Eagles?
— They were noticed, so the umpires were not too good.
—Fourteen to one in the first quarter.

—Senator Crichton-Browne noticed them, therefore they were not doing their job properly. I think that analogy fairly much holds. There is a difference between loyalty to the Senate-and I say to Senator Kemp that I do not say this in relation to the Clerks-and Senate chauvinism, which has often reared its head in this chamber; for example, `We are the greatest in the world', et cetera. Let the record stand if we are; we do not have to trumpet it all the time. There is no necessity to trumpet it all the time.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that Senator Kemp is right in one sense. Some of these issues have been aired. It is probably time that that happened, and now that is it. The same sort of issue was aired six months ago about the same Clerk supposedly being biased for sending someone to a Labor lawyers conference. I did not jump up and down about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the distinction to be made.
—What distinction is to be made there?
—The distinction between dealing with matters where genuine criticism lies as distinct from attacking the person.

—So not only do we have the prosecutor sitting opposite, she has appointed herself as judge as well. Let us all make those sorts of judgments. I thought that Senator Bishop's points last year in relation to that point were absolutely moronic. It indicated no bias whatsoever. As to the role of the Clerks, the bottom line is one for this chamber to determine and for the President to determine.

SPEECH.PARA: The extent to which Clerks should give newspaper interviews was especially highlighted in 1985 when the then Clerk gave a legal opinion on Lionel Murphy which appeared on the front page of the Age. I think all of us in this chamber would say that, at that extreme, that is wrong. On the other hand, writing for learned journals that no-one reads on the thrill ship and psychic thrill of being a Clerk in the chamber, as I think Mr O'Keeffe wrote, is at the other end that I do not take seriously. He has put his views; even if I find them offensive, I do not care. That is part of the debate; it is part of the political process. The article was written for a learned journal in a specialist area.

The only question is-I think even Senator Coates would agree-we would probably differ on where we draw the line. I draw the line somewhere down the middle, which would not surprise any of the four people sitting on this side of the chamber, knowing what a pragmatist I am. It is pretty much down the middle; I would regard the sorts of articles that appear in the Parliamentarian and all the rest as grist to the mill. It is possibly a pity that sometimes there is not a counter article put in so that we can have an intellectual debate over some of these issues.

As to articles appearing in the Canberra Times giving opinions on this and that, one of the articles accused people in this chamber of being rubber stamps, being ruthless in trying to get government legislation through; if an identikit picture of me was put in with the article, I would wear it, because it is true. But it should be identified that it is me, otherwise it may leave a view that it is everyone. That is part of the problem.

The question that should be thought about is what the role of the Clerks is in the public arena. I think some sorts of guidelines should be put down as to what that role is. They should not be too restrictive; on the other hand, being involved with the daily newspapers and giving interviews on certain matters could at some stage come to rebound on Clerks, as it does on all of us because we get misquoted and stories are distorted. We have all been through that. We can come into this chamber when that happens and have the record corrected. Our colleagues who assist us here have no such rights other than through writing letters to editors that they find published on the back page a month later and their views are never properly represented.

I say in conclusion that in my experience in this chamber I have seen a variety of public expressions from the Clerks in learned journals through to the front page of the Age. I was infuriated about what was on the front page of the Age in 1985-absolutely infuriated. I am in no way particularly offended by what is in some Clerks' magazine in England with a circulation of 180 or something. Who really cares? People can put in a response to that.

I think Senator Kemp has come up with a very sensible suggestion when he says that the President might be able to have a look at this matter. I just take it a step further: the President may be able to issue-having washed it through the chamber, so to speak, in an informal way-some guidelines as to what sort of public role the Clerks could have in expressing their views and where to draw the line. That may avoid some of the more abrasive sort of debate that was complained of today and may bring about a situation where, by knowing all the rules in advance, no-one can take offence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add to some of the comments that were made by Senator Ray. I was pleased to hear from the Minister for Defence ( Senator Robert Ray), who is at the table, that he did not have any particular problems with the articles which were written. That is my view too. He referred to an incident in 1985. I am not aware of that particular incident, but I would be happy to have a look at that.

SPEECH.PARA: In perhaps one or two matters the Minister carefully skirted around some of what I thought were the more substantive issues I raised, which was a bit of a pity. What I was talking about was not in any way restricting the right of honourable senators to come into this chamber and raise particular issues. At the end of the day, I would argue for the widest possible ambit for honourable senators to raise issues in this chamber.

I am saying that there are procedures which I think are better to follow, particularly in relation to the Clerks and the officers involved. I would have preferred Senator Coates to have done the more manly thing-to have gone along to the Clerk and had a frank discussion with him. I would have thought that that would have been the decent and sensible thing to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or the Clerk to come and speak to us.

—Senator Schacht will have his turn in a moment. If I have a concern about what the President is doing, I would either express it in a moderate way in this chamber or I would go and see him privately and express it in a more forceful manner. Then I would say that if the matter could not be resolved, and if I felt that there was a fundamental issue of principle involved, I would come into this chamber and raise it. But I think that courtesies and respect for officers have to be extended. It was a great pity that in Senator Ray's comments he carefully avoided discussing the behaviour of Senator Coates and the extremity of his language.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not that Senator Coates said that the Clerks were wrong, unbalanced and lacking in sensitivity. Senator Coates went a major step further and said that the Clerks were being partisan. On the basis of these articles, on the basis of the views that Senator Ray has just given to this chamber, to my mind he does not agree with Senator Coates. But I should have thought that, if one of Senator Robert Ray's colleagues made a virulent accusation against officers and people who serve this chamber so well, he may have made some comment about that.

The second issue I wish to raise and to clarify, which Senator Ray tried rather cleverly to skirt over, is that the Clerks and their officers report to this chamber. That is their reporting relationship. I would like to see a meeting between the President and Senator Coates to determine whether there is not a better way to deal with this issue, not a meeting to lay down tight guidelines on what the Clerks should or should not do. What I have argued in this chamber is that there is a better way to deal with this issue.

The Presiding Officer, the President, is a man who has great respect on both sides of the chamber and who in the end is the defender of this chamber. His role as President takes considerable precedence over any party political role. He may not be able to resolve this matter but I should like to see him take a particular role and determine whether the matters in relation to Senator Coates and Senator Schacht cannot be handled in a better way. I will leave my comments there but I would not want my original comments to have been misrepresented or reinterpreted by the Minister in the way that he did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with the report of Estimates Committee A. I wish to refer to a number of things that occurred as a result of the report and the reservation. Estimates Committee A, once again, was the Committee that took the longest time to complete its hearings, twice the time taken in Estimates B or any other committee, and I draw that to the attention of honourable senators, as I have previously. Estimates A took 25 hours 49 minutes; Estimates B, 12 hours 30 minutes; Estimates C, 11 hours 18 minutes; Estimates D, 8 hours 40 minutes; Estimates E, 12 hours 47 minutes; and Estimates F, 8 hours 44 minutes. That shows a continued pattern. It also indicates that we had limited time at the end of those public hearings for our deliberations, but that was still done in an efficient way. I am concerned with the way in which the reservations that Senator Bishop proposed have been dealt with. That is why I draw attention to the fact that, while limited in the time we had, every opportunity was given for all honourable senators to express reservations.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with your ruling, Mr Chairman, regarding the proposal by Senator Crichton-Browne. But my concern is the way that Senator Bishop and her colleagues have raised matters in their reservation that were not brought before the Committee itself. If this is to continue we will end up, on a day such as this when people are talking about the procedures of the Senate, in a situation where we will seriously challenge the traditions of the way Estimates committees are held.

Before I go into that in any detail I should like to refer to the matters that are being discussed. The very point in the reservation that Senator Bishop and her colleagues have made is to deplore the activities of two Government senators. The point that I find objectionable is not the issue in this case but the fact that on a sensitive matter various senators put forward various points of view and we reached a concluded wording in the report about that matter. We tried to deal with it in a sensitive manner. It is fairly offensive then for a gratuitous attack to be made by Senator Bishop and her colleagues on at least one of the senators who was actively involved in trying to get agreed wording on the Committee. That in itself means that it will be harder next time when people are working in the way that we always have in the Senate to reach an agreed position and so benefit the institution itself.

I must comment on the other debate that is taking place. On the issue of the role of the Clerks, Senator Kemp has called for a degree of sensitivity. I support what Senator Ray said because there is a need for a degree of sensitivity. I think sensitivity has been lacking in the current discussion-I do not want to go into all the detail-in those references that I see as disparaging to my Party, with its 100 years of tradition. In other words, there was a lack of sensitivity in some of the articles towards at least a significant part of the Senate chamber.

Hopefully, out of this whole exercise we will have more sensitivity. I can certainly understand why people have objected. What has been written has been seen as lacking sensitivity towards a significant and traditional view that comes from one side of the chamber. That is implicit in this debate and it should be acknowledged. Everybody would be more satisfied if the positive suggestion by Senator Ray were taken up-that the President use his good offices to determine whether the role of the Clerks could be codified a little more.

On the other hand, Senator Kemp, having raised the issue of the President using his good offices, wants only to discipline, if you like, people with whom he disagrees in the chamber. He has clearly put the onus back onto the person who raised this matter, Senator Coates. Senator Coates has done us a service because he has brought to a head something that, if it were to smoulder, would be against the interests of everybody. One way that might resolve the problem is for the President to try to introduce sensitivity on all sides.

The other matters I wish to deal with concerning Estimates Committees A are in the area of what I would describe as an unprecedented move by Senator Bishop and the Opposition to bypass the Committee itself, not raising an issue with the Committee and introducing it in a reservation. Firstly, I take issue with the reference in the Opposition's reservation to the Governor-General. If Senator Bishop had brought the matter of the Governor-General before the Committee we might have been able to modify her view.

Bypassing the Estimates Committee and the discussion that takes place in any Estimates committee has resulted in pure political propaganda going into the reservation without those involved having to go through the hurdle of the argument in the Estimates committee hearings. In this case, Senator Bishop has attacked a three-week trip by the Governor-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —She has become a republican.

—The effect might be the same, but I am sure that Senator Bishop does not realise that she is denigrating the Office of Governor-General in her biased attack on the Governor-General. In this reservation she and the Opposition have said:

SPEECH.PARA: While not disputing the Governor-General's right to visit the Queen, we believe that this is an excessive cost for the taxpayer to bear . . .

Of course, had Senator Bishop raised that matter at the Estimates Committee, we would have referred her to page A168 of the transcript where, when the question was asked of the officers of the Governor-General's staff, they pointed out that the length of the journey itself had been kept short. To the question of what had happened previously, we had a specific rebuttal of the attack on the Governor-General in that Mr Sturkey said:
An overseas visit in 1985 by the then Governor-General was 61 days in length.
He gave the length and the cost, saying:
In 1987, the then Governor-General was away 46 days. The cost was $107,000.

The specific answers given by the officers show that the current Governor-General's mid term visit is far shorter-as we were told, just over three weeks-and was deliberately kept short. Yet we have a clearly implied criticism. In this reservation we then have Opposition senators requesting:
. . . the office of the Governor-General to provide a full breakdown of the cost of the trip along with the schedule of the official engagements undertaken on the trip.
That implies that something is not forthcoming. Mr Sturkey clearly said:
We are accountable for the official costs, naturally.

In other words, the clear answer to the question was that those figures would be supplied. Of course, if I were participating in the Estimates Committee, I would have been able to draw that to Senator Bishop's attention and we would not have had the clear bias, the clear attack, regarding the Governor-General that is implicit in the report that has been put forward by Senator Bishop and other Opposition senators. The whole of the reservation is based on matters that have not been brought forward to the Committee itself.

In the consideration of the Australian Customs Service, we have a significant part of the report-the Midford Paramount case-not being brought forward to the Committee. Therefore, there is no debate of the Committee on it. That is referred to in paragraph (d) of the report relating to the Customs Service. The disclosure of confidential information was not brought forward to the Committee, yet it is included in the reservation by Senator Bishop and the Opposition.

The tendering procedures referred to in paragraph (f) of the report were not brought before the Committee. There is no committee input on the biased attack on the Customs Service reflected in all of these reservations. Indeed, paragraph (g) of the reservations, which once again was not brought before the Committee, shows the bias of Senator Bishop. The comments are expressed without any testing and allowed her to continue the attack on the officers in the Customs Service on matters that she has been pursuing for some time.

These comments did not stop in the final section of the reservation, which relates to the Department of the Treasury. Once again, allegations are made but were not brought before this Estimates Committee because Senator Bishop again had a matter in her mind, and her colleagues acquiesced in her action in putting forward this report. It means that the Committee is being made a mockery of because we can sit for endless hours to hear evidence and we can sit down and genuinely try to reach agreement on the issues that we have agreed are issues that might go in the report. But that will not stop Senator Bishop leaving aside her pet list of issues so that she can bring them into the chamber.

If this continues there is only one alternative, and it is a simple process. There will be a Government report and an Opposition report. Why waste the time of honourable senators in trying to get agreement when we know that there will be an additional list, almost as long as the report in many cases, where those matters have not been dealt with at the Committee. I believe that Government senators would be fools to allow this free kick, if you like, to take place every time there is a Senate Estimates committee meeting. It simply means that we are moving into a situation which, in my view, threatens the whole system of Estimates committees.

I speak with the experience that I have gained from being on endless numbers of committees where time and time again, in good faith, we have haggled for hours and hours about each sentence and each paragraph of a report. We have been able to do that successfully in all sorts of committees that I have been on. It seems that it is only in this area of Estimates Committee A that we have had this partisan development of the bypassing of the Committee. I inform those who are concerned about the forms of the Senate that these issues are much more challenging than some of the issues that we have spent time debating up until now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the President, I mention that we are on matters relating to the Department of the Senate. As Senator Childs was Chairman of Estimates Committee A, I allowed him to traverse a number of departments other than the Department of the Senate. When we do get back to Senator Childs's remarks, I urge honourable senators to leave those matters relating to other departments until we actually arrive at them.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that the debate that has taken place about the Clerks and their role is one that I should be involved in, particularly here in the chamber. I would like to point out that the Clerk and I meet at least weekly, and sometimes we meet daily. We do not always agree. I do not think that would surprise honourable senators. I have complete confidence in the advice that he gives me.

INTERJECT.PARA: I think that the important thing is that those discussions are always private. The reason I am standing now is to indicate that I will accept the suggestion made by Senator Kemp. I will initiate a meeting with the Clerk, Senator Schacht and Senator Coates. I have already spoken to them in the chamber this morning and they have agreed to such a meeting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, your statement that you would not entertain debate on what Senator Childs has just had to say, I find very difficult. It think it is important to have on the record the way in which committee reports are formulated, what the meaning of a reservation is, and the practice and the way in which they used to be prepared. I would like to have those aspects on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: There are very specific issues that I want to raise with regard to the Department of the Senate, particularly the question of security. There are some remarks that I want to make with regard to those things which Senator Childs has just dealt with. I was aware that he was going to raise them because we discussed them over dinner one evening. Indeed, I want to place on the record the way in which these things come about.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is fine. You can respond to Senator Childs's remarks. I would ask you not to go into detail on reservations concerning other departments.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I shall just go through the history of how reports of Estimates committees used to be prepared. When I first came on to a committee, I went along to a meeting at the end of a hearing; the report was first provided in draft form; we looked at it and the Government, which always had the numbers to pass the report, virtually said, `We came, we sat, we went'. It was a meaningless thing. It said nothing. It reflected none of the debate or the questioning that had gone on.

SPEECH.PARA: At the next meeting I inquired how we would effectively show the debate and the questioning that was dealt with. I was told that the mechanism to do that was by a reservation. The next time I went along to discuss a report-I got the usual meeting: we came, we sat, we went-the Opposition senators on the committee wrote a reservation which was included in the published document. A reservation is just that.

Here is a report passed by the Committee. It includes matters wished to be reserved by members who do not have the numbers. Quite frankly, the Government would not and could not agree with the matter dealt with in the reservation to this report. We had I think three-quarters of an hour to discuss the draft of the basis of the report prepared by the Secretary of the Committee in consultation with the Chairman. Therefore, that reflects those matters which the Chairman wishes to include in the report. When we came to deal with it, we settled some of the language in the report. That matter took some three-quarters of an hour.

At the end of that, I think two items which were not previously mentioned in the report were included because Opposition senators wished to speak to them and, under the Standing Orders, they needed to be included in the report. Had the Chairman decided that they would not go in, they would have gone in the reservation. At one stage we had reports that were in the `we came, we sat, we went' category. We had reservations of substance, which made the Government look foolish.

The next time we came along to discuss the report there was serious discussion on matters of substance that would be included. On this occasion honourable senators on this side were most keen to find words in the report that the Government had the numbers to pass. Indeed, we did not vote against that report, as we had done on previous occasions; we voted in favour of the report and then added the reservations because we wished to raise these matters.

It is quite clear, as honourable senators have heard from the debate, that Opposition members have strong feelings of anger, insult and impropriety about the statements made regarding Senate officers. To expect that that not be reflected in the report--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are getting a bit thin skinned, aren't you?

—It is very disappointing that someone who purports to have an intellect like Senator Schacht's stoops to name calling, when he is quite able to argue a matter of substance with some degree of decorum. It is most disappointing. He lets not only the Senate but also himself down.
—Get on with it, Bronwyn.
—Shame on you, Schachty.

—Quite right. Senator Faulkner ought to be campaigning in the seat of Sydney. I return to the question of the report. That is how we arrive at a report with a reservation. Senator Childs said that he has sat on many committees for countless hours, as indeed I have, to find a report with which all people who participated in hearings regarding particular matters can agree. They go forward with a common purpose to see something achieved. Reports are usually full of recommendations. The nature of these reports is to reflect the information elicited during the process of the hearings; to bring it together so that it may be debated in this place in a coherent form. That is exactly what we are doing now-debating the issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Chairman, you allowed Senator Childs leeway to deal with matters raised in the reservation of Opposition senators. You would prefer that I deal with the substance of what he dealt with when we come to those particular parts on those departments. I am pleased to follow that ruling, Mr Chairman. I place on notice the fact that I will be delighted to debate the question I raised under the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and the point dealing with the Governor-General, which comes under the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

TALK.START.PARA: —I allowed Senator Childs to go the way he was because he was using those particular items to develop the argument that he was putting before the Committee. Senator Bishop, I think you probably understand that.

—I understand that, Mr Chairman. I just do not want anyone to think for one moment that I will not be challenging his statements. But I will do it in accordance with your ruling, under the appropriate heading. I now turn to the question of parliamentary security.
—Senator Bishop, it might be satisfactory that all honourable senators-if there are any more-who want to speak on the matter of Senate officers do so. We can then conclude that matter.
—I would be delighted to do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I spoke on a general Appropriation Bill. I made some remarks on the role and the function of the Senate Clerks and their officers. I am not a member of Senate Estimates Committee A, but I attended and asked questions because of my concerns on a number of matters. I did so because that was the most appropriate forum in which to raise issues. It gave the Clerk of the Senate and his officers an opportunity to respond directly to any of my queries. I thought that was the most open way to do it. It is much more preferable than doing it in any other forum where the Clerk and his officers would not be able to respond on the public record. If people read the transcript of the Senate Estimates Committee A which was held in April they will see that the Clerk of the Senate and his officers responded very fully. They raised their views in response to questions. That is excellent. That is what the process is about.
—Why didn't you go to them?

—Senator Kemp suggested that Senator Coates and I should have gone and spoken to the Clerk and made our views and concerns known at that time. That is certainly a valid point. But I suspect that, if we had, the Opposition would have said that we had gone there privately to intimidate the Clerk. One gets caught both ways in these sorts of arguments. I thought that the most appropriate way was to start at the Estimates Committee, where the Clerk could respond to any questions that I or other senators asked on these matters. That is the most open and the fairest way under our system. I also note that in the reservation in the report Senator Bishop, Senator O'Chee and Senator Short say:

SPEECH.PARA: We deplore the attack made by two Government Senators-
I presume Senator Coates and me; we are the ones in the gun-
