during the hearings on the integrity of officers of the Senate and uphold the propriety of officers of the Senate in making a contribution in a nonpartisan way to discussions concerning the procedural operations of the parliamentary system.

Again, if people read the Hansard of Senate Estimates Committee A they will see that we were asking questions and getting responses. It was a very healthy debate. Surely, no Opposition member is afraid of debate in which people have the opportunity to respond.

Those opposite say that we were attacking the integrity of the officers of the Senate. We were not doing that; we were raising the question about the content of some of the public comments the Senate Clerk and his officers had made.

I agree with Senator Robert Ray. I said the same last night. Quite frankly, I do not give too much weight to these arguments. It does not worry me too much whether the Senate Clerk or anybody else in the Senate or anywhere else in the community disagrees with my views about the functioning of the Senate. That is part of the public debate. My point is that when they are made, even in obtuse learned journals, no-one should be surprised when occasionally some of us choose to respond and say, `We disagree with that view' or `We want more information of why the Senate Clerk and his officers hold that view'. That is part of the public debate. No-one should be upset about that.

I want to draw the attention of the Committee to an article written by the Clerk entitled `Unbogging the Parliamentary Reform Wagon' that appeared in a magazine called Legislative Studies at Volume 5 No. 2 Summer 1991. The document is part of the public debate, but a number of views have been expressed in it by the Clerk with which, I suspect, even Opposition senators may disagree. The Clerk makes an assertion in this article about the beginning of operation of the referral of Bills to Senate standing committees. He says:

The operation of this new system was delayed by the 1990 general election until August 1990, and immediately ran into troubles, indicated by disputation in the Senate as to how the system should work. There were a number of causes of the problem. The government, having agreed to the changes just before an election the outcome of which was uncertain, appeared to be trying to reverse them and to claw its way back to the old system, which is seen, probably mistakenly, as being marginally more congenial to government control of legislation, or at least to government minimisation of parliamentary interference with legislation. Government party members still instinctively regard parliamentary scrutiny as a hostile tactic of oppositions. It seldom occurs to them that it is what they should be doing.

A number of value judgments are expressed. The Clerk expresses a view that the Government backed off on this because we were worried about the election outcome. As a senator from South Australia, I have to say that the operation of the parliamentary Senate system or the committee system was not a really top issue in South Australia. I did not get any constituents knocking on my door or going berserk and saying, `You terrible people do not have a decent Senate system or committee system in the Senate and therefore we are going to change our vote accordingly'. Those of us who meet the electors regularly, particularly in the last election campaign, know that many other issues had a much higher priority.

I do not disagree that the Clerk has the right to that view, but it is a view that has some controversy; it concerns the Government's attitude to the introduction of the new system. Why should we not have a right to respond, either in the Estimates committees or here in this chamber, or defend our view that we believe he is wrong in expressing his view about the Government? It is not a cause that I will die in the ditch for, but if a senator wants to respond, he or she should be able to do so.
In this same article there are comments as follows:

The Australian public, or those of the minority who have dealings with members of parliament, have to be educated out of the idea that members are overpaid social workers, personal counsellors and departmental liaison officers. In this regard, Senators have always been in a better position than members of the House of Representatives, but there is a disturbing tendency to involve Senators in ` `consistency work''-
I think that should read `constituency work'-
most of which is a waste of time and resources.

If we go out and tell members of the Australian public that we are wasting our time listening to what they are saying, they will take action on us all right: we will not get re-elected. If the Clerk wants to have that view, that is fine, but I have the right to say to any member of the public who did happen to read this article that I do not agree with it. I believe that constituents have the right to tell me what they want done, even if I or someone else may think it irrelevant. Democracy is responding to the people who elect us.

When we go on, we find comments in this article about how to improve the calibre of members of parliament. Everybody in Australia has a view about improving members of parliament. The Clerk is quite right to raise the issue if he wants to, but there may be members in this place who would say that some of these views would be refuted by some senators opposite.

For example, there is a suggestion in this article that there should be a minimum age limit for a member of parliament. Senator O'Chee, who is still in his twenties and is the youngest senator, and who made a reservation in support of our right of attack on the so-called integrity of the Senate Clerk, may be a bit bemused that the Clerk has suggested that there ought to be a minimum age because people of an older age are more mature in handling their responsibilities. If the Clerk wants to hold that view, that is fine, but he should expect that some senators who are of a young age-and at 44, I am not in that category any more; even the Clerk may say that mine is a reasonable age to be in the Parliament-may disagree. Senator O'Chee is clearly the youngest member of the Senate. He may disagree and say, `I am a fully mature person who is able to debate issues and put my view'. A lot of electors aged 18 might say that they would like to vote for younger members if they had the chance.
The same article also says:
Certainly the selection processes-
of parliamentary candidates-

whereby candidates are chosen need to be reformed. A critical examination (where are our investigative journalists?) of the candidate-selection processes is long overdue. Such examination would inevitably give rise to a campaign for the introduction of primary elections, a reform which is often suggested for countries with parliamentary systems.

That is a very strong view. It may be valid, but I would suspect that, in Australia, some people in this Parliament would strongly disagree with imposing a primary system of preselection. One should ask a lot of American congressmen what they think of the primary selection process. It means that a person has to be a millionaire to meet the cost of that primary election if he is to have any chance of getting selection to run for parliament. So we may well change the nature of members of parliament, but it will only be on the basis of how much money they have to run the primary election campaign. It is a matter of interest and controversy which should be debated. If the Clerk or other members of the Department of the Senate wish to debate it, that is fine, but they and Opposition senators should expect that occasionally some of us may choose this forum or an Estimates committee to say that we disagree with that view because it is part of the public debate. These are not matters dealing narrowly with even the function of the Department of the Senate; they deal with the whole nature of Australian government and the democratic system. In that case let us have a debate.

The President has indicated that he has spoken to me and that I have agreed to have an informal discussion with the Clerk on some of these matters. I am happy to do so at any time under the chairmanship of the President. In that forum I am sure that we will go through some of these and other issues.

One matter which really has to be debated is the function of the Department of the Senate. We want a Senate department that clearly is efficiently and effectively operating and, as Senator Robert Ray says, is like the umpire-it is doing a good job when no-one thinks about it. That is what we want the Department of the Senate to be about.

Since my remarks last night when I talked briefly about industrial democracy and the morale in the Department of the Senate, a number of employees of the Department have spoken to me; there were not many, but a number. They said, `You have raised the real issue. There is a problem of morale in the Department of the Senate'. It ought to be the first function of the Clerk and Assistant Clerks of the Department of the Senate to deal with questions such as the morale of the staff. If there are such concerns about the morale of the staff of the Senate, it is an issue that should, in a management sense, be the first priority to be dealt with. We cannot have a Senate department where morale is affected. Clearly, the gossip and backbiting about the resignation of the Secretary of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority has led to a lot more comment about the functioning and the operation of the Department of the Senate.

Clearly, I welcome the commitment given in a document produced at the Estimates about the introduction of industrial democracy. I believe that that is the way in which the energies of the Senate officers should be directed so that we can get the Department of the Senate operating; so that some of the possibly misguided feelings of staff members who are unhappy with the way the place is functioning can be overcome; and so that Senate personnel can feel that they have the confidence to openly express their disagreement with management. At the moment I suspect that they are not that confident that they can do so.

I conclude my remarks by saying that the real issue in the debate that I want to deal with is the functioning of the Department of the Senate. I would be quite happy to debate, with the Clerk or anyone else, the issues of the functioning and role of the Senate in democracy. However, the day-to-day issue-the bread and butter issue-is having an efficient Senate department running, one with good morale, one which no-one has any doubt about, where there is no controversy and no argument and one that goes on unseen. I welcome the introduction of industrial democracy into the Department of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that Senator Coates said on 14 May:

SPEECH.PARA: That raises a significant point: does it not make the Clerk, and the Opposition for that matter, stop and think, when all the support and defence comes from one side of the chamber?

Unless I thoroughly misunderstood the President of the Senate, he demolished Senator Coates's observation by his own public statements. Unless I am thoroughly wrong, that is a thoroughly untrue assertion. The vast majority of this chamber-all four parties, plus the independent-do support the Clerks, their work and their conduct. In my view, this attack by Senator Coates is perhaps one of the most squalid and bigoted attacks that I have seen. It reeks with prejudice and old hatreds.

It is no secret that there are those on the Labor Party side who believe that the Government of 1975 was sacked as a result of some deep, dark conspiracy between the Clerks and the Opposition. That bigotry, bitterness and hate, that conspiracy theory, oozes from them from time to time and manifests itself in the way that we have seen in Senator Coates. I do not mind there being great haters on the Labor Party side any more than I mind there being great haters on our side of politics, but I do not believe that I have to be visited daily by those prejudices.

I am sympathetic to those who waited a whole generation to win government in 1972, only to see it snatched away from them three short years later as a result of the failings of that Government. I am sympathetic to those who sat in this Parliament for 16 and 17 years, waiting for government, only to see it evaporate before their eyes, but there is no reason why everybody else has to be visited by their bigotry, bitterness, and dissatisfaction.

There is no reason why this chamber has to be subject to a failed member of the House of Representatives who uses this forum to express his own political views, who keeps his family at whatever standard suits him as a result of the income he gets from being a senator, and who then turns around and condemns, criticises and attacks the forum in which he participates.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a failed member of the House of Representatives sitting in front of you. There are a few of them in this chamber.

—With respect, if I had my way, the Constitution would read that nobody who had been a member of the House of Representatives could be a senator. That is my view. We would probably find that Senator Short would still be a member of the House of Representatives occupying a seat in Victoria. This attack is a disguise for another agenda.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested to hear Senator Ray say that he was outraged by a front page article in the Age by the Clerk giving a legal opinion on the Lionel Murphy case. We all know the convulsion that that inquiry caused the Australian Labor Party. We all know what that did to Senator Tate's career for a little time. If the subject had been a legal interpretation upon parliamentary privilege, it would not have raised a mention. I do not criticise Senator Ray for being sensitive and concerned about that. I understand that, but my sympathy does not make it right.

I am sorry that Senator Schacht and Senator Coates have left us. If we need any example of this agenda, of this sort of attitude, we may look at Senator Schacht's referral to the matter of Miss Leanne Craze and the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority (NCA). Recently, we had a meeting of the NCA Committee at which the Clerk was invited to address certain matters. After that meeting the Clerk left the meeting room, and some short time later I followed him. As we walked down the corridor-I was some 100 yards behind him-I passed Senator Schacht, chatting idly, presumably, to Senator Walsh. He made a comment like this: `I wonder what sort of conspiracy is being cooked up now, with the Clerk going past us first and now Crichton-Browne'-words roughly to that effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —You heard that from 100 yards away?

—No. If Senator Faulkner listened carefully, he would have heard me say that I walked past, following the Clerk. What was said was within my earshot. Perhaps that is a squalid comment, but that to me is symptomatic of the mentality of, and articulates better than anything else, the debate that we are having today. Bad manners and bad breeding ought not be a qualification for being a member of any political party. Senator Coates's assertions are not supported by fact.
—Breeding! You will want a wealth tax next.

—It is interesting that those without breeding are the last to know it. It is interesting to read the line of questioning in Estimates Committee A. It was clear from the outset that there was an attempt to establish the political bias of the Clerks of the Senate. Without question, that was the intention.

SPEECH.PARA: Being familiar with Senator Schacht's new found interest in the NCA Committee matter, which revolves around Miss Leanne Craze and her criticism of one of the Clerks, a matter which Senator Schacht has enthusiastically taken up, it is fairly obvious where he is coming from. I find the attack to be without foundation, without merit and in poor taste. It certainly has no justification whatsoever.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was amused by Senator Crichton- Browne's reference to my poor breeding. I have to tell him that my parents were conservatives. If that is a comment on conservative breeding, the responsibility rests much more on the other side. The other amazing phrase that I heard earlier-I have not heard it used for years-was Senator Kemp's reference to manliness.
—I thought it was a curious comment that he referred to you.
—Exactly. I would have thought that such a sexist comment was several generations out of court. I have no feeling that I need to be manly about anything in connection with this matter.
—Don't be a coward, is that better? Would you prefer that?

—Cowardice is not particularly gender based. There is no problem with that. As indicated earlier in the debate, the President said that he would like to convene a meeting in answer to Senator Kemp's suggestion. Because the President asked me, I will attend and participate. I would not say that I am happy about such a meeting, because I still believe, as I have said all along, that there ought not to be a confrontation between honourable senators and the Clerks.

SPEECH.PARA: This is where I disagree with Senator Schacht, who has said words to the effect that he thought the Clerk was right to raise certain issues and to espouse them. My point has been that I do not think it is right, because I am, if you like, offended by having to be in dispute with the Clerks. There should not be controversy between the Clerks and honourable senators, especially if it is a question of honourable senators on one side rather than another. It is sad, but I acknowledge that there are some on the other side who genuinely cannot understand what I am on about. I acknowledge that there are some in that category. I think there are others who know only too well what I am on about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be mistaken; we understand.

—Senator Walters interjects and I should acknowledge that I am grateful for her speech yesterday reminding me of some of my statements of the past. I had quite forgotten about them and, once I was reminded of them, I enjoyed the memory. It just shows us what a good research service we have in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like briefly to back up Senator Childs in his point about the references in the report of Estimates Committee A to make sure that it is understood what the complaint is. The Government members on the Committee compromised in the first place by agreeing to take out words and paragraphs that Senator Bishop objected to. My assumption was that what was left as a relatively bald and factual statement was all that was necessary to put the matter on the agenda. If arguments in the other direction are going to be then put in reservations without our knowing about it, even though the matter is on the list in the body of the report, the majority on the Committee must insist on keeping to its side of the argument. I do not want to extend this whole issue any more than is necessary. I do not want to go over all the issues again that I dealt with in my speech on the second reading, or necessarily all the matters dealt with by the Committee, but it is important to repeat my point that I believe in the independence and neutrality of the officers of the Senate Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —So do we all.
—So do we. So why are you launching this attack?

—Those opposite assert their support for independence but what they are asserting is the Senate officers' right to make political statements, to enter into the thick of debate about highly political issues. It just happens that on many of those issues Opposition senators agree with the points of view being put forward and they suggest, therefore, that an independent position is being put. The problem is that the fact that the officers concerned claim to have, or ought to have, independence adds to the status of what they say, in that it is not just regarded as a statement by a politician which can be judged on the basis of that politician's own political interests. That is why this entering into the political process is something which ought to be avoided.

SPEECH.PARA: I will again use the word `sensitivity', which was used earlier in the debate. The suggestion was made that I ought to have been more sensitive. I guess my answer is that there ought to be sensitivity about how comments will be received. There are many people on this side of the chamber offended by the sorts of things that have been written.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they are not; two of them.

—All right; Senator Walters knows better about people on this side of the chamber than I do! Be that as it may; I am just letting her know that people do take offence at some of the things that have been said. One of the things that I want to do-Senator Walters has reminded me of it-is to answer a couple of misrepresentations that she made in her comments yesterday. Referring to me, she used the words:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . visited our committee in an attempt to thwart its smooth running.

I assume that she was referring to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs when I was temporarily put on that Committee to fill in for someone who was away for a couple of days. I was certainly not put on it to thwart its smooth running, and I cannot remember what she can be suggesting as to how I did any such thwarting anyway. I participated in a fairly mild sort of way, but with no such thwarting. She certainly misunderstands the reasons for my being on that Committee. I was merely filling in for someone who was away. The other matter I want briefly to refer to rather than go into the whole history of it is that Senator Walters asserted that I had:
. . . refused to allow the Opposition to elect a deputy chairman to that Committee-
that is, the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration-
until, in the last couple of weeks, he was finally forced to do so.

I was not forced to do anything. I agreed to appoint a deputy chair on the basis of an assurance that I had received about the Opposition's attitude to an alteration of Standing Orders. That has since been reversed and my attempt to change--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who gave the assurance? That is the point; one name we want.

—The assurance was passed to me, as Senator Kemp knows, by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) on the understanding of what he had been told by Senator Hill. I have not made any further fuss about that matter since. I sought to change the Standing Orders. The alternative was put up that it ought be referred to the Procedure Committee. I moved that referral and that is where the matter rests at the moment. I am merely trying, without developing the whole issue again, to answer Senator Walters's suggestion that I was forced to do so. Also just for the record, I feel the need to correct an assertion by Senator Harradine on what he said was a fairly minor matter. He asserted that I had interfered in a closed meeting of a committee of which I was not a member. Yes, I was waiting outside in a different corridor from the one he was waiting in. That ought to close that particular matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to deal fairly briefly with one thing that arises in some of the articles of which I complained and which was referred to in the debate this morning. That is the question of the procedure for the referral of Bills to committees and the problem I have seen in the Clerks' articles making assertions about the attitudes of people to that procedure. I guess this illustrates one of the problems of entering into the public debate, especially when inaccuracies or, to put it in another way, incorrect observations, are made because of insufficient knowledge-perhaps I can be as generous as that-adding to the offence taken about what is written.

The Clerk's position seems to be that there was unanimous support for the referral of Bills to committee procedures at the end of 1989 and that at some later stage after the election Labor members started objecting to it. The record is that in December 1989 the Government at the time agreed, with a high degree of reluctance, to go along with a short experiment of this procedure. There was no suggestion at the time that we were wholehearted supporters of the procedure or anything like that. There was great reluctance but, in the spirit of compromise, we agreed to a short experiment. That is the situation. There was no great support for the procedure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because you thought you were going to be in Opposition.

—Not at all. I remind the honourable senator that Senator Chaney thought he was going to be in government and he agreed with Senator Ray that it should be only a short experiment so that he-if it turned out that his side was to be in government-would not be stuck with it after the election. That is why the amendment was moved to make it a sessional order which was intended to expire at the end of that session. As it turned out, that session did not continue because the election was held before the Senate sat again in 1990.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened is that the other leg of the motion, about it beginning on the first sitting day in 1990, took precedence over the procedure coming to a conclusion at the end of that session. Hence, we are having not just a short experiment, which was the understanding and agreement, but a much longer experiment which still has no sunset clause except the end of this session, which could be as far away as early 1993. I raise that point to illustrate the problem of involvement in public debate on matters of dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. Before I call any further honourable senators I would like to make two remarks. Firstly, we have had a fairly good debate on the matter of Senate officers. I do not intend to curtail debate at any stage, but honourable senators might keep in mind that we have had a fair debate on the subject. Secondly, when Senator Coates was speaking the word `coward' was used. I do not think it will appear in the Hansard because I do not think it was responded to. There is a presidential ruling that that term is unparliamentary when used to refer to another honourable senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some follow-up remarks in order to respond to the comments made by Senator Coates and Senator Schacht. Firstly, Senator Schacht raised the issue of industrial democracy in the Department of the Senate. He complained that it had been in the corporate plan for three years and he asked why nothing had happened on that. I would like to pose a question which perhaps could be answered at some stage. Is it the case that the whole procedure of industrial democracy in the Department of the Senate has been held up because there is a dispute with the Public Sector Union? I understand that the Public Sector Union believes only those people who are members of unions can vote for this procedure, whereas I understand another view is that everyone in the Department of the Senate should be able to vote for it. If the answer to the question I have posed is that that hold-up has been caused because the view is that all members of the Department of the Senate, not just those who are members of the Public Sector Union, should vote, then I hope that this whole procedure is held up until everybody has his or her chance to vote. I pose that question and I would like to put that view on record.
—You can have democracy without procedure.
—There can be democracy only if everybody votes, not just a privileged ambitious class of people.
—There is a wider meaning to democracy.
—Democracy refers to union members and non-union members alike.
—Regardless of procedures.

—Regardless of whether or not a person has a union ticket. If a hold-up has been caused by the Public Sector Union with regard to this issue, I hope that the matter continues to be held up until the Public Sector Union backs down.

SPEECH.PARA: I did fully agree with one matter raised by Senator Coates and I would like to record that now. He said that he believed the office of the Clerk should be independent and neutral. I also believe that is the case; there is no question about it. Furthermore, I believe that is the view of all of the Clerks. What worries us on this side is that we have heard these accusations and extreme language used against the Clerk-and these attacks have been partisan-on such an incredibly trivial basis.

When the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray, was at the table he mentioned to us that he had no worries about the articles. I think he thought that some of them were a bit robust, but he had no worries about them. Senator Schacht got up and said that he felt that because the views were put in the article and he had had a chance to debate them that was okay too. As I have said before, I would have preferred, because of the sensitivities of the position and because of the need to maintain the independence of the position, that there had been a better procedure. But I do not dispute any honourable senator's right, after having followed proper procedures, to come in here and raise particular issues.

What worries me-I would like this to be recorded and I hope that the President of the Senate will take some note of it-is that we are seeing an attack on the independence of the office of the Clerk. If the Clerk cannot write academic articles or cannot put a view about the way this chamber operates without being subjected to attack-this is Senator Coates's intention; he did not want to see the Clerk or hear about his office, even on matters about which the Clerk may undoubtedly be able to make an important contribution to public debate-Senator Coates is politicising the office of the Clerk.

I raise another point made by Senator Coates. He is worried about proactive advice which the Clerk is giving to Opposition senators. I will read from what Senator Coates said during Estimates Committee A. He said:

It is appropriate that a section of the Senate Department should advise non-government senators. But how proactive is that objective supposed to be? Is there any guideline given to the staff of that office to indicate that they should respond to requests? Are they permitted to take some initiatives themselves in providing advice and drafting support for non-government senators?

When Senator Coates raised that issue-and he may feel that it is a fair issue-he caused a great deal of concern to this side of the House and, I am sure, to the Australian Democrats. What Senator Coates is doing is attacking the right of people on this side of the chamber to get advice from the Clerk's office. If Senator Coates has his way, no Clerk in this chamber will be able to give advice fearlessly to honourable senators who are not members of the government party because they will be subjected to the sort of harassment that he and, regretfully, Senator Schacht have conducted.

The Clerk's office must be independent and neutral. But the great precedents in our constitutional history, stretching back to the Bill of Rights at the end of the seventeenth century, have involved matters of great controversy regarding presiding officers and Clerks. I think it is better that the Clerks and the presiding officers are not accused of being politically partisan. At the end of the day the President of the Senate and the Clerk of the Senate have to stand up and defend this chamber. I resist to the greatest extent anything which would inhibit the capacity of Opposition senators to get advice from the Clerical office.

I suggest to Senator Coates that if he takes the Senate down this road and if he makes these threats-and I point out that his Party does not have the numbers in this chamber-this chamber will resist strongly any threat to the independence of the office of the Clerk and any threat to the rights of Opposition senators to get fearless advice from those officers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Coates I again remind honourable senators that we have had a fair go on this particular issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree, Mr Chairman. I do not want to prolong the debate and I will respond just briefly to Senator Kemp's comments. Obviously, he is one of those who have not listened to what I have said. First, I refer to the industrial democracy issue that the honourable senator mentioned. Once again, I suppose his comments simply illustrate his prejudice about the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I have read the written response to the question, which indicated that there was a dispute. It is a fair statement of the matter because there is a dispute, whereas Senator Kemp says there is a problem with the union. It takes two sides to have a dispute. That is the whole problem with the Opposition's attitude to industrial relations. The fair way of saying it is that there is a dispute which has yet to be resolved. I hope that it can be resolved and that we can improve the situation. The main thing that I need to say in response to Senator Kemp's comments is that the very thing that I want to avoid is the politicisation of the office of Clerk. The problem is that the--

TALK.START.PARA: —You're the problem.

—Well, I am pleased to be a problem for Senator Bishop. I take that as high praise. The point is that I do not object to the question of giving procedural advice. It is one of the most important roles of the Clerk. There should be no inhibition on the part of the Opposition seeking procedural advice from the Clerks. I have said that over and over again, and Senator Kemp and others appear just not to want to listen to what I have to say.

— Senator Kemp has raised the issue of the industrial democracy plan, and I indicate that in the additional information received for Senate Estimates Committee A there is a quite comprehensive answer on pages 2 and 3 that deals with this subject. I also believe that the unions were again written to last week and that negotiations are continuing.

—I would like to move on to questions dealing with security. Honourable senators will note that I am referring to both the report and the reservation. First, I want to deal with the question of the officer who was found attempting to illegally remove property, was subsequently dismissed and subsequently reinstated. I would like to know whether that is still the situation, that is, whether the person who was caught stealing pot plants is still employed as a security officer.
—Yes, that is still the case. The person concerned took the case to the Merit Protection Review Agency and in fact was reinstated, and is still here.
—What position is that person in, as Senator Crichton-Browne just mentioned, sotto voce?
—I am advised that she is a parliamentary security attendant.

—I note from Hansard that the Clerk said that he was disappointed with the way that the security measures were carried out but, of course, it is not up to him. During the Estimates committee hearings, we were unable to get a clear definition of just who is responsible for security. Who is the person with whom the buck stops?
—I suppose that the buck stops with myself and the Speaker.
—Can the President tell me who is the person who directly reports to the Presiding Officers, the person who takes responsibility for what goes on and, presumably, reporting to them?
—The Security Controller reports to the Presiding Officers.
—He is employed by both Presiding Officers?
—Administratively he is in the House of Representatives.
—What does that mean?
—He has to be in either one department or the other and, as an employee, he is on the payroll administratively working within the Department of the House of Representatives.
—We are unable to examine in Estimates hearings the Department of the House of Representatives, so does that mean we are never going to be able to get a straight answer on security?
—That is not true. The Security Controller in fact appeared before the Estimates Committee.
—Was that Mr Rogers?

—He is the person acting in the position at the moment. Advertisements have been placed to fill the vacant position. The Speaker and I looked at the list of applicants recently. They were interviewed, and the recommendation of the committee, I believe, is that we could not find a suitable person at this stage, and we are in the process of readvertising.

—Previously I asked the Black Rod questions concerning the suitability of security arrangements as they presently are and, if my memory serves me correctly, we have a budget allocation for security in this building of some $5.2m; is that correct?
—We can obtain that figure. We do not have it here at the moment, but we can get it for Senator Bishop quite quickly.

—Thank you, because I am relying on my memory. The thing that concerns me is that, having raised this matter in the Estimates Committee, many pieces of information have come to my attention. It does seem that, the way in which the security force, for want of a better word, is structured by taking in such groups as the old night watchmen's battalion, shall we say, and the way it is broken up into sections, with some people on the Senate side and some people on the House of Representatives side, and some people in the 24-hour roster group, the line of who is responsible and where authority lies seems to be far from clear. Is it possible for us to get a diagram that would show us just who is employed on the security staff and to whom each level of people reports? I think this could be quite a key to improving our security arrangements. Is it possible to get that?

—Yes, it is possible. I must say that I personally share some of the doubts that the honourable senator has expressed at times about security in the building. In fact, quite recently I asked the Black Rod to carry out a full review of the security arrangements in the building, and involving some of the other departments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Referring to page A52 of Hansard of 16 April, I note that I asked the Black Rod:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . what concerted plan of action have you put together and submitted to the President and/or the Clerk for implementation to improve the security in this building?
The Black Rod replied:
. . . I believe we have done everything possible to resolve the situation. It is very frustrating to me that disciplinary action should be overturned -
referring to the lady who was convicted and re-employed-

as I imagine it must be frustrating to any prosecutor-if that is the proper word-who wins a case in a lower court only to have it overturned by a higher court. I believe that the processes have been fair to the officers involved. Whether I like the processes is perhaps immaterial.

I am pleased that that whole section of discussion showed an attitude that there was some degree of complacency, which just will not do. I wonder, Mr President, whether you have set a timetable on that plan being brought forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —We certainly hope to have it within a period of three months from the date I asked for it. We do have this problem at the moment, to which I have referred, that in our opinion we did not get a suitable candidate for the top job in security. The Speaker and I will be holding some discussions tomorrow on how we might solve this problem.

—I am particularly concerned about the message that is sent out; that is, we have in this building somebody employed as a security officer who was caught in the act of theft. It really sends out a message that we are not serious about protecting material in this building. Just this morning, when I first raised the question of security-I would like to test this one, please, because I have had no time to do any back-up investigation-a person, who had overheard two people from the Sound and Vision Office having a discussion, telephoned my office. The discussion was that this week several thousand dollars worth of equipment had disappeared from this building. I have had no opportunity to test that; I do not know whether it is true. If that could be denied, I would be more than happy. I hope it is not true.

—I do not believe that that is true. Mr Templeton will find out and we will get that advice as soon as possible. I also refer to the other matter that Senator Bishop raised. The problem that the Speaker and I have, in the particular case that Senator Bishop referred to, is that the person who has been reinstated said that they were moving the property from one part of the building to another. Obviously, that is what the Merit Protection and Review Agency accepted, and it reinstated the person. That makes it very difficult for us to then turn around and say that they were stealing.

—Would it be inappropriate for the details of that matter to be provided to the Senate, so that we can at least get a feel for it? As I understand it, the person in question had finished their day's work-I think it was after midnight, in fact. Pot-plants were being placed into the boot of that person's motor vehicle-which had been taken from the car park to the front of the building-under the supervision and watchful eye of two other security people. There had been no authority, no direction, no instruction by anybody for the person in question to move the pot-plants anywhere. Presumably, the pot-plants would have been put in a room somewhere. It is all very mysterious. On the face of it, the proposition that they were simply moving pot-plants from one part of the building to another seems bizarre.

—My understanding of the incident is exactly as Senator Crichton-Browne has put it. I do not know whether we can make the full file available. I will check on that and give Senator Crichton-Browne an answer as soon as I can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne is placing, shall we say, the colour of the incident on the record. There is a little more to it. It has been said to me, firstly, that one of the reasons charges were not laid is a reason that circulates in the rumour-mill of this building. Secondly, when it came to the question of the review, it was a question of having no reports of previous behaviour which would have rendered that person unsuitable. Again, an allegation has been made to me-I will not use it this time-as to why those reports did not exist. Those sorts of stories are worrying because they come from more than one source.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like a thorough investigation into the matter because, in the final analysis, we are in a Monty Pythonesque situation of employing someone who was found, in any ordinary interpretation of the circumstances, to be taking goods which did not belong to that person. Yet we say to the world that we will continue to employ that person as a security guard. Surely, she can be found something else to do that does not in any way place her in the area of being in charge of security.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take note of the comments that Senator Bishop has made and examine whether that is possible.

—I would also like to know whether any more information has come to hand regarding the diplomat from Iraq. I want to know whether we have any definitive answers as to why he was allowed to wander around this building and, indeed, why he was sometimes followed and why, at other times, he was not. We did not get any satisfactory answers-simply to say that when it was raised in the Australian Financial Review something was done about it.
—I thought that this question was fully answered. But if it was not, I will check and get Senator Bishop an answer as soon as I can.

—The matters that I would like clarified relate to the sequence of events. And, indeed, should we go to war next week and have another enemy, what steps would be taken by the Parliament, and who would be responsible-the Senate will remember that we were unable to get a clear answer as to who was actually responsible for this matter-to make sure that all passes to diplomats of whoever that enemy may be would be withdrawn? I want to know the precise steps that we go through and who is responsible for it being done or not being done.
—An answer to that question will be provided.
—I ask a further question in relation to the lady who stole the handbag containing $200. She was to be summonsed, having been caught in February and charged in April. What has happened to that case?
—I am informed that the case has not yet come to court.
—If that person is on bail, can I be assured that that person does not get a pass to come into the building?
—Yes, I can give Senator Bishop that assurance.

—I refer to a question I raised in the Estimates Committee of security generally in this building through the application of mechanical devices. As I recall, we learnt that there are machines in place which, but for very modest alterations, could very effectively monitor the flow of bags and other goods-certainly one way and perhaps both ways. It would not be a difficult task to have the conveyor belts and monitor screens operating as pass-holders left the building. What is the status of that matter? Is there any intention to pursue that? I do not have the list with me, regrettably. If my memory serves me correctly, I was provided with a document in the Estimates Committee which showed some hundreds of thousands of dollars of theft of goods belonging to the taxpayers from this building. I would have thought that the yardstick for the putting in place of that equipment ought not to be the measure of the cost of that as weighed against the value of goods. As a matter of intrinsic principle, there ought to be some security system put in place.

—The issues that Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Bishop referred to are part of the review that I have asked the Black Rod to carry out. We have set a time limit on it. Certainly, those points will be taken up. I would like to point out, however, that the amount of theft from the building has shown a dramatic decline in recent months-in fact, even in the last year. It is a much better record than it was when the building was first opened. I reiterate: we are carrying out a full review of the security of the building.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I made the point in the Estimates that in many respects this building is unique because of its enormous size and because of the general access that all pass-holders have to all parts of the building, with exception perhaps-I say perhaps-of the ministerial wing. Anybody with a pass can gain access to almost any room or any office in this building without being apprehended or questioned. To that extent, it is very easy for people to move improperly and without authority into any part of the building for the purposes of stealing either money or equipment.

SPEECH.PARA: I give the example of the Liberal party room which is locked outside normal working hours. Our video was stolen from that party room. To be able to go in there and physically pick up a piece of equipment of that size and walk out with it in the midst of a busy working day in a building of this size, with so many people moving around, and without being questioned gives some indication of the ease with which people can steal equipment.

I can only assume that the video player has been taken home, not simply moved to another part of the building. That highlights the difficulty we have with security of the building. In a slightly more trivial matter recently, we had a party meeting and moments after it finished, somebody stole the biscuits, the milk and the sugar.

TALK.START.PARA: —An inside job.

—An inside job, perhaps. Those examples show how easy it is for so many people to go into these rooms without being questioned. So the only real point of supervision and scrutiny is at the entrances to the building. It seems to me that a very practical way of overcoming this problem is by having this process in place.

—The review is being drawn up. In response to Senator Bishop's earlier question about the sound and vision equipment being stolen, I have been advised that we have no report of any sound and vision equipment being stolen this week.

—I am tempted to ask: was it last week? In light of this overheard conversation which, as I said, I have been unable to test, could the President ask Mr Templeton to take a good look at the issue. I do not know how a mini stocktake is done--
—Mr Templeton has advised me that, to his knowledge, no equipment has been stolen, but I am sure that he will undertake such a review.

—On exactly that point, it seems to me-and this has been discussed with me in a very responsible way-that we ought to have a chip attached to such things as sound and vision equipment and the very expensive equipment which is in offices in this Parliament. If the doorways to the building were sensitised and such a piece of equipment were taken through them, the chip would trigger a signal in the same way as occurs if someone steals something from David Jones or Grace Bros. In those stores if someone steals something with a chip attached, whether it be a pair of socks or a piece of furniture, alarms go off as it goes through the door. It seems to me that in a building such as this, we ought to be able to put in place a system which is readily available in every large department store.
—That is certainly part of the review. It is a matter that is being discussed with the Usher of the Black Rod, Mr Templeton and myself.

—I would like to return for one moment to the question of the lady who is now being charged concerning the theft of the handbag and $200. I asked for an assurance that she would not be issued with a pass. I would very specifically like to ask: has the pass which she had been recalled and how can it be guaranteed that she will not be granted a temporary pass?

—That is a very difficult question to answer, because it was suggested that she had a pass, but I do not think there is any evidence that in fact she did have a pass. I will investigate that matter, but that is the situation as I have been advised.

—With respect, I say to the President that those two statements are non sequitur. Presumably there is a register of everybody who has a pass. We know this woman's name. Is she on the register? If she does not have a permanent pass, as I understand it, we also have a signature system for everyone who gets a temporary pass. It would be a matter of checking that. As to the question of whether she would get another pass, presumably her name and photograph ought to be at the attendant's desk to ensure that that does not occur.
—We are not sure that she did not have a Commonwealth officers pass, in which case it would not have been registered here, but that is certainly one of the things that we are looking at.

—With respect, if she has a Commonwealth officers pass, there must be a register somewhere which has that pass on it. Presumably the President would talk to the relevant authority which has control of that register.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not often rise to speak in this sort of debate. I have been in my room listening to the debate that has been taking place here. As is usual in this chamber, it is a very good debate. However, I must confess that I am somewhat concerned to hear a person who has-as I understand it, and I have just picked this up from the debate-not yet been convicted of any offence, being discussed in a way which infers that she has been so convicted. I put on record that to treat people as though they have been convicted before they in fact have is not generally in keeping with the process of the law as we know it.

SPEECH.PARA: If a person is going to be so restricted that she is not allowed a pass or she is not allowed this and not allowed that, that would seem to infer that we have already decided upon her guilt. It is not a proper function of this chamber in the present circumstances to decide anybody's guilt; that is a matter for a magistrate or for a court. For us now in this chamber to pursue the matter of a person who is in jeopardy of her liberty may be prejudicial to her trial and that seems to me to be not the sort of thing we should be doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are probably two matters there, Senator Cooney. One is to do with the administration and what might be done in relation to a pass. The other is in relation to matters that are being discussed in the Committee this afternoon. I have been very careful to listen to the debate to make sure that nothing that has been said in the chamber has been prejudicial towards this person; I do not think anything has. I assure you that I have had this in mind.

—Perhaps I have not explained my position properly. I am simply saying that for us to decide now that a particular person should be treated in a particular way on a basis that would infer that we have already decided upon her guilt is not the sort of thing we should be doing in this chamber. Regardless of the other things we do in here, it is not for us to decide on her guilt; that is a matter properly for a magistrates court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is important to place on the record that we are not discussing what transpires in a court where the criminal standard of proof beyond reasonable doubt will be applied. We have a discretion in this building whom we admit to certain parts of the building. In order to get into certain parts of the building, one requires a pass. In order to get that pass, one has to be vouched for and found to be a person who does not place other people at risk. The civil standard is applied.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a balance of probabilities and it is a question of risk. It is not dealing with preventing an individual coming into this building who comes as of right. It is a question of granting a pass which makes a statement about that person and grants him or her a privilege which other people do not have in terms of access to certain parts of the building. With respect, I think it is a bit of a red herring.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it from what Senator Bishop says that we have already decided, on the basis of probability, that this person is guilty. I did not hear any evidence that would indicate that such a decision has been made.
—She is on charge.

—Senator Bishop has, with great respect, made a statement which I certainly would not agree with, that because a person is charged that means her guilt has been established on the basis of probability. That is a proposition that I have never understood to have been the situation at law.
—What is your point?

—Senator Crichton-Browne has, as usual, asked a fair question. My point is simply this: I have been listening to the debate in the chamber. A woman's position has been discussed in a way which would lead anybody to the conclusion that the Senate has reached a conclusion that she is, at least on the basis of a test of probability, guilty of an offence, and that, as a result, we are taking certain action against her. That seems to be a very harsh approach for anybody to take, given the fact that her guilt has not been established even upon the balance of probabilities.

—I have been advised that a staff member in one of the offices the woman entered believed she may have had a Commonwealth officer's pass. She did not say that she did have a Commonwealth officer's pass. Quite frankly, we do not know how she got into the building-I should say the private part of the building, because anyone can get into the building. That is the problem and that is one of the things that is being investigated.
—Thank you for that, Mr President. So inquiries are going to be made whether she did have that pass and what has happened to it?
—That is correct.
—I will leave it there at the moment.
—Are there any further matters in relation to security? Is there anything else on the Department of the Senate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask one question, which I trust the Government will not have difficulty with. I refer to the matter of Senate offices, where the President made a request in his appropriations for $289,000 and the Department of Finance reduced that to $239,000. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Finance is supporting supplementation for the Department of Administrative Services for similar increases for all ministerial staff but is not prepared to support supplementation for staff in my office--

What is the status of the communication between the President and the Minister for Finance? I raise it because it has always been a strongly held view that the President should not be subject to ministerial direction and there should be a very clear distinction between areas of responsibility and autonomy between the Presiding Officers and the Department in these sorts of matters?

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue is still unresolved and it does not apply only to my office. The exact same principle also applies to the Speaker's office. The last letter was written and signed by the Speaker and myself on this issue on 10 May, and we still do not have a reply to that. The matter has not been concluded and we are still following it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any further matters in relation to the Department of the Senate? If not, when we resume we will move on to the Department of the Parliamentary Library. It being almost 12.45 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
The Chairman having reported accordingly-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., pursuant to order, I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in this debate on what would seem to me to be a matter verging on an orchestrated campaign of distortions, half-truths and perhaps even downright lies being perpetrated by several leading Labor luminaries. My attention has been focused in this direction by remarks made by Mr Baldwin this morning on Radio 2CN, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition are talking about throwing people off income support after nine months.
That comes only a matter of some days after the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) spoke in similar terms in the other chamber. Talking about the Opposition's performance, he said:

. . . they have made this their policy . . . after nine months they would take them off the benefit completely. That is the Opposition's policy: to take them off the benefit and to throw them on the scrap heap.
After several points of order were taken, he simply repeated that proposition and said:

Even worse, as I have said, not only would those opposite reduce the real value of benefits, but after a period of nine months they would throw the unemployed entirely off the benefit . . . How dare they get up and pretend in this House that they have any real concern for the unemployed in this country? It is hypocritical grandstanding.

That is breathtaking hypocrisy of the highest order. It is, I think, clearly a deliberate attempt to frighten the pants off thousands of Australians who have been thrown on the employment scrap heap as a direct result of the Government's failed economic policies. I think the latest official figure for unemployment is 844,000. Those people are not simply accidental victims of a recession. They are helpless statistics of a callous and deliberate economic strategy of high interest rates and high unemployment, designed to knock high inflation, and anything else that moves, out of the system.

We have a government that in effect has deliberately embarked on a strategy which is now coming to fruition, and that is to drive inflation out of the system by raising the level of unemployment to intolerable levels. It is against that background that I find it absolutely extraordinary that in the space of less than a week we have two senior Ministers, one of whom is the Prime Minister, somehow pretending to the electorate that the Opposition has a policy of taking people off benefits after nine months when they know that to be false.

We should just look at the degree of sympathy that has been demonstrated in the past by the Government on this very question. We should bear in mind the Government's approach, which I think most commentators would accept has been a direct result of a response to the Opposition's proposals during the last election campaign. We made it clear then, and we maintain it now, that it is appropriate that there be a finite cut-off point for those in receipt of benefits.

In this instance, we have taken the view, as we did then, that the unemployment benefit per se should cease after nine months. But-and it is a critical and crucial `but'-we would then expect those people to satisfy the Department of Social Security that they had made every reasonable endeavour to find and accept work. If they do satisfy the Department, they would then be eligible for special benefits. That is precisely the distortion and half-truth that I am so concerned about today. Both of those Ministers have deliberately omitted reference to the second half of the equation, which is absolutely vital.

I will just hark back to the last election campaign and look at some words of that great sympathiser with the poor, the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Speaking on the 7.30 Report on 22 February-in other words, during the heat of the election campaign-this is what he had to say in response to questions from Paul Lyneham:

But we're now down to those people who've been there for years. And we've got to go now and intensively interview them and say . . . look at them. Make them apply for work. If they don't apply for work we bump them off'.

That is the Treasurer for you. That is the dripping with compassion approach adopted by the Treasurer in terms of the unemployment benefit. His view, his preference, is to cut people off after a fixed period. Whether it is nine months or 12 months would be incidental to him. `If they don't apply for work, we bump them off'-that is what he has to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not what he said at all.
—Is it not? I seek leave to table the transcript of the 7.30 Report, Madam Acting Deputy President.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Senator Button interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —For the edification of Senator Button, who obviously should be using a bionic ear himself before he offers to make it available to others, the Treasurer said, `If they don't apply for work, we bump them off'. Nothing could be clearer than that. Again, just to show that the Treasurer was very much aware of the second leg of our approach, this is what he had to say at a doorstop interview on the same day--
—What date was this?

—It was 22 February of last year in the heat of the election campaign. Senator Button was probably up north relaxing with a crook back, but everyone else was out on the hustings. The Treasurer was doing his best, of course, to demolish our policy on unemployment benefit. I will be very interested to see whether Senator Button can correct what the Treasurer had to say at the time because he was at pains to demonstrate that somehow the costings of our proposals were unreliable. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have costed the Opposition's unemployment benefit proposal-
which he described as unreal-

and what they said was they could yield the $700 million savings from unemployment, we're yielding a $3 million saving. Remember that we're yielding $3 million, they said they could yield a saving of $700 million, that is by saying after 9 months you're out, and we've said that's unreal, if you're out, they'll just turn up for special benefit and so therefore the issue was that assumption, how many people would return for special benefit.

So there it is, as clear as crystal. The Treasurer knew full well, and no doubt still does, that our proposal clearly involves the cessation of one benefit and eligibility for another after a finite period of time. That is the distortion that I complain about. I have not yet heard Senator Button, or Senator Richardson for that matter, perpetrate this falsehood. As a result of my comments today, I hope sincerely that we will not. But if this is the first shot in a dirty tricks election campaign for a poll some 12 or 18 months away-I could not imagine that the Government would want to go to the electorate prematurely this time around-it really does deserve a very solid response and the record must be set straight at this point.

I hope we will hear no more at all of the suggestion that somehow the Opposition is about cutting people off after nine months with no further recourse. Our policy on this issue has always been that after that period of time they would, if necessary, be eligible for special benefits. So let us get it straight. We are interested in an active employment strategy. Our concern is not to punish victims, our concern is not to simply achieve restructuring which by hook or by crook reduces the numbers on benefits. Our approach is to ensure that there are adequate incentives in the system, that all attempts to find work are maximised and that every endeavour is made on the part of each and every applicant for benefits before they are considered for special benefits. I hope that that is clear and there will be no more of this nonsense.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Evaluation of Tenders for Computer Consumables

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Senate and the public to a very offensive and quite disgraceful allegation that Senator Robert Ray made in the Senate on 8 May 1991 regarding me. He indicated that the Liberal Party in Queensland was silent when there were allegations of impropriety in the tendering process. The exchange occurred when the Opposition was referring to the fairly dishonest way in which Senator Bolkus was handling his portfolio and the contracts he was dealing with.
—I raise a point of order. I object to the use of the word `dishonest'. It is quite unparliamentary in relation to a Minister.
—I ask the honourable senator to withdraw.
—I withdraw that, Madam Acting Deputy President. I probably should have said, `the bungling and the impropriety with which Senator Bolkus was handling the matter of the Nashua contract'.

SPEECH.PARA: When I interjected, Senator Ray pointed at me and said:
I searched the public record to see whether I could find Senator Macdonald saying something about the tendering processes in Queensland. He has been absolutely silent.

He then went on to say that the Liberal Party in Queensland never objected to those tendering processes. He was indicating that we should not accuse Senator Bolkus of impropriety because we had said nothing about the impropriety that was alleged to have occurred in Queensland. As one who lived through the difficulties in Queensland politics at the time when we went out of government, to me Senator Ray's allegation is particularly offensive, especially as we went out of government over something as basic as public accountability in the way the Queensland Government was run. At the time, Senator Ray challenged me not to provoke him further. I did try to provoke him further and told him he should go on and be provoked and come out with whatever he wanted to say about that. But at that point of time I was stopped and warned by the Deputy President, and so the exchange ceased.

I call upon Senator Ray to be provoked and to go further if he wants to. He will find from my record, and from that of the Liberal Party in Queensland, that we have always been determined to see that the right thing was done in government in relation to contracts. We were very concerned about it in Queensland. We are equally concerned about it here when Senator Bolkus mismanages his portfolio and deals with contracts in what we consider to be a very improper way in this particular Government as well.

Senator Ray may know a lot about how the Victorian economy is falling into disrepair; he may know how to fight factional fights in Victoria; he may know how to deal with gold and stamps in Western Australia; but he obviously knows nothing about political history in Queensland. I take particular offence at the remarks that he made on 8 May, as reported in Hansard.

I remind Senator Ray that it was a New South Wales Labor politician who was the first serving politician to be gaoled, and that was for misappropriation and for dishonest conduct. There are legends in history about the bully-boy tactics of the New South Wales Labor Party and iron bars and hospitalisation and criminal charges. History books have been written about that. For Senator Ray to suggest that we, in the Liberal Party in Queensland, never raised our voices is, as I say, quite offensive.

The revelations in the Western Australian Royal Commission in no way surprised me. They are simply a repeat of the allegations that are being made against the Australian Labor Party (ALP) and the union movement in the Cooke inquiry in Queensland. Mr Cooke, the Commissioner, recommended, before the beginning of this year, that a number of people be charged. He has recommended that criminal charges be laid against ALP and trade union officials. He has recommended that one of those who should be charged is the then vice-president of the Queensland ALP who allegedly misused union funds to buy himself a Gold Coast unit. And yet in spite of those recommendations by a commissioner, not one of those people has yet been charged. There is a growing feeling within Queensland that there is one set of laws for everyone else but a different set of laws for the ALP and its union mates in Queensland.

In 1989, the office of the special prosecutor investigated more than 40 former government Ministers and charged five National Party Ministers within six months. Yet the same department, under this Labor Government, has dithered for more than eight months over charges against a dozen ALP officials and trade unionists. One might well ask: why do the wheels of justice move so slowly when it comes to the ALP?

I understand there have been allegations of misappropriation of large sums of union funds which have found their way into the personal accounts of trade union officials and ALP members. Therefore, it is no wonder that Mr Burke felt he was justified in mixing his own stamps with some more valuable stamps that belonged to the ALP. It has been alleged in the Cooke inquiry that union members' funds have been spent on prostitutes, and it is therefore no surprise to me that revelations are coming out of the Western Australian inquiry on how the ALP prostituted itself to obtain funds for its election campaigns. Five former National Party Ministers have been convicted of misappropriation of funds, but why are the trade union officials and the ALP members not being brought before the courts to answer the allegations of misappropriation made against them by the commission of inquiry in Queensland?

The Queensland Government is trying its best to distance itself from every other Labor government in the country, in spite of Mr Goss's claim that he wanted to do for Queensland what John Cain had done for Victoria. We do not hear too much about that now. But Mr Goss's Government is trying to distance itself from the Federal Labor Government and from every other Labor government. It is trying to put on the lilywhite image of `We are so good; we do everything properly; we don't misuse public funds'. Yet we have the spectacle that came to light earlier this week of the former member for Nundah who, for political reasons, the fact that he could not handle and put up with the political dishonesty of the Goss Government, took off from Queensland and went to Port Macquarie. The expensive Joh jet that the ALP spent months-nay, years-criticising the former National Party Government for using, and which it guaranteed that it would sell and never again use for any purposes--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a Liberal-National Party government.

—It was not a Liberal-National Party government, as the honourable senator well knows; he is perpetrating the lie that I find quite offensive that Senator Ray tried on me the other day. The honourable senator can do it as much as he likes; he will get the truth from me, not the sorts of mud-slinging allegations that he throws.

SPEECH.PARA: But I am diverted, probably deliberately, from the point I was making: the Joh jet, which the ALP in Queensland promised to sell-promised never to use improperly; in fact, promised never to use-was used to go down and get this Labor member of parliament back from New South Wales. It was used to bring him back to Queensland so that the ALP Government would not have to face a by-election in these tough times that the Labor Party has imposed upon the whole country.

Those in the Queensland ALP Government are scared stiff of the by-elections this weekend because, although they have done nothing themselves, they are worried about the muck that the Labor Party in Western Australia has been through and all the dishonesty over there, and they are worried about the mess into which the ALP has put this economy. They are petrified at what might happen this weekend in those by-elections. So they went down to get this fellow, one of their political mates, to come back and not resign, to rip up his resignation and sit back in the House so they would not have to face a by-election.

But did they send the Minister, Mr Mackenroth, down on a commercial aircraft? Did they charter their own aircraft? Did the Labor Party in Queensland use some of its $15m cash box to hire its own aircraft to go down and do that? No, it used the Joh jet, the jet that it used to criticise Joh and the Queensland Government for using in former times. But it found no difficulty whatsoever in using the Joh jet on its mercy dash to Port Macquarie to try to drag one of its members back so it would not have to suffer the indignity of a by-election in these times.

Those representatives of the Queensland Government said that they went down to get him and they tried to justify it by the fact that he was suicidal. They said he was ill and they were concerned about his health. But, if that is correct, I ask them to tell me how many doctors they took down on the plane on this mercy dash mission in the Joh jet. Of course, they took none. They took the Police Minister and his private secretary for what Mr Heath, the ex-member, said were purely political purposes. That is not me saying it; it is a member of the ALP saying it and a person who was a parliamentarian in the ALP Government in Queensland. So they have used the Joh jet at a cost of about $3,000 or $4,000 to Queensland taxpayers to get this fellow back for purely political purposes.

There are former Government Ministers languishing in Queensland gaols for misuse of taxpayers' money of as little as $2,000, $3,000, and $4,000. One could well ask why Mr Mackenroth is not going in there to join them-because that is what he has done. He and his Party, for their own political purpose, have used that Joh jet and gone off on a private mission of their own, simply to save themselves the embarrassment of this election.

Fancy Senator Robert Ray and fancy Senator Burns accusing members of the Liberal Party of not raising their voices about improper tendering! They have the absolute hide to do that. They have only got to look in a mirror. I could ask about Ravenshoe. Why has the Government not done something about Ravenshoe? I refer to the mismanagement of almost $8m of Commonwealth money that has been spent there. We have been asking for inquiries; I am continuing at the moment on a general business motion to get that whole matter referred to an inquiry. The Government says, `Don't bother doing that. We are having the police look at it. We are having the Director of Public Prosecutions look at it'. But nothing comes up. Again we might ask: what has the ALP got to hide? Why does it not come clean with this? I raised in Estimates also the question of the loss of another $4m on a bungled fitout that Senator Bolkus could not handle properly in his Department. I still cannot get answers to that.

All of these things are very improper and show that the ALP does not care a skerrick about using public moneys or about misusing public moneys when it suits it. I just hope that the people of Queensland will, this weekend, tell the Labor Party, as the Western Australian public have told the Labor Party over there, that they will not tolerate that sort of dishonesty, that misuse of public funds to use taxpayers' money to jet off on frolics.

I think the people of Queensland will be aware of that, will notice it, and will make their decision known this weekend at the two by-elections in Queensland. They will tell the Government that they are not prepared to put up with the dishonesty. While they are at it, they will tell the Federal Government that they will not put up with the record unemployment it has created in the `depression that we had to have'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to use the occasion of the matters of public interest debate to continue examining a serious matter that was raised during the examinations by Senate Estimates Committee A. I use this occasion because it was not raised as a reservation. Although the matter was raised yesterday, the answer was unsatisfactory and did not provide the true position of the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). Therefore, I could have been challenged by using the forums of the committee stage of the debate to further this particular examination.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a case that has already been raised in the lower House by our colleague on the Government benches, the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), in a grievance debate on the legal system as he saw it. I commend him on the action that he took and the concern with which he debated this issue as a legal matter. I have looked at it from the taxation aspect. After all, it was an action inspired by the Australian Taxation Office that resulted in the gaoling of this poor single lady.

During this debate two taxation cases were contrasted and the treatment by the courts was explored. The first case concerned a Canberra solicitor who did not have to pay $230,000 in tax, because of a misplaced decimal point. He had to pay only $25,000. No gaol sentence occurred here. In fact, he benefited from not having to pay his debts.

The second case concerns a single parent who, deserted by her husband, bankrupt and unable to pay her tax, eventually went to gaol for failure, as she understood it, to do so. This case is usually referred to as the Moorby case. The original sum of the tax liability involved here was around $5,000 or so. I hasten to add that a much larger sum than this was involved in fines imposed by the courts for the non-payment of this tax and for the continued failure to pay the original fines.

The fines eventually totalled $9,200, to be shared by her ex-husband and herself. Thus, the eventual amount of money that this deserted, bankrupt mother had to pay was a figure of the order of $7,000 or more. Her ex-husband was also liable for an equal amount as they were both partners-at an earlier stage-in the business that got into trouble.
