An extenuating circumstance throughout the entire ordeal was that Mrs Moorby was under extreme emotional and financial stress. She found it difficult throughout the ordeal even to meet the instalment payments.

During the recent Estimates hearings I raised questions about the procedures followed by the Australian Taxation Office in both cases. This week I received the Australian Taxation Office's explanation of what had happened in the Moorby case, and it raises a number of concerns. The Estimates answer I received states:
. . . the fact of the particular case is that the taxpayer was gaoled for non payment of court fines and not for failure to pay any outstanding tax as has been suggested in the question.

This is the Taxation Office's version. Mrs Moorby's version is that she did not realise that there was a distinction between the non-payment of the court fines and the non-payment of her tax liability. Fair enough-we do not expect everybody to be a Queen's Counsel. As far as she understood, her imprisonment was for both and in a sense, I suppose, she was right.

This point of view was corroborated by the courts' treatment of her case while she was in goal. Mrs Moorby was, and is, an upright citizen. She is a woman who ran a small business with her husband, a woman who ended up being deserted and left with a large amount of debts which she attempted to pay. Overall, she is highly respected in her township.

The people of her community were so incensed that they, not the Taxation Office that instigated her being there, came to her aid while she was in prison. The township, in fact, raised the $7,000 needed to pay her debts-a commendable action on the behalf of the community. This $7,000 included her taxation liability-and this is the point-and her fines. When the full amount was paid, Mrs Moorby's sentence was shortened and she was allowed to leave gaol.

If the imprisonment was not for failure to pay taxation liability but for the non-payment of fines, why was this not explained to her and only the money for the fines raised and the rest allowed to be paid off in instalments? The community was asked to pay something more in terms of its sympathy for this lady than it really had to pay. As I understand it, this did not happen?

The answer given by the Australian Taxation Office to my Estimates question gives the wrong impression. The important point is that the answer given virtually exonerates the Australian Taxation Office and puts all the blame on the courts. However, in Mrs Moorby's mind, the court fines and the non-payment of tax were all part of the one crime. I think most of us here would agree with that proposition. I think it is petty of the Australian Taxation Office to excuse the situation by putting the blame on the courts.

To give credit where it is due, the Australian Taxation Office had offered to allow the payment of the taxation liability and the fines by instalment before her arrest. However, it was the courts which issued the warrants for her arrest and the courts which insisted that the tax liability and the fines be paid before she could be released. But it was the ATO which prosecuted Mrs Moorby in the first place for failure to comply with its requirements. It was the Australian Taxation Office, which had not investigated the situation thoroughly, which brought it to court.

This case, naturally, is not black and white. Mrs Moorby did do some wrong. The Australian Tax Office did attempt to allow her to pay by instalments and did advise the court that it had no opposition to the court accepting payment of fines by instalment. The courts did fine her a number of times and was harsh in terms of her prison treatment.

Overall, what the case points out is the inadequacies in our present system of handling cases like Mrs Moorby's and particularly the role of the Australian Taxation Office. These inadequacies are as follows: firstly, are the guidelines or processes followed by the Australian Taxation Office for people struggling to pay their taxation liability sufficient to discern the genuine cases from the fake or the put-on cases? I do not believe they are. If they were, would this case ever have gone to the courts? The only contact during the final notices to pay the tax was by letter. The same occurred with the court fines. Mrs Moorby did not appear. The matter was heard ex parte.

Secondly, why did the Australian Taxation Office not encourage Mrs Moorby to apply to the taxation relief board? We read in the Budget Speech that this Government wants to do away with this board as an economy measure. Why did not the Australian Taxation Office tell her of the availability of this sort of relief? Relief would have been given in most cases with extenuating circumstances such as those I have referred to. She would not have been taken away to gaol in front of her crying children. Without prejudging the situation, she probably would have received assistance from the taxation relief board and she would not have had to struggle so much.

The guidelines should be such that a case like Mrs Moorby's should not arise. The purpose of my speech today is to make sure that there is never a repetition of this disgusting situation anywhere in Australia.

Thirdly, the treatment of these cases by the courts and the prisons also needs review. Mrs Moorby was treated as if she were a hardened criminal. She was fingerprinted and transported, without breakfast, in a paddy-wagon from the Hunter Valley to Sydney. Once in Sydney, she was body searched, made to shower in the presence of a male guard and locked up with a drug afflicted prisoner, with a murderess in a nearby cell.

As my colleague in the lower House has stated, the punishment should fit the crime. Failure to pay fines for not paying taxation liability in such circumstances-when a person is insolvent, has subsequently gone bankrupt, is under severe financial and emotional stress, is unemployed and is still the supporter of two children-does not deserve a gaol sentence. This is an indictment of both the courts and the Australian Taxation Office. I call for the presentation to the Senate of guidelines to ensure that the procedures that are adopted in such circumstances are humane. I ask the relevant Minister to respond immediately because the charge is serious.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak today on a matter which is of continuing concern to me, the ability of the Commonwealth to prevent and to detect fraud. I have had a long interest in this matter, going back to at least the time when the Commonwealth Government had a report presented to it entitled Review of Systems for Dealing with Fraud on the Commonwealth. That was in 1987. The report was the subject of some questioning of the Minister, Senator Tate, in the Estimates committee hearings in late 1987. I have pursued the matter subsequently in Estimates committees examining the Department of Defence.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak today because charges have now been laid against three individuals who, it is alleged, have been operating a system of frauds against the Commonwealth. I do not intend, obviously, to go into the details of the case which will be heard before the courts. But the allegations are that there is a network operating to defraud the Commonwealth, based on improper authorisation of invoices and the stealing and conversion of cheques. It is alleged that the fraud against the Commonwealth in that case would total about $600,000. That is only one case that is coming before the courts. I notice that there has been no official announcement by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) or the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) of this claim of large amounts of fraud against the Commonwealth.

Another case coming up is an alleged fraud of a quarter of a million dollars against the Department of Defence, and there is another one alleging the theft of $13,000 from the Department of Defence by an employee of that Department. I know that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) has acknowledged that every allegation of fraud that has been referred to the Defence Inspector-General so far has revealed elements of waste and mismanagement and the abuse of resources.

I am very glad to think that there is an Inspector-General in the Department of Defence. I am concerned that the people under his authority are so few in number. I think something like seven people are employed by the Inspector-General in the Department of Defence. By comparison, some tens of thousands of people work in the comparable office in the United States Department of Defense. That is an indicator of the lack of importance we place on prosecuting and pursuing fraud. We seem to have a laid-back approach. Despite all the warnings we have been given by people who know well what we should be facing and what we are facing, we are inclined to disregard the warnings.

Not only did the 1987 report tell the Government just what needed to be done but also the recommendations were really quite important. They were summarised just recently by the Auditor-General in his report No. 25. He said that the main thrust of the review of fraud was that agencies should take responsibility for the prevention and detection of fraud against their programs. They should also investigate routine instances of fraud against their programs, improve communication and develop formal links with the Australian Federal Police and the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions to allow resourcing in the AFP and DPP to be responsive to the demands resulting from agency activity and fraud matters. He also said that agencies should develop the use of administrative remedies as a cost-effective means of dealing with minor instances of fraud and they should cooperate in law enforcement efforts. The report went on in some detail.

I was concerned that Defence moved very, very slowly to put in place a fraud control report. It was not, I think, until 1989 that it was actually up and operating. That was one indicator of the lack of urgency which the Department of Defence and its former Minister, Mr Beazley, accorded to the control or prevention of fraud against that Department.

Another indicator was that after Mr Beazley and I had both been approached by an employee in the Department of Defence with allegations of fraud against the Commonwealth, it was a year before Mr Beazley allowed two AFP officers, who were offered by Senator Tate, into his Department to work on controlling and preventing fraud. I think it is quite disgraceful that for one year the AFP was not allowed to help the Department of Defence in fraud control measures. It was an indicator, once again, of the lack of a sense of urgency by the Minister in controlling his Department.

Defence expenditure is extraordinarily large. After all, $3.1 billion is spent on defence equipment and stores, on procurement, acquisitions and projects. Similarly, the Department of Administrative Services has a budget of $2.7 billion for its involvement in property and construction, purchasing and disposal, printing and publishing, surveying, land transport and storage. These are all areas where the Commonwealth is enormously vulnerable to fraud. The Department of Administrative Services does a large amount of work for the Department of Defence in its expenditure and procurement. So there we have two major departments of state which are vulnerable and from which I have had employees come to me with allegations of waste, mismanagement and fraud in those departments. The allegations have been taken up eventually by the AFP and prosecutions have been launched in some cases.

I am particularly concerned about what happens to the individuals who, through a sense of duty, bring those breaches to the attention of the proper authorities. In three cases that have been brought to my attention, employees have, by one means or another, been harassed or have been pushed from the department concerned. They have either been included in planned, `phased' redundancies-and it is incredibly coincidental that they have been the people involved in those redundancies-or they have been scheduled for disciplinary action or downgrading, or expected to work in inadequate and difficult circumstances. These include such things as having to work in weapons rooms or in basements, or given jobs without the status commensurate with their experience and responsibility. I am very concerned about that, as I am about the lack of urgency in preventing the fraud in the first place.

TALK.START.PARA: —There should be internal control.

—Yes, I believe there is a lack of internal control. I am speaking particularly about that today. The time has come for the Department of Defence to look at and re-evaluate its fraud control plan. To do that, it should be asking for advice from the Australian Federal Police, the Director of Public Prosecutions and also the Auditor-General. They are all organisations or individuals with expertise in various areas relating to the control of the finances of the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: We should be looking also at whether the scrutiny that is being given to more junior officials in the Department is also being given in adequate form to more senior officials. It is my understanding that the level of scrutiny diminishes as officials become more and more senior. At the same time, those more senior officials have greater authority than the juniors. We should not allow that situation to continue.

Although I support the devolution of financial authority in the Department of Defence, I am worried that, unless we are very, very careful, it will mean even greater vulnerability to fraud. I do not know that there is sufficient appreciation of, or a sense of urgency about, that. I have raised before the question of control over credit card usage by officials. I have not been terribly satisfied with the answers I have been given. There were official requests that the usage of cheques be reduced so that direct credit be the rule wherever possible. I think that is a very sensible measure to introduce wherever possible.

Commander Allen of the AFP made a fairly well publicised speech last year on the whole question of fraud control in the Department of Defence. He gave a great deal of information about the situation in the United States and contrasted that with Australia's. He also raised some of the matters which I have alluded to. He pointed out that, as a result of this devolution policy, by the end of 1990 we will see some 3,000 personnel engaged in the procurement process. That is a large number of people with authority to spend money for the Commonwealth.

We should also think about the conflicts of interests that occur sometimes when people are involved in procurement. We should be looking at collusion between defence personnel and contractors. That is a very great problem for us that we should be warned about. I have also been very concerned about the question of post-separation employment, but I do not think the Government shows much concern about it. There is also the question of collusive bidding and tendering.

Commander Allen said that what we need is `aggressive policy and prosecution'. I could not agree with him more. One of the things that we lack is sufficient legislation. I know that the Inspector-General, Mr Harvey, told the Estimates Committee examining the estimates for the Department of Defence that the Americans have a great proliferation of legislation and he referred to the fact that they also have a lot of prosecutions.

One of our problems is that we do not have sufficient legislation. I draw the Senate's attention to the shadow Attorney-General's legislation introduced last year to try to beef up the approach to crime and corruption against the Commonwealth. The Federal Government took no notice of that legislation at all and I ask why it did not do so. What is it that holds its hand? Do we all not have an interest in seeing that fraud against the Commonwealth is stopped?

The Commonwealth should be looking at whistle-blowers legislation. We are not going to get people coming forward when they know of individuals being harassed or forced out of the Public Service if they do what they see as their duty. Everywhere one turns there seems to be a lack of urgency to push ahead with the measures that we need, the zeal that we need, the legislation that we need and the resources that we need in the AFP or the Inspector-General's area. If we are serious about finding the fraud that I believe is there, we should be doing what is needed to combat it.

The Government should explain, first of all, why it did not make a public announcement about this $600,000 worth of alleged fraud against the Department of Defence. It should tell us why it seems to be prepared to pick up the pieces afterwards but is not prepared to put enough effort into the prevention of fraud. Why are efforts so slack and inadequate? Fraud is going to become a greater and greater problem the more we ignore it. It is the most fertile field for individuals and organised crime, yet this Government seems to be prepared to sit on its hands and allow it to go ahead. Why is the Government not prepared to pick up the shadow Attorney-General's legislation that he introduced into the Parliament last year? Nothing has been done about it at all. Why is the Government not prepared to introduce whistle-blowers legislation to protect individuals? Why do we have to sit back and read about the fraud in the crime pages of our newspapers once it has been committed? It is not good enough. I only wish that I had much longer to speak because the amount of material that is available on this question should all be on the public record and people should be alerted to the lack of urgency with which this Government is approaching it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this discussion of matters of public interest as a result of an answer given to the Senate yesterday by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). He was responding to a question I had asked the day before about Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) meat inspectors working at Wodonga. In doing so, I want to paint a picture of this particular works so that the chamber has some idea of what I am talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: When Wodonga Meats Pty Ltd is operating at full capacity, it processes approximately 400 cattle and 2,500 sheep per day. It employs between 350 and 400 people. Its export sales per week are worth more than $1m, and its export markets include the United States, Canada, Japan, Korea, the Middle East, Russia and Taiwan. Currently, because of the continuing disputation in the meat industry and at Wodonga itself, the works is employing approximately 140 people and its capacity is working at about 50 per cent.

As I run through some of the points and issues involved, I am sure honourable senators will realise that there is no reason that this works-which is one of a number throughout Australia that have been bedevilled by industrial bandits and lawlessness over the last 18 months to two years-could not get back to full capacity quickly and employ some of those 9.9 per cent of people in this country who have not got jobs, thereby assisting in overcoming our current account problems.

In dealing with the answer which I received yesterday, the first point I want to make is that I found it absolutely incredible that on the day I asked my question the Minister had to admit to this chamber that he did not know anything about what had been going on at Wodonga, particularly in relation to the AQIS inspectors. He is directly responsible in the Senate for the functioning of that particular department. The answer given to us yesterday reads, in part:
I have been advised by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service that meat inspectors working at Wodonga Meats are not engaging in a work to rule campaign.

The thrust of my question related to that work to rule campaign. Yet according to the local newspaper, the Federal Secretary of the Meat Inspectors Association, Mr Don Ford, said that inspectors would be working by the book and not assisting the abattoirs. `Working by the book' is jargon for working to rule. On checking with the management today I found that, in its opinion, Mr Don Ford was correct and the answer that was given to me yesterday was incorrect. The Minister should pursue this matter and make sure that the people employed by AQIS, which is now totally industry funded, get in there and do their job.

Let us go a little further down the line and look at the situation in Wodonga. The headquarters of 23 meat inspectors are at Wodonga and the company is paying for 14 of them. That is the core number of inspectors required during normal production. The total cost is $910,000 per year, or $65,000 per man. The company is still paying for all of those inspectors, even though it has work for only six of them. Therefore, eight are being paid but they are not working. There have been a number of problems, apart from working to rule, at Wodonga. I refer to such things as coming back late from morning tea breaks and lunch, and not turning up when the men have been working after hours and loading, all of which exacerbate existing problems. Before saying more about Wodonga, I wish to pick up a reference in the Minister's answer yesterday which I do not believe befits a Minister in this place. The Minister stated:
. . . employees whom I think the union might call scabs.

I hope the Minister thinks that those 140 people who are prepared to work there and keep the wheels of industry turning are to be applauded for their action in that they are prepared to stand up and are prepared to work. They do not want to be in the dole lines; they just want to get on with the job.

It is interesting to note the concern for safety which has been expressed in press reports. Obviously, I am as concerned about safety as anybody else. At this moment an inspector is talking to the people on the picket line. It is also interesting to note that the company also employs a departmental veterinary officer at a cost of $93,000 a year. That person has had no problems whatsoever in passing through the picket line and to go to work.

I want to examine some of the aspects of the Wodonga dispute. For 23 months the Wodonga Meats Pty Ltd export abattoir at Wodonga has been the victim of protracted industrial action by the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union (AMIEU). A State-wide campaign of rolling strikes has continued to plague the Victorian export meat industry and, I would add, the Australian industry-we had a problem at Robb Jetty, Western Australia, just last week-because some employers have refused to enter into agreements outside the wage principles of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. I emphasise `the wage principles of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission' because that is the law under which we operate now.

After 45 strikes in 10 months throughout the Victorian meat processing industry, the Industrial Relations Commission set up the national meat inquiry-the Harrison inquiry. It recommended, and this was accepted by the parties, that all existing terms and conditions that applied throughout the meat industry should continue to apply with no strike action while the inquiry was being conducted. Since then, 72 days production totalling approximately $70m in lost export revenue and representing more than 21,000 man days has been lost.

In chronological order, the history of the Wodonga dispute is as follows: since May 1989, there have been 72 strike days. On 8 January 1991, Deputy President Riordan inserted a bans clause in the Victorian award. The AMIEU has refused to abide by the Commission decision and has breached the bans clause on several occasions throughout the State. At Wodonga there have been 12 breaches of the bans clause since 8 January 1991.

On Monday, 8 April there was a further stoppage. On Friday, 12 April Wodonga Meats Pty Ltd commenced giving final written warnings to 14 union delegates that they would be dismissed if they continued to breach the bans clause and the settlement of disputes procedure. Within two hours of receiving the final warning, 11 delegates breached the bans clause and called a strike for the rest of Friday, 12 April and Monday, 15 April. The 11 delegates were dismissed. On Tuesday, 16 April a picket was established and an indefinite strike was called at Wodonga Meats abattoir over the dismissal of the delegates.

On Tuesday, 16 April 1991 Wodonga Meats Pty Ltd advised that the Victorian Export Meatworks Agreement 1987 was thereby cancelled because of the continued breaches of the bans clause and the settlement of the disputes procedure. From Tuesday, 16 April to Thursday, 18 April more than 30 meatworkers continued to attend the abattoir to work and I congratulate them for wanting to keep their jobs. Management decided not to kill on Friday, 19 April because of violent attacks the previous afternoon by picketers against the workers who continued to work.

The company sought meetings with the Wodonga police to develop strategies to ensure the safety of workers-AMIEU people who wished to work, other union employees and new applicants reported by the Commonwealth Employment Service as at Friday, 19 April to be in excess of 200-and to ensure there would be no repeat of the previous day's unlawful incidents.

Employees were advised on Tuesday, 16 April that they had until 5 p.m., Thursday, 18 April 1991 to indicate their intention to resume work to qualify for the company's offer that the terms and conditions and rates of pay that applied under the cancelled agreement would continue to apply provided they agreed to work five days a week.

Employees would be required to complete an individual employment agreement which included a clause stating that they would be prepared to work five days a week when required without any bans, strikes or limitations in accordance with the bans clause and the settlement of disputes procedure. On Thursday, 18 April this deadline was extended to 5 p.m., Monday, 22 April because there was confusion surrounding the issue of which terms and conditions and rates of pay would apply.

This issue really highlights the bloody-mindedness that has occurred in this industry over a significant period. It highlights the fact that there are people who want to work and earn a decent living; that there are people who want to keep this industry operating. And yet, these people are continually harassed, continually interfered with and continually prevented from going about their normal business.

The answer that I was given yesterday referred to `scabs'. I was told that the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service meat inspectors were not engaging in a work to rule campaign. When we compare those comments with what Mr Don Ford has said and with what management has reported to us, the serious problem that we have in terms of the current situation with AQIS is succinctly highlighted. One could well allege that there is collusion between some of the inspectors at this works and people on the picket line.

I have raised this matter in this place before. The time has come for the Government, which has responsibility for AQIS, to take firm and strong action immediately as far as our meat industry is concerned. It must ensure that there is reasonable industrial practice in this country. I repeat what I have said in this place before: the Federal Government should adopt the same approach to this matter that it adopted with regard to the Builders Labourers Federation and the airline pilots.

The Government should immediately move for deregistration of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union. The members of that union have continually frustrated the meat industry. They have continually abused the rulings of the various commissioners of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. It is about time that the Government carried out its responsibilities in respect of this industry.

As I have said in this place before, this very important industry contributes to this country some $3 billion in export earnings. In recent times, this contribution has been seriously eroded. Rural markets are depressed and rural producers, not only in this country but internationally, are in crisis. It is time that a firm stand was taken.

I say to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), who is at the table, the Federal Government and, in particular, Senator Peter Cook: it is time to stop talking about the antics that have been going on in this industry and the walkout by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the AMIEU from the Harrison inquiry with three days to go. It is time to take some positive action. The best way to get our meatworks operating again at full steam or full throttle is to proceed immediately with the deregistration of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union.
Motion (by Senator Collins) agreed to:
That the sitting of the Senate be suspended till 2 p.m.
Sitting suspended from 1.49 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to comments made by the Minister in Estimates Committee F on 18 April when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: It is my view that the public sector is not a sector that should lead in setting wage movements and not a sector which should come last either, but is a sector that should move with the generality and not be the pacesetter.
How does the Minister reconcile this statement with the Government's headlong pursuit of an agreement with the public sector unions to implement accord mark VI instead of the national wage decision?

TALK.START.PARA: —The public sector is not a pacesetter in these circumstances. The public sector is providing a model for other sectors in the economy to emulate. The proposal that we have put, which is not yet an agreement, provides for negotiations on a productivity basis in the public sector and, on the basis of achieved and demonstrated productivity improvement, a wage increase. The effect of that proposal, if adopted, will be that unit labour costs in the public sector will decline; there will be no cost-push pressures because of it in the economy. The benefits of that reduced cost in the public sector can be taken, and ought to be, in some percentage in wages for those who have helped generate that higher productivity, in greater flexibility in the budgets of the agencies of the public sector, and possibly globally, in the sense that it may contribute towards an easing of the taxation levels. They are the possible outcomes. As a consequence, it is a formula for fighting a recession rather than reacting to the pressures of a recession. If it were emulated in the private sector, it would mean that we would be able to grow this economy out of recession.
—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. Will the Minister guarantee that these improved unit labour costs and productivity increases will come about?

—If the proposal we have put is accepted, the commitment in the framework agreement that we have negotiated is that the Government will have the ability to demonstrate what the productivity achievements are, with payment following the achievement of those demonstrated gains. On that basis I think that it is reasonable to say all the things I have said about lowering unit labour costs and so on and not generating cost pressures. I do not imagine that there will be anything now other than a commitment to achieving as a model a productivity negotiation in the public sector.
—Is the Minister for Administrative Services aware of any international recognition of the purchasing reforms being implemented by the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite illustrative that, when Senator Childs asks a serious question such as this, Opposition senators respond only with laughter. The Government's policy objectives underlying our purchasing reforms, as I have emphasised on a number of occasions to the Senate, are based on three pretty essential principles. One is value for money in government purchasing; the second is open and effective competition in government business; and the third is maximising opportunities for Australian industry.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators opposite might haggle, but I ask them to hold on for a few seconds so that they might get an idea of the importance of Senator Childs's question. To this end we have conducted some rather active and major education campaigns. First we had a `Purchase Australia' campaign, which is designed to increase awareness among buyers of the need actively to seek out Australian suppliers so that they may be sure the Government stands behind them when they do so. Secondly, we have conducted a `Meet the Buyers' campaign, a campaign which is continuing and which is designed to take the mystery out of selling to government, and to make sales to government more accessible to Australian business, especially small business.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. This may be an interesting speech, but is not an answer to the question, which asked whether Senator Bolkus was aware of any international recognition of his so-called initiative.

—On the point of order, Mr President: I think it is fair to say that, in answering a question about international recognition, I can canvass what the international community is recognising. That is what I am doing at this stage.
—I ask the Minister to continue.

—I must say also, in the light of the interjections, that it is not only the international community that is appreciating what is going on in these areas, but also the States. It was only last week, for instance, that I received a letter from Steve Hatton, the Minister for Industries and Development in the Northern Territory, endorsing my Department's role in training purchasing officers along these lines. So Opposition senators are totally on their own when it comes to this matter. There has been international recognition. There has been international recognition as to the role the Government is taking in specification writing, for instance, and also as to the way in which we are reorganising specification writing to emphasise functional specifications.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Overseas enthusiasm obviously is not matched by any appreciation of this area by the Opposition. The enthusiasm for our purchasing reforms is indicated, for instance, by the Central Unit on Purchasing in the United Kingdom Treasury.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition senators have shown in recent weeks a lack of appreciation in the area and a lack of sensitivity as to the need to assist Australian business in government purchasing. I would appreciate it if Opposition senators would keep quiet to get the full import of this answer before they haggle again. Overseas enthusiasm is strong. As I said, the Central Unit on Purchasing in the United Kingdom Treasury has been seeking to develop closer working relationships with Australia. It has sought and we have given it copyright waiver on our guide to specification writing to allow the United Kingdom to use the material for its own purchasing officers. Also it is collaborating with us in our work on risk management in government purchasing.

ANSWER.PARA: This does not apply only to the United Kingdom. In the United States of America, for instance, we have just given a paper on purchasing reform to the seventy-sixth international purchasing conference in San Francisco, at which most of the delegates were from the private sector. It was well received and as a consequence the city of Las Vegas wants to examine our system very closely with a view to implementation, and we have had contact with the Federal United States General Service Administration, the equivalent in the US of our Department of Administrative Services. It is impressed and in its contacts with us has expressed the enormity of the problem the Americans are having in going down the road as far as we have. They are stuck, for instance, with 15 inches of regulation compared with our three and a half pages. Reform there is a long way off, but they are interested in what we are doing. It is not just the United States and the United Kingdom which have expressed an interest. The head of the Hong Kong Government Supplies will soon be visiting Australia to study how we do things.

Overall, as a result of the international interest, I am pleased to be able to say that interest in our purchasing reforms has excited such interest overseas that we have been asked to host the fifth international colloquium on public sector procurement. We have agreed to do that and the conference will now be held in Australia in 1992. It is a great honour for Australia.
Opposition senators-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —It highlights where Opposition senators continually find themselves when it comes to policy development and implementation. When the rest of the world can recognise what is going on here, they sit in their darkness on the other side of the chamber lacking appreciation.
—Order! There are too many interjections, but this is becoming a very long answer, Senator Bolkus.

—Mr President, I am coming to the end. As in other areas of public policy, we are at the cutting edge of developing and implementing reforms. They have been recognised internationally. It is a pity the Opposition does not appreciate what is going on.

—I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the Government's decision to enter into an agreement with its own employees to implement accord mark VI rather than the national wage case decision. Will this agreement be subject to the approval of the Industrial Relations Commission? If not, how does the Government propose to get around the existing paid rates award, or does it simply propose to ignore the Industrial Relations Commission?

—I remind the Senate that we have a proposal which, if the guidelines associated with productivity and enterprise bargaining are agreed, will then become an agreement. At this stage it is not accurate to describe what we have as an agreement. Senator Crane asks whether the agreement will be registered with the Industrial Relations Commission. Certainly that would be our wish and desire. Hopefully that will occur. If it does not occur, the Government will honour the terms of the agreement with our own employees and see that the standards of conditions and remuneration that employees of the Australian Government currently enjoy continue, with the addition of the increase of $12 a week for the continuance of award restructuring and what other increases come out of the negotiations for achieved and demonstrated productivity increases that would also flow from the agreement.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I ask: has the Minister's attention been drawn to a statement by World Vision of Australia that more than 1.5 million people died in the cyclone that hit Bangladesh recently? What action has been taken to ensure that Australia's assistance is directed to the most vulnerable groups, in particular women and children?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were early reports including one, I think, from World Vision that the death toll may have reached as high as 1.5 million in Bangladesh as a result of that awful cyclone on 30 April. However, on the basis of subsequent reports it does seem that the death toll is not of that order of magnitude, even though the tragedy remains nothing less than horrific. Current official estimates put the number of dead at close to 140,000 with a similar number injured, and an additional 50,000 people now suffering from diarrhoea and related illnesses. In human and material terms, the situation in Bangladesh is clearly a devastating catastrophe.

ANSWER.PARA: National and international efforts to deal with the disaster in Bangladesh have at last been gaining real momentum over the past few days. Reports reaching us from our High Commission in Dhaka and other sources confirm that assistance is now getting through. Australia's response has been primarily a financial one with a total of $2.25m in two packages of emergency assistance. Those funds will be used to supply food, water, medicine, shelter, materials, clothing, blankets and other priority goods. Of this amount, as of a couple of days ago, the Australian High Commission had already disbursed some $250,000. That emergency assistance is in addition to 50,000 tonnes of wheat which is being provided as part of Australia's regular program of assistance and funds which have been diverted from the direct aid program and the special activities scheme which are administered by our High Commission.

In addition to that government assistance, Australian non-government organisations have made a tremendous contribution. A Boeing 747 carrying approximately 90 tonnes of food, medicines and blankets arrived in Dhaka the night before last and has been unloaded. That flight was chartered by Care Australia, and the Australian Government contributed 60 tonnes of high protein biscuits valued at $250,000 to the manifest for that flight.

Coming to the last part of the question-while it is difficult to target emergency assistance, when speed of delivery to those in greatest need is our primary objective, women and children will benefit directly from much of this assistance. Furthermore, I should say that of programmable bilateral assistance to Bangladesh this year, almost 50 per cent of it, that is to say, over $5m, is quite specifically directed towards women and children through population, family health and nutrition programs and the vulnerable group development program, so-called, which earmarks 20,000 of the 50,000 tonnes of Australian food aid, which I mentioned, specifically for women and children.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Before I ask the question I would ask whether Senator Evans could adjust his microphone so that those of us at this end of the chamber can hear his answer. I wonder, too, whether other Ministers will do likewise. They seem not to want the microphone to interfere with the television coverage of their answers. I ask, firstly: will the Dalai Lama be received as a guest of the Government when he visits Australia next year and will he be met by the Prime Minister? Secondly, if the answer to either of those questions is no, can the Minister explain why the Dalai Lama, a Nobel peace prize winner, who is the spiritual and political leader of the Tibetan people, would be accorded a lesser status than both Nelson Mandela who, while worthy of the honours bestowed on him, is neither the spiritual leader nor political leader of his people, and President Turgut Ozal, whose human rights record has been publicly criticised by the Prime Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the information available to me, it is possible that the Dalai Lama will visit Australia in April-May next year. Interim committees consisting of private individuals have been established in several Australian States to organise the visit. As yet we have been without any formal approach so far as such a visit is concerned. There has certainly been no specific request made for meetings with me or the Prime Minister. Accordingly, the Prime Minister has not yet given any consideration to whether he will meet the Dalai Lama.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as I am concerned I have already said, on the public record in a radio interview when I was asked this question on 13 March, that I will be happy to meet with the Dalai Lama, especially in light of his international standing, both as a religious leader and as a Nobel prize winner. I am particularly concerned to discuss with him the human rights situation in Tibet, which continues to be the subject of some very distressing reports about limitations on religious and political dissent and the imprisonment and torture of the people involved in such dissent.

The Government, I should say, has expressed this concern to the Chinese authorities on many occasions, most recently at ministerial level during my recent visit to China when I addressed that whole question of human rights and in particular made reference, to both my foreign ministerial counterpart Qian Qichen and also to Premier Li Peng, to the situation in Tibet.

It is our judgment that it would not be appropriate for the Government to extend guest of government status to the Dalai Lama. It is the case that guest of government status is occasionally accorded to prominent individuals who have no particular political office at the time. Nelson Mandela was one, although I find it odd to hear Senator Powell say that he is not a political leader of his people because manifestly he is. Quite apart from Nelson Mandela, from time to time other people have been given that status. However, normally that status is accorded only to people who are representatives of states or governments with which Australia has diplomatic relations.

Where a question arises, however indirectly, of competing claims for recognition of sovereign statehood or competing claims of independence, clearly it is difficult to treat as a guest of government an individual who is involved in such claims purely on his or her own terms as a prominent individual, be it as a spiritual leader or a Nobel prize winner. It does become a question of diplomacy and political significance as to how that person is regarded and treated by the host government. Given the Dalai Lama's association with the Tibetan government in exile, so-called, the Australian Government really could only accord the Dalai Lama guest of government status were we willing to support a bid by the Tibetan people for independence from China, which we are not.

It does need to be made clear that the Australian Government recognises that Tibet is part of China. Discussions between the Dalai Lama, myself and anyone else in the Government would therefore only proceed in the context of Tibet's status as an autonomous region in China. As I have already indicated, while we are prepared, in our discussions with Chinese authorities, to take up as often as is necessary questions of human rights in Tibet, we are not prepared to talk about the question of independence with Tibet. It simply has to be acknowledged that Tibet has just not been recognised by the international community as a sovereign state in the way that was the case with Kuwait, and such like. Accordingly, quite difficult and sensitive issues arise if one gets into that sort of territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask: has the Government drawn up a set of guidelines for bargaining wages and conditions at the workplace level under accord mark VI? Are these guidelines designed to achieve higher productivity and to ensure that wages will not break out in the recovery phase of the economic cycle? Can the Minister also advise honourable senators of the terms of those guidelines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table documents which I have released to the media today, including a general statement on wages policy, a list of government guidelines on workplace bargaining and a framework agreement for accord mark VI in improvements to Australian government employment. Today I announced measures which pioneer the transition to a new wages system in Australia. I have proposed to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), and I will be proposing to employers as well, a framework for its agreement to a set of guidelines on enterprise bargaining which will simultaneously allow Australia to grow out of the recession and at the same time continue with the lowering inflation objective of the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: In 1987, with the decision on the second tier wage increase, massive award restructuring changes were started in the awards around Australia. That process has to continue. It has now reached a point where the benefits of that process can be achieved at workplace level. When they do, the productivity growth, because of that significant and massive change, will begin to appear. Given that we have reached this point, it is our view that we should not stall or go back; we should go on and achieve those gains. Therefore we need a set of guidelines, in the present hiatus over wage fixing, to guide the various players in enterprise negotiation. For that reason, the Government has developed such a set of guidelines based on accord mark VI.

As I have said, the guidelines will underpin higher productivity and ensure that there will be no wages break-out during the recovery cycle of the economy. We will require a commitment from the ACTU to work within the guidelines and ensure that they are adopted by the unions affiliated to the ACTU. If this commitment is given, the Government will be in a position to proceed with accord mark VI agreements reached with public sector unions.

I will be discussing with employers the application for guidelines as soon as possible. The guidelines themselves will ensure that real productivity gains are delivered; that workplace agreements contain no extra claims commitments; that workplace agreements be for a defined period; and that all increases be consistent with agreed aggregate wage outcomes compatible with declining inflation.

Under the guidelines there will be continuing falls in real unit labour costs. Therefore, the productivity related wages available under accord mark VI will contribute to further falls in inflation and will enhance the efficiency and competitiveness of the Australian economy. This will improve Australia's growth prospects with associated benefits for employers.

The public sector, as much as any other sector, must accelerate the process of achieving productive change in its workplaces. The accord mark VI agreement, in the Australian Public Service, provides for $12 payable from today in return for a commitment to continue the process of award restructuring; three wage increases over a 16-month period strictly conditional on demonstrated productivity achievements at a market rate survey; and a no extra claims commitment for the life of the agreement.

Government business enterprises will be free to develop their own workplace agreements to reinforce their commercial identities and to improve their effectiveness and competitiveness. This pioneering agreement in the public sector, with its insistence on achieved productivity, is a model for workplace bargaining throughout the economy. It is a vital ingredient in the economic recipe required to secure a productive and internationally competitive Australia.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ACCORD MARK VI: METAL TRADES INDUSTRY

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Will the Government support the application by the Metal Trades Industry Association to vary the metal trades award to permit the suspending of employees engaged in industrial action in support of implementing accord mark VI instead of the national wage case decision?

—The guidelines that I have just referred to in my previous answer, if embraced by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, ought to provide an orderly method by which negotiations can be entered into between unions on behalf of workers in industry and employers to achieve productivity gains. If those accord guidelines are endorsed, I do not anticipate that there will be any rash of strikes or an outbreak of industrial unrest, given the hiatus that has developed since the national wage case decision one month ago. In those circumstances, it seems to me best to stick with the process of having those guidelines implemented in order to concentrate on generating the productivity flow in the economy that those guidelines speak for rather than talk about what might happen in a hypothetical set of circumstances that has not occurred.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister give me a yes or no answer as to whether this Government will support the metal trades industry's application.
—I thought I just answered that question at some length.

—My question is directed to you, Mr President. It concerns the energy audit of Parliament House. Following the announcement of recommendations arising from the audit, I ask: what program has been undertaken to conserve energy in Parliament House? What savings, if any, have been achieved to date? What is the estimation of future energy savings that may be realised in the next year? How far advanced is the program to replace conventional lighting with energy efficient globes and what is the cost of the program to date? Are any of the energy efficient globes manufactured in Australia? Did the energy audit comment or make recommendations on the automatic perimeter lights in the building's outer offices?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to questions from Senator Coulter on 21 December 1988 and 5 December 1989, I advised that an energy conservation program was in hand, that energy savings of 9.4 per cent had been achieved for the spring of 1989 and that an energy audit was planned for the latter part of 1990. On 4 December 1990 I advised the Senate that a comprehensive energy audit was under way. I can now report that the energy audit has been completed. The energy auditor has supported the thrust of the Joint House Department's engineering services section's energy conservation program, which has included: recommissioning and balancing of air-conditioning and ventilation systems; installation, where possible, of lighting time-block controls; adjustment to water temperatures and volume in heating and cooling circuits; installation of power factor correction capacitators; and installation, on a progressive basis, where appropriate, of energy efficient lamps.

INTERJECT.PARA: Approximately 18 per cent of consumption, or $700,000, has been saved over the past two years. By continuing with present initiatives and with recommendations of the energy auditor, it is estimated that a further $180,000 will be saved next financial year. Further savings are anticipated in the future as the energy conservation program is fully implemented. However, the savings will not be as dramatic as they were initially.

It is planned to extend the use of energy efficient globes to replace incandescent globes in corridors, desk lamps and in the Great Hall. Tenders for energy efficient lamps have been called. Installation will be undertaken progressively in accordance with the overall lamp replacement program. Energy efficient lamps are not made in Australia.

The energy auditor commented that greater efficiency of the switching for the automatic perimeter lighting-that is, pelmet lighting-is constantly under consideration and much has been modified. Particular requirements, such as security, limit the extent to which pelmet lights can be disabled. The engineering services section, in its energy conservation program, is addressing the question of reducing the use of these lights.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ACCORD MARK VI: FORGACS FLOATING DOCK

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware that the Forgacs floating dock in Newcastle has been forced by strike action to agree to the accord mark VI increase of $12 to 400 metal workers, painters and dockers, despite the rejection of this increase in the national wage case decision on 16 April?
—That is enterprise bargaining, which is what you want.

—It is not enterprise bargaining if it is by strike action. Does the Minister agree that this is only the first of such union actions to obtain the accord mark VI increases across the country despite rejection by the Industrial Relations Commission? With the economy and the job market in such dire straits, is this the time for the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) to be arrogantly hijacking Australia's wage system without regard for the consequences?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that an agreement has been reached at Forgacs docks in Newcastle. I understand that that agreement was reached between the company and the unions on this occasion. There was some industrial action at the site but I note that the company did not refer that matter of industrial action to the Industrial Relations Commission for settlement, as is its entitlement and as it would do if it believed that that action was imposing on it demands that were unreasonable or unfair. If that industrial action was doing that, I would have recommended to the company that it refer the matter to the Industrial Relations Commission so that the matter could then be brought within its ambit for settlement.

ANSWER.PARA: What I have to say to the balance of Senator Tierney's question is this: a month ago today the Industrial Relations Commission brought down a national wage case decision offering up to a 2.5 per cent increase for Australian workers, subject to their giving guarantees to continue award restructuring, not asking for any extra claims and giving up some productivity give-backs to their companies. In relation to that decision, which is a month old, no union in this country-except for perhaps one-approaching the Industrial Relations Commission made an application for that increase.

We have here a case of institutional failure in the wages system. In the face of no applications by unions, there is a hiatus on wage settlements in Australia. That is exactly what the Government has moved to fill today in issuing the guidelines on enterprise level negotiation that I have issued. If those guidelines are accepted by the ACTU today-or whenever it accepts them; I hope it will be very soon-what we will have in this hiatus is a set of rules by which wage negotiations can proceed at an enterprise level aimed at generating productivity and then sharing that in a fair way between the customer, the owner and the worker.

That is a responsible approach by the Government in the face of what has been a very difficult time in wage fixation in Australia. For Senator Tierney or anyone else to slip back into the old street fighter approach about industrial relations-the old blast from the past-and attack unions and many employers who are agreeing to the accord, is simply not recognising the fundamental shift that is being made in Australia today in relating wages to productivity so that we can grow this economy out of recession.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is interesting that Senator Cook says that this is a blast from the past. I remind the Minister that this strike action by the union is continuing at Forgacs, despite the fact that the unions signed an agreement not to strike while the yard was refitting HMAS Tobruk.
—Senator Tierney, would you ask the supplementary question?
—Yes. As a result of this action by the union, is the Minister aware that the owner of Forgacs is now considering leaving the industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said in answer to the first part of this question that, if there is continuing strike action, it is the proper option for an employer to refer that matter to the Industrial Relations Commission for dispute settlement. In fact, I said I would encourage an employer to do that.
—But you don't take any notice of it. You ignore it.

—Mr President, through you I will reply to that interjection. We do believe in the Industrial Relations Commission and see a continuing role for it in Australia. That is not something that can be said for the Opposition or the alternative industrial relations spokesman, Mr Howard, who has never made clear what the status of the Industrial Relations Commission would be should the Liberal Party come to power.

ANSWER.PARA: I will complete my answer to Senator Tierney by saying that industrial disputes in this country can be settled through the Commission. That is where disputes should go if there is a continuing problem. My understanding is clearly that the issues arising from accord mark VI negotiations have been settled by agreement between--

TALK.START.PARA: —And they continue to strike after it.
—I will respond to that interjection. If they are, that must be about other matters, and surely those other matters can be taken to the Commission and settled.
—Will the Minister representing the Treasurer inform the Senate of the economic implications and importance of today's interest rate cut?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I touched on the anticipation of interest rate cuts in answer to a question about the inflation rate. Yesterday's consumer price index figure has led to a reduction in both official and bank interest rates. The Reserve Bank of Australia cut official interest rates by a further one per cent this morning. The official cash rates are now 10.5 per cent, 7 1/2 per cent lower than their peak in late 1989. Private banks and money markets have reacted immediately to this cut with the 90-day bank bills falling to 10.4 per cent and 10-year bond rates falling to 10.5 per cent. At least one bank, the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd, has cut the variable housing mortgage rate by a full percentage point to 13 per cent. Other banks are to meet over the next day or so to review their rates. I am informed that the banks also expect to make announcements soon regarding their rates offered to business.

ANSWER.PARA: These interest rate cuts and yesterday's fall in inflation are positive news for Australia's economic prospects, a confirmation of the fact that this Government is removing business cost impediments to an improved trade performance, particularly through lowering the cost of capital in Australia, which is very largely determined by the ratio between inflation and interest rates. With the annual inflation rate less than 5 per cent and business interest rates coming down on the back of this inflation figure, real interest rates are now more in line with those of our trading partners.
Yesterday I reminded the Senate about our comparative inflation performance--

TALK.START.PARA: —In a high recession economy.

—Comparative in the sense that a 4.9 per cent annual rate of inflation now makes Australia a low inflation economy compared with most of our Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) competitors. We now have an inflation rate appreciably lower than that of the United Kingdom, also a high recession economy; Canada, also a high recession economy; Italy, not a high recession economy; and Sweden, an economy with some economic difficulties. Importantly, in relation to that inflation rate, we are below the OECD average for the first time in more than a decade.

ANSWER.PARA: The resulting fall in real interest rates and the inflation result is very positive for Australia's future economic performance. That means that Australia's rapid improvement in its ability to export complex manufactured goods, even in a recessed economy and a recessed world economy, will be given an extra and well-timed boost. I believe that we can now look forward to a period of sustained low inflationary growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Administrative Services.
—For the third time.

— Would the Government have been prepared to go ahead with its legislation to ban political advertising if it had received advice from the Human Rights Commissioner that the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters report entitled Who pays the piper calls the tune, which the Minister has cited as the basis for the legislation, was in fact not a satisfactory basis for the ban, was misleading and incomplete in important respects and may have materially misled the Government? If so, can the Minister explain why the Government is willing to ignore such crucial advice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I think Senator Schacht said, Senator Olsen has tried for the third time to raise this issue. It may be third time lucky for Senator Olsen, but I do not suppose that it will be. I have already made clear that the advice received from Commissioner Burdekin was advice received prior to the introduction of the Bill. It goes without saying, therefore, that the advice was not based on a final version of the Bill, the second reading speech or the explanatory memorandum. That is the first point one should take into account.

ANSWER.PARA: I have also stated quite consistently that, in framing the legislation, we have acted squarely in accordance with the advice of the Attorney-General's Department. That advice has formed the basis of our actions in this matter. It is also quite apparent that Commissioner Burdekin has some difficulties with the proposal, as opposed to the Bill. But we have had a discussion already. He has undertaken to come back to me with constructive suggestions on how to deal with any difficulties he may have in assessing the proposed legislation.

Senator Olsen makes some assertions as to what the Government's basis was for proceeding with this legislation. I have said before that we will consider Commissioner Burdekin and whatever views he might have. The Government has consistently made it very clear, both beforehand and in the second reading speech made by Mr Beazley last Thursday night, that our primary object in putting forward this legislation is that the ban is directed squarely at preventing potential corruption and undue influence in the political process. Senator Olsen may not have noticed it, but in the same passage of that speech the Government clearly stated that it had carefully considered the implications of the proposal on the right to freedom of speech, both as it is generally accepted and specifically under international law.
It is probably worth quoting a little further from Mr Beazley's second reading speech. He said of our international obligations:

. . . article 19 (2) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which Australia is a party, requires parties to guarantee the right of freedom of expression. This right is not absolute.
Article 19 (3) of the covenant provides that the right may be limited in the interests of public order.

Regardless of whatever assessment anyone makes as to the effect of article 19 (2), the Government is satisfied that the prevention of potential corruption and undue influence of our political process falls squarely within the meaning of the limitation `in the interests of public order'. As such, we are satisfied that the proposals are a necessary and proportionate response to this threat and do not constitute a breach of our international obligations. I add again, for the information of Senator Olsen, that the position of the Government is squarely in accordance with the advice of our official advisers, the Attorney-General's Department.

I have to make one quite ironic point about Senator Olsen and the point that he is pursuing. It has been the Opposition in this place and the Opposition in the other place which have consistently over the best part of a decade opposed any initiative by government or by community organisations in this country to protect and to entrench rights of individuals, either through constitutional amendment or through legislation in this place.

Senator Olsen may shake his head, but it is his Opposition which is still committed to the abolition of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission; it is his Opposition which opposed its creation; and it is his Opposition, particularly in this place, which consistently opposed constitutional amendments designed to entrench in legislation basic principles-such as the right to vote; one vote, one value; rights of freedom of religion; trial by jury; and fair compensation-despite the fact that those proposals were endorsed by a widely based group in the community.

Senator Olsen comes in here as a latter day convert to the rights of individuals. His Party and the National Party by his actions, both here and in State legislatures, have shown that they do not in any way deserve to come in here under that pretence. It is quite clear from the underlying basis of his question that he has not understood, and does not now understand, the need for principles in this area. We know what the articles mean. We know what articles 19 (2) and 19 (3) mean. We know that the Government's proposals are in accordance with those principles. For Senator Olsen and everyone else, let me state once again that the advice of our official advisers is that we are acting in accordance with the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister, therefore: did Mr Burdekin, during his meeting with the Minister and his staff on Tuesday night, withdraw the advice that he gave on 20 March? If he did not, will the Minister table the original advice?

—Senator Olsen may just as well ask me whether I enjoyed the hamburger that I ate during the meeting with Commissioner Burdekin. As I have already indicated to the Senate, the basic fact is that Commissioner Burdekin has given advice to the Government. The advisory process is continuing. Consultations are continuing. As I have indicated, in view of that, the advice is not being made public.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. By way of preamble, I mention that the latest copy of the Australian Way contains a special section with several advertisements from manufacturers claiming the manufacture of environmentally superior products. One two-page advertisement contains information from the car manufacturer, BMW. Inter alia, the material says that Australia has very lax vehicle emission standards, which are easily met by BMW, and that this confers on BMW the ability to export its cars to any country in the world. Firstly, how many countries have emissions standards more stringent than Australia? Secondly, if, as claimed, it is possible to meet standards 20 to 30 times more stringent than those now applying in Australia, why has the Government not mandated tighter controls? Thirdly, has the Government made lessening environmental impact a feature of its car plan, and, if not, why not? Finally, if the claims in the advertisement are misleading, will the Minister undertake the instigation of a prosecution under the Trade Practices Act?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised that Senator Coulter would be giving a commercial for BMWs. That is most unfortunate. I have driven a BMW only once, and I thought it was pretty flash. I do not know how many countries have emission standards more stringent than Australia's. As I do not know that, it is difficult to answer parts 2, 3 and 4. The emission standards of other countries are not immediately accessible. I had some notice of the question, but Mrs Kelly's Department, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, could not get that kind of information very quickly. It will take some time to come up with the information concerning other countries.

ANSWER.PARA: Obviously, we will have to check with the Department of Transport and Communications on whether or not we can meet standards that are 20 to 30 times more stringent than those now applying here. We will have to talk to Senator Button's Department, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, about the car plan. I guess that we will have to speak to the Attorney-General's Department about the Trade Practices Act. All of that will take a little time. I will get back to Senator Coulter as soon as I can.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The third part of the question was: has the Government made lessening environmental impact a feature of its car plan, and, if not, why not? I ask the Minister: does his reply mean that the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has had no part whatsoever in setting environmental standards with respect to the car plan? If it had, it seems to me that he may well have had knowledge of that which I asked him.
—That is an answer that I will be supplying as soon as the departments give me an answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I refer to the Ravenshoe sawmill. Why was the payment of $968,000 made on 9 January 1990, six months before the due date of 1 July 1990? Was it because of financial difficulties at the mill?

—In answer to a question yesterday, I informed the Senate of the date of that payment. I think the reason for it was that it was an advance on a scheduled third payment. I do not have with me the reason why that advance was given, but I know that it took place after discussions between the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and the company at the time. I shall endeavour to find that out for Senator O'Chee as soon as I can.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the payment was an advance, what were the reasons given for it and who initiated the discussions which led to the money being paid before the date on which it was due?

—I have just said that I will get an answer for Senator O'Chee on that. One would assume that, if it is an advance, the discussions were initiated by the company. As to the reason, I will have to take that on notice.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Has the Department of Community Services and Health made advance payments for fee relief to private child-care centres in excess of the amount that will be required up to 30 June this year? Is the Department trying to recover the money? Will the Government avoid this problem in future by making the income tested payments directly to parents through the Department of Social Security; if not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has given me an outline of an answer to the honourable senator's question. I can tell him that on 1 January 1991, when the Government extended fee relief assistance to the users of commercial and employer sponsored child-care centres, it was necessary to estimate the likely demand for fee relief from users for the first quarter of 1991. The estimated amount was advanced to services in early January of this year.

ANSWER.PARA: In some cases, the estimate turned out to be incorrect. In cases where the advance was found to be insufficient, it was topped up. In other cases where, after the claims experience of the first quarter was known, it was found that the initial advance exceeded the likely need beyond 30 June 1991 action has been taken to recover the excess.

The second question asked whether the Department is trying to recover the money. As stated above, after the fee relief claims experience of the first quarter it was found that the initial advance was in excess of the amount needed up to 30 June. The excess amount is being recovered.

As to the problem of high initial advances, it should be obvious that the need to recover excess amounts will not occur in the future because the problem lay in making an estimate as to the initial advance that should be made. All subsequent fee relief advances will be based on the fee relief claims experience of the preceding quarter. This experience was not available for the first quarter and estimates had to be made of the income distribution of users in each service.

The Government is not considering making payments direct to parents. The existing system, whereby payments are made to about 2,300 services on behalf of the 110,000 users of these services, is extremely effective and efficient. Senator Walsh would recognise that the voucher option would require services to carry the cost until they claimed reimbursement. Monitoring expenditure and implementing meaningful fraud control procedures for such a system would be extremely costly and inefficient.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, and I refer to an answer he gave yesterday. Why was a cheque for $968,000 paid to the business name Timbertech when, under the assistance agreement, it should have been paid to Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd? Is the Minister aware that Timbertech is not the trade name of Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd, but of another company, National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd, which owned the Kyogle mill?

—In authorising a payment, the normal situation would be that the Department provides the Minister with advice. The Minister then weighs that up. If the Minister feels that the payment is appropriate, then it is ticked. I do not recall ever authorising a payment to a particular name, be it Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd, National Associated Plywood or Timbertech; rather, I recall simply authorising payments. I will have to check that further. As to the fairly complex web of which company had what name and who owned what, I cannot remember that off the top of my head. I will certainly get back to Senator Boswell with an answer.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the Minister was not aware of this, why did he allow a cheque to be paid to a party other than the party in the agreement?
—I just answered that. I anticipated Senator Boswell's question and answered it. He might later on get out the Hansard and read it again.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Is the Minister aware of this week's Saulwick poll, published in the Fairfax press, which found that 74 per cent of the public supports disclosure of political party donations? Given this overwhelming level of public support, does the Minister believe that a uniform system of disclosure throughout Australia is necessary? What will the Government do to encourage State and Territory governments to adopt full disclosure laws?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the Saulwick poll and the very high levels of public support across the political spectrum for the disclosure of political party donations. I also note that the Saulwick poll questioned people as to why they considered political donations were made. It is interesting that only 19 per cent of the community believes that people make political donations to parties because they agree with their policies. The worrying part of the poll is that 75 per cent of the community believes that people make such donations to obtain influence.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government clearly recognises the need for disclosure legislation, and we also recognise the need for uniform disclosure legislation throughout the country. Without such uniform approach covering all levels of government, public confidence in our system of political administration cannot be ensured.
