The type of cynicism which is obviously evidenced by the Saulwick poll results will be perpetuated without a uniform system of disclosure laws throughout Australia. To this effect, the Prime Minister will soon be writing to State and Territory governments calling on them to introduce disclosure legislation on a uniform basis. I also welcome the news that Victorian Government support will be expressed today in the introduction in its Parliament of legislation mirroring the Federal Government's disclosure legislation.

It is also interesting to note that the poll was restricted to questioning whether donations to political parties should be disclosed. The Government believes that disclosure should extend further than that to third parties which participate in the electoral process. With such disclosure, the public will be able to scrutinise the extent to which such third parties are involved in the process of government. We recognise the need to go further than just covering political parties. The need for such third party disclosure can be evidenced by the system in the United States of America, where political action committees run rampant, and also by the case in recent years of Community Polling in New South Wales. In that case, the New South Wales disclosure laws were shown to be totally inadequate. An organisation which was not technically a political party and did not technically participate in the last New South Wales elections was not required under New South Wales legislation to disclose fully the extent of its involvement in that election.

In reality, of course, we all know that Community Polling was a front organisation run out of the office of Dr Metherell, then a senior Liberal shadow spokesperson. The organisation contributed funds to Independent candidates in that election and it is no coincidence that those candidates' preferences went to the Liberal Party. I say that because in recent weeks on the Sunday program we had an assurance from Mr Greiner, when interviewed by Laurie Oakes, that everything in respect of Community Polling had been disclosed.

I cannot see how that took place under New South Wales legislation. Given the fact that the candidates who received donations following the last New South Wales election but are not contesting the forthcoming State election are not required under New South Wales law to disclose such donations, the public cannot with any degree of confidence accept Mr Greiner's latter day assurances. For instance, if New South Wales legislation were to apply to third parties, as the Government would propose on a uniform national level, this would not be an issue. Groups such as Community Polling would be required to disclose their contributions to candidates and to parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Bob Carr paying for this ad?

—I must say in response to that interjection that the other important part of effective disclosure is to have effective auditing powers with the Electoral Commissioner. New South Wales does not have that either. We are concerned to ensure that the political process is protected by full and frank disclosure laws that operate on a uniform basis across the country. It is pleasing to see that Victoria is going down that path.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, you are debating the question.
—In closing, I indicate that the Prime Minister will be writing to all State governments in the near future.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, concerns the very important question of real interest rates. I ask the Minister: is it not the case that the fall in inflation announced this week has actually exceeded the fall in interest rates that the Minister referred to today and that therefore real interest rates are actually now higher rather than lower, as the Minister indicated in his answer? Furthermore, does the Minister acknowledge that real interest rates in this country are still uncompetitive with those of other countries, with Australia at 5.6 per cent compared with Canada at 3.2 per cent; Japan, 4.1 per cent; the United Kingdom, 4.3 per cent; and the United States, 0.8 per cent?
—On a number of occasions it has been said here that the decline in the inflation rate would lead, hopefully, to a further decline in interest rates.
—You said that before.
—I did not say that. At this precise point of time Senator Hill wants to take a 12-hour snapshot and then make a comparison with real interest rates in other countries. That is a ludicrous exercise.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware that the Burmese military regime has recently announced the reopening of universities, but with readmission being conditional on students and their families signing a pledge not to engage in any political activities or join any political parties? What is the Australian Government's response to the situation in Burma?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am all too sadly aware of the reports coming out of Burma about the conditions under which the military regime appears to be reopening universities there and, in particular, the draconian conditions being placed upon students enrolling. This is, depressingly, all too typical of the pattern of repression which is becoming more and more evident in that unhappy country. All of this is a matter of great and continuing concern to the Australian Government.

ANSWER.PARA: There has not been even the slightest perceptible move by the State Law and Order Restoration Council to implement the results of the 1990 elections. Indeed, it is now increasingly difficult to avoid the conclusion that, as much as we hoped and believed otherwise at the time, that election was a fraud designed by the military only to flush out the next layer of dissident democratic leaders making it easier to move against all significant opposition groups, using increasingly intimidatory measures.

In spite of all these circumstances we have been giving thought to ways in which Australia can contribute to increasing international pressure on the Burmese authorities, designed to try to begin to get them to behave in a decent and democratic way. In the first place, there will be no relaxation of the current strict approach to our bilateral relationship with Burma and our Embassy in Rangoon will continue to use what limited links are available to us there to express again and again our very strong concerns.

Secondly, in a practical way the Embassy in Bangkok will pursue the situation of Burmese displaced persons in Thailand. In this respect, Dr Blewett has agreed that we should increase our humanitarian and medical assistance to these people to a figure of $100,000 this financial year. I have also instructed my Department to make renewed efforts to have the tragic situation in Burma addressed in suitable multilateral forums. In particular, I have instructed our Embassy in Sweden to talk to the Swedish Government about possible Australian co-sponsorship of some action in the United Nations General Assembly this year along the lines of that which the Swedish Government initiated last year. Regrettably, that initiative emerged too late to be effective then, but I believe-particularly given the enhanced authority and standing of the United Nations in light of events of the last 12 months-we should do what we can this year to use the forum of the General Assembly to focus the world's attention on the situation in Burma.

I have also asked our Embassy in Washington to discuss further with the United States State Department the possibility of implementing trade and economic sanctions such as those outlined in Senator Moynihan's 1990 Bill. The limitations on the effectiveness of trade sanctions in the face of possible non-adherence by some of Burma's most crucial trading partners may well be real, but I think that we should examine afresh, with other like-minded countries, what the prospects may be. I will also be reiterating, finally, to like-minded governments that we would support action for the imposition of an arms embargo on Burma and, in that context, I believe we should seek the support of Burma's regional neighbours, including China, Singapore and Thailand.

Classically, this is a situation where our influence is limited-we have to acknowledge that-and where the organisation of concerted and united international action is also not easy. But I believe we must keep on trying. The accounts of continuing complacency and repression on the part of the military authorities in Burma do make it important that countries like Australia make their views crystal clear and do what we can to mobilise international opinion. Maintaining pressure is an encouragement to the many very decent Burmese who are suffering and who are looking to the international community for support and succour.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 May Senator Harradine asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a question about youth unemployment measures and the current unemployment situation. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In seasonally adjusted terms in April 1991, the unemployment rate rose to 9.9% from 9.2% in March, and the number of unemployed rose by 66,900 to 844,000. Among 15-19 year olds seeking full-time work the unemployment rate rose to 27.0% from 25.8 in March. In non-seasonally adjusted terms, the total unemployment rate for 15-19 year olds was 22.9% in March. The participation rate rose to 63.7% from 63.2% in March. For males it rose to 75.4% from 74.9% and for females it rose to 52.3% (from 51.7%).

The current unemployment situation is a consequence of several factors, including the slowdown in economic activity in Australia and in the major world economies, depressed market conditions affecting many rural industries and reform and restructuring of the Australian economy. To a substantial degree, the current high level of unemployment is also a consequence of historically high labour force participation.

The youth labour market is typically the hardest hit in an economic downturn. The active labour market programs this Government has in place, together with new initiatives announced in the March Economic Statement, ensure that education, training and employment opportunities are available for young people.

At a time of recession it is particularly important that we maintain opportunities for young women and men to develop skills through apprenticeships and traineeships. In the March Economic Statement we announced the provision of an additional $16 million over three years for measures to keep apprentices and trainees in employment or to help them continue training while unemployed. Extra pre-vocational training places will be provided at TAFE colleges at a cost of around $59 million to help young people prepare for work in skilled occupations.

Other measures announced in the March 12 Statement that will also assist young people include enhancements to the employment access program including increasing the duration and value of assistance available under the JOBSTART wage subsidy, thereby improving the effectiveness of the program in assisting the unemployed; the expansion of the SkillShare program by $31 million over the next three financial years to address increased demand and to create 21 new outreach services including six for Aboriginals in remote communities; and early intervention for the unemployed with literacy and numeracy problems at a cost of around $20 million over three years.

In addition, some 8000 of the long term unemployed will benefit from up to six months training and work experience on projects of community benefit while in receipt of a training wage, at a cost of around $40 million in each of the next two financial years. This includes provision of $5.4 million announced in the 1990-91 budget for work experience. The Training and Skills Initiative (TASK) will assist firms to retain employees in danger of retrenchment or who are working short-time and provide them with training in industry-related or basic workplace skills at a cost of $15 million in 1991-92 and $25 million in a full year.

Higher rates of education retention mean that those entering the workforce are now better educated and trained. The apparent retention rate was 64% in 1990, compared with 36% when we first came to office in 1983.
We have also recognised the special plight of young people in rural areas by providing additional funding of $15 million over three years to boost rural school retention.

Unemployment should start to fall after the economy begins to recover later this year. The Government will adopt a long term focus in addressing the unemployment problem. It is important to protect the skill base of the workforce during a recession and to ensure that government programs assist sustainable recovery and job creation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 May Senator Coulter asked me a question concerning gemfish and orange roughy. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has supplied me with an answer. It is a rather long answer and I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

Scientific advice earlier this year was that there had been a significant decline in recruitment to the east coast gemfish fishery over the last two years and that the catch levels should be substantially reduced to allow recovery.

The decline in recruitment was not expected and the reasons for this situation are not clear. Scientists will continue to monitor the fishery and catches will be set at levels which should facilitate a recovery of the stocks.
Gemfish catches recorded in 1989 and 1990 were 2037 and approximately 1300 tonnes respectively.
A number of boats that had fished for gemfish in the past have been fishing for orange roughy in recent years. This has been primarily an economic decision by the fishermen concerned.

A total allowable catch of 24000 tonnes of orange roughy was set for the period May to December 1990 in the southern and eastern zones of the fishery adjacent to Tasmania. On the basis of the most recent scientific advice, this has been reduced to 21400 tonnes for the whole of 1991. Unless additional resources are found, current intentions are that this be reduced to a long term TAC of less than 6000 tonnes per annum by 1993. Scientific advice is that these catch levels should be sustainable in the longer term.

The Government has a firm commitment to manage Australia's fisheries resources on a sustainable basis. The Fisheries Act requires that in administering the legislation a major objective is to ensure that stocks are not over-exploited. In addition, the Government policy statement on the management of fisheries in the 1990's states a clear objective of ensuring the biological sustainability of the resource.

In this regard the preferred management strategy is to allocate individual quotas to fishermen based on scientific assessments of the long term sustainable levels for the relevant fish stocks. This arrangement will be put in place in the South East Trawl fishery later this year.

Research on Australian fisheries is an ongoing process and management arrangements, including total allowable catches, will be adjusted over time in light of the scientific assessments of stock levels to achieve maximum sustainable returns from fisheries resources.

DEBATE.TITLE: PUBLISHED NURSING HOME STANDARDS MONITORING REPORTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) has been publishing statements in relation to approved nursing homes visited by Commonwealth officers since July 1990. The statements published by the Minister include an assessment of the nursing home's compliance with the 31 standards as outlined in the document entitled Living in a Nursing Home: Outcome Standards for Australian Nursing Homes. The assessment of the standards in the nursing homes is completed by the Department of Community Services and Health standards monitoring teams. When the report is completed it is forwarded to the nursing home proprietor for comment. From these comments the Minister will decide either to amend the report or to publish the report unchanged.

The report is distributed to the nursing home proprietor and the Director of Nursing, staff representatives, residents of the home, the State health department, and is also made available to the public through the Department's State offices. It is also made available in the Commonwealth Parliamentary Library and I will refer to that in a moment.

I think all of us here would agree that the concept of monitoring standards in our nursing homes is commendable and I would certainly not argue with it. But if the statements on nursing homes are available to the public, it is important that they are correct as the nursing homes are to be judged by these reports. I have received a number of interesting comments about the operations of the standards monitoring teams and the accuracy of the reports from nursing homes in my State, the State of Victoria.

Firstly, a comment was made to me that the first visit by the team was being made in a very friendly fashion. Points raised regarding unmet standards were very understandable. However, the second visit by the standards monitoring team was not always conducted with the same attitude. Claims of unmet standards were being made by the teams where there was clearly no drop in standards from the time of the first visit-so points that were not made on the first visit were made on the second visit. A number of nursing homes feel that they have been treated rather harshly during the second visit.

I have been advised by a group of directors of nursing, who have been through two standard visits, that reports are not being written strictly in accordance with compliance interviews. There is an example of one nursing home which had been picked up on one of the safety standards. Apparently, one resident did not have accessibility to a bell. The compliance interview identified this single patient. This patient was in fact a mobile resident who, I am told, was mobile enough to have access to a bell. When the final report was published it claimed that this safety standard had not been met. It is claimed by the nursing home that the wording of the report-and I must tell the Senate that I have not seen these reports, and I will turn to that in a moment-indicates that the problem did not relate to one patient, but to a number.

If I were a relative looking to read these reports in order to decide whether someone would go to a nursing home, I may be misled and believe that this nursing home was failing to meet the standard in general when, in fact, it was only one incident relating to one individual. This is clearly unacceptable. As I have already said, members of the public who have access to the statements may decide against having a relative admitted to a nursing home on the basis of the statement. If the statements are incorrect or misleading then they quickly lose their usefulness. I think all of us would agree-and I am sure the nursing home proprietors and directors of nursing would agree-that the very thing we want to do is maintain standards in nursing homes and publish the findings correctly.

The other thing of concern to me-and it may just involve a timing factor since this is the first time that these reports have been listed-is that it says in the explanatory memorandum that a copy of each published report is also forwarded to the Commonwealth Parliamentary Library. A very quick inquiry to the Library today failed to find these reports. This might involve a timing factor, as I said, but I ask the Library to ensure that it does make these readily available and accessible to members of parliament.

I also call on the Minister and the Department to notify House of Representatives members and senators, but particularly House of Representatives members, about reports on standards of nursing homes in their electorates and advise them that they have been made so that members of parliament can access them in the Library and find out for themselves details about these nursing homes. The more publicity we can have, as long as these reports are accurate, and the more knowledge that both senators and members of the House of Representatives can have, the more useful we can be to people who are in the difficult situation of having to find residential care for their friends and relatives.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

Australia has ridden on the sheep's back for years. Over time, the wool industry has provided so much of our export earnings. It is indeed Australia's greatest earner of export dollars. Some 99 per cent of Australian wool is Australian owned and 97 per cent is exported-or it was, until the troubles of recent years. Wool has always helped Australia to pay its way yet today, in Australia, wool has become so expendable that, daily, we read of farmers who have to shoot their flocks because it is not profitable to ship these worthless animals to market. As one newspaper headline read, `$1.80 will buy you one beer or 18 sheep'. That is a very sad state of affairs.

The wool industry faces a very difficult time. Production is dramatically ahead of demand so, naturally, we are witnessing an ever increasing stockpile problem. With that, there are rapidly increasing taxes to finance the purchase and storage of those stockpiles. How dreadful it is that this once great industry has been reduced to such circumstances.

This corrigendum to the Australian Wool Corporation Annual Report 1989-90, which we are now discussing, corrects an entry in that report under the heading `Inventories'. That section deals with the immense wool stockpile and its maintenance. As I told the Senate last year in a number of debates on this issue, nowhere had it been demonstrated-as distinct from asserted-that, were the offer price for Australian wool to be lowered, there would be any kind of direct and significant demand response. Further, and more importantly, it had not been shown that any such response would ensure that gross income for the industry would increase, or even be maintained. Our current growing wool stockpile, I regret, is testament to those predictions.

For 20 years the Australian wool industry benefited from unprecedented price stability, yet the Government decided to intervene, purely because it was unhappy that money was not going into the Treasury coffers quickly enough to cover the enormous balance of payments deficit that had been created. During the two World Wars, Britain bought the whole Australian wool clip under generous conditions. It knew that it could not depend on Australia's military support if it allowed financial disaster to befall an industry vital to our balance of payments and economic growth. Times have changed and Australia has 4.8 million bales of wool stockpiled, the Australian Wool Corporation has a $3 billion debt, and there is no war, I am happy to say.

The reserve price has been abandoned and a banker, Mr David Clarke, has been appointed Chairman of the new Wool Realisation Commission to sort out the mess. He is described as being brilliant with figures, and the future of all Australian woolgrowers lies in his calculations. His debt management skills will have to be worthy of the accolade given him by a finance magazine last year- `Banker of the year'. Mr Clarke has almost no connections with the bush or with wool growing.

The Australian Wool Council has, rightly, projected one of the Vines report recommendations on the wool stockpile, namely, the setting of a minimum trigger sale price, which would only succeed in limiting the extent to which prices could rise if the market recovered. It could also destabilise the market. In discussing this issue, the editorial in today's Australian said:

Although the Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Kerin, believes the stockpile problem can be overcome in five years, Mr Clarke has been given seven. He could burn the stockpile or selectively destroy it as each bale, given a nominal value of $1,000, costs $200 a year in storage charges. He could offer it all on the market at no fixed price or sell it as `cowboy bonds', with investors buying shares and selling in the future.

One suggestion is for measured amounts of the stockpile to be sold to special, large wool manufacturers. The bulk would be offered to China and Taiwan. Other schemes have been suggested including the creation of a wool bank and the establishment of an options market similar to the gold trade.

Whatever solutions he finds, Mr Clarke's job is to `sell off the assets-presumably in a way that doesn't disrupt things-and by so doing clear the debt'. The master of the `big numbers', he has a formidable task, but the future of one of our most important industries depends on his success.
These are some of the important things that we should remember as we consider this corrigendum to the Australian Wool Corporation Annual Report 1989-90.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the corrigendum to the Australian Wool Corporation Annual Report 1989-90, it is worth noting that it refers to the reserve price scheme. Of course, we know that the reserve price scheme has finished. But we are left with a total of close to 5,000,000 bales of wool in the stockpile and with a very substantial debt, which will bear down on the wool industry over the years to come. I listened to my colleague Senator Bjelke-Petersen giving an outline of some of the problems and the appointment of Mr David Clarke.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I want to make in this debate concerns the importance of the management of what has been left behind and I refer, of course, to the disposal of the stockpile. It is absolutely crucial, if we are to avoid a situation where that stockpile bears down the market, that whatever decisions are made by Mr Clarke and the Government in terms of the handling of it, they must be visible and consistent in terms of release or, to use the current jargon, transparent. In the short time available to me in this debate, I want to emphasise the importance of this.

I refer to a survey involving 35 genuine woolgrowers who rely on wool for 80 per cent or 85 per cent of their total income. However, the cost of production in the area involved, that is, the Esperance area in Western Australia, is some 300c a kilo, greasy, which relates to about 450c a kilo, clean. In addition to that we have to add the proposed tax of 15 per cent. What we must realise about that 15 per cent tax is that it is a net figure and when it is grossed out it comes to somewhere between 22 per cent and 25 per cent. So, when taking that 450c, clean, as the cost of production, we have to add another 60c to 70c on top of that. So, in terms of the total cost required to break even without any improvements to the property, proper fertilising and proper conservation practices, and all those things that go with it, we are looking at a break-even price of somewhere around 515c or 520c.

I want to emphasise, in terms of the matter that we have before us, the importance of the management of the wool stockpile. It cannot be allowed to bear down on the market. Fortunately, since the reserve price scheme was dropped the recovery has indeed been remarkable; far better than most commentators and most industry leaders predicted. In fact, the price was sitting at 570c as of yesterday.

The point that I want to make here in terms of that is the transparency of the release of that stockpile so that the trade knows what is going on. The industry was bedevilled with uncertainty from about August last year when the debate started on the 870c price. That price went down to 700c. The 700c was rock solid and it was revoked and the world lost confidence in the ability of Australia to be a reliable, consistent provider of a product at a consistent price. That brings me to the last point that I want to make here when we look at that particular price.

It is absolutely essential that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) reconsider his position as far as the 15 per cent tax is concerned. There are mechanisms-with the management of the Australian flock, with the management of the assets and with the management of the promotion-by which that tax can be significantly lowered. The lowering of that tax will have an enormous impact on the social cost which will occur through this restructuring process. I particularly refer to demands on rural reconstruction, on social securities and on State governments. It is absolutely imperative that a reanalysis be done of the proposals that have been put publicly in order to get that tax down to more like 8 to 10 per cent. It can be achieved if the effort is made, but if it is not, I fear that we could see up to 30 per cent of woolgrowers disappear from this country in the next two years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words about the Australian Wool Corporation's annual report. I know that we have had a lot of discussion in the past month or so on wool, but it is not out of the question to reinforce what has been going on in the industry. Both the wheat and wool industries in Australia are in strife, one of its own volition and the other because of foreign markets, the export enhancement program in America and the subsidisation in the European Community. That is the great difference: one industry led itself into this downfall and the other was led into it by world trends.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as wheat is concerned, Australia is trying to get some fair competition going overseas. As to wool-and I am a woolgrower-I must point out that the greed and arrogance of the industry led it into this situation. Woolgrowers wanted to pay themselves too much for a fibre that was not in demand as much as it used to be worldwide. Woolgrowers were simply borrowing more to keep themselves at a standard of living that they just could not afford at this stage. They should have seen the writing on the wall much sooner than they did. They were simply borrowing money and, unfortunately, a lot of that was going through the Treasury in higher taxation and that need not have been the case. Anyway, that has been done now. It is to the credit of the Vines report that, hopefully, we are now on our way to restructuring the wool industry.

I have said before in this chamber that I believe that no-one will make money out of wool for five years. Unfortunately, along the way there will be some tragedies as some growers go out of existence. That is the tragedy that came not from the present situation, but from what led up to it; it should never have happened. At least the restructuring is on its way. As Senator Crane pointed out, the prices are a little better than we expected. This week the clean wool price reached about 580c or thereabouts a kilogram. As Senator Crane also pointed out, the cost of production is that high. At least if the cost of production is that high, growers might be able to get themselves in balance until better times come in five years.

I also commend the authorities for some of the appointments they have made to the Wool Realisation Commission. The appointments will no doubt have to be ratified by legislation in the Parliament a bit later. I like the type of people and the integrity of the people who have been appointed to the Commission. I slightly disagree with a previous speaker, Senator Bjelke-Petersen, who criticised the appointment of a former banker, David Clarke, saying that he had no experience in the wool industry. As far as realising the stockpile is concerned, I believe that he is the sort of person that we want; he has no axe to grind. We need a person who will simply apply business principles to that realisation. It is not much different from liquidating a big enterprise except that there is only one line of stock to sell. I believe that a person like David Clarke and the other people who have been appointed will see the industry back on its feet.

The only aspect on which I disagree with the Government is on the wool tax we will be paying. I believe that the Opposition has a far better scheme by which the stockpile would disappear earlier. We would be charging a lower wool tax, therefore enabling more growers to survive until better times. Indeed, the Vines report recommendation on how to conduct the realisation would have been superior to what the Government intends to take on board. Legislation for that will be coming forward in a later session of this Parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the eighty-eighth report of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report deals with the operations of the Committee from July 1989 to June 1990. It describes the scrutiny by the Committee of the 1,258 instruments of delegated legislation which came before it. The Committee detected possible defects in 184 of these instruments, or some 15 per cent. The report gives details of the main concerns raised by the Committee. It also illustrates how the Committee obtains from Ministers undertakings to amend instruments to meet these concerns. The Committee is grateful for the cooperation it has received from Ministers.

The report is a convenient consolidation of the work of the Committee during the year. The Committee makes a detailed report to the Senate at the end of each sittings. Whenever it gives a protective notice of motion of disallowance in order to preserve its option to recommend further action, it incorporates in Hansard a statement of its concerns. Similarly, where a notice of disallowance is removed or otherwise dealt with, the Committee incorporates its correspondence. The present report now provides in a single volume a reference point for all aspects of the operation of the Committee.

Delegated legislation is no less Commonwealth law than the Acts under which it is made. However, it is legislation which does not have the procedural safeguards and guarantees of a Bill which passes through Parliament. The Senate has therefore entrusted the Committee to oversee this legislation and to ensure, in its non-partisan fashion, that it complies with parliamentary proprieties and personal liberties. I believe that the report justifies the confidence of the Senate in the way the Committee improves the technical quality of delegated legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in my capacity as Deputy Chairman of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. I would like to add to the remarks of the Chairman, Senator Giles, in two respects, and that is to take up the point she made that delegated legislation is just as binding, and sometimes just as harsh, as ordinary legislation. Yet here, when we debate primary legislation, the feeling and the knowledge that delegated legislation flows from those enabling Acts gets less attention.

SPEECH.PARA: More and more people's lives are regulated by what flows from primary legislation. The more we can expose and give access to the general public to the sorts of regulations that are passed subsequent to the debate that takes place in this chamber, the better understood the legislative process will be and presumably the fairer way people will have to act under that delegated legislation.

The other point I wanted to make was simply to place on the record once again the high regard in which the Committee holds our legal counsel, Professor Douglas Whalan, who serves the Committee and is paid only an honorarium but indeed has read every piece of delegated legislation that has been passed since he has been legal adviser to that Committee. Both his knowledge and understanding of delegated legislation--

TALK.START.PARA: —And his humour.

—And his humour, as Senator Patterson says, is something that we appreciate enormously on the Committee. It means that we do our work more effectively. Sometimes advisers go unrewarded and indeed unacknowledged. But on this occasion I would like to place on the record the debt that I think all the Senate owes to this particular legal adviser for the splendid work that he does.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the statements made by my colleagues on the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances-in fact you, Madam Acting Deputy President, are a member of that Committee-and to say that I wish to support the comments that Senator Bishop made regarding Professor Whalan and to put on record our appreciation to the staff of that Committee. It is an arduous job and it is very detailed. If the rights of individuals and the rights of this Parliament are to be protected, their diligence and attention to detail is very important.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that concerns me greatly about the public knowledge of this Committee is that when I move around the schools in Victoria and I tell students that we can have three Liberal-National Party coalition and three Government members who sit and discuss issues that are a cut above party politics-issues about the rights of individuals and the rights of parliament-and that we can discuss these in a very rational and reasonable way, they are surprised since the images they get from the television and from the Press are ones of attack, counterattack and the political cut and thrust.

Yet here we see a Committee with a long and proud history-in fact a history since 1932, and I will be recommending that the Committee celebrates next year in 1992 a special anniversary-a history where a recommendation put to this chamber by that Committee has never been opposed or challenged by this chamber. That shows the regard in which that Committee and its various members since 1932 have been held.

We pay very keen attention. We think very carefully and hard and long if we recommend the disallowance of a regulation. Yet we hold very, very important and very dear the protection of an individual's rights. I would ask, especially those people gathered in the Press Gallery who so easily and so often report the bad things about parliament, that they remember the sort of work of the Scrutiny of Bills and Regulations and Ordinances committees and report the good news of Parliament about the protection of rights through this Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate a speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
ANNUAL REPORTING GUIDELINES FOR STATUTORY AUTHORITIES
Mr President
I present the 309th Report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts-Annual Reporting Guidelines for Statutory Authorities.

The Committee initiated this Inquiry into Annual Reporting Guidelines for Statutory Authorities in the context of, and in response to, the significant public sector reforms that occurred during the 1980s.

The present Guidelines for the Content, Preparation and Presentation of Annual Reports by Statutory Authorities were issued in November 1982. However, since that time the guidelines have been neither up-dated nor re-reissued to reflect the major changes to the reporting requirements of all Commonwealth entities.

From the early days of the Inquiry, it has been abundantly clear to the Committee that the current 1982 guidelines are out of date and do not adequately reflect the changes that have taken place in both the present day administrative environment and the legislative framework within which Commonwealth government entities operate.
In the Committee's view, the annual report lies at the heart of the accountability process and is one of the most important vehicles for effective Parliamentary scrutiny.

Statutory authorities have generally been afforded more management autonomy and flexibility in financial administration than departments of state. This is particularly the case in the light of the ongoing reforms to public sector management and since the issue of the Government's Policy Guidelines for Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises in October 1987.

But this increased autonomy and flexibility give rise to an even greater need for detailed and proper reporting by statutory authorities of their performance to fulfil their accountability requirements to Parliament and through Parliament to the public at large.

Accordingly, the Committee strongly endorses the existence of guidelines which lay the foundation for statutory authorities to prepare high quality annual reports that focus on the meaningful reporting of both financial and non-financial performance. Furthermore, the Committee is of the view that no statutory authority-large or small, commercial or budget-dependent-should be exempt from meeting the minimum requirements set down by annual reporting guidelines.

The Committee is particularly concerned that while many statutory authorities have specific annual reporting provisions in the Acts by which they are established and others are subject to the annual reporting provisions of the Audit Act 1901, there is no consistent or all embracing legislative requirement for every statutory authority to report to Parliament annually.

The fact that there is no statutory backing for the annual reporting guidelines for statutory authorities is incongruous with the existence of statutory backing for the departmental annual reporting guidelines, by virtue of the Public Service Act 1922, and the requirements of the Companies Code in relation to annual reporting by private sector companies.

In the Committee's view, the most effective way to ensure that there is a minimum level of quality information presented by all statutory authorities to Parliament each year is to give new annual reporting guidelines statutory backing and it has recommended accordingly.

Furthermore, in line with the current practice for the guidelines for departmental annual reports, the Committee has recommended that the statutory authority guidelines, and any amendments made to them from time to time, be approved by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

The Committee has also recommended that new annual reporting guidelines for statutory authorities be prepared by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and that the Department be responsible for an annual review and up-date of the guidelines.

There is a vast array of bodies that can be classified as statutory authorities and as part of the Inquiry the Committee closely examined the classes of statutory authorities to which the annual reporting guidelines should apply. The Committee has recommended that there should be one set of annual reporting guidelines for statutory authorities and that these new guidelines should clearly state the categories of statutory authorities to which they apply. These categories should include:
* government business enterprises;
* statutory marketing authorities;
* other commercial statutory authorities; and
* non-commercial statutory authorities.
Furthermore, the Committee recommends that the guidelines should be presented on two levels:
* the first covering broad issues applicable to all authorities with an emphasis on accountability requirements for both financial and non-financial information; and
* the second level divided into sections relevant to particular categories of statutory authorities which outline the reporting requirements applicable to each category.
The Committee believes that these recommendations will clarify the present state of confusion surrounding the annual reporting requirements for statutory authorities.

All statutory authorities are accountable to Parliament for their performance and, as I have already mentioned, the reporting of performance takes on added importance in the context of the recent reforms in public sector management. In the light of the reforms, the Committee has concluded that the current annual reporting guidelines for statutory authorities do not adequately emphasise the importance of results-oriented reporting.

The Committee considers that currently there is inadequate guidance from central Commonwealth departments for production of performance information by agencies but readily recognises that development of quality information is a dynamic process and is still in its relative infancy.

Against this background, the Committee has recommended that all statutory authorities be required to report on non-financial performance in their annual reports, providing as a minimum, an outline of program objectives and of desired results together with a description of key performance indicators. Comparative data over successive years should be presented where relevant.

During the Inquiry, the Committee paid particular attention to the situation of statutory authorities with commercial operations. With the aim of improving the quality and timeliness of information to Parliament, the Committee has recommended that such authorities be required to present to the relevant Minister on a half-yearly basis, interim reports on financial position. Furthermore, all statutory authorities should be required to report critical events which have a material effect on financial position to relevant Ministers as they occur. In the formulation of the new annual reporting guidelines, the Committee has also recommended that stronger consideration be given to the treatment and disclosure in annual reports of commercially sensitive information.

Parliamentary scrutiny of annual reports is an essential link in the accountability chain. Such scrutiny can have direct benefit in improving the accuracy of information provided in annual reports and in promoting adherence to annual reporting guidelines. The Committee also recognises a need for direct feedback to authorities from Parliament about the type of information presented in annual reports. Without such feedback, reporting entities are left in the dark about the quality of the information they have provided, how useful it is and how and where it could be expanded upon.

The Committee considers that a valuable form of Parliamentary scrutiny is that conducted by standing committees of both the Senate and the House of Representatives. As a result of a Senate resolution on 14 December 1989, the legislative and general purpose standing committees of the Senate now undertake systematic review of annual reports of all Commonwealth entities, although the Committee notes that the review process is somewhat uneven. The Committee also notes that scrutiny by the House of Representatives standing committees tends to be of a more ad hoc nature than that conducted by the Senate. The Government, however, has indicated its intention to implement a recommendation made in the Committee's Report 304 on Guidelines for Departmental Annual Reports that the House of Representatives standing committees formalise the scrutiny process.
Against this background, the Committee has made a number of specific recommendations to bring about enhanced scrutiny by the Parliament.

In this Report 309, the Committee has endeavoured to set the major parameters for the drafting of new guidelines for annual reporting by statutory authorities. While the Report does not address all detailed issues in annual reporting, it identifies the critical matters that should be included in annual reports.

This Report is seen by the Committee as providing the overdue impetus for new annual reporting guidelines for statutory authorities. More importantly, the Committee views the Report as the foundation for the creation of relevant annual reporting guidelines within a framework of constant review and revision.

It remains for me to acknowledge the contribution of all members of the Public Accounts Committee to this Report, and particularly my fellow members of Sectional Committee B-the Chairman, the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch), the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) and Senators Giles and Reynolds. The honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay) was also a member of Sectional Committee B until March this year.

The Committee would like to thank the Australian National Audit Office for the secondment of Jenny Peachey to assist with this Inquiry. The Committee wishes to extend to Jenny Peachey its appreciation of her highly professional contribution to its work. Finally, the Committee records its appreciation of the valuable contributions of the Inquiry's administrative officer, Yolanda Campagna and of the Secretary to Sectional Committee B, Jennifer Blood.
I commend the Report to honourable Senators.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON MIGRATION REGULATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator McKiernan, Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, I present the report of the Committee entitled Change of Status-Marriage and De Facto Relationships and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement on behalf of Senator McKiernan.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON
MIGRATION REGULATIONS

I am pleased to present the Committee's second report, dealing with change of status on spouse/de facto spouse grounds. This report is part of the Committee's ongoing inquiry into the Migration Act and Regulations, as required by its terms of reference.

Change of status from being a temporary resident to having permanent residency on the grounds of marriage or a de facto relationship has become more of an issue in recent years. Dramatically increased numbers of applications and allegations of fraudulent practices on the part of individuals and migration agents have heightened concerns that this means of remaining in Australia on a permanent basis is being abused.

The committee felt concerned about the increase in spouse applications because of the potential for abuse of the system. Applicants for change of status on spouse grounds are preferential applicants-they are given priority for assessment and they do not have to satisfy some aspects of the public interest test. It may also be said that the ability to change status from within Australia encourages people to do so in preference to their applying from overseas.

The amended Migration Act and Regulations came into force on 19 December 1989. The legal regime established by that Act and regulations gave very little scope for visitors to change status on grounds of marriage or a de facto relationship. However, it became clear very quickly that the new law was extremely harsh and operated unjustly in many cases. On 15 February 1990 the previous Minister, Senator the Honourable Robert Ray, moved to institute a concessional arrangement for an interim period, whereby visitors here legally could apply to change status on grounds of a spouse relationship with an Australian citizen. At the same time the Minister referred the problem to a working party of the National Population Council for consideration and recommendation. The Working Party's recommendations were then referred to this committee for consideration.

The Working Party recommended a return to the pre-December 1989 situation, that is that visitors should be permitted to be able to change status on the grounds of marriage or a de facto relationship, with added measures to reduce fraud. The committee, in November 1990, sent interim advice to the Minister, Gerry Hand MP, essentially concurring with the recommendations of the National Population Council, but recommending specific measures to reduce fraud and for the assessment of de facto relationships. The committee also argued strongly for victims of domestic violence to be given special consideration for permanent residency, even though their marriages may have broken down.

Following the committee's interim advice to the Minister the committee continued to investigate change of status and has made a number of conclusions and recommendations, principally in the following areas:
* collection and provision of statistical data;
* consideration of relevant cultural factors;
* marriage and immigration law;
* immigration marriage fraud;
* marriage breakdown.
The committee discusses at length the problem of immigration marriage fraud. The committee notes that marriage fraud is of particular concern for the following reasons:
* the integrity of the immigration program is compromised when those who cannot qualify within the program secure permanent residence through a sham marriage;
* such sham marriages jeopardise the community goodwill which is necessary to sustain humane migration provisions facilitating family reunion;
* prevention and detection of marriage fraud is expensive in terms of staff and time resources.

The committee attempted to assess the extent of the problem by analysing the statistical data relating to change of status. However, this proved to be difficult, given the unavailability of much of the data and the paucity of data provided by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, especially in its annual reports to Parliament. The committee has commented particularly on this aspect of the inquiry in its report and has made several recommendations to rectify the situation.

Further, the committee was unable to get a clear picture of the incidence of sham marriages, with much of the evidence being suggestive or based on departmental case officers experience. The committee has made recommendations in this area to ensure that the department collects and maintains a more effective data base.

The necessity for departmental officers to be made aware of the different cultural values and practices with regard to marriage is discussed in the report. Case studies discussed in the report illustrate the problems which can arise if officers responsible for assessing the validity of a relationship do not understand the relevant cultural factors. The committee has recommended in the report that assessment officers receive appropriate training in cultural considerations.

The marriage issue itself is an inherently difficult one. Moreover, the current legislative procedures in place to assess the validity or otherwise of a relationship for immigration purposes have complicated the task Departmental officers are required to perform. The Committee is especially concerned at the lack of guidance in the Procedures Advice Manuals relating to some areas of assessment, for example the test for a genuine marriage for immigration purposes. The Committee regards this issue as central to the question of marriage and immigration and discusses it at length in the report. As well as recommending and endorsing a number of changes to the law, the Committee has recommended that the Department provide more data in its annual report and more support for its staff in the form of training and better guidance in Procedures Advice Manuals.
In January 1991, in response to the Committee's interim report, the Minister announced a number of changes to the procedures for changing status. These included:
* increased evidentiary requirements through changes to documentary and interview procedures;
* a two year period of conditional residence for eligible spouse/de facto applicants with limited sponsorship rights and permission to work;
* a requirement that a de facto relationship be in existence for six months prior to date of application;
* increased application fees;
* provision for domestic violence victims to be granted permanent residence.

On 15 April this year the regulations were amended to put into effect the changes announced by the Minister in January. The committee welcomes the Minister's response to the recommendations made to him on this issue. However, the committee does have some reservations about the 15 April amendments, particularly the mandatory condition that there be no material change in the circumstances of the applicant during the period of validity of the visa. The committee has recommended that such material changes be confined to changes in the nature of the marriage or de facto relationship, such that the relationship is no longer genuine or continuing.

The regulations as a body continue to be a source of concern to the Committee, given their complexity and the frequency and number of changes being made. The Committee feels that such a degree of constant change to an already complex system without the simplification foreshadowed by the Minister in May 1990 disadvantages all those involved in the immigration process, including applicants, Departmental officers, community advisers and migration advisers.

All Committee members and staff have worked hard to finalise this report. The Chairman asked that I express particular gratitude for the advice and assistance given to the Committee in its endeavours by Dr Kathryn Cronin, the Committee's legal consultant. Dr Cronin's objective and intelligent advice has enabled the Committee to pursue its inquiries effectively and has without doubt enhanced the quality of the Committee's deliberations. I would also like to thank the members of the committee for the large amounts of time members devote to the work of this committee. It is a very demanding and sensitive subject area. My thanks must also go to the secretariat staff particularly our Secretary Robina Mills. I am also pleased to thank Ms Heidi Quinlan and to congratulate her and her spouse on the recent birth of their first child.
I commend the report to all Honourable Senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations that has just been tabled has tackled the emotive and controversial issue of change of status on spouse-de facto grounds. I am pleased that this report prepared by that Committee has, in the main, had the support of all Committee members in its direction, unlike the first report. That is an indication of the extent to which the Committee was prepared to take evidence from around Australia and to grapple with what is and has been a complex and difficult issue.

SPEECH.PARA: This has been part of the Committee's ongoing inquiry into the Migration Act and regulations as required by its terms of reference. Given the number of regulations that come out and the constant change, it is a particularly difficult and, of course, sensitive area.

The Committee met in most capital cities to hear evidence, evidence which indicated that we cannot ignore how much of a problem sham marriages undoubtedly are as a method of acquiring Australian residency. As our report on illegals last year indicated, while we see ourselves as living in difficult and uncomfortable times, we are still the lucky country to most of the rest of the world, with the result that we have a crush of people attempting to find ways around and through our migration regulations.

Fraudulent marriages have been on the agenda in that regard of achieving life here in Australia. Yet despite this, we found during this investigation very haphazard methodology in the statistical records of such cases in the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. This must be reorganised as a matter of priority so the Government, the Committee and its officers have immediate access to what is actually happening within the community.

Disorganised data and, therefore, reliance on much anecdotal departmental evidence are not good foundations for changed regulations and legislation. Certainly the evidence we found of increasing and widespread rorts to the system was qualified by so many different people in each State that there was no reason to doubt it. But it is a lesson to the Department that statistical information cannot be treated as casually as it has been when the future of people's lives and the success of our migration regulations depends on decisions made from that information. Changing the format from report to report makes it extraordinarily difficult to get a common base on which to make value judgments.

That information is important, especially when everyone dealing with the situation on a daily basis knows that applicants for change of status on spouse grounds are preferential applicants. It can be a prime area of abuse. Surely, therefore, some constancy in collecting data on that area of immigration should have received high priority before now.

Much of the evidence that we heard during public hearings was harrowing. We heard of women abused by their Australian husbands, yet too frightened to leave their marriage in case it also meant having to leave Australia. We heard of men conned by the women they married, deserted immediately when their wives achieved the prize of Australian residency. We did not hear many happy tales, because happy stories are success stories and therefore are not reportable or the basis of evidence. But stories of use and abuse and distrust and despair in the system were common.

Just as sad, we heard of men and women who were refused residency here because we take such a narrow view of what marriage is. The tyranny of distance, I suppose, strikes again. As Australians we generally believe that the marriage mould which fits our society is the old Anglo-Saxon one of choice and love. Yet we should be heeding the standards and customs of others who wish to join us within our true multicultural society. In making that judgment, if we are serious about being a multicultural society, we must take note of the views of those, and there are many, who believe that a happy marriage is between cousins many times removed who may never have met each other, or between persons born on the same day in neighbouring villages, or with someone 40 years older who for a variety of reasons participates in a marriage, or even with someone chosen by the family back home and sent to Australia for the marriage. They are cultural matters relating to particular societies that need to be taken into account when assessing these regulations within Australia. Those cultural backgrounds are important to the true integration of Australia as a multicultural society.

That does not mean that we in any way dissipate the standards which we in Australia, and I in particular, support and encourage. It means recognising the rights of the cultural background of some people who would be applying for permanent residency in Australia. So the Committee in its report recognises and recommends that the immigration officers who are dealing with this complex range of world values on a daily basis must have workable, understandable guidelines to help them. They must have guidelines to enable them to recognise the fraudulent practices, yet guidelines that can help them accept in some instances the unusual as valid. We have no right to expect those officers to make the correct decisions for those couples if they are not armed with the information they need. In every aspect of this investigation the Committee members expressed concern not only at the lack of guidelines but also at the complexity of the migration regulations and the frequency and number of the changes being made. It is becoming a monster, there is no doubt about it, and it needs to be simplified. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) foreshadowed such a simplification in May 1990. A year later, unfortunately, things are much worse.

Again, as with the lack of guidelines, we are asking the front-line officers to shoulder a burden that is impossible as a base for correct decision making. In the middle are people, many trying to stay here fraudulently, and such complexities and changes can only help their cases to stay in Australia on a fraudulent basis. They are people who are rorting the system who ought not to be given assistance to do so. Others-some the victims, as we had in evidence before us, of quite dreadful domestic violence-deserve protection and compassion from some straightforward regulations. I trust and hope that the Department will heed this report, particularly as it relates to the area of statistical information, and that there will be a common format year in, year out so that appropriate value judgments can be made for setting regulations for the future.
Debate (on motion by Senator Bell) adjourned.
