SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Foreign Investment Review Board annual report urges its readers to be very cautious about the statistical information contained in it-more cautious, I think, than previous Foreign Investment Review Board reports that I have read. Perhaps it is a reflection on the significant public concern that exists about the level of foreign investment which turns into foreign ownership by default. In this country a recent Bulletin poll indicated that 67 per cent of Australians thought that there was too much Japanese investment in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The total expected investment associated with foreign investment proposals approved by the Government in 1989-90 was $24.1 billion, about 25 per cent less than in the previous year. The number of proposals considered was 2,913 compared with 5,163 in the previous year. Most of the total expected investment was in real estate, $10.5 billion; followed by tourism, $3.9 billion; manufacturing, $3.1 billion; mining, $2.7 billion; and services other than tourism, $2.7 billion. The main locations for expected real estate investment were my State of Queensland, $4.3 billion, and New South Wales, $4 billion.

The rejection rate for proposals was 2.3 per cent compared with 1.7 per cent in 1988-89. Of the 61 rejected proposals, 57 were in the real estate sector, one in the tourism industry, one in manufacturing and two in the resource processing sector. As people will probably be aware, Japan was the largest source country for expected investment, accounting for 35 per cent of the total expected investment for the year compared with 28 per cent for the previous year. The main feature of Japanese investment was its concentration in real estate and tourism.

Under current policy for off-the-plan arrangements, foreign interests may receive approval to buy up to 50 per cent of the units or condominiums in new residential development projects provided the dwellings are bought before or during construction, or following completion, but prior to being first occupied or used. I think this obviously begs the question: why do we allow this sort of arrangement? It is totally speculative in nature. Who gains from this arrangement? I believe the effect of this is to cause values in the area to rise and to make accommodation even less affordable for the majority of Australians.

The Government's foreign investment policy has also had a major impact and a negative impact in rural Australia. There were eight proposals for the establishment or acquisition of interests in abattoirs and 15 rural property proposals involving total expected consideration of $250m. This may seem insignificant, but this fact takes little notice of the amount of vertical integration which exists in the beef cattle industry in this country, and the purchase by the United States food giant Con Agra of a 50 per cent share in Australian meat holdings takes away majority Australian control of the beef cattle industry in Queensland. This is a disgrace and it is no wonder that the Cattle Council of Australia has called for a restructuring of the Foreign Investment Review Board to give it greater visibility and accountability. I support its call. In fact, the Australian Democrats have been proposing such changes for some considerable time.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you propose?

—I think that Senator Spindler intends to speak about that. The Government's foreign investment review policy is framed and administered with a view to encouraging foreign investment in Australia and ensuring that such investment is consistent with the needs of the community. What is the criterion for working out the needs of the community? In my opinion the vague qualification of `not contrary to the national interest' is not enough. It is not in the national interest to use foreign investment as a short term solution to our economic problems.

SPEECH.PARA: We do need foreign investment. Let us have it on our terms. Let us have something which adds to Australia's own manufacturing and technological base. We must have a government which is prepared to set more strict guidelines so that we do not have a majority of Australia becoming foreign owned by default.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to address a few remarks to the Foreign Investment Review Board Annual Report 1989-90 and to draw to the attention of the Senate some of the very important and interesting information that is contained in the report. In doing so, I think I come to the report from a position very different from that of Senator Kernot. I detect very strongly in Senator Kernot's remarks, despite some comments that might indicate otherwise, that essentially-I hope I do not misrepresent her-she is more anti, rather than pro, foreign investment in Australia.
—On our terms.

—On our terms. I think that if we adopt that approach, we would not have had the foreign investment in Australia that we have had throughout most of our history. We would not have had anything like the living standards and the growth and the development of this nation that we have had. Nevertheless, there are aspects of foreign investment in Australia that require careful attention and monitoring, and attitudes taken towards them.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that Senator Kernot made one remark which is, in fact, not correct. If I got her right, she said that more and more of Australia is falling into foreign hands. That is not, in fact, the case. If Senator Kernot looks at page 28 of the report and at the table which follows, she will find that the report states:
In the past decade or so, there appears to have been no major change in the levels of foreign ownership of Australian industries and resources that have been the subject of ABS studies.

Some of those studies are several years old. There has been a considerable reduction in the amount of surveying done by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in this area of foreign ownership of assets in Australia. I think that is something that needs to be looked at. Nevertheless, the fact is that, according to the Foreign Investment Review Board and the statistics that are available, there has been no major change in the overall level of foreign ownership in Australia as a proportion of the total Australian economy over many years.

The report does make some very interesting reading in other areas, particularly the statistics. It highlights the extent to which the policies of this Government have led to such a massive increase in the total level Australia's foreign debt. Although it does not go back to the first year of the Hawke Government in 1983, the report starts with figures from 30 June 1984, which show that at that date Australia's level of external debt was 15 1/2 per cent of total gross domestic product (GDP). By 30 June 1990, that figure had increased to no less than a staggering 33 1/3 per cent of GDP.

It is precisely for those reasons that we have the enormous debt servicing burden that we do have today and, therefore, the essence of our external account problem. All the reasons for that enormous growth in debt in Australia can be sheeted home fairly and squarely to the Hawke Government's policies, which have seen the level of external debt rise from $44 billion in 1984. I think that when the Government came into office it was of the order of $20 billion. That has now risen to a staggering $150 billion or so throughout that period.

Unless the Government adopts policies that will really tackle in a meaningful way that foreign debt problem, and it is showing no inclination of doing that, the problems facing this nation will become increasingly intractable. I commend the material contained in the report of the Foreign Investment Review Board. I hope that someone may speak to it subsequently. I think it is something that should be kept on the Notice Paper so that we can consider it in more detail later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to the Foreign Investment Review Board Annual Report 1989-90, particularly regarding its relationship with the Australian Heritage Commission. I was under the impression that the Australian Heritage Commission Act required all governmental bodies to take cognisance of that Act in making determinations and that nothing any Minister, who has control over Commonwealth bodies, should allow to be done should in any way impinge on those sites, buildings or areas that are protected under the Heritage Commission Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I raise this in the context of the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) is that because of a court case, and only because of a court case, the people of Australia became aware of the fact that the Treasurer (Mr Keating), as the Minister with responsibility for the Foreign Investment Review Board, totally ignored the requirements of the Australian Heritage Commission Act in the matter of Paddy's Market in Sydney. In fact, the Treasurer just ignored the requirements of the Act-thumbed his nose at it-without reporting in any way to the Parliament.

I suppose that we expect that sort of arrogance from the Treasurer, and we certainly got it again in this case. Foreign exchange approval was given to a foreign-based development without the requirements of the Heritage Commission Act being met or, in other words, every effort being made to ensure there were no suitable alternative methods of handling this matter. These requirements were just ignored by the Treasurer.

I raised this matter during the Senate Estimates Committee hearing. I will deal with it at greater length when the matter of Estimates Committee C comes before this chamber. I hope that by then I will have been able to establish some facts. The Australian Council of National Trusts wrote a letter to the Government, that is, both the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and the Treasurer, expressing concern that the Department of the Treasury had not fully met its obligations under the Australian Heritage Commission Act. Was the Commonwealth bound by the Act, at least in terms of the Foreign Investment Review Board?

This important matter should be resolved. Is the FIRB, as a governmental body, bound by the Heritage Act? If not, why not? What does the Government intend to do to ensure that bodies such as the FIRB, when allowing foreign investment to take place-the situation that clearly obtained in the Paddy's Market matter was recently resolved in the courts-take note of the Heritage Commission? Otherwise, the Government's alleged commitment to preserving Australia's heritage is clearly hollow, and its hollowness was evidenced in the court case.

I hope that the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), who is on duty and who I know is concerned about heritage matters, takes this matter up with his Government to ensure that this body is bound by the Commonwealth's legislation, which is supposed to relate to and control the Commonwealth's activities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My first concern in addressing the annual report 1989-90 of the Foreign Investment Review Board is that the guidelines in respect of foreign investment are far from clear. My other concern is that the Foreign Investment Review Board seems to be toothless. Ultimately, the decisions are made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his own capricious way. From what I can tell, George Pooley, who is head of the finance and investment division of the Department of the Treasury, really seems to run the show subject to the Treasurer's approval.

SPEECH.PARA: Not so long ago in Sydney a proposal was put up by I think the Pivot Group Ltd and an overseas group. The Treasurer declined it I think for aesthetic purposes. He did not approve of the development. I think he thought that it was contrary to his perception of how the Sydney skyline should look. If that is the nature of the decisions, it really gives no guidance to anybody trying to make a judgment as to whether the project is likely to get approval. Of course, an enormous amount of effort and cost goes into the preparation of these submissions.

We have guidelines-I think they were referred to by one of the Australian Democrats-in respect of residential property, particularly condominiums. Foreign investors can own 50 per cent off the plan of any given project. I was fascinated with the number of golf courses being built in northern Queensland. I wondered what was unique about the Queensland climate that it attracted so many golfers and what attracted so many condominiums to the golf clubs? I quickly discovered that it was the cheapness and the access of playing golf in Australia for the Japanese. That is a very attractive component of any development. The golf course is really there as a sweetener for the condominiums.

How does the Government decide that 50 per cent is a good number, that 40 per cent is a good number and that 60 per cent is a bad number? It is an arbitrary figure that does not have any intrinsic intellectual assessment attached to it. Perhaps it is driven more by the xenophobic nature of Australians. Perhaps it is driven by the fact that two years ago real estate prices were skyrocketing, particularly in Sydney but in Australia generally, so the Government had to make a political statement. People were convinced that they could not afford to buy a home because all the Japanese were flooding into Australia and buying up all the homes. That was what was driving prices up. The Government seemed to be making a political statement.

There is a very real need to get proper and clear guidelines that are intellectually sustainable, of course, measured and mixed with the natural, but not necessarily healthy, concern of Australians about the flood of Japanese money coming into Australia. They have essentially gone into real estate-besides the attraction of the golf courses-because of Australia's taxation system and its high levels of inflation and therefore the escalating value of non-productive assets in the form of bricks and mortar. That is why the Japanese have been investing in real estate. One might describe some of the rural sectors of Australia as real estate areas. This money is not going into manufacturing or other areas. It is simply Australia's economic environment that attracts investment into that area. It is not that the Japanese have any quirk or quaint notion about real estate.

TALK.START.PARA: —They like marble beef though.

—Indeed, they do like marble beef, but they are particularly attracted to the investments that give them the best return in Australia. That is why they go where they are. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 May, on motion by Senator Tambling:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The final report of the Resource Assessment Commission entitled Kakadu Conservation Zone Inquiry is before us because of this Government's incompetence and failing, and its incapacity to make the right and honest decisions-in fact, when the crunch comes, as it did before the last election, to make any decision at all. I suspect that Senator Richardson thought that, having convinced Cabinet to put off the inevitable day, after the election things would go nicely and that Justice Stewart and his body, the Resource Assessment Commission, would agree to the mining of Coronation Hill which could then proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know the history of the conservation zone. It makes up part of stage 3 of Kakadu National Park. We also know that Senator Gareth Evans, when he was the Minister for Resources, described a very significant part of the third stage as `clapped out buffalo country'. I do not say that that is true of all stage 3; there are some very beautiful parts of it. But there are also hundreds of thousands of acres of country which I would not have thought, by any reasonable measure, would be unique or particularly attractive.

Ultimately, when stage 3 was set aside for the park and there was a proposal that it be nominated for World Heritage listing, Senator Evans very sensibly tried to rescue what he could of that very rich resource potential of the Northern Territory. He looked around to see what part he could set aside into a conservation zone for future mining. At that stage, it was pretty obvious to the Government that, for political reasons relating to its internal politics, no more uranium mines would get off the ground. So Senator Evans found himself looking at resources other than uranium. He selected for his conservation zone mineralisation, which was essentially related to gold, platinum, palladium and such exotic minerals and metals.

Senator Evans imagined-and it was proposed and announced-that there would be research and exploration of conservation areas in stage 3 and that those areas in due course would be set aside and allowed to be mined. Coronation Hill was one of them. It is no coincidence that Coronation Hill is in the conservation zone; the conservation zone was drawn so that Coronation Hill was in it.

When the decision had to be made, the politics hotted up and the Government made a judgment that the last election would be very much decided by minority groups, particularly the conservation movement. Therefore, the tenet of its faith was that there would be no mining in stage 3. Senator Richardson had to find some excuse for not mining Coronation Hill. The environmental impact statement had been prepared and presented and it was approved by the Government. There was no logical reason why mining at Coronation Hill should not proceed, but there were political implications.

We ended up with the establishment of the Resource Assessment Commission. It essentially reported that there was no practical or tangible reason why mining could not proceed. Its report was really just a very expensive rerun of the environmental impact statement which had previously been prepared. In the process of his inquiries, Justice Stewart and his commission came to the conclusion that the Jawoyn people would object to mining. We ended up with a report to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) on the Kakadu Conservation Zone, which is the next document I see listed. I see that my time is about expire, so I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 May, on motion by Senator Reid:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report brings me to the next stage of the saga. Justice Stewart drew the breathtaking conclusion that the Jawoyn people were opposed to mining in the conservation zone and at Coronation Hill. I say with respect that that flies in the face of the best evidence thus far obtained from the responsible elders of the Jawoyn people. My own view-a view which is supported by evidence given to the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts-is that the Northern Territory Sacred Sites Authority and other groups sought and successfully influenced the outcome of the determination of the Jawoyn people.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not without significance to note that this new found sickness country, the born again Bula boundaries, actually changed twice in a matter of months. When that was pointed out by Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd to the Northern Territory Sacred Sites Authority, it simply changed the boundaries. If these boundaries are prepared and drawn on the basis of the views of Aboriginal custodians, one has to ponder as to how the Northern Territory Aboriginal Sacred Sites Authority, when trapped and caught fiddling the boundaries, could arbitrarily change them again without the authority of, or consultations with, the Aboriginal custodians.
This area has already been subjected to the Jawoyn Katherine area land claim, which was heard by Justice Kearney. He came to the unqualified conclusion that sites 4 and 5 failed. He said:

. . . the traditional evidence put forward in relation to Areas 4 and 5 is insufficient to enable any finding to be made that the members of that group (or any group, for that matter) are the traditional Aboriginal owners of those areas, within the meaning of the Act. While there are sites on both areas and Dreamings to which the Jawoyn have links-
and he then gives those examples-

the existence of common spiritual affiliations to sites on Areas 4 and 5, or to sites which can be linked with those areas, is not established; nor is there evidence of a strong traditional attachment to Areas 4 and 5. Accordingly, the claim to Areas 4 and 5 fails.

Claims 4 and 5 are those areas that are very close to Coronation Hill. It is not without significance to note that the Resource Assessment Commission, in seeking expert evidence, used Dr Merlan. Dr Merlan was the person who identified the alleged sacred sites in the first place, registered them on the part of the Aboriginal community and then consulted for the Northern Territory Sacred Sites Authority to examine whether they ought to be registered. In other words, he was a bit like Laurie Connell-the honest broker for both parties, the Aboriginal community and the Sacred Sites Authority. Of course the sites were bound to be registered.

Notwithstanding that, the Jawoyn people made it quite clear to Justice Kearney that, in their view, it was not country in which they had any interest. When an area nearby-for instance, the Eva Valley area, which would have to be considered Jawoyn country if Coronation Hill country was-was referred to, they said, `We have nothing to do with them fellows. That is another group. Forget that. We only want Jawoyn country.'. We now find that Justice Stewart claims that the Jawoyn people believe that it is their country. When giving evidence before the Senate Committee, the responsible custodians made it quite clear in unequivocal terms that, in their view, Coronation Hill ought to be mined. They had no objections. It was not sacred site country, it was not sickness country and it did not impinge in any way upon their traditions or beliefs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in this debate to express concern about the prospect of this Government making a decision based on the Report to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on the Kakadu Conservation Zone which clearly is unsatisfactory in some elements. If mining is to be prohibited on the grounds that it would offend Aboriginal belief, the manner in which the report has concluded this, does not, to my mind, stand up to any kind of clear test.

SPEECH.PARA: The report entitled The Significance Of Shallow Traditions by Mr Ron Brunton, an anthropologist and head of the environmental policy unit of the Institute of Public Affairs, clearly indicates some major areas of concern about the quality of the report on which the Government will be making this decision. In particular, The Significance Of Shallow Traditions points out that there is a real prospect that `illegitimate pressures', to use its description, have been put on some of the Jawoyn people when they were giving evidence before the inquiry. As the report says, at one stage Justice Stewart obviously believed that the question of pressures from anti-mining individuals and groups had to be addressed because, at the hearing at Barunga on 6 March 1991, he asked each of the custodians whether they had been subjected to any such pressures. The custodians said no. However, the question was asked in the presence of some of the very people who may have been applying the pressure.

This might explain some of the extraordinary conclusions that were made. For example, Mr W. J. Fisher had been in charge of mining Coronation Hill in the past, the so-called sickness country, which, under present claims from some Jawoyns, would prove a disaster if it was mined. This man had working for him a large number of Jawoyns. He provided information along these lines to the inquiry. Justice Stewart clearly did not consider his evidence to be significant. Mr Fisher demonstrated that Coronation Hill itself is not the area of the sickness country that it is held out to be in the report and that this sickness country is 30 kilometres away.

We have had major expressions of concern about the location of the mine, but we have clear evidence that Jawoyns were prepared to work on the old Coronation Hill mine site. I stress this again: this area has been worked in the past by the very Aboriginal people who are today claiming that it has magically become a sacred site. As Dr Brunton concludes:

But now the Government is being advised to protect areas on the basis of beliefs which the RAC Inquiry has acknowledged are only a decade old. (While the beliefs about specific sites in the Zone are older, the justifications for protecting the whole Zone are not.) The change from tens of thousands of years to ten years is quite a trajectory, and it could have the gravest implications for public acceptance of the need to protect sacred sites. The obvious question is whether there is any part of Australia that could not be protected under the Act, should anyone set their minds to it. Perhaps the most worthwhile thing to come out of the Inquiry will be the realisation that the definitions of Aboriginal tradition in existing legislation need to be completely rethought.

I do believe that there is a case for protecting and preserving the true sickness site and supporting sites, as identified by Mr Bill Arndt in 1955-which do not include Coronation Hill; it is 30 kilometres away-but it looks like the Jawoyns have the wrong site. Mr Justice Stewart did not even discuss this matter in his report, as raised by Mr Peter Fisher.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words on the report to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) on the Kakadu Conservation Zone. I believe that it is a report that, on balance, the Government can come down on either way. Honourable senators may remember that this report was commissioned in the lead up to the 1990 election. At that time this Government did not want to make a decision on whether to mine Coronation Hill. It did not know how to deal with the environmental groups. It did not know whether it would have the Australian Democrats completely on side with the Green groups.
—That is very cynical.

—If Senator Tate casts his mind back to that time, he will remember that that was the sort of decision that the Government could not make, pending the election. It decided to have another inquiry to inquire into the last inquiry and into the inquiry before that. Sooner or later, after all these inquiries, the pigeons have to come home to roost.

SPEECH.PARA: With the millions of dollars that Pancontinental has sunk into that place, it wants to know whether it will get any return on its money by mining or whether it will have to close up forever. Unfortunately, if it closes up forever, it will probably close up its other prospects around Australia forever and, as reported in the press the other day, do its exploration, and maybe mining later on, in countries that appreciate it. That was the gist of that report. It was commissioned to get the Government past the election. Now, 12 months past the election, the decision still has to be made.

Coronation Hill has known reserves of 1.1 million ounces of gold. That deposit would result in a $500m profit and would employ 600 men. Of course, a lot of those would be Jawoyn people. Probably contrary to Senator Tate, I visited that place twice when I was on an inquiry. They told you, Mr Acting Deputy President, as they told us, that they were very interested in getting jobs, so that their colleagues could get away from some of the social pressures existing at the time and resulting from being unemployed, such as alcoholism. Added to that-and I know that I have said this before-I have never known of a mine, starting up on the basis of reserves found on exploration, not to find an extension of that lode.

TALK.START.PARA: —West coast of Tasmania.

—Yes, the west coast of Tasmania. Mining at Kalgoorlie started in 1893. It is coming up to the centenary of mining there. Nearly 100 years after extensions are still being found. In my own home town an extension of the original lode, discovered in 1888, was found. There are more reserves to be found.

SPEECH.PARA: In this brief period that I have to address this subject, I will mention what worries me. As Senator Michael Baume pointed out a minute ago, this is a precedent. All of these conditions, reasons, excuses or red herrings that are being applied to Coronation Hill can be applied to anywhere else in Australia, whether in the Nullarbor, the eastern gulf, the west coast of Tasmania or in the conservation zone of Kakadu National Park.

If an environmental group can get its way on this matter it can apply the same criteria to everywhere else. There are moveable sacred sites. We have found that out over the years, for example, when a new mineral reserve has been found or when at various times the Department of Main Roads in Western Australia has wanted to put a highway through. It worries me that Coronation Hill will create a precedent if the Government does not have the gumption to say, `Right, this project is going ahead'.

That precedent could be used around Australia time and time again. We will be closing down the resources that we badly have to get moving in order to get Australia out of the recession-not the recession, but the depression-and to get us on the road to prosperity again and to get rid of some of the unemployment. For those reasons, I call on the government to get the project moving. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADVANCE TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 May, on motion by Senator Bishop:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Advance to the Minister for Finance again, I have had cause to look at the Hansard and the remarks I was making when the debate was adjourned; I was making the point that I suggested in the Estimates hearings that the Department of Finance should compile a list of the number of Advance applications that are made by departments that fail to meet the criteria and are rejected. This could be a useful indication as to which departments are, in fact, efficient and which are inefficient. I am hopeful that that will be taken up.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I want to address my remarks particularly to that matter listed as a request for act of grace payment for unused recreation leave and leave bonuses on retirement for the Commissioner of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, because here is a very good example of the correct use of an Advance to the Minister for Finance, pursuant to section 34a of the Audit Act.

I raised the question of the proper functioning of section 34a of the Audit Act in asking a question of Senator Evans fairly recently. I asked him how he was going to make the payment to Mr Brian Burke-as he had stated he was going to do, as it was a resignation-when the Department of Finance in Estimates hearings had answered that it would be most reluctant to exercise its act of grace payment power and to make such a payment to Mr Burke.

Senator Evans replied to me that he believed that it was a payment which was made pursuant to the powers that the Governor-General conferred on him in making the terms and conditions. He later told Senator Hill that he was relying on section (n) of that agreement, and then he told us again at the beginning of this week that he had changed his mind again. He had yet again another legal opinion, and it was now going to be pursuant to section 2a (2), the termination power of the terms and conditions agreement.

I still contend that the proper way in which any payment would be made, unless he is sacked pursuant to section 2a (2) should be an Advance to the Minister for Finance in the form as we presently have before us in respect of former Commissioner Caesar. I am driven to ask myself the question: why has the Government put itself through the contortions that it has in trying to find ways to pay Mr Brian Burke money? Why has it gone through the agonies of saying, `He has given notice of his resignation; no, he is going to resign straight away; no, he is going to be sacked; no, he is not going to be sacked', and so on.

The only answer I can come up with-aside from the fact that, if his appointment is terminated under the agreement, the Government will pay to bring him, his family and his goods and chattels home-is that I suspect it has more to do with the way the payment will be treated for taxation purposes. If the payment of $28,000 had been made in the way it was first outlined, it would have been treated as an ordinary employment payment and, as such, taxed at the highest marginal rate of 48.25 per cent. That would have meant a tax bill on that $28,000 of $13,510. But if his appointment is terminated within the terms of the agreement-most people would understand termination to be sacking but the Government wants to have it both ways-it would be treated as an eligible termination payment and as such it would attract the lesser rate of 31.25 per cent.

A termination payment for Mr Burke would result not in a gain of just the $7,000 by going from $28,000 to $35,000 but a tax gain of nearly another $3,000. In other words, by changing the arrangements under which the payment is to be made, former ambassador Brian Burke will receive a net gain of nearly $10,000. When we look at the correct way in which an Advance to the Minister for Finance is dealt with in the papers before us and at the contortions that the Government has put itself through, we can only conclude that the driving force has been to give him yet another benefit, this time under the taxation requirements-an advantageous rate at which he will pay tax. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I wish to address my remarks on this occasion to the payment of $11m sought by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce in respect of the Bounty and Capitalisation Grants (Textile Yarns) Act 1981. In May 1990 when an amendment to that Act was debated in this place the explanatory memorandum under the heading `Financial impact statement' contained a statement that the anticipated dollar values on a financial year basis for the anticipated payments pursuant to this bounty for the year 1990-91 would be $85.96m.

Yet, when we go to Budget Paper No. 2, the Commonwealth Public Account, at page 46 and look at the appropriation made in respect of that Act, we see it as a sum of $63,000,829. I wonder why it is that the appropriation was less than the sum which was forecast in the explanatory memorandum. Then we find that there is an application for a further $11m, which presumably means that the appropriated sum of $63m has run out. The application is for an advance under division 868, paragraph (c), of Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1990-91.

I put on record that I would like some answers as to why the sum that was finally appropriated was less than the sum prognosticated in the explanatory memorandum, and I would like to know to whom the $11m is in fact paid. There was some concern at the time of debating the amendment to the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Amendment Bill that the amounts paid by way of capitalisation could create the capital by which an enterprise could be acquired. We were simply assured that that would not be the case. In looking at this application under section 32 of the Audit Act, I place on notice that I will be seeking answers to those questions in the correct forum. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the figures simply do not seem to make sense in terms of what the Government had said it would do and what it in fact has done.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL HEALTH AND MEDICAL RESEARCH COUNCIL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) is the peak medical research body in Australia, which was founded in 1936 together with the Medical Research Endowment Fund from which money is appropriated for medical research in Australia. The Council is a type of sorting body for these funds. In 1990-91 over $95m has been appropriated for allocation around the country. The National Health and Medical Research Council has been an outstanding success over all these years in the way in which it approaches this dispensation of funds.

However, the Council has some critics. It has 30 members, including representatives from each of the State health departments and, in addition, representatives of the Public Health Research and Development Committee and the Medical Research Ethics Committee; nominees of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations, the Australian Council of Social Service and the Australian Academy of Science; and the First Assistant Secretary of the Health Research and Services Division of the Department of Community Services and Health. Of those 30 members all are academics or bureaucrats. There are no practising medical practitioners or nurses.

The Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) has been approached in this regard and has refused to include a nominee of either the Royal Australian Nursing Federation or the Australian Medical Association. It is as a result of not having anybody who actually treats a patient on that Council that we have the absurd situation where a subcommittee of the NHMRC recommended that a four-year training course be established in acupuncture. This recommendation has gone forward but has not yet been acted upon. At the same time, we have an excess number of medical practitioners in the country. We already have two bodies within the medical profession whose members are trained in acupuncture and available to treat patients, yet the NHMRC is recommending that yet another a four-year course be established in this regard.

In Brisbane there is already a college called the Australian College of Natural Medicine which has training courses in acupuncture. We have two separate bodies within the medical profession whose members are trained in acupuncture and the Australian College of Natural Medicine conducts training courses, yet we have the NHMRC recommending that further courses be established in one specific entity. Before long we will have courses in iridology, quackmancery or other things being established if some stop is not put to this. Membership of the NHMRC should also be open to people who actually treat sick people.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to address again report No. 2, the Foreign Investment Review Board report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report is an interesting document. As my colleague Senator Kernot has outlined before, the rejection rate for all applications that the Foreign Investment Review Board is dealing with is very low. It is only 2.3 per cent and almost all of those applications included real estate. It means that we are selling our farms and our businesses at an increasing rate. In fact, it is not putting it too strongly to say that the low rejection rate confirms that the Board and the Government are interested only in, basically, rubber stamping foreign investment proposals. I do not believe that is a course of action which is in the best interests of the country.

SPEECH.PARA: In the preliminary December quarter of 1990, foreign investment statistics showed that the total level of foreign investment in Australia, as at 31 December 1990, was $264.3 billion. The gross foreign investment in Australia during 1989-90 was $21.2 billion. From these figures we can extrapolate an increasing rate of foreign investment. I believe it is time that the community and the Government took action to ensure that whatever foreign investment occurs in Australia is actually carried out in the interests of the Australian community.

The history of the Foreign Investment Review Board is an interesting one. On 1 April 1976 the then Treasurer, the late Hon. Phillip Lynch, made a statement on foreign investment to the House of Representatives. As well as spelling out the Government's sector of foreign investment policies, the then Treasurer announced the creation of the Foreign Investment Review Board. The Board was subsequently established on 8 April 1976. In the same statement Mr Lynch said:
Initially we will establish the Board by administrative action. It is proposed that it be given a statutory basis as soon as possible.

Fifteen years later the Board is still without statutory backing. The Australian Democrats believe that the current status of the Board and the foreign investment guidelines which it administers are totally inadequate. We believe that foreign investment may indeed be beneficial where funds cannot be raised in Australia, but it also causes obvious problems concerning the liability to fund profits and with decisions affecting Australians being made in the boardrooms of Tokyo, Berlin and New York.

In response to what we consider to be a totally unsatisfactory situation, we will be introducing legislation to create an independent foreign investment review commission. The functions of the commission will be: firstly, to make decisions on foreign investment proposals; and, secondly, to hold inquiries and make reports in respect of foreign investment proposals or on broader issues relating to foreign investment. In order to establish and maintain a register of foreign investment in Australia, it is absolutely essential that we know the current state of affairs on the extent to which we are owned by people overseas.

In determining whether investment proposals should proceed, the commission will have regard, firstly, to the sustainable development and growth of Australian industries that are efficient in their use of resources and that are self-reliant, enterprising, innovative and internationally competitive. Secondly, it will also have regard to the maximisation of Australian participation in the development and exploitation of Australian natural resources and in Australian industries generally. Thirdly, it will have regard to the maximisation of employment and harmonious industrial relations, the national and local environmental and cultural policies, the concentration of foreign ownership in the particular industries, and the interests of consumers and the community in general. In other words, before we approve foreign investment, the commission will be charged with a duty to assess whether, on the basis of all of these criteria, that particular investment is in the interests of the Australian community. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to order agreed to this day, on behalf of all relevant senators, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes that:

(a) notes that 352 500 women in Australia were unemployed in April 1991;

(a) notes that the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) has over one million Australians registered as unemployed and looking for work;

(a) notes that an additional 19 400 Australians were granted unemployment benefits in April 1991;

(c) recognises that serious implications for both the individuals concerned and the national budget will result; and

(a) notes that youth unemployment in the ACT has reached 28.1 per cent, the second highest in Australia;

(a) notes that 503 800 men in Australia were unemployed in the week beginning 5 May 1991;
(b) recognises that these men are paying the price of eight years of a Labor Government led by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke); and
(c) calls on the Prime Minister to resign.
That the Senate-
(a) notes that:
(i) 111 600 full-time youth jobs were wiped out over the 12 months to April 1991, according to Australian Bureau of Statistics labour force figures,
(ii) this is the biggest 12 month full-time job loss for the 15 to 19 year- old age group since statistics have been available,
(iii) this means that more than one in every four jobs for youth have been wiped out over the past year, and

(iv) these 111 600 lost jobs for youth make up 55 per cent of all the 204 400 full-time jobs lost in Australia, even though 15 to 19 year olds make up only five per cent of the employed full-time work force; and
(b) condemns the Hawke Government for making young Australians the cannon fodder in the recession the Treasurer (Mr Keating) says we had to have and in the record unemployment we had to have.
That the Senate-

(a) notes that the seasonally adjusted youth unemployment rate of 27 per cent for April 1991 is the highest April figure on record and is worse than the figure for any month during the Fraser Government, despite the Government's expensive schemes to hide the real level of unemployment among 15 to 19 year olds;

(b) agrees with the statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) seven years ago that the disastrous unemployment situation, particularly that facing young Australians, cannot and should not be tolerated as these levels of unemployment are the ones that `no Australian Government should ever be forgiven for creating'; and
(c) calls on Mr Hawke to confirm his view that his Government should never be forgiven for creating Australia's worst level of real youth unemployment since the 1930s depression.
That the Senate-
(a) notes that more than 52 000 jobs were lost to the manufacturing industries in the year to February 1991;
(b) notes that this represents a decline of 4.3 per cent of manufacturing jobs;
(c) recognises that the Government's failure to implement reform in the areas of taxation, industrial relations and transport and communications has been instrumental in the loss of those jobs; and
(d) calls on the Government to shake off the shackles of the ACTU and other vested interest groups and urgently introduce reforms which will help get Australia moving again.
That the Senate-
(a) notes that 856 300 Australians were unemployed in April 1991 as a direct result of the policies of the Labor Party at state and federal levels;
(b) recognises the anguish and worry of those who cannot find work, whether they be school leavers, parents with dependants or older people made redundant;
(c) notes the long-term effects on the savings and dreams of those whose lives are so disastrously being shattered; and
(d) calls on the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to direct his full attention to the tragedy facing these Australians, rather than to the selfish and destructive pursuit of his leadership ambitions.
That the Senate-
(a) notes that:
(i) the number of people receiving unemployment benefits in Victoria has jumped by an incredible 120 per cent over the past 12 months, more than three times the 37.6 per cent rise in NSW,
(ii) the number of jobless in Victoria has more than doubled from 109 300 in 1990 to 237 400 in April 1991, three times the NSW rise,

(iii) the full-time youth unemployment rate in Victoria has almost doubled, from 14.6 per cent to 27.4 per cent over the 12 months to April 1991, to a rate far higher than the NSW rate of 22.5 per cent, which is the lowest of all states, and

(iv) all the Labor-governed states have seasonally adjusted unemployment rates higher than 10 per cent, while the Greiner Liberal State Government in NSW has Australia's lowest unemployment rate of 8.6 per cent; and
(b) draws to the attention of the people of NSW the clear link between the `double whammy' of having a State and Federal Labor Government and double digit unemployment.

I wish to speak particularly on those 12 notices of motion which relate to the appalling levels of unemployment in our country. The figures themselves are stark. The figures from the Commonwealth Employment Service-and I extract these from the relevant notices of motion-show that approximately 12.4 per cent of Australians are looking for employment; more than one million people are registered as unemployed. The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that some 844,000 people are now unemployed and of those some 40 per cent are women. My colleague Senator Newman tells me that if I looked at last month's figures I would see that 50 per cent of those unemployed were women. In addition, 63,800 people were officially discouraged, and that of course is why we have very high levels of hidden unemployment, despite a minor upward movement in the participation rate. There are still many thousands of people who have simply given up.

Finally-and this is the most important statistic of all in many ways-there is the level of unemployment benefits, which is currently some $616,000; an extra 19,400 people having become recipients of that benefit in the last month. In Victoria alone, over the preceding 12 months the number of people in receipt of unemployment benefits has risen by some 120,000. On the youth unemployment front the figures are similarly shocking. The national level is 27 per cent. In the manufacturing sector 52,000 manufacturing jobs were lost in the year to February.

These figures, each in themselves devastating, will have a cumulative effect which will inevitably sink this Labor Government. I simply refer to the headline which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald the other day when Max Walsh got it right-as he so often does-which stated, `The dole queues, not WA Inc, mark Labor for defeat'. I think it is particularly important for all those people who relied on this Government when it came to office to go back and examine its record to see on what basis the Government was elected and whether it has delivered the goods. One cannot do much better than start with a quotation, which Senator Bishop included in her notice of motion, from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) seven years ago. He said:
. . . the disastrous unemployment situation,-
we should recall that the number of unemployed at that time was some 750,000 as compared with almost 850,000 now-
particularly that facing young Australians, cannot and should not be tolerated as these levels of unemployment are the ones that `no Australian government should ever be forgiven for creating'.

There are many devastating quotations and I will simply turn to several of them. Senator Richardson-Mr Fix-it if ever there was one-is someone to whom one simply says, `Deliver the green vote' and he will turn the politics of the issue green; ask for the grey vote and he will turn them grey. He no doubt almost took it for granted that he did not have to cultivate the traditional constituency-those in the Australian Labor Party and beyond who regarded the Labor Party as the Party which could deliver on what was regarded, above all, as the most important issue; the issue of jobs. On 25 May 1983, Senator Richardson said, in unequivocal terms:
The last election was won by the Australian Labor Party on the issue of unemployment. This Government will sink or swim on its performance in providing jobs.
On 5 October of the same year, he said:

By March 1983 the Australian electorate had had enough. It clearly wanted and needed a new approach to economic policy. The Hawke Government has provided just that. We have rejected the policy of fighting inflation first, the one that never worked.

Tell that to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who has been desperately casting around. Then there is the Prime Minister who would now have us believe that this is really part of the grand strategy, that fighting inflation is what it is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —They continue to explicitly reject fighting inflation first.
—I see. All right. Well, it just happens to be the one thing that they would like to jump on the coat-tails of because it is heading in the right direction.
—That is not to say that getting inflation down is not a good idea; it is simply to say that they explicitly reject fighting inflation first.

—All right, I accept that current acknowledgment from Senator McMullan. Of course, though, there is a lot more to it than that in terms of their position on unemployment. I think I quoted yesterday those immortal remarks of Senator Richardson, which will no doubt come back to haunt him:

SPEECH.PARA: I might say that the Labor Government was elected primarily on the issue of unemployment. It recognises its responsibilities in this area and if it fails over the years to meet the problem of unemployment it will not be elected again, and it will not deserve to be.

I think we also realise how important employment is to all Australians. I can do no better than to quote from some recent remarks of the Catholic bishops on the occasion of the one-hundredth anniversary of the encyclical Rerum Novarum. What they said was this:
. . . human society is built upon and around productive human work.

Indeed, they were quoting the words of Leo XIII some 100 years before, but those remarks remain as relevant today as they were then. That is why we all stress the primacy of employment, and it is why there is such an appalling tragedy attached to very high levels of unemployment. Again, I quote Senator Richardson, who said on 26 March 1985:

If the Government fails to reduce significantly the unemployment rate for the young unemployed in particular, it really will have failed. This is our great challenge for our next term in office and, hopefully, it is the one on which we can embark as soon as possible . . . The first and most important one is the problem of youth unemployment-the ugliest, the most frustrating and the most frightening statistic to come from Australia's economic recession.

They are indeed devastating because these words illustrate, in all their starkness, what Labor regarded politics as being all about, what it believed its mandate was when it came to office, and what it believed it would stand or fall on in the intervening years. Of course, we now have the statistics. Labor is condemned not only for what came out of its own mouth but also for the essentially fraudulent and dishonest nature of the rationalisations that we have heard recently. It can never disguise the fact that simply it has not delivered. It cannot excuse its incompetence on the basis of having a drought, for example, nor do we have falling world commodity prices or a Halfpenny led wages break-out. It is indeed all its own work.

The figures encapsulated in the motions constitute the most devastating indictment of a Labor government, which has now forfeited all moral legitimacy. The litany of Federal incompetence, aided and abetted by State recklessness on an appalling scale, simply demonstrates that many in the Labor Party retain their commitment to outdated economic theology. In recent times we have heard the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) once again talking about solutions that would deviate dramatically from the doctrine espoused by the Treasurer over the past eight years. Instead of a floating exchange rate, Mr Dawkins would have us bring it down artificially and peg it.

We have also had innumerable contributions from people wanting to make use of the assets and income of superannuation funds for socially desirable investment purposes. Also, of course, in recent days we have had Mr Bannon and others embracing further corporatist solutions. Quite clearly, job creation concepts are alive and well in the Labor Party. Very little seems to have been learnt in terms of proper economic management. That I think is the great tragedy of the statistics which will return to haunt this Labor Government and which will inevitably bring it to defeat at the next election.

It is no joy for the people of Australia to know that this Government has failed so comprehensively, to know that those figures are part of a nightmare that this Government could never have envisaged in its wildest dreams. But they are there for all to see: 180,000 long term unemployed, a phenomenon barely recognised a decade ago, and now we look like having a permanent underclass trapped in a cycle of poverty and despair, and this Government offers very little hope.

In bringing together all these motions, we have been able to demonstrate that, if ever there was a government that failed the acid test that it set for itself, it is this Government. It is hoist on its own petard in a way that no-one could ever have imagined, and it will undoubtedly pay the price with a decade in the wilderness. Mr Hawke's legacy will not only be a place in history as the longest serving Labor Prime Minister but also as the one who ultimately made Labor irrelevant in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Alston outlined, we are having a cognate debate on a series of motions, notice of which was given yesterday by a number of Opposition senators, concerning the serious unemployment situation in Australia. It is not surprising, I suppose, that we do not have an equally impressive array of motions before the Senate on the outstandingly good inflation figures that we saw yesterday. We continue to have the enthusiastic obsession of people trying to find every piece of bad news they can. That is not to underestimate the importance of unemployment. No-one in this Senate should, and certainly no-one on the Government side does. The Government is obliged to respond to the debate and Government members will be participating in it. Several of them have indicated that they are keen to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I want to make some general remarks about the employment situation and the policy context in which it is being dealt with by both the Government and the Opposition, and I shall make some references to aspects of some motions. Although I would like to have a chance to talk about them all in some detail, time does not permit.

We have a continuing situation in the area of unemployment-and I will refer to some others as I go through-where Opposition members want to have it both ways. They want to come into this place and make speeches about their grievous concerns about the unemployment situation and their heart-rending concern for the individuals who are so sorely affected, but they also want to be able to go round to the financial media and business and publicly talk about how tough their fiscal policy is going to be and how they are going to crack down on welfare-all the tough rhetoric that goes with the ideological obsessions that drive their leadership at the moment.

But there is nothing unusual about this seeking to have it both ways initiative. It is part of a broader pattern. For example, today Senator Tierney was bewailing the fact that a bit of enterprise bargaining was going on somewhere and, shock, horror, there had been a strike. This Government has been very successful in reducing the level of time lost through disputes in Australia, and that has made a substantial contribution towards increasing the productivity of our economy. The Opposition has underestimated how significant the reduction in strikes has been as a factor in improving productivity, because people are actually at work. The fact is that members opposite cannot come in here and maintain that they want enterprise bargaining but there should never be any strikes.

The Opposition's policies, as has happened with the policy of the New Zealand Government, would tear the industrial relations environment of this place apart. That is one of the reasons why the Opposition will not get a chance to implement them. Senator Alston came in here at lunch time during the matters of public interest discussion and he said it was shocking for anybody to suggest that there was some element of heartlessness in the proposal to cut off people from unemployment benefits because they would all be able to get special benefits.

Once again, the Opposition cannot have it both ways. A person who I assume is a senior spokesperson on behalf of the Opposition in these matters said on a recent occasion that this policy would save $750m. It cannot save $750m and have nobody worse off. Those two things are not possible together. If the policy is to save $750m, it will mean that a lot of people who otherwise would have received benefits will no longer do so. This policy cannot save money and at the same time be at no cost to individuals. Members opposite want to have omelettes without breaking eggs.

They are saying that our attempts to manage the unemployment situation more effectively will not save enough money and will not be tough enough. They claim that they will save $750m. I am quoting from somebody who may or may not be an authoritative source, because these comments are made by Dr Hewson. Opposition members must stop him from engaging in this bad habit of blowing their arguments out of the water.

We have the situation again in this debate which is supposed to indicate a concern about unemployment. A certain senior Opposition spokesperson has said that the Opposition will take unemployment off the economic agenda. It will change the terms of reference of the Reserve Bank of Australia so that it is no longer concerned with the maintenance of full employment. That is going to be taken away from it; it will no longer be part of its charter. Its charter will deal exclusively with the question of inflation. At the moment, the Reserve Bank has a series of economic objectives in its charter, one of which is the maintenance of full employment. Employment is a proper consideration for the Reserve Bank at the moment, but under the charter proposed today, once again by Dr Hewson, we find that the maintenance of full employment goes off the agenda of economic policy.

Opposition members want to come in here and pretend that they are worried about unemployment, but they also want to be able to go out to the financial media and say that they will fight inflation first and that they will take full employment off the economic agenda; that it will no longer be a criterion upon which they want economic policy to be judged. During Question Time Senator Hill expressed concern about the fact that the one per cent cut in interest rates meant that real interest rates had gone up; yet we also have Dr Hewson saying that we should be maintaining our high interest rate policy.

In all these areas, those opposite think that they can come in here and advocate one thing in the hope that the public will get some false impression of how benign they are while they advocate the alternative policy in other forums. For a while, oppositions can get away with that. Having been a member of the Labor Party for a long time, I know a fair bit about being in opposition. Oppositions can get away with those sorts of things for a while, but over a period of time, the people start to ask them how they are going to make these contradictory remarks add up, and at the end of the day it cannot be done.

There is also the inevitability that the Australian public, who cannot be underestimated-they are not bad judges; they have been pretty good four times in a row-will start to ask how these policy prescriptions of the Opposition will achieve the outcomes which it proposes when they are entirely contradictory. Concern is expressed in this place continually that the surplus is falling. It is ironic that a party that has never delivered a surplus should be here pontificating about the fact that this financial year it looks like the surplus will be only $1.7 billion.

If those opposite are proposing that the surplus should be anything like $8 billion in the middle of a recession, they are dispensing with one of the fundamental things that distinguishes a modern industrial economy from the economy of the 1930s-what is called in the jargon the `automatic stabilisers'. They are talking about trying to maintain the surplus by either increasing revenue or slashing expenditure. That is just a recipe to extend or deepen the recession.

Those opposite talk about setting targets of zero to 2 per cent inflation, which none of the major Western economies have at this time-not one. Yet somehow they are going to achieve that. It is possible to achieve it, but only at the price of flattening the economy. If they try to achieve that objective simultaneously with introducing a broadly based consumption tax without any form of wages policy whatsoever, the only way to fight inflation in those circumstances is to flatten the economy further.

In all these areas those opposite cannot go on forever advocating contradictory policies. They come in here shedding crocodile tears about the unemployed, about a very real and profound social and economic problem in our society, while they go out elsewhere advocating policies that have exactly the opposite effect to that which they purport to be advocating here. They cannot make omelettes without breaking eggs. They cannot go on advocating these policies without the contradictions eventually being pointed out.

Without taking up too much of the limited time available for this debate, I would like to talk about one very important part of Senator Tambling's motion. It may be an unintended consequence of the way in which Senator Tambling has drafted his motion; I hope so. I am particularly concerned about what I consider to be a very severe reflection on the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). The motion seems to indicate a strong implication of criticism of the policy of the Australian Bureau of Statistics in excluding certain people from unemployment figures and in the way it measures unemployment. Without getting into the technicalities, the motion seems to carry a strong criticism of the legitimacy of the process by which the ABS raises its figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh! It does nothing of the sort.

—I am hoping that it is an unintended consequence, but when the whole motion is read in context, it is a source of some concern to me and I would like to make a few remarks about it, without indicating that I think Senator Tambling set out with that objective. There is no need for that paroxysm of concern on the opposite side of the chamber. I am not attacking Senator Tambling; I am simply defending the Bureau of Statistics because it is a very important and respected body.
—You don't need to defend it. It is not being attacked.

—It actually has been attacked a few times in this place by the Opposition, but that is not my concern at the moment. I simply want to put a few comments about it on the record. A large number of comments could be made, but I will quote from an article in the Economist referring to a major study that had been done by the Royal Statistical Society about how Britain's records might be improved. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: How might Britain's record be improved? Look at the world's best official statisticians: Canada, followed closely by Australia, Sweden and Holland. These countries' systems are centralised with most numbers collected by a single body whose independence is guaranteed by law.

The article goes on to say that the Australian Bureau of Statistics is one of the best two national statistical bodies in the world. I want to talk about the reason the statistics are collected in the way they are in case the motion carries some unintended implication that there is something wrong with the ABS statistics or that they are being in some way manipulated.

The method of gathering unemployment figures by the Australian Bureau of Statistics conforms to international definitions of the International Conference of Labour Statisticians (ICLS) which is convened by the International Labour Organisation. The definition originally dates from 1954 and was reviewed by the ICLS in 1982. This relates particularly to the question of people who work one hour or more per week. There was some reference, which was also raised in a question asked in the Senate earlier this week, about people who do unpaid work.

People who do unpaid voluntary work are not counted as employed except where they do unpaid work for more than one hour per week in a family business or farm but where the nature of their remuneration differs; that is, they are more likely to receive payment in kind than wages. This method of calculation also conforms with ILO definitions of employment. Through a series of resolutions there is reference to the fact that the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) figures are not used now but we use the ABS figures instead. For 15 years they have been considered the appropriate method of measuring unemployment, and they are all round the world.

In 1977, under a coalition government, the method of calculating unemployment figures was reviewed and in 1978 the decision was made not to use CES figures in the calculation, and unemployment data began to be issued monthly rather than quarterly. Sometimes the CES figures are under and sometimes they are over. So sometimes it might be in the Government's interest to put them out.

But overall they are not a true indication of underlying unemployment because people can be registered with the CES and they certainly have no obligation to, and do not necessarily, remove themselves from the register when work is found or they move interstate or whatever. It is not a priority of the CES at this time to keep those records precisely accurate. The obligation of the CES is to provide a service to the people who come in to see its officers, not to produce a second-best set of statistical records. That is what the ABS is there for. The priority of the CES is and should be otherwise.

Many unemployed people are not registered with the CES and the CES figures can vary for reasons not simply to do with the state of the labour market. Therefore, it is appropriate that we do not have a whole series of data coming out. The ABS is the accepted measure. There are other ways we could go about getting a second-best measure of inflation or a second-best measure of other economic statistics but we do not do that. When we find the one that works best we persist with it. No serious commentator that I am aware of suggests that the public debate about economic policy would in any way be enhanced by releasing a second-best set of statistics.

Before I go any further I want to comment on some proposals which I understand the Australian Democrats may be going to raise concerning amendments, and indicate that, to the extent they have indicated some proposal to delete various parts from the motions as proposed, they would not be surprised to know we agree with that part, and to the extent they are proposing to add words we do not agree with that part. That would be perhaps the least surprising bit of news Senator Powell has had all day but I give it to her for what it is worth.

I want to give other people the chance to participate in this debate, although there are a number of things I would like to say about particular resolutions. But the most appropriate thing is to conclude, having made those general remarks and referred only to one matter that gave me cause for concern with regard to the Bureau of Statistics and its measurement, firstly, because I thought it may have been criticised and, secondly, because it seemed to reflect some understanding about the proper mechanism by which those figures should be recorded.

We really are being flooded with crocodile tears. As the policy of the Opposition is eked out the contradictions in it get shown up. We do have a very profound social problem in Australia with regard to unemployment. It is very profound for those individuals and it is a serious economic and social problem for the nation. But to come in here expressing concern about unemployment, while advocating policies that will make it worse and that would make the situation of those individuals affected by it worse is not a consistent and credible position in public policy.

Over time, as the predictions of independent economists and international observers correctly indicate, as Australia emerges from this recession, the Opposition will have to start making positive contributions to the economic debate in Australia instead of simply shedding these crocodile tears, and that is the test which it will fail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I utterly reject both the introductory and the concluding comments of Senator McMullan, in that we are not shedding crocodile tears in the Opposition. We are extremely concerned at the Government's policies and what they have achieved on the backs of the unemployed. What we reject utterly is the suggestion that we are trying to have it both ways. What we believe is the case is that the Government's policies have caused the problems that we are facing. It is the Government's attempt to use blunt instruments which have directly been the result of the high unemployment that we are facing. It is the unemployment which will in fact chuck this Government out of office as soon as we get a half a chance to go to the people.
—Why is your Leader saying we should keep interest rates up?

—Our Leader is saying that we should have structural reform, Senator-structural reform, taxation reform; things which Senator McMullan does not have the guts to do, partly because of his close association with vested interest groups of one kind or another, particularly the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and he knows it. The Reserve Bank of Australia deserves to be independent too and it is not being proposed by our Leader as a separate item but as part of a whole process taken together with structural and taxation reform.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the dimension of the expression `the unemployed'. We have heard a lot from Senator McMullan but not much sympathy, and he was referring to Senator Tambling's motion and what he saw as implied criticism of the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). He managed to use quite a bit of time talking about how marvellous the Bureau of Statistics is. But in point of fact Senator Tambling's motion casts no reflections on the Bureau of Statistics whatsoever. The reflection was on the Government, which since 1988 has found it convenient not to continue to publish the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) figures. That is the purpose of that motion and I draw the attention of the Senate to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what it says.

—It is exactly what it says. It calls on the Government to come clean with the nation and reintroduce the publication of the CES figures, Senator. Let that be on the record straight away. We are concerned that we cannot get a handle on the problem because we cannot work out what the figures really are. We know that there were 616,300 Australians in receipt of unemployment benefits in April, and that excludes those whose spouse is employed. Those are the unemployment benefit figures.

SPEECH.PARA: Then we know also that there are 856,300 Australians who show up in the ABS as unemployed and that excludes those who have worked for an hour of paid or unpaid work. We also know, through unpublished figures but released on freedom of information to the Melbourne Age, that the CES says that there are 1,054,102 unemployed.

Now the CES figures are for those who are registered for work. It does not include those who are not registered because there are no jobs available or those who do not register because they have no entitlement to unemployment benefit because they have a working spouse and, therefore, the CES figures in fact could be considerably more than they are.

Goodness knows, but whatever they are, they are appalling figures, and it does not do to have Senator McMullan come in here and pontificate about how the figures are collected. The awful thing is that they are there to be collected.

I am particularly concerned about the unemployment of women and, therefore, the motion which I moved related to the 300,000-odd women who are unemployed. In the previous month it was 308,100. It has gone up in this week's figures to 352,500. Some 44,400 women have gone on to the unemployed lists, the official unemployed lists, in the past month. Whatever else one says, that is an awful thing for those individuals.

It may be something Senator McMullan is trying to explain away but at least some people on this side of the Parliament are concerned about it. I think it is highly offensive that a Minister of the Crown would come in here and say that this debate is about the crocodile tears of the Opposition. In fact that reveals the lack of concern by the Government in my view.

Let us face it, the Commonwealth is not even a shining example when it comes to employing women. It is not making it very easy for women, apart from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, which seems to be leading the push to be an all women organisation. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is being severely criticised by women for not giving women jobs in that Department.

Look at Comcar. We have had an answer to a question on notice recently in an Estimates committee that only 6.5 per cent of the Comcar drivers are women. It has just put on another 62 drivers. How many women did Comcar put on? It put on four. So much for giving women job opportunities. Less than 10 per cent of the new applicants who have been successful have been women, so the Government should get its own house in order.

This week, the Government has disbanded the Women's Bureau in the Department of Employment, Education and Training. That Bureau was established by the Menzies Government 20-odd years ago to do research and policy development on the employment of women. At a time when we have 352,500 women officially unemployed that unit has been disbanded. Some concern this Government seems to have for unemployment and women! Senators Bolkus and Evans, whose departments I have just referred to, should be ashamed of themselves. What will happen to policy development and research on women's employment? What will happen to research into the high rate of unemployment among women and the need for training programs, and the most appropriate training programs, now that the Women's Bureau is no longer? It has slunk out of the Federal scene with not a mention from the Minister responsible-not an official tear from the feminists in the Australian Labor Party.

We know that figures that were published earlier this year said that child-care difficulties were cited by 194,400 women as the reason they could not work, although they wanted to do so. The Australian Bureau of Statistics back in September last year found that there were then half a million women who wanted to work and were actively looking for work but were not able to start work. In addition, there are now 47,200 women who are discouraged from looking, for good reasons-because they believe they will be considered either too young or too old, or considered as unsuitable because of language or ethnic difficulties, or lack of the necessary skills or experience, or because there are no jobs available at all.
