In March, 30,300 Australian women gave up looking for work altogether. Let us not forget that women do not show up very well in the unemployment figures. In the March figures, although 308,100 women were shown as officially unemployed, only half of them received unemployment benefit. What a great saving to the nation, although many had been taxpayers for years and had contributed to the funds that were available to meet the needs of the unemployed.

Lack of employment and the loss of employment are leading to terrible pain and fear among women. First is the problem of keeping a roof over their heads, with high repayments. Despite the gradual reduction in high interest rates, those repayments are still a heavy burden. It should not be forgotten that that is still on the heads of all Australians. It came to particularly dramatic notice back in March when the Preterm Foundation in Surrey Hills in New South Wales announced that it had a 31 per cent increase among married women coming to it asking for abortions because they could not afford to lose their jobs and leave employment if they remained pregnant. That announcement was followed up by similar announcements from abortion clinics in both Melbourne and Adelaide. That is what is happening to women in this country. They are having to choose between having a baby and staying in employment, because the employment situation is so difficult and they are so vulnerable. Doctors tell us that it is leading to increasing physical and stress problems.

What is particularly worrying is the high percentage of young women who are unemployed. Back in March the proportion of unemployed females in the 15- to 19-year-old age group was 26.8 per cent. Nearly one-third of our young women under 19 cannot get a job. There have been reports of tertiary students who cannot get part time work to keep them going through their studies going into prostitution in order to continue their courses. The Australian Council of Social Service announced just recently that it expects one-quarter of a million Australian children to be living on unemployment benefits by the middle of this year. So much for the children of Australia! So much for the Prime Minister and his hollow promise about children living in poverty! It is this Government's policies which have directly put those children into those areas of poverty and strain on their families. These are the fruits of the Treasurer's labour. These are the lovely numbers he brags about. It is his policies that have caused the anguish.

As I said at the beginning, Australia needs policies of structural and taxation reform, it needs an independent Reserve Bank, and it needs a consistent monetary policy. By comparison, the Treasurer's policies have been cruel and unintelligent. They have led to shocking hardship and a waste of the national resources through high unemployment. The Opposition believes that Australian women particularly are the unwilling victims of a Labor Treasurer and his policies, and that is why the Opposition calls on the Treasurer to resign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In taking part in this debate I refer to the motion moved on my behalf today which points to the deplorable figure of 856,300 Australians who were unemployed in April 1991. The second part of my motion recognises the anguish and worry of those who cannot find work, whether they be school leavers, parents with dependants or older people who have been made redundant. I shall refer to those matters later.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that the only good news this Government has had for as long as I can remember is the 0.2 per cent inflation figure for the March quarter. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has taken much pride in this-even Senator McMullan today has been talking about it-and there has been much backslapping in the media and everywhere else. But it does not take away from the point that the biggest worry that is now facing this country is unemployment. In April 1990, a little over a year ago, there were 534,200 Australians unemployed and, in April, 1991 856,000 Australians were looking for work. Therefore, in the last 12 months this Government through its policies-this recession that we had to have, the one that was engineered-has engineered 322,000 Australians onto the unemployment scrap heap. That figure has increased by 60.3 per cent in one year. It is a record that no government would ever be proud of.

Involved in that is the sad and tremendous figure for youth unemployment. As a member of my very honourable colleague Senator Michael Baume's task force on young Australians, I am very concerned to find that in the last 12 months there has been a rise of 29,600 in the number of young people put out of work-a rise of 35 per cent. The number of young Australians in work has fallen by 11,600 in the last 12 months. The figure that I quoted earlier-the 856,000, or a 60.3 per cent increase in one year-is the biggest rise ever recorded in Australia over a 12-month period.

I take no joy in seeing that my State of Tasmania has an unemployment rate of 10.8 per cent-double digit unemployment, something that was never going to happen. That is an increase of 28.8 per cent over 12 months. We now have the dubious honour of having the second highest unemployment rate in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was 12.1 per cent in 1983.

—It may have been, but I believe that an increase in unemployment over a 12-month period has never been greater. My colleagues in Victoria must be shocked to find that unemployment in Victoria, as a result not only of Federal Government policies but also of the ineptitude of the Victorian Government, has increased by 117 per cent in 12 months. Would Senator Sherry disagree with that figure? All the Labor States have double digit unemployment. The only State that has unemployment lower than 10 per cent is New South Wales, with an unemployment rate of 8.6 per cent.
—And who is in charge there?

—We know who is in charge there, the Liberal Party-I am sorry, the coalition. There is no doubt that the figure of 856,000 which I quoted, created a new record for unemployment. This broke the old record of 770,000 which was set a month before. As my colleague Senator Newman pointed out earlier, March of this year saw 1 1/2 million people registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service as looking for work. This does not include the hidden unemployed, whom my colleague Senator Baume refers to from time to time-all those people who have given up hope of looking for work, those who have been pensioned off by the Government, or those who have been reduced to part time employment.

SPEECH.PARA: I noticed today in my local paper a very sad article on homelessness amongst Tasmanian children. I agree that a lot of those are under the age for employment. The sad fact of the matter is that in my own State the Department of Community Services and Health is quoted as having to turn those children away because it does not have the resources to cope with the homeless youth in Tasmania. Mr Les Whittle who is involved with the youth care program run by Anglicare Tasmania Inc. said:
They say ``don't refer any more to us because we can't do anything''.

What do we do when a 12-year old lives in a shelter with 24-year olds? Do the people in charge of the shelter wait until the boy gets bashed up and go back to the Department and say, `Can you do something now'? It is very unacceptable. Anglicare has said that last year between 120 and 130 people were coming to it for the first time and that another 250 others were coming back. Of those, 30 per cent were under 16 years of age. What hope do those young people who are homeless have? What hope will they have of getting jobs with unemployment the way it is?

As I said, Senator McMullan, who is just leaving the chamber, talked about the drop in interest rates and this month's wonderful figure for inflation. I put it to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, and to the Senate that the interest rate drop we had today and the further predicted interest rate drops are too late for many thousands of Australian families. What use is a reduction in interest rates if people do not have a job to enable them to pay off their family homes? What comfort will a drop in interest rates be to families who have had their homes repossessed? What use will a drop in interest rates be to the hundreds of thousands of small and large businesses which have had to close their doors and lay off their staff?

As a member of Senator Michael Baume's task force, I have spent some time going around talking to young unemployed people and viewing the efforts made under the Skillshare program and the Jobtrain program, and by the youth shelters in northern Tasmania and in north-western Tasmania. I have identified 111 groups of people in Tasmania, which has a population of only 450,000 people, who are trying to do something to help young unemployed people. Even with all the will and the good intentions in the world, there is no coordination or very little coordination between any of them. They are paddling their own canoes. The church-based groups are doing one thing and the Skillshare groups are trying to do another.

It was interesting to note that the Skillshare groups and the Jobtrain groups have people queuing up trying to get into these training schemes to do something to get re-employed. What happens once people have been through these training schemes? The sad fact is that they come out into the community where there are no job vacancies. They sit around for a while. The motivation that some of these programs have given them has only built up their hopes to be dashed again when they go out into the cruel hard world of unemployment.

There is no doubt that the homeless youth shelters are seeing the effects of unemployment. They are also seeing the effects of some very clever young people who are using the shelters as a means of touring around Australia. People have told me of their concerns, some of which worry me. One parent in Launceston telephoned me and told me that his son had actually been encouraged by other young people to antagonise them into hitting him so that he could leave home and get a better allowance under the scheme relating to homeless youth. These are the results of this Government's policies and the unemployment. I just despair for the young people in our community at the moment. We can all rejoice about the inflation figure, but there is very little joy in what is happening to the unemployed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I wish primarily to concentrate on the question of economic management, its relationship with unemployment, and to look at the question of the ethos that prevails in particular countries and try to make some comparison between those that have been successful and those that are currently in recession. I do not think anyone in this chamber does not know that unemployment is both a personal and a national tragedy.

SPEECH.PARA: In Australia at the moment we are experiencing, in common with a number of other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries, a high level of unemployment which is absolutely and utterly unacceptable. All of us are aware of the personal tragedy that involves. All of us fear the question of a build-up of unemployment in this country which ultimately can lead to certain areas literally becoming long term unemployment pockets that will never change. In Australia we have not reached the situation yet where, for example, in the United Kingdom whole regions have been deeply in recession with dramatically high unemployment figures for more than 20 years. That has not yet happened in Australia. It is a matter of some concern to all of us on the Government side, and I believe also to the Opposition, that that possibility is cut out before it becomes a reality.

Obviously when in Opposition, parties look for simple solutions. Primarily parties which are in opposition have to try to show that the Government is incompetent and hard-hearted, and has inadequate policies to deal with particular issues in front of it. Those parties in opposition obviously have to offer some very simplistic solutions which can be understood by the electorate at large. Of course, the difference is that if the members of an opposition actually believe in those simplistic solutions and hope that they will be the answer, they are not only deluding themselves when they ultimately get into government, as they will one day, but they will also be deluding the electorate and doing damage to Australia.

As I go through some of these issues I might just mention those areas where I believe the Opposition is deluding itself by putting all its eggs in one basket, believing that there are certain policies which will be the answer for Australia's problems. All of us know that Australia has deep structural problems which go back to the 1950s, when we had the opportunity to make decisions and when we could afford to make decisions but slept on behind the protection of high tariff barriers, behind the protection of quotas on imports, and behind the protection of a solid and artificially constrained Australian dollar-or pound as it was in those days. In fact, sooner or later Australia had to come out of its lucky country syndrome, out of its dreamtime. As a government we are now having to deal with that legacy of absolute inactivity-I might say intellectual inactivity, as well-on the part of governments of those days, particularly the Menzies Government.

As everyone in this place knows, the Menzies Government was a very comfortable, conservative government which made Australians feel good. That is why it got re-elected, with the exception of the 1961 election when it came close to being defeated. Bob Menzies was a past master at making people feel good about themselves and at making sure that Australians relaxed. It was a time when on the whole Australians accepted the status quo and, if ever they were internationalists, were only internationalists in so far as they were interested in test cricket matches between ourselves and England. We had no interest at all in South East Asia at a time when we should have been moving into those markets.

In fact, we had very little interest in the Common Market. Many Australians were dramatically surprised when Britain, for example, entered the Common Market. Suddenly, Australians were faced with the notion that they did not have a favoured relationship with Great Britain any more. In the early 1960s we then decided that we had to look to other markets such as South East Asia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's 30 years ago; talk about today.

—That may be history, but this is the point: Senator Tambling lives in a State where history is very important. He talks about the Aboriginal people and the importance of history to them. But like half the politicians on his side-and like all populous politicians-he is always looking for the simple solution. He thinks that history is about four or five years. The simple fact is that our economic structure was not created yesterday or during the Malcolm Fraser era; it was created much earlier than that. The decisions that were made should have been made back in the 1950s, at least.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us get back to the current situation. There is a large measure of dissimilarity between the way that governments of the OECD countries approach the management of their economies. Let us look at the Keating legacy. A number of people would know that in some ways I disagree with some of the policies of Paul Keating; I do not hide that. Anyone who says that he believes in everything his political party does ought to have his head read, or it must be the most wonderful political party in the world that can incorporate everybody's interests and viewpoints to the extent that everyone can therefore agree unanimously to every policy in that party.

Paul Keating created an ethos of entrepreneurialism; people thought more about economics and economic literacy was required as a prerequisite for most politicians and journalists. He created a situation in which people started to see themselves as part of a world economy rather than just a regional or national economy. He opened the doors and said, `Let's have competition in this country so that our industries, our entrepreneurs, can start to see themselves as part of a world economy'. Sure, that was a rough and ready approach but it had to be done in a rough and ready way because we did not have any option.

As I said, if we had started to see ourselves as part of a world economy in the 1950s we would not have needed to do it in such a rough and brutal way during the period of this Government. But it was done, and the Treasurer, Mr Keating, must be given credit for dragging Australia in to the 1990s. It will be an uncomfortable process. Some of the finetuning of those policy decisions will sometimes be wrong. It is a question of whether they are able to be fine tuned in the right direction.

Let us look at the countries I mentioned before. Let us look outside ourselves and try to get some perspective on matters relating to economic management. Let us take five countries-the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Canada, the United States of America and Australia-the ones that have the greatest similarity in terms of demography, cultural history and, to some extent, economic history. Let us look at the stark figures and make a comparison of unemployment in 1990. It is interesting. Unemployment in the United Kingdom was 6.9 per cent; in New Zealand, 7.7 per cent; in Canada, 8.1 per cent; in the United States, 5.4 per cent; and in Australia, 6.9 per cent. The Australian level is below that of New Zealand and Canada and about the same as that of the United Kingdom.

Let us look at inflation: the United Kingdom, 8.9 per cent; Canada, 6.2 per cent; the United States, 5.3 per cent; and Australia, 4.9 per cent. I believe that we can validly compare the performance of these countries on two fronts-control of inflation and unemployment statistics. The United Kingdom-the country which in the last decade has most clearly put into effect the policies advocated by the Opposition-has an inflation figure of 8.9 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say the United States?

—No, the United Kingdom. It has an inflation rate of 8.9 per cent, with a 6.9 per cent unemployment level. So Australia's inflation is half that of the United Kingdom. Our unemployment is about the same. Here we are, sitting on the other side of the world, with no ready access to markets the size of the Common Market, and with markets as far away as Japan, the United States and of course Europe. Australia has no peculiar advantages that might be held by the United Kingdom.

SPEECH.PARA: One looks at those stark figures and wonders how the United Kingdom can perform so badly when it has followed all the policy prescriptions pushed by the Opposition. It has privatised whatever it could, it has sold off the family jewels; it has this magic consumption tax that the Opposition talks about; and it has gone for policies, across the board, which would be absolutely acceptable to the Opposition. Yet it has an inflation rate of 8.9 per cent and unemployment the same as ours. Is the Opposition telling us that, simply by adopting its policies on the consumption tax and on total privatisation, we will improve this country's economic performance?

TALK.START.PARA: —Increasing a bit of productivity; getting rid of your union mates.

—All right, we will talk about increased productivity. That is like talking about motherhood and apple pie. I will take Senator Macdonald's comment on board. He said something about beating the unions; I am not sure how he expressed it.
—I said getting a bit of productivity.
—And the rest?
—Getting rid of your union mates.
—Exactly; that was his point-we must get rid of the union movement.
—Mates.

—All right, union mates. He is basically implying that we ought to be defeating, as is part of the Opposition's policy, the trade union movement, destroying not only its importance in the Australian community but also its relevance to economic activity and to Australian society at large; that we ought to be getting rid of the union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, I guess that Senator Macdonald will be saying that we should be moving towards the New Zealand model: we make sure that the trade union movement has no legal role whatsoever in the relationship between labour and management. Senator Macdonald says that if only we could do that-privatise all the public institutions that really count, bring in a consumption tax, and destroy the power base of the union movement and give it no right to represent workers-Australia would be resurrected and economic management would be vastly improved.

Senator Macdonald cannot really believe that cargo cult approach. Every one of those three policies has been tried in New Zealand and in the United Kingdom with disastrous results. In fact, the New Zealand Labour Party was conned into following some of those policy precepts. It was the worst thing that the Labour Party in New Zealand ever did. It ended up paying not only the electoral penalty but also a penalty in terms of its prestige and respect in New Zealand and the international community.

So one looks to simple solutions. They can be used as electoral ploys, but the real danger is that a party might even come to believe them. If that party really believes them and, by some accident, manages to become the Government of this country one day, heaven help us all. A government should always look internationally at the other economic and political management models that exist around the world, not just at those of the United Kingdom, the United States, New Zealand and Canada on which it thinks Australian activities should be based. One might go to Sweden, Japan or Germany and ask, `What are the features of those immensely successful economies? What stands out about those economies that we could borrow ideas from?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —People are given some incentive to work.

—All right, let us look at that aspect. What incentive is there to work in Sweden? The Swedes have very high personal income tax rates. What does stand out about those three countries-Germany, Japan and Sweden-first and foremost is the very close relationship they have between a well organised union movement and management and between a well organised union movement and government. Unions are given a rightful role in the management of the economy and of the companies for which the people they represent work. In other words, cooperation is still the most important key to economic management. In German companies German workers sit on the boards as of right. There are formal structures of consultation not only about industrial relations matters but also company investment policies. The Japanese have similar structures.

SPEECH.PARA: Sweden, Japan and Germany are all high labour cost countries-countries with high wages-but they make up for it in other ways. First of all, there is cooperation. Secondly, they are export and quality oriented.

TALK.START.PARA: —And education oriented.
—They are education oriented, and that is the key. When one gets down to tintacks, as we move slowly towards a notion that education is a lifetime activity--
—Far too slowly.

—I agree with Senator Powell that it is coming too slowly. We are moving towards an acceptance that education and training is a lifetime activity and of value not only to individuals but also to the country at large. These countries have been practising for years the notion that, at the centre of all successful economic activity and sound economic management, is proper education and training. All three countries spend immense amounts on education and training and on research and development. Meanwhile, Australia sits back and says, `Yes, we will move quietly towards improving our expenditure on education and training and we will try to lift the expenditure on research and development in this country'. Those countries are streets ahead of us for the simple reason that they regard education as the fulcrum on which everything is built.

SPEECH.PARA: I will look at the statistics for Germany. Of all people over 15 years of age, 70 per cent go into apprenticeships. Twenty per cent go on to higher education. I will even do the sums for Senator Macdonald. That leaves only 10 per cent who have no training-are not going on to apprenticeships or are not going to higher education-when they pass 15 years of age. At any given time, 39 per cent or more of German workers aged between 19 and 65 are in training.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's this got to do with the massive unemployment you have created?

—Is that not fascinating! Poor old Senator Macdonald! I did the maths for him and then he asks, `What has all this training and education talk got to do with the economy?'. I said it slowly for Senator Macdonald so that he would understand it-or at least allow his prejudices to flip over a little-and so he could go home and think about it over the break. He can ask himself, `What has education got to do with the management of the economy?'. The first step, of course--
—What has German education got to do with it?

—The second question that has come from the other side of the chamber is from the senator from the far west. Senator Campbell asks, `What has the German education system got to do with this?'. I had already made the point that we ought to be looking at both the good and bad models of economic management in the rest of the world to learn from them. For heaven's sake, we are part of a world economy. I am sick of the debate in Australia being centred on what happens in the United Kingdom, the United States, Canada and New Zealand. There are other economies and countries which function better than we do and which are worth borrowing ideas from.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are going to be part of that world economy and overcome these problems of unemployment, our balance of trade deficit and the problems in the manufacturing industry, we have to look at the best models in the rest of the world. I make no apology for coming into this chamber and saying, `Let us look at those models and talk about other countries', instead of looking all the time in our own backyard comparing, for example, the Hawke Government with the Fraser Government backwards and forwards and New South Wales with Victoria. In some ways, who cares? Those comparisons involve statistical differences that can sometimes be interpreted one way or the other. The key issue is to go outside ourselves and to look at how it is done elsewhere. It is only when we start to look elsewhere and make those comparisons to find what we can learn from others that will we advance.
I leave Opposition senators with this message. I know that some of them have listened tonight although they have tried not to.

TALK.START.PARA: —They haven't heard.

—Some Opposition senators have not heard, but I know that some have because I have noticed a number of them nodding. They were not nodding because they were going to sleep, but because they know that deep down as an opposition they have to come up with more than just the three policies-privatisation, consumption tax and bashing the unions. That is not a prescription for running a country. It is not good enough for a party to go to the electorate in two years' time and say, `That is what we stand for and that will be the solution'. The Opposition has to do better.
—What is your solution?

—As I said, my solution is to look at what these other successful countries are doing. I pointed out the issues that are important for us to look at and the reasons why those countries are successful. We ought to be borrowing ideas from those countries, even if it means that this Government has to turn some of its policy prescriptions around. All of us in this Senate ought to be looking at that.

SPEECH.PARA: I have really enjoyed educating Senator Macdonald. I was a teacher for nine or 10 years. Occasionally, I would go into a classroom and see about 35 children. In those days classes had about 35 students; then a Labor Government brought down the number of students per teacher in a class to about 24. It was even lower when I was a Minister. When I was a teacher, I used to look at these faces and say, `This is really good. These young people might benefit if I really do my job'. When I succeeded, I got a glow of satisfaction because I would look at each child and say, `That one is not very bright and that one does not want to listen, hear or learn. But if I can just ignite a spark of curiosity and interest, I have succeeded and given them skills'. If nothing else, today I have helped Senator Macdonald and some members of the Opposition to think a little more. If I have done that, in some ways I have done my duty today and earned my salary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very glad that I speak in this debate after Senator Aulich because, in debating this series of motions from the Opposition-which really represent a litany of the failure of the prevailing economic approach, which is all too much shared by the Government and the Opposition, as almost admitted by Senator Aulich-he has exhorted us to look beyond our shores, to look elsewhere, for inspiration as to what to do about the disastrous economic situation and now the disastrous social pain that is being felt in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, I exhort other political parties to look elsewhere, to policies which have been put forward in this place almost ad nauseam as well as out in the community, to policies which provide alternatives, which should be listened to and which should be taken up. I take up that challenge and again lay down an alternative economic approach which is designed on the basis of what the Democrats believe-that is, that government should be working towards a society that is socially and economically just, environmentally responsible and democratically controlled.

That should be the objective of any Government. Government policy should be designed to influence the economy so that such a society can be achieved. That can be done, but it is not being done by the policies of the Hawke Government; nor will it be done by the implementation of the policies of the conservative alternative government. That is because the Government and the Opposition share deregulatory, free market-driven policy directions.

I think it was something of an embarrassment to Senator Aulich to have to complain about the privatisation policies of the Opposition. It is more inclined to more privatisation than the Government. Let us not take comfort in the legislation we have had thus far of so-called partial privatisation. As the Democrats have stood in this chamber and pointed out, the privatisation legislation for the Commonwealth Bank is now a perfect vehicle for total privatisation by either this Government or any subsequent government, as will be the situation for our telecommunications industry, should the legislation that is coming forward pass through this chamber and this Parliament. Nevertheless, it only serves to illustrate the like-mindedness of both the Government and the Opposition.

We have an officially acknowledged 10 per cent unemployment rate, although the figure is probably more closely in the region of 15 per cent because of the use of lies, damn lies and statistics, as one of the Opposition's motions puts forward. We have a dramatic escalation in the level of unemployment, as has been pointed out earlier by Senator Calvert. A 60 per cent rise in unemployment has occurred in the past 12 months. That is an enormous shock to the system of any community, any society; to the individuals and the families concerned.

While it may be appropriate to claim that the Opposition is crying crocodile tears, as Senator McMullan has done in this debate, it is surely the responsibility of legislators in this place at least to attempt to do something about unemployment. Our contribution to this debate, at least initially, is to run through briefly the alternative proposals which have been put by my colleagues-including Senator Spindler as Treasury spokesperson, Senator Lees as representative of the social justice portfolio, Senator Bell and Senator Kernot-in past debates on this and other economic issues.

It is important that we have a change; it is now urgent that we have a change. As I have said, this Government and this Opposition are interested and have pursued economic policies of a deregulatory, free market-driven nature. As we say, government must take up its responsibilities and intervene selectively in a targeted way in the economy to achieve the sort of society that certainly we, or any government, should believe ought to be developed for Australians. We have achieved a drop in interest rates and that is one thing that has changed, but we cannot lose sight-and these motions before the Senate today refuse to let us lose sight-of the human misery and the social destruction that has been created as the vehicle for the reduction in interest rates.

The Democrats are suggesting very strongly that, if we are going to reduce unemployment, if we are going to create employment, the Federal Government must take responsibility for the elimination of payroll tax, which is a tax on employment. We are putting forward suggestions of ways that that can be done. I want to emphasise our suggestion that there should be a 40 per cent lift in the excise on alcohol and tobacco. Those products are actually costing our community money. To the extent that the pricing regime attached to those products can affect their use, it would not only be a revenue raising measure which then could be used by the Federal Government to reduce payroll tax, but it would also be a major contribution to the better health of our country.

The Democrats believe that there should be a 5 per cent bounty paid to exporters on new exports in a targeted fashion, so that we can get our exports going, so that we can get our economy back in balance and so that we can support our appropriate industries and create employment. This is now an absolute necessity. In the area of accelerated depreciation-something we have been pushing for some time-we see what has been put forward in the industry statement as being inadequate. It must be increased, especially where it would contribute to our export potential.

The Treasurer is on record recently as chastising the community for wasting the share of profits that the accord has delivered since 1986. We have seen a remarkably greedy business sector, so one thing must be done: we must be assured that company taxes are paid at appropriate rates, and indeed we suggest that possibly the rate of company tax should be increased, if that is the only way we are going to get the corporate sector to pay its way.

Senator Aulich mentioned the need for increased research and development investment in this country. We have an abysmal record. Just as the Government has come up with a training guarantee scheme in order to twist the arms of business and industry to get involved in training programs-a measure which we supported, but had to fix up as it went through-we believe that a research and development guarantee scheme may very well be appropriate in order to ensure that business in this country pays its way in research and development.

Business does not pay its way. It is the exact reverse of the situation we see in countries like Germany, as Senator Aulich has mentioned. In this country, to the extent that we have research and development spending, the great majority comes out of the public purse and the minority, a mere trickle, comes from business and industry, which, in the end, are the beneficiaries. We believe that that is something which government should be looking at.

It is important to get involved, and the Government should be generating this involvement, using the development of public infrastructure as a pump priming method. Quite clearly, that is now an urgent need. We have major figures in the Australian Labor Party making those suggestions at long last. I only hope that some of those suggestions will be taken up.

There will be the need for initiatives, perhaps at the grass roots level. In recent days, the Democrats have been discussing our proposal for a community work program, a proposal which was first put forward many years ago in this place and which the Democrats developed and took as far as the then Minister for Social Security, the former Senator Don Grimes. This was back in the very early 1980s. The then Senator Grimes looked at it at the time, but it was lost in a succession of elections and indeed in the process of the Hawke Government's increasing the incidence of jobs and plateauing out employment in the 5 per cent to 6 per cent region. We are calling on the Government to resurface a scheme of that nature.

Very briefly, I happened to be in New South Wales yesterday-the State which the Opposition extols as the great virtuous State which does not have an unemployment problem-where I spent part of the afternoon with unemployed people in the western suburbs. A report of the activities and thoughts of those young people appeared in this morning's Telegraph-Mirror. These young people are seriously looking for work. They are presentable, firm minded and determined young people who are chasing work and not getting it. I discussed with them the Democrats' proposals for a community work program. They were very enthusiastic. They see around their community jobs that need to be done but they and their friends are unable to get jobs.

What the Democrats are saying is that, if government can be flexible about the way unemployment payments are made, a coordinated program-our proposal sees local government as a potential coordinator, although non-government organisations, service clubs and others might be able to be involved-would be able to coordinate putting together the jobs which need doing and the people who want to work. It is a fact that unemployed people want to work. In order to ensure that the unemployed are not exploited-which is what work for the dole schemes are all about-we propose that a service fee be paid on top of the unemployment benefit. This means that when people worked they would not immediately lose that income support which it is our social responsibility to give to people in the community when we cannot and do not provide jobs for them. That service fee would bring these people up to the minimum wage rate, the award rate. They would therefore be doing socially useful work and would not be being exploited. The community would be paying the base unemployment rate to them and that would be topped up by a service fee.

Let us think about those elderly people on fixed incomes, such as pensioners and superannuants, who own their own homes but who cannot afford to get their fence fixed. Those are the sorts of people whose jobs would be able to be done. Kevin and Nathalie, with whom I spent time yesterday afternoon in the western suburbs at Homebush Bay, could see an area of State government land which needs cleaning up, where there is work to be done. They could see where such a scheme would enable them to work, put value back in their lives and put very important dollars into their pockets. It is a challenge for government, for unions and for the community at large to get behind such schemes as this at the local and community level to see that jobs are done and that people are given work.

Senator Aulich spoke quite a deal about the importance of education. Certainly, the Australian Democrats support the views of Senator Aulich and condemn the inaction and the wind-backs of this Government in that area. We must have an overhaul of the education system. We must consider education as a major resource in our community. In yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald we see the headline `Students turned away as TAFE money runs out'. Many courses around this country are overfull in technical and further education (TAFE). There is an unmet demand for courses in many colleges. The article states:
Hundreds of students . . . have been turned away from TAFE courses because TAFE has run out of money to pay for them.
According to one student, Mr David Stinson, at Katoomba TAFE:

. . . students enrolled in accounting courses were told last week that they would not be able to continue their studies at the college from 1992 onwards and that no new students would be admitted to the course from the second semester.
I do not know whether it is this Government's policy that we will not need accountants any more in the future; I hardly think so. The article continues:

``And colleges have suddenly been advised that the budget in TAFE is overspent and key courses cut. Unofficially, principals have heard that TAFE head office miscalculated this year's allocation of funds and is $15m in the red.''

All those things are no consolation to young people in Australia-and, as Senator Aulich said, 90 per cent of German young people are educated and trained-who are wanting to be educated and are wanting to be trained. Family breadwinners losing their jobs are needing training or retraining, yet courses are full. Those are the people who are now on the unemployment treadmill.

There has been a dramatic cut in apprenticeships, in part as a result of the overcrowding but also as a result of the failure of business to be prepared or to be able to support those apprenticeships. If we look at universities we see that again the demand outstrips places. We have students in overcrowded courses in overcrowded facilities. We need more lecturers urgently. We have not put enough resources into our tertiary education to attract lecturers into it.

Country students have enormous difficulty accessing courses. Lack of finances is a major problem and, of course, this Parliament has reduced the access of rural children in particular through its miserly approach to the Austudy program, and it stands condemned for that. In 1990, around 20,000 people who qualified for entry to university failed to get a place. I will give the Senate a few headlines from the last few days about the record on education.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for consideration of General Business has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion standing in the name of Senator Hill, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely a motion, to give precedence to a motion relating to the tabling of written advice, dated 20 March 1991, from the Human Rights Commissioner relating to the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991.

I will not speak to this motion at length because the Australian Democrats have indicated in discussion that they will support the suspension of Standing Orders and that they reserve their right on the substantive motion based on the arguments that are put before the chamber. I will not take an inordinate amount of time of the chamber debating the motion to suspend Standing Orders but to say that this is a fundamental issue which touches the democratic rights and principles of this country and the people in Australia. There can be no more important issue debated in Australian society than the freedom of expression and the democratic rights of individuals within Australia. It is for that reason that I move the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I would have appreciated some notice of this motion other than a bit of a rumour around the place about 30 seconds ago, which did not come from the Opposition. The Government will oppose the suspension of Standing Orders. There are a number of reasons for that, one being the very pre-emptive and undisciplined way in which this matter has been raised.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing I would like to say to the Senate and Senator Olsen is that I do not know how long he expects this debate to continue. I have made our position clear with respect to those documents. I have to catch a plane not all that long after we get up this evening and go overseas very early tomorrow morning. That puts the Senate in a very difficult position.

The trip I am going on is for the commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary of the Battle of Crete, and I have no intention of frustrating my and the Government's commitment to that ceremony. I do not know where Senator Olsen finds himself now. Had he approached this in a more decent way we might have been able to work it out earlier on this afternoon, but any continuation of the debate will place everyone here in a very difficult position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been the Australian Democrats' practice, in the interests of the democratic process and open processes in this chamber, to support suspensions where we did not believe they were essentially mischievous-that is, where we thought a purpose would be served and where we wanted to listen to a debate in order to be guided on a substantive motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I am disturbed to know once again-and this has happened before-that, while the Opposition has spoken with us in order to ensure passage of the motion, it has not had the courtesy to go to the Government, particularly where a certain Minister is concerned, to inform it of the process. I was given to understand that if a suspension of this nature was going to occur it would occur before the consideration of General Business. It did not, and that choice was made for some reason or other by the Opposition. The fact that it did not and the fact that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) was not aware that it was going to happen appears to have left the Minister, the Senate and, certainly, me, personally, at quite a loss as to how this matter-if the suspension passes-can be dealt with properly.

I think we appreciate the responsibilities of ministerial office which will take the Minister away, I understand, at the dinner break. My Australian Democrat colleagues and I had made a decision to support this suspension, but, as always, my colleagues are perfectly at liberty to vote any way they like when this motion is put. I suggest that there may very well be a division on this matter for that reason.

I have found it difficult, on this and other occasions, to deal with the Opposition in what I consider to be an honourable and rational way. Frankly, I am angered by this process. In the time that it takes to ring the division bells I, for one, will make up my mind as to how I will vote and I am quite sure those of my colleagues who are listening to me will do the same thing.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Olsen's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.29 to 8 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Olsen, at the request of Senator Hill) agreed to:
That a motion relating to the tabling of advice from the Human Rights Commissioner, dated 20 March 1991, may be moved forthwith and have precedence over all other business till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate orders the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) to table, prior to the adjournment this day, advice from the Human Rights Commissioner, relating to the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991, dated 20 March 1991.
I preface my remarks in asking for this action to be undertaken--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I ask whether that motion is in order, and under what standing order or power of the Senate that motion can be moved. I am trying to clarify it at this stage.
—I am advised that the motion is in order. Although I am advised that it is not the usual wording that is used, the motion is in order.

—I raise a further point of order, Mr Deputy President. The only other time I have seen this type of motion moved has been in relation to a document quoted from by the Minister. This is a slightly different sort of motion. It is saying that they believe a Minister has a document and ordering him to table it here. The Senate has the power to consider the motion, but I do not know that it has the power to enforce it. If an honourable senator comes in here and asks me to table defence intelligence documents or something like that, I can tell honourable senators right now that they will not get them.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Standing order 164 (1) states:

INTERJECT.PARA: Documents may be ordered to be laid on the table . . .
and there are further words in that standing order which are not particularly relevant here.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bolkus

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on that point of order, that standing order relates very much to the normal tabling of papers and those sorts of documents. Taken in its context, standing order 164 (1) states:

INTERJECT.PARA: Documents may be ordered to be laid on the table, and the Clerk shall communicate to the Leader of the Government in the Senate all orders for documents made by the Senate.

To me, that means the tabling of government documents or other documents of Senate committees. I take Senator Ray's point that there is not a power under the Standing Orders for the Senate to insist on the tabling of this document. To assist the Senate and you, Mr Deputy President, in interpreting this standing order, at this stage I refer to a view not from this side of the Parliament but from Sir Robert Menzies who said:

TALK.START.PARA: —You're quoting him!

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bolkus

TALK.START.PARA: —Precisely. Senator Hill has come a long way. Sir Robert Menzies said:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . it would be curious and alarming if an anti-Government Senate could undermine the objectivity and non-political integrity of the Public Service by exposing its senior and most responsible officers to a Parliamentary inquisition from which they had a right to be immune and compelling their entry into a field of political debate.

I think that would help you, Sir, to interpret the point of order. However, in terms of precedents one can go to Odgers Senate Practice for more of them or, particularly, one can look at the events of 1975, when matters were raised of this sort and it was determined at the time that the Senate did not have the power to insist on the tabling of documents.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Robert Ray

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to the point of order, Mr Deputy President, I indicate to Senator Olsen that, whilst we are taking points of order we will not eat into his time, inasmuch as he will have the maximum time; we will grant an extension. We are not wanting to filibuster on this theme.

INTERJECT.PARA: The other time that I believe this matter came up, Mr Deputy President, was in the Tasmanian Parliament in 1960. Fortunately, because of the dinner recess, I have not had a lot of time to research this matter. However, I understand that Prime Minister Holt in October 1967 reaffirmed a similar principle.

The point is that what we might be setting today is something that has not been done in this Parliament before, namely, demanding a document sent from one person to a Minister. The efficacy of that, given the fact that there are other laws on the discovery of documents, in terms of freedom of information with qualification, is something that this Senate really should consider. We had this sprung on us at 25 minutes past 6, with no forewarning. We may in fact be wrong in the points of order we are making right now but we have not had sufficient opportunity to research the matter and to look to the consequences of this motion, whether it is within the power of the Senate or not within the power of the Senate to consider such a motion.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Michael Baume

TALK.START.PARA: —We could withdraw the motion if you provide the document.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Robert Ray interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Newman

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, Mr Deputy President, standing order 164 has been referred to and I draw your attention also to standing order 168, which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: A document relating to public affairs quoted by a Minister may be ordered to be laid on the table . . .

I draw your attention also the fact that, in his answer today, the Minister referred both to legal advice and to Mr Burdekin's report, and the Minister at that time did not suggest that there was anything there of a confidential nature, which could be obtained --

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not quote from the document.

—Public affairs were referred to, and the document was involved in that. It was done by a Minister, and I think it is all consistent, if standing order 168 is read together with standing order 164. If we read those standing orders in context, as I think we must, it is appropriate that we can ask that the document be tabled.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Robert Ray

TALK.START.PARA: —On a further point of order, Mr Deputy President: in claiming that standing order 168 is pre-eminent, had Senator Newman gone on she would have found also the further provision in standing order 168 that:

INTERJECT.PARA: An order under paragraph (1) or (2) may be made by a motion without notice moved immediately on the conclusion of the speech of the Senator who quoted the document.

The key words there are `quoted the document'. Honourable senators will recall that not so long ago we had a similar discussion about Senator Bolkus getting up and quoting from a document. That is quite within the ambit of standing order 168, and no-one challenged that at the time. However, the motion before us asks a Minister to produce correspondence written to him, and table it here. The implication of this eventually for all governments concerns what people write to government. I do not want to see that just ripped up here with a few minutes debate without full consideration. I think it is a separate issue to the sort of issue that we had when we were involved in Senator Bolkus quoting from an internal departmental document. He quoted it here, claimed commercial in confidence and, when we got around that problem, we did not have a problem releasing the document.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bolkus

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two points to raise. First, in terms of clarification, Senator Ray is quite correct. Today I did not quote from any document emanating from the Human Rights Commission. In fact I quoted from no document during Question Time. The document that Senator Olsen is attempting to have produced was not quoted from. I add to the first point I made about Sir Robert Menzies' comments. We should recognise also, as I said before, that Odgers is of some assistance here, in that it is recognised there on page 563, I think, which I quote:

INTERJECT.PARA: Certainly there are affairs which in the public interest, or for reasons of national security, should be kept confidential; Parliament recognises that principle and the practice is not to press for certain disclosures, such as in relation to Cabinet documents and advice given by officers to Ministers.

The point we are dealing with here obviously is advice that is being given by officers to the Minister involved. As I say, it is pretty clear from the interpretation of the powers of the Senate in the past, not only as recognised by Sir Robert Menzies, but also as recognised by Odgers in his Australian Senate Practice that there is no power in the Senate to so force. If I were to reinforce the point, I would also quote Odgers on page 561 where he recognised, in respect of the loans matter, the plea of privilege that prevailed-as I said, for the time being-and public servants were not by resolution held to be in contempt for refusing to answer questions on ministerial instructions. That assists in defining the sort of power the Senate has.

I think that Senator Ray was spot on when he asked what if it were the case that the document that was being asked for tonight was an Australian Security Intelligence Organisation report, or a police report, or an National Crime Authority report, or whatever. Basically, the point is that under Standing Orders there is no power and in the way those Standing Orders have been interpreted for quite some time and consistently during that period, the privilege of the Crown has been recognised.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Newman

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on that point of order, Mr Deputy President. There were two matters raised by the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Administrative Services that I would like to respond to and draw to your attention. Senator Ray continually referred to the Minister quoting from a document. I draw your attention once again to standing order 168 with its subsections (1),(2) and (3). There is reference first, to a document quoted by a Minister; secondly, to one quoted by a senator, who is not a Minister; and thirdly, to an order made by a motion without notice moved immediately on the conclusion of the speech of the senator who quoted the document. The document was quoted in the sense that it was referred to, not quoted from, which would be in there if it was needed.

INTERJECT.PARA: The other thing I would like to draw to your attention, Mr Deputy President, is the fact that the Minister was referring to an `officer'. I ask whether in fact the person concerned is truly an officer for the purposes described in Odgers or whether that person is a statutory appointee and therefore the term `officer' may not be appropriate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Robert Ray

TALK.START.PARA: —On that point of order, I did refer earlier to Prime Minister Holt. I do not know whether that arises in a direct sense here, but the case quoted here was from 17 May 1960. The then Minister for Education in considering this made a statement to which I refer honourable senators, on pages 586 and 587 of Odgers. The only further information I have is to back up what I said before. Speaking in the House of Representatives on 31 October 1967, the Prime Minister, Mr Holt, stated that he agreed with the Tasmanian statement and that it might well be adopted as sound policy. What this also refers and leaves open is the question that may one day arise: what happens if the Senate orders the production of certain papers and the responsible Minister refuses to table such papers? Regrettably no answer was provided there. I suppose that is why we have raised the question today.

INTERJECT.PARA: On the second issue, this is a specific case; I think Senator Newman raised the question of whether the person who wrote this particular document or letter-I have not seen it-was an officer. I am not sure; I have not read the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission legislation; I will be straightforward there. The person certainly is not a direct employee of government; I think we all assume that. Again, that is another question of status. I am not trying to delay things because we want to get on with Government Business. I just say that there are greater matters of principle than rushing in for something that I do not even think is going to be a big political advantage if it is tabled and you, Mr Deputy President, will see the essence of that somewhat later tonight, I suspect.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister could offer to table it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Robert Ray

TALK.START.PARA: —We establish the principle first, but if we set a principle that the Senate has the power to order the tabling of a document not quoted in this chamber by the Minister-and that means any document-I could move in here tomorrow and ask for certain documents from 1981 and 1982 to be tabled, making it a very personal sort of thing, that Senator Newman might not like. I could do that, but I do not think that that has ever been the tradition, especially as it involves an issue that will be debated here when the substance of the legislation comes in.

INTERJECT.PARA: I am sorry to delay matters, Mr Deputy President. There is a major matter of principle here, of which we are somewhat uncertain. If we make a quick ruling that binds the Senate for ever, I may well one day be the big beneficiary of it if I am sitting on the opposite side of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite soon, yes.

—Senator Baume says, `Quite soon'. He has been chirping away like that since March or May 1983-from John Howard's office, and then from in here: `Quite soon, quite soon'. Well, it will be quite a while yet. I will leave it at that.

—Could Senator Bolkus give me the reference to that part of Odgers to which he last referred which seemed to indicate that advice to Ministers need not be tabled? It was not only on advice to Ministers; there were some other references.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bolkus

TALK.START.PARA: —It is from page 563 and I will quote from it again:

INTERJECT.PARA: Certainly there are affairs which in the public interest, or for reasons of national security, should be kept confidential; Parliament recognises that principle and the practice is not to press for certain disclosures, such as in relation to Cabinet documents and advice given by officers to Ministers. Where it is considered that public servants should not give certain information to Parliament or its committees, the appropriate course, it is submitted, is to instruct the officers to ask to be excused on stated grounds, such as that the questions may be of a nature which should more appropriately be addressed to Ministers.
It is recognised very clearly in that paragraph that there is a reserve area where Ministers can claim privilege and one that the Senate would normally respect.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Hill

TALK.START.PARA: —I will briefly contribute to this debate. I submit to you, Mr Deputy President, that the passage that the Minister for Administrative Services has just quoted from Odgers, in effect, demonstrates that the Senate does have the power. What it does say, however, is that there is a practice that certain types of documents are not sought under that power, such as Cabinet submissions and matters that relate to national security. Speaking for this side of the chamber, we would not seek to have documents of that nature ordered to be put before the Senate.

INTERJECT.PARA: This is not the type of document that is referred to here as a document relating to national security, the type of document to which the Minister for Defence referred a few minutes ago. It is a document from a statutory body that has not only a responsibility to the Government, but a wider responsibility to the people of Australia that relates to the basic principle upon which proposed Government legislation has been premised. Therefore, it does not fall within the exclusion of the practice that is referred to-and I stress practice rather than a lack of capacity.

I also suggest to you, Mr Deputy President, that Senator Ray and also Senator Bolkus, to some extent, are blurring the issue of the capacity of the Senate to make the order and also the question of enforcement. We are not here debating the question of enforcement. It may well be, as has been suggested by the Ministers, that there is not a specific power of enforcement. But that is not a subject to be decided in this debate on this particular question of the Standing Orders. Enforcement is something to be settled on another day and, hopefully, in relation to a matter such as this, it will not need to be argued. I separate that debate because I think that it should be separated. But I bring you back to this passage in Odgers which, I suggest, by its very language, makes it clear that in fact the Senate has the capacity to do what is being sought by Senator Olsen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I respond on two points put forward by the Minister for Administrative Services. Firstly, during questions and the Minister's response over the past three days, the Minister has referred to advice from the Attorney-General's Department and also to advice that the has been given and discussions that he has had with Mr Burdekin. The Hansard of today indicates a reference to Mr Burdekin and also to advice that the Minister received from the Attorney-General's Department. Therefore, the matter has been raised in the Senate during this week.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point of order is that in February 1986, Senator Bolkus, in arguing for the establishment of this Commission, referred to it as a body which needs to be the public watchdog for government abuses of human rights. We are talking about a public watchdog and a report from a public watchdog, which is relevant to the matter before the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the first point raised by Senator Olsen: he continually glosses over the fact that in the three days that he has asked questions on this matter, Senator Bolkus has not quoted from the document sought.
—Quoted from.
—That is not, I do not think, the way--
—It is an important distinction.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Robert Ray

TALK.START.PARA: —I take Senator Newman's point in the technical sense but then I looked at the past practice of the way this particular standing order has been enforced. Generally, we would concede that quotation from a document is the very reason the standing order is there-to protect honourable senators in this place from the Minister coming in, potentially quoting, misusing and misquoting from a document and getting away with it without anyone seeing a document. That is why the standing order is here; to prevent that particular abuse. Therefore, I would argue that my interpretation of what `quoted' and `quotation' are historically has been a more valid one.

INTERJECT.PARA: This is the first time apparently in 90 years this has come up in the chamber. The fact that it has not come up before means it is not really addressed in that sense in the Standing Orders. Again, it therefore is very difficult for you, Mr Deputy President, I would think, to rule one way or the other because it effectively is the first real ruling on this particular matter.

When one looks through the record in looking for other guidance in this through parliaments throughout Australia-and no-one has pretended here we have had an extensive search-one cannot find any examples that fully clarify the matter. But again, I know oppositions at times stand on principle and opportunism. I do not know, and I cannot divine, what the motive is here, other than the Opposition is setting a precedent if it says that this chamber can demand any government document because it will affect advice tendered by a whole range of people to government in future.

I do not know whether this advice was sent to Senator Bolkus on the basis that it would or would not be published. But the Opposition had better be careful in the precedents it sets because the wheel always turns, and it will turn back on the Opposition if it is not careful, and we do not have this thing properly sorted out.

My initial advice to Senator Bolkus-but he can say what he likes or not if this motion is carried-is at least not to meet the deadline by tonight. If the Senate wants to go to Crete with him and enforce the Act, well good luck to you all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call any further honourable senators, I would indicate that it is my opinion that standing order No. 168 is not at all applicable in this situation. It is only standing order No. 164 which we are looking at. As the Minister said, I am placed in an awkward position because I was not given any indication that I would be asked to rule before I came into the chair. So I am going to ask shortly whether someone would allow me to have a break, say for 30 minutes, so that I can go away and look at the matter properly. But before doing that I would ask any honourable senator who wishes to make some submission to do so, so that I would have it before I leave the chamber.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bolkus

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assist you further with your deliberations, Mr Deputy President, and refer you to the Hansard of the Senate of 16 July 1975. I do so because at that particular time, the Solicitor-General, the then Mr Byers, in essence the whole question of Crown privilege and the production of documents and witnesses was very much a live issue before this place. At page 2782 of Hansard, Mr Byers was asked by then Senator Withers, `What privilege does the Crown have?', and said:

INTERJECT.PARA: I am not asserting anything. I am giving my understanding of the law. My understanding of the law is that the privilege resides in the Crown. That privilege may be asserted. It has been. When it has been, the question next arises as to my duty in relation to that assertion. I can see my duty to be no less than keeping secret the Crown's counsel. The duty which the oath of a Federal executive councillor imposes on him is not to reveal matters directly or indirectly. That is my understanding.
At page 2788, in response to questions by the then Senator Wright, Mr Byers said:

Again with respect, I do not understand those as but specific examples of the central constitutional notion. The central constitutional notion is the secrecy of the deliberations. That is the central constitutional notion.

What we have here are very much deliberations and what we also have is an opinion by the first law officer of the Crown at that particular time making it very clear that the power of privilege imposed in the Executive is one that is protected. That is why I say that any interpretation of the Standing Orders needs to take that into account.

It would be quite a farcical situation if this Senate found that it passed a resolution-as indicated by Senator Hill may be possible-which it could then not enforce in respect to a member of the Senate or an officer, which it attempts to enforce it over. The opinions of Mr Byers, the then Solicitor-General, are fundamentally important when one interprets the Standing Orders in place.

I would also suggest that the Parliament has-and the Senate by its committee structure has participated in the development of-a structure which does allow for publication of documents. That, of course, is the Freedom of Information Act. That Act recognises a whole range of exemptions to it. That Act is available to members of the public and members of the Parliament-it has been accessed by both of them.

That Act was passed by this Senate after some very heavy committee deliberations-a committee that I chaired and I think Senate Hill was deputy chairman. That legislation-the committee's proposal-was there, and provides for us a framework to ensure what documents are provided and what are not in accordance with the privileges that have been protected through history.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, in your deliberations I wonder whether you could take into account the proposition I want to put: if Senator Bolkus is relying on Odgers' remarks about public interest, and that there would be no tabling of documents if it was in the public interest not to do so, surely there would be a requirement, would there not, for the Minister to establish in what respect it is not in the public interest to table this document to the extent that there is an awareness of the thrust of the document? Surely there would be an onus on the Minister in such a situation to establish that the public interest was best served by not tabling the document, if in fact he is relying on Odgers for that view.

—I want to comment on what Senator Baume has put forward-that the onus should be on the Minister. In a situation such as this I would be concerned if that was so because if, as seems to be argued by the Opposition, any document is to be made available to the Senate-indeed, not only to the Senate, it is to be laid on the table-and to the public, if the Senate so desires, then it would mean that Cabinet documents, documents relating to defence, the sorts of documents that Senate Robert Ray has spoken about would be--
—Odgers excludes them.
—No, it is not Odgers. Odgers gives an opinion.
—If he relies on Odgers.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Cooney

TALK.START.PARA: —If he relies on Odgers, that is right. Those documents would only be excluded if the Minister concerned could discharge the onus.

INTERJECT.PARA: If the Minister claimed that it was a document relating, say, to defence there would be nothing, according to the Opposition, to stop it saying, `We want to see those documents to establish whether or not they relate to defence'. It is my proposition that the onus is not on the Minister but the other way. That would seem to me to flow from the way in which chapter 26 is set up. I shall go to that in a moment. That would seem to be correct. If the onus lay the other way, all that would have to happen for all sorts of documents to be produced is for either side of the House to ask the other for a document. There is nothing under this proposition to stop the Government side of the House saying to the other side, `We want all the documents that in any way relate to the policy that the Opposition will adopt on social security, defence or what have you'. If Senator Michael Baume is right, it would then be incumbent on the other side to prove that it should not be produced. Standing order 26, paragraph 164 (1), reads:
Documents may be ordered to be laid on the table, and the Clerks shall communicate to the Leader of the Government in the Senate all orders for documents made by the Senate.

That is not confined to the government situation; it is general. We could ask the Australian Democrats to produce all the documents that they have relied upon to come to their decision about a particular policy, or all the documents which, say, Senator McLean produced when he was talking to the many people who came to see him about the banking inquiry. In other words, if we open this can of worms we are opening it not only in respect of the Government but in respect of everybody in this chamber.

I could say now to Senator Powell, somebody for whom I have nothing but the greatest admiration-and I am not saying this in any way to prompt this, but just by way of illustration-`I now call upon you to produce all the documents that you have used to come to your policy on the economy, and all the letters that have been sent to you by your constituents. On the analysis made by Senator Michael Baume, unless you can show that they ought not to be produced, they are to be laid on the table. Our eminent Clerk shall communicate to the Leader of the Government in the Senate all the orders for the document by the Senate, and when we have gone through that process all your documents will have to be put on the table'.

I imagine that one of the reasons why, as Senator Robert Ray has pointed out, over 90 years there has not been a precedent for this is that, if tonight this Senate votes for Senator Bolkus to produce the documents, there is nothing to stop Senator Ray coming in tomorrow and demanding all the documents that he wants from the other side.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not tomorrow. We will not be here.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Cooney

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy President. Under your presidency, I would be more than happy to come back. I believe that there are documents which the Senate might want from time to time which are clearly documents that should be put on the table on any analysis of the situation. That is what these refer to. But we are now on a fishing expedition. If we are to go on a fishing expedition in respect of Senator Bolkus, we can go on fishing expeditions in respect of everybody here. It would seem to me that, on the basis that this matter has been put forward tonight, it would be a little inconsistent for this chamber to require Senator Bolkus to put forward the documents which those on the other side want should they then refuse to put their own documents forward if we want them to do so tomorrow.

INTERJECT.PARA: If, on the other hand, it seems on the face of the debate in the chamber that it is essential for the proper functioning of the chamber that a document should be put forward, it should come forward. But, on the evidence so far, there is nothing to indicate that it is in the interests of the Senate and its workings to know what conversations took place in private or what documents were prepared in private between Senator Bolkus and anybody else. It does not affect the Bill as drafted, excepting that this was another element in the various discussions that took place prior to its being drafted. It seems to me very dangerous to go ahead tonight to look at this document in these circumstances.

The only other thing I want to say is that the Constitution has three chapters. This indicates that there is a division of power between the Executive, the legislature and the judiciary. It is proper that the Executive should be allowed to conduct its affairs correctly and, where justified, in secret and with confidentiality. If in preparing a Bill many or few opinions are sought, in my opinion they should be kept confidential in the interests of the proper division of power.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are working under some difficulty because we have not had the written motions.
—Is this a different point of order?
—This is a different point of order. It is a more technical one, a sort of lawyers' shyster one in one sense.
—Should we deal with this one first?

—No, because it throws the whole debate into doubt. The point is that Senator Olsen, as I understand from his first motion, asked for the suspension of Standing Orders to move a motion relating to a document of 21 March. I ask him whether I am right there.
—The date is 20 March.

—It is 20 March. What he requires to be produced under this motion is a different document. I cannot say how it can be consistent to refer to one document which exists which was sent on 20 March and suspend Standing Orders to discuss it but then demand a different document-all documents. I do not understand how he can do that. He has suspended Standing Orders to move this motion about a particular document, and then he moves a different motion pertaining to another document or documents. I do not understand how we can let that go by, Mr Deputy President. It is something that should be sorted out. It will not foreclose this debate because it can be moved again, I suppose, in another form, but it may also lead to putting the Minister into a farcical position as to which document he produces. I suspect that if Senator Olsen had given us some notice and typed up the things and circulated them around the chamber-I know that sometimes one does these things on the run, but he has been thinking about the matter for three days-we would not have run into this problem.

—Order! I have just about reached the stage where I will have to ask someone to move that the debate be adjourned, but I notice that Senator Hill, Senator Olsen and Senator O'Chee wish to make comments. I will ask those three senators to do so.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Hill

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief, Mr Deputy President.
