I want to address the suggestion that a unique application is being made and, furthermore, that orders of this nature have not been made in the past. I suggest to you that when you retire to deliberate on this matter you will find many occasions on which orders similar to this have been made. One that I have put my hand upon at very short notice occurred on only 7 November last year and related to a series of documents concerning the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Durack, who unfortunately had to leave the chamber to meet another obligation, made mention to me of a legal opinion that he was once required to table as Attorney-General. As I said, Mr Deputy President, I suspect that, when you start going through the historical records, as you will when this adjournment is given for that purpose, you will find many instances. There is nothing unusual in this process at all.

Much of the debate has been about the question as to whether the motion should or should not be carried on its merits. It reminds me of the experience we had just a few days ago when we were seeking from Senator Bolkus the production of another series of documents. We accepted that parts of those documents that were genuinely commercial in confidence should not be the subject of our application, which gets back to the point of practice rather than the point of law. As a matter of practice, we therefore excluded them. In that instance one of the documents was a legal opinion to the Government.

We believed that as a matter of practice we should not include that within our motion. Honourable senators may well have said that, had we included it, as a matter of practice they should not have passed a motion if it included such a document that was clearly commercial in confidence. That is a question of the merits on the debate, which is another stage of the issue. This debate is all about whether the Senate has the capacity to carry the motion. I suggest that not only has it the capacity to do so but that it has also done so on many occasions in the past. I bring to your attention simply that one example of 7 November 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hesitate to rise because I have had my say on the principle. I draw your attention to the problem that we have here. Senator Olsen moved three motions. We were not given notice of those motions. We did not see those motions. I then approached Senator Olsen and asked him to give me the third motion, and he did so. The difficulty we now have is that the motion as originally moved and signed by Senator Olsen, and the motion that he gave me are different. I do not know whether he did it deliberately.
—Come on!

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Robert Ray

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me read the two motions; the difference is substantial. Senator Olsen's motion which he moved in this chamber, but which he did not give me, states:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate orders the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, to table, prior to the House adjourning today, the written advice dated 20 March from the Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Brian Burdekin.
When I asked Senator Olsen for the motion because we did not have a copy of it, he gave me the following motion, which stated:

That so much of standing orders be suspended that enable me to move a motion relating to the tabling of written advice dated 20 March 1991 from the Human Rights Commissioner relating to the Government's Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991.
There is a date in one, and nothing in the other.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think the first one refers to?
—There is a difference in the documents. For a start, Senator Olsen will turn this place into a farce.
—This is an aside, isn't it?
—It is an aside.

—If you want to go on the subsequent one and argue that the motion that has been moved goes beyond the capacity of the suspension, do so and the question of the motion can be cleared up. It has nothing to do with it.
—I am just drawing attention--
—It is not. It is just a straight diversionary tactic.

—It is a little more than a diversionary tactic. I think it is a serious matter when a motion is moved here, we ask to see a written copy and we are given a different motion. Had the copy not come in, we never would have known.
—Come on!
—Senator Olsen might like to get up and explain.
—You do not seriously suggest it is about a different subject matter, do you?
—I certainly do.
—Order! I am trying to listen to the points of order.

—That is for the Opposition to determine, not for us. Senator Olsen may at least be able to clear up how he happened to give me a different motion to the one he moved, one having a date in it and the other referring to the full title of a Bill, both in conflict. It makes it very difficult even to take points of order on the substantive principle if we are given different motions.
—Order! I shall ask for two more speakers and then I shall ask for someone to move for the adjournment.

—The three substantive motions I read out to this chamber, on which I sought advice prior to moving, subsequently signed and passed in to the Clerk, and to which the Minister now refers, are word for word with what I read out to this chamber.
—So this document you gave me is a pack of lies?
—Oh, come on!
—Which one are you pursuing?
—You are changing the whole nature of the thing. This is before this document was handed in.

—I take some exception to the implication that Senator Robert Ray is trying to put before the chamber. The fact is that the motion that I moved, signed and passed in to the Clerk, will be part of the official record of this chamber. It is already there as part of the official record. To suggest that, after that, I will modify that in some form, is just arrant nonsense. Minister Ray came over to me and said, `Can you scribble out the motion?'.
—The motions.
—Yes, and I did. If there is a slight variation between one and the other--
—More than slight.
—Mr Deputy President, the point is that the motion I moved, word for word, and signed, and handed in--
—After you gave me this.
—That is the motion that the Minister now has. I take great exception--
—Why?
—For the implication that Senator Ray is putting before the chamber now. That is why.
—What other inference can I draw?
—Order! Senator O'Chee will be the last I hear on the point of order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator O'Chee

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very grateful to you, Mr Deputy President, for this brief opportunity to address this point of order. I wish to tackle three arguments put forward by my good friend and colleague Senator Cooney from the other side of the chamber. His arguments were basically these: there is a separation of the Executive from the Parliament; the second argument was that this could lead to a very dangerous precedent because any document could be ordered to be produced; the third argument related to burden of proof of public interest or otherwise.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Cooney's first argument relates to Dicey's rule of law which says that there is a separation between the Executive, Parliament and the judiciary. That is, indeed, the case. There is also a whole string of cases in which actions of one have been subject to the scrutiny of another. The classic case in point is a recognition of that in the Acts Interpretation Act where provision is made for the interpretation of an Act by consideration of what is said in the Parliament. In that respect, I think that Australia is somewhat different from the United Kingdom. It is very important that we draw very careful distinctions in that respect.

I make the other point that, whilst we have an Executive, the authority of that Executive to make decisions is necessarily a delegation of certain powers of the Parliament itself, which is why this Parliament exists to scrutinise and to examine the decisions and activities of the Executive. It has never been a principle in this Constitution or, indeed, within the Westminster system that the Executive is exempt from scrutiny. Therefore, the basis of Senator Cooney's first argument that the documents should not be tabled because our documents belong to the Executive is, with great respect to my good friend, quite simply false.

Senator Cooney's second argument was that it creates a very dangerous precedent because any document could be ordered to be produced. I think here there are some unwritten, but nonetheless recognised, distinctions which are made between an honourable senator acting in the capacity as a Minister and an honourable senator acting in a private capacity as a senator. The argument which we made against an order for production of documents from a private senator on the Opposition side or from the crossbenches is that it would be an oppression of that honourable senator's freedoms, which are recognised as part of our common law and which predate the Constitution.

There is an argument that a senator, acting in the capacity as a Minister, is subject to the same scrutiny that any other member of the Executive is subject to. Therefore, it is very easy to draw the distinction between which documents could, under the common law which underlies the whole Constitution and underlies the standing orders, be ordered to be produced. Clearly, they are only documents which are official in nature.

Whilst a document may have a certain status within a party on this side, or on the other side, it is doubtful whether any motion could be carried successfully, or be valid, which would order the production of a party document. I think the distinction has to be made between whether the Senate would have the capacity to order an honourable senator to produce a document which relates to his or her party's activities-on reflection, at this moment, I would have to say that I doubt it-or whether we would require an honourable senator who is a member of the Executive to produce official documents.

Certainly, the whole framework of our legislative system-in particular, the freedom of information legislation-recognises certain categories of documents which may be in the possession of members of parliament which are still subject to scrutiny. Therefore, that creates a precedent for the sorts of things we are doing here. It is a well-known principle that the Senate can determine its own procedures. Therefore, Mr Deputy President, I submit to you that the presentation of the document is not out of order; it is within the scope of the Senate so to order.

My final point relates to Senator Cooney's argument that it would be up to the side moving for the order for the documents to be tabled to prove the public interest. I disagree most strongly. There is a grave difficulty, an evidentiary difficulty, with this; that is, quite simply, this side would not know what the documents were and, therefore, could not prove the public interest of the documents because this side would never know the contents. The Minister, of course, does know the contents of the documents and is in a position to make a case that it is not in the public interest to table the documents. That is my first objection to Senator Cooney's third argument.

I have a second objection to his third argument which is this: in Senator Cooney's argument there is a presumption which runs against freedom of both the individual and parliament to determine their own procedures. As I said, it is a longstanding principle that a parliament has a right to determine its own procedures. This is a presumption which would have the effect of fettering parliament's own discretion in respect of its procedures but placing upon parliament, and individual members of the parliament, an evidentiary requirement which they would be incapable of fulfilling. It is a longstanding principle of the common law that no law, ruling, or judgment shall be made which is unenforceable or which brings the law into disrepute by making it an absurdity. I respectfully submit that, for this second reason, Senator Cooney's third argument is also false.

I close my arguments in relation to Senator Cooney's third proposition by saying that it has been recognised in other jurisdictions which have a common law basis-in particular the United Kingdom-that there are certain public interests and certain public freedoms, the protection of which has overridden statute and sometimes other common laws. I refer particularly to the Official Secrets Act in the United Kingdom under which it is an offence to disclose certain matters which are covered by that Act.

In the Ponting case-I hasten to add that the father of a very good friend of mine was a judge who sat on that case-it was recognised that, although Mr Ponting had disclosed documents which were covered by the Official Secrets Act, and had prima facie committed an offence to which there was no defence, the jury sitting on the case ruled that, in spite of the direction from the judge to convict Mr Ponting, he be acquitted because it was held by the jury, although it was not subsequently challenged successfully in any court, that there was a public interest category, a public interest defence, which justified certain actions.

I draw the parallel between that recognition of a public interest argument and the sorts of public interest arguments that this side of the chamber is putting tonight, particularly the importance of the public interest argument, to overturn Senator Cooney's arguments with regard to the burden of proof. Mr Deputy President, I thank you most sincerely for this opportunity to speak.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it will take me too long to come to a decision. However, under the circumstances, I think it is best if the debate is adjourned for a short period so I can go away and look at the matter dispassionately. I feel a bit like a magistrate who has been addressed by a number of High Court judges.

INTERJECT.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I rise to move a motion relating to a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs which I moved and which was passed earlier today. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After paragraph (b) insert the following paragraph:
``(c) the extension of section 52A (unconscionable conduct) to all commercial dealings;''.
This action is necessary to correct a transcription error in the preparation of the notice of motion.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 14 May, on motion by Senator Cooney:
