Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Parliamentary Information Systems Office

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 March, on motion by Senator Bishop:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel there are a few points that should be made with regard to the tabling of this report. As the Senate will remember, an inquiry was conducted by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts following a reference from the Senate which, in turn, followed a report of Estimates Committee A, which found that one of the witnesses appearing before Estimates Committee A had lied to the Committee and subsequently wrote to the Committee and confessed that that was the case.

SPEECH.PARA: The Public Accounts Committee considered this matter in great detail. The findings of the Committee concerned the individual players in the illegal secret account-otherwise known as the `unofficial account'-which was established by certain officers within the Parliamentary Information Systems Office (PISO), taking so-called obsolete equipment; namely computers, and selling them for a sum of $88,000. The Constitution was broken; the Audit Act was broken; the Finance Regulations were broken. In fact, there was a culture that pervaded the place that said that they were people who were not covered by the Public Service Act, or the other legislation that I have mentioned, and that they were somehow a law unto themselves.

The fact of the matter is that had that unofficial or secret illegal account not been detected, it could have gone on being a cipher of funds for an unspecified time. The fact that we were able to detect the existence of that account through the Estimates committee hearings meant that we were able to terminate both the account itself and the practice that had been established. Further, I make the very strong point that I am very pleased to see that secretaries of certain departments have taken the case up and used it as an example in instructing members of their staff that they must properly conduct themselves.

As I said, the findings of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts concerning the principal players were very strong and very definite. Indeed, they included a recommendation that one particular party, who no longer works for the Crown, should be very seriously deterred from ever doing so again. That is a very serious finding for the Committee to make. I am pleased to recount that, in reports that come back to me, there is a sense of appreciation that the matters were pursued, firstly by Estimates Committee A and then by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. It ensures that the message that all public servants are just that is received by those concerned and informs public servants that they are compelled to comply with the Public Service Act 1922, the Constitution, the Audit Act 1901 and the Finance Regulations by which they are covered.

I have cited at least one copy of the instructions of the Secretary of a department which are in accordance with the new requirements. They are comprehensive and they have been followed up by that Secretary. I would be most interested to ascertain how many secretaries of other departments have compiled a similar manual and are instructing their staff in the way in which this report of the Public Accounts Committee instructs they ought to be so informed.

I repeat the really worrying and unresolved aspect of this PISO unofficial or illegal account: had we not detected this cipher of public moneys-it was $88,000-what else could have been sold off in the same way? What else could have been pushed through this illegal account and how would that money have been dispensed? If one reads the report, one sees that some of the money was spent on the now infamous weekend at the Hilton Hotel. One will see that the money funded the purchase of all sorts of extraordinary chattels such as a cocktail cabinet to furnish a room for the comfort of the people who were involved. But, in truth, unless this account had been detected in the way it was, there was no way that the practice of selling articles and items could not have gone on indefinitely, for years, without being detected. That is the very worrying aspect because one asks oneself the question, `If it could happen in this department, could it happen in others and, indeed, has it happened in others?'.

Once again we relied on the scrutiny process, the efficacy of the Auditor-General and the various committees of scrutiny and finally this Parliament, where a sense of responsibility prevailed. The Senate will remember that the recommendation to refer this matter came not in a partisan way but jointly by all the members-Government and Opposition-of Estimates Committee A calling for this further inquiry.

Without sounding the importance of this Committee too highly, in a way it is indeed a benchmark. It does point to the fact that the Public Service must make itself informed of its duties and obligations. It is not open to members of the Public Service to say, `We do not think or believe we are covered by the law in this regard'. It is an important report in that way. It can contribute overall to an improvement in the administration of the expenditure of the taxpayers' dollar and ensure that the taxpayers get value for that expenditure. The final duty that all of us have on both sides of this chamber is to the taxpayer, the constituent and the voter. All those titles can represent the same person, but that is the person to whom we have a responsibility which we must meet.

This is an important report; it made important points. As I have said, I am pleased that those points have been picked up by those who have a responsibility within the Public Service for ensuring that proper conduct is followed. It is beholden upon us all to ensure that not just some of the secretaries of departments follow, maintain and carry out their responsibilities, but that they all do. I guess that slowly, department by department, we will ascertain who is efficient, who is competent and who is not. This report has been an important part of the scrutiny process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make somewhat similar remarks to those of my colleague Senator Bishop in relation to The Parliamentary Information Systems Office (PISO) `Unofficial Account' report. In doing so, I acknowledge the role that Senator Bishop played in this report and her penetrating investigatory analysis that brought so much to light.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that the focus of this report has been on the immediate participants in the unofficial account as required by the terms of reference to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. However, the Senate should not close its eyes to the lack of top management supervision. While I have a great deal of sympathy for the position of the Presiding Officers at the time, they less than adequately addressed their wider management obligations. Since then they have attended to the detail and systems have been put in place.

The PISO report should not have been necessary. It is indeed a sad day for our Parliament and our democratic system. At the lower level within the parliamentary administration events went dreadfully wrong. Here in the parliamentary administration the day-to-day administrators, people who should have known the rules, were not informed and, further, chose not to be informed. However, it is not unreasonable to assume that these executives should not need to be educated in the rudimentary requirements of their offices. Their business is to know. While parliamentarians expect others to have proper systems of accountability, the very basics of the control mechanisms were never implemented by the PISO officers.

A basic question remains unanswered: why did those responsible for setting up an illegal, unofficial account, into which the proceeds of the sale of Commonwealth assets were deposited and withdrawn for unofficial purposes, go to so much trouble with so little communication and with no official records being kept? Computer Power Pty Ltd, the outside firm in question into whose bank account the public servants illegally deposited the Commonwealth moneys from the sale of those assets, has, in my view, been treated very lightly by the Commonwealth Attorney-General, the Auditor-General and, indeed, by the Government.

I find it totally unacceptable for a firm of this size with considerable dealings with the Government to accept funds into its books illegally to facilitate such a scheme or arrangement. It is really astonishing that those dealing so closely with government expenditure have had virtually no sanction applied to them. One cannot help but wonder whether there is one rule or procedure for the public at large and another for employees or subcontractors working for the Federal Government.

It is indeed a sad day for parliament that a report such as this has had to be tabled. I remind honourable senators that initially, had the Presiding Officers taken a more active management role, then perhaps this sorry episode may not have happened. I regret that I have to say this, but the Presiding Officers have the sorts of responsibilities of company directors and should have exercised their powers at the time accordingly. They do now, but they did not then.

It appears that there is a view that devolution of responsibilities through the ranks absolves the delegator, in this case, the Presiding Officers. The Parliamentary Librarian received a verbal wrap across the knuckles for not drawing the matter to the attention of the Presiding Officers and for the length of time taken to call in the Auditor-General to investigate rumours concerning the existence of an unofficial account. He was also admonished for having engaged a consultant whose field of expertise was not auditing and who was therefore unable to provide authoritative advice.

However, the Parliamentary Librarian's responsibilities were by then difficult to exercise as a result of the ambiguous reporting responsibilities, a reporting arrangement which was instigated from above and which was far from satisfactory. But it is one that finds its way into a number of Commonwealth areas. This is rather serious. The managers of the Parliamentary Information Systems Office were allowed direct access to the Presiding Officers on information systems matters, thereby bypassing the Parliamentary Librarian.

The issue of organisational charts taking the place of responsible dotted lines of authority is anathema to normal procedures, and yet this was allowed. We still find it in examinations by the Joint Committee on Public Accounts of many departments and statutory authorities. It is just not good enough. Responsibilities must be clarified and detailed. Organisational charts tend to be the excuse, on the one hand, for unnecessary meddling and, on other occasions, the reason for non-performance. Therefore, I call on the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of Finance to focus attention on the shortcomings of diffused accountability and to clarify a very unsatisfactory position which is widespread across the public sector. I add that this dotted line diffusion no longer applies in the case of the Parliamentary Information Systems Office.

The reporting arrangements put in place by the Presiding Officers tend to diminish the Parliamentary Librarian's ability to exercise his authority over PISO. However, as a departmental secretary, which is what the Parliamentary Librarian is, he had a statutory responsibility to assert his control. In this case it was a formidable task, given the uncertainties of the scope of his authority, when the offending parties had the opportunity of bypassing him. Others in similar roles within the Public Service should take note of this unfortunate situation which arose to ensure that the same thing does not happen to them.
The situation was not helped by an absence of internal audit, and thus we have the recommendation of the Joint Committee on Public Accounts:
Each parliamentary department that has not already done so should establish, as a matter of priority, an adequately resourced internal audit function.

In addition, there was a lack of minuting of major decisions, which smacks of unprofessionalism in management. The current fashion in the public sector is to concentrate on outputs rather than inputs. Thus we now have a system where senior officers claim to be unaware of financial obligations and unaware of parliamentary requirements with regard to Finance directives.

Hopefully, for the first and last time, a situation has arisen where a private account was established into which funds from the sales of Commonwealth assets were deposited. These funds were then used for dubious purposes. Right at the centre of the democratic system such things should never have happened. We expect officers to perform according to the law and to establish correct procedures. The positions of the Presiding Officers are akin to those of directors and managers, but one does not get the fruits of office without the detailed responsibilities of management.

I believe that in the initial case the Presiding Officers cannot be absolved from some neglect. However, I am pleased to report that, having taken upon themselves responsibilities in this area, they are now highly professional and efficient, but at the time they left themselves open to question, not that they received any benefit or that they were involved in any way. As the chief executive officers, they had the ultimate responsibility to ensure that there were proper systems and procedures so that these sorts of practices were impossible. The report now acknowledges that the Presiding Officers take a more active role and have implemented adequate control procedures. I regret that this has been necessary.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 March, on motion by Senator Aulich:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not speak for very long, but I want to draw the attention of the Senate to a couple of issues in relation to the report Active Citizenship Revisited. As honourable senators would be aware, the report is the second in about 18 months on the same issue. I think it is fair enough to indicate that, in about a year or 18-months time, we will again look at the issue to see what has been done so far and to see whether, in fact, our original recommendations have been carried out and whether matters have improved throughout Australia in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a very good reason for that. All too often very good Senate committee reports are brought into this chamber, debated and then left on a shelf. Governments respond within the appropriate time. Sometimes governments take up some of the issues and recommendations. On many occasions they do not. Some reports are responded to with a degree of alacrity. Others are not responded to in the appropriate time, and the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training has from time to time made comments about that too.

Above all else, though, it is essential for all honourable senators to ensure that reports that come into this chamber, given that the vast majority of them have been the product of a great deal of intellectual and political effort, ought not to be left to gather dust on a shelf. They ought to be responded to, not only by governments, but also by the bureaucrats who advise governments and who are responsible for carrying out any decisions governments may make as a result of reading and studying the reports.

Active Citizenship Revisited is the second report in what I hope will be a series of reviews about the way democracy is promoted in our society. I once again remind the Senate that only a handful of democracies have existed continuously since the turn of this century. Luckily, Australia happens to be one of them. Democracy is not just something that drops out of heaven as a gift to all of us and is here to stay forever. It is something which requires the efforts, the understanding, the education and the participation of the whole community in order to ensure that it does continue and is an active method of government.

This report made many recommendations and assessed the current improvements that have been made in the teaching of active citizenship throughout this country. The State education Ministers at their annual meeting in Hobart accepted that the teaching of active citizenship should be one of the 10 major factors or issues to be taught in the school curricula. In other words, it was elevated to an essentially important position in education throughout Australia. The big question, of course, is now whether or not that theoretical decision to make active citizenship so important a part of the curriculum for all Australian school students will be followed up in practice. In other words, are the resources to be put aside? Is thinking going to be done which will enable, for example, appropriate resources-that is, teaching materials-to be made available? Are teachers to be trained in the appropriate way? Will courses be written which are imaginative and realistic and which encourage students to involve themselves actively in democracy around them-that is, in their own local councils, sports clubs, local communities and, of course, ultimately in politics in general?

It is a big question and it is something that is not going to happen overnight. It will happen as a result of a long, calculated campaign on the part of all politicians-all people in government, including local government-and all teachers who have an interest in ensuring that Australia remains not only a democratic society but a fundamentally viable democratic society. It is all very well for us to be in this chamber and feel that democracy is doing very nicely out there in the community, thank you very much, but I can assure the Senate that the practice of democracy is not just what goes on this in this chamber. It is also a question of whether, for example, the voters out there are informed, whether they are interested rather than apathetic about political issues, and whether they are prepared to put in for themselves-to say, for example, not `they ought to do it' but `we will do it'. If we are to look for a slogan which summarises the whole question of active citizenship, it is just that: replacing `they ought to' with `we will'.

That applies to every aspect of people's lives, from the relationships that exist within their own family to the schools which they teach in or go to as students, to the local council, the local sporting club or whatever. It is a question of giving people the skills in order to give them the enthusiasm, the confidence and the self-respect to be active participants in the groups to which they belong. Active Citizenship Revisited is a second report. I hope it will not be the last and I hope that each report indicates a clear progression or improvement in the way we approach the teaching of democracy in this country.

I leave the Senate with one thought in relation to the type of materials which are available in schools not only for students but also for the teachers. Our first report indicated that many teachers are not at all at home with the teaching of political science, let alone the general techniques of teaching active citizenship. That applies particularly in years 11 and 12 where, for example, many students for many reasons deliberately choose not to take political science. That is partly because the subject is not interesting and partly because it does not seem to carry the prestige which would enable one to get a better choice when one enters university.

I draw to the Senate's attention the fact that I understand that former Senators Macklin, Puplick and Black are currently working on a project which would provide course materials for years 11 and 12 students and for teachers involving a very modern, realistic and imaginative approach to the teaching of politics. The members of this group come from three political parties. I am sure the project will be challenging. They have certainly got their ideas together in terms of the techniques they will use. It will not be just written material but will involve computer files and videotapes-in other words, the whole caboodle.

In this way, for the first time, we may get some really interesting and exciting material not only into the hands of years 11 and 12 students but also into the hands of the teachers themselves, who in many cases need a lot of education in this area. I wish those three former senators the best of luck in this project. As I said, if I were going to take a punt on whether or not it would sell and be very effective, I think I would choose these three people to put together that particular work. The three major parties in this chamber, no doubt, will all rush out and buy copies of it. They will be waiting for it to appear on the bookshelf. For the first time since I have been in the Senate I am actually doing a little promo for those others who have left this chamber.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I thank you for your time. Above all else, I need to say that the cooperation that I have received as Chairman from past and present members of the Committee in this area has been extremely encouraging. It is fair to say that on this Committee there has been a genuine tripartisan approach to the issue, because all of the Committee members recognise just how important an issue this is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very glad to have the opportunity to support the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, Senator Aulich, on the report Active Citizenship Revisited. I want to make a few further remarks on this concept and the importance of this report. Active citizenship is defined in the report as:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a compound of knowledge, skills and attitudes: knowledge about how society works; the skills needed to participate effectively; and a conviction that active participation is the right of all citizens.
The report clarifies the role of active citizenship as:
. . . participation and empowerment as well as formal knowledge of institutionalised parliamentary and political processes.
The previous report issued by the Committee entitled Education for Active Citizenship found:
. . . most young people's knowledge of parliamentary politics remains woefully inadequate.

We also found that there was a serious discrepancy between curriculum theory and classroom practice. The Committee was presented with evidence which created a bleak picture of ignorance and apathy. In Australia there is a lack of knowledge of the political process, a marked lack of interest in the political process and a lack of innovative programs to correct this. The Committee was presented with a number of reasons for this situation. Parents and schools are more inclined towards curricula that appear to lead to employment rather than social education. Initiatives require support which is not available. There is a lack of curriculum materials. Some political studies courses have turned into a boring collection of mental stodge. Teachers tend to retreat to the safety of a neutral approach to the subject-facts and figures rather than stimulating debate.

It seems that one of the reasons why teachers do not do enough in this area is that they have difficulty with the problem of teaching values, since values vary with individuals and with different social groups. One of the contributions that I was able to make to this report related to this question of values. I indicated that one of the ways of resolving the dilemma was to distinguish between `procedural' and `substantive' values. Substantive values are the beliefs that people hold, such as their views on a particular political issue. A teacher should teach about these values and facilitate informed debate rather than impose their views on students. Procedural values are those values that we all support in a democratic society: freedom, toleration, fairness, respect for truth and respect for reasoning.

These are the key values which underpin democratic society. It is both proper and desirable for teachers to nurture and strengthen these in students. The Committee emphasises in the report the importance of values learning on the part of students rather than values teaching on the part of the teacher. The Committee spelt this out very clearly, as follows:
Teachers should give students the opportunity to examine a range of value positions as the basis for forming their own judgments.

That is, on political matters. I emphasise that education for active citizenship is a different way of teaching. It is, in fact, active learning. There are a number of activities which are appropriate to this, including mock parliaments, debates on political issues, media tracking and analysis and field trips, to name just a few. The Committee found in its latest report throughout the nation over 20 innovative programs which use these types of active learning experiences.

Recently in my own city there was an excellent example of an active citizenship program in action. A group of students were brought into the Newcastle City Council chambers and, in a mock parliament, went through all of the procedures relating to the second reading of a Bill. This is exactly the kind of program which the Committee had in mind when we reasserted at the end of the report our strong belief in the importance of providing citizens with a thorough induction into the mechanisms of parliamentary democracy, with a clear understanding of their rights and responsibilities as citizens, and with the motivation to participate actively in the creation of the country's future.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I will now rule on the points of order taken in relation to the motion by Senator Olsen to require the tabling of a certain document. During the adjournment of the debate I have consulted with Mr President and the Clerk of the Senate, and kept in mind the arguments which were presented to me on the points of order. Mr President agrees with the ruling as follows.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Olsen signed and handed in his motion. The signed motion is taken to be the motion as moved, and it is on the basis of that motion that I make my ruling. Standing order 164 provides that the Senate may order the tabling of any document and there are no exemptions or exceptions in the standing order. It is for the Senate to determine whether any motion for the tabling of the document should be passed. There are a number of precedents for legal advices and other advices to Ministers being tabled in response to orders of the Senate, and there are also precedents for Ministers arguing that legal advices should not be tabled.

The argument which the Senate has heard really goes to the question of whether the motion moved by Senator Olsen should be passed, rather than whether the motion is in order. If the responsible Minister considers that there are reasons for not tabling the document, that is a matter which may be argued in debate on the motion. If the motion is passed, it is then for the Minister to decide whether to comply with the order of the Senate. There is no doubt that the motion is in order under standing order 164, and the question of whether the document should be ordered to be tabled is for the Senate to consider and determine. I call Senator Olsen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the motion that I have moved, I want to deal with it in three parts: the importance of this issue; why advice that the Government has received from Mr Burdekin is important, and why it ought to be available to this Senate; and why that ought to be tabled now. We are talking about issues of fundamental importance which can be best summarised by a group called Article 19. I will quote from a release from that group dated 19 March. I preface my remarks by saying that Article 19 is the International Centre Against Censorship. It is a London-based international human rights organisation which works impartially to defend the right to freedom of expression and to campaign against censorship around the world. In other words, it is equivalent to Amnesty International. In relation to the Government's legislation that we have before us today, Article 19's press release claims that it will:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . constitute an unnecessary intrusion on freedom of political expression.

. . . the Australian government's proposals go beyond these acceptable limits. The Government's stated need to guard against corruption should not infringe the right to freedom of expression-the Government shouldn't throw the baby out with the bathwater.
It goes on to say:

It is common political wisdom that access to the news media gives tremendous advantage to the government party. All-out denial of access to the media whether by denying political advertising or free-time will benefit incumbents and does not create a level playing field for all parties and lobby groups.
It continues:

The electronic media plays an important role in the democratic right to influence public opinion. Political parties and lobby groups which demonstrate a desire and need to have access to the electronic media should be granted this access.

Those comments from Article 19-from an organisation protecting the rights of freedom of expression throughout the world-clearly demonstrate the importance of the issue that we are debating here. I think the importance is also underscored by the lengths to which the Government has gone this evening in an attempt to not have this motion debated before this House and the lengths to which the Government wants to ensure that the documentation-the advice received from Mr Burdekin-does not go onto the public record. There can be only one reason for that: the Government is embarrassed by the report of Mr Burdekin, in that it clearly challenges the legislation and the Government's direction as infringing the rights of Australians.

Over the last three days I have raised a number of questions which have gone to the heart of this matter: the heart of democracy in Australia, the fundamental right of people and the freedom of expression of people in this country. In these questions I clearly identified-and the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) did not deny any one of the allegations contained in the questions-that the development of this legislation is impermissible under the covenant. He referred to some Attorney-General's advice but he did not go on to rebut Mr Burdekin's advice, which is, I understand, well argued in a lengthy document.

Nor did he rebut the fact that the Government's legislation takes another step. The most serious effect of the ban relates to the impact on the accessibility to information of blind and other sight-impaired Australians who presently number some 110,000. In addition to that, more than one million Australians are functionally illiterate. As I understand it, the advice goes on to say that a ban on political advertising, as the Government is proposing in the electronic media, is likely to have a discriminatory impact on these people's right to take part in public affairs. What we are talking about here is infringing upon the rights of a group of Australians and taking away their right to participate fully in public affairs of this country.

That is what Mr Burdekin is putting to the Government and that is the advice that the Government is trying to keep from the Australian people, the Senate and the House of Representatives. Article 19 also makes the point that the distinction between free speech and bought speech is neither sustainable nor helpful in the context of ascertaining our international legal obligations. It has been clearly pointed out by Article 19-whether it be point two or point three-that Australia has international obligations. We guarantee people, as Australian residents, the right to freedom of speech, the right to participate in democracy and the right to be activists within our community. That is what we are talking about: individual and fundamental rights for Australians. The Government's proposal would remove those rights.

A London-based organisation, which is the equivalent of Amnesty International, has clearly highlighted how the Government's proposals are removing those rights from Australians. The Minister for Administrative Services, in response to the questions I have asked in the course of this week, has not denied that there are 110,000 people in the Australian community who are sight-impaired in some way and that there are one million people who are functionally illiterate whom this legislation will discriminate against. The Minister offered no defence in answering the questions that I put to him during this week-no defence at all.

Honourable senators will recall that on each occasion I asked that he put that advice before the Parliament so that we can make a value judgment on it. In addition to that, I stressed today that the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters report entitled Who pays the piper calls the tune, to which the Minister consistently in this House, in press releases and in the public arena has used as the basis for the need for this legislation--

TALK.START.PARA: —Abused.

—Yes, he has, because it is misleading and incomplete in some respects-apparently we had Mr Burdekin's advice to the Government-and to the extent that the report may have materially misled the Government. If that is the case, why is the Government pursuing this matter? Why is the Government not prepared to take this advice on board? I understand that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in the House of Representatives today-he made some acknowledgment-that the Government is going to re-assess its position on the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I certainly hope that that happens, and quickly, because what the Government is proposing denies what are fundamental rights of Australians. Article 19 of the International Covenant of Civil and Political Rights is quite clear and specific as to what it guarantees to Australians. It is important that these rights be maintained. Article 19 (2) states:

Everyone shall have the right to freedom of expression; this right shall include freedom to seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kinds, regardless of frontiers, either orally, in writing or in print, in the form of art, or through any other media of his choice.

I would have thought that what is clearly spelt out in Article 19 of that covenant, to which we are a signatory and of which we are a supporter and which we attempt to guarantee as part of our international obligations, is being thwarted by the Government's legislative direction. Mr Burdekin has said as much to the Government. I find it interesting, and perhaps a sad irony, that in February 1986 Senator Bolkus, in arguing for the establishment of the Human Rights Commission said:
There is no doubt that our legal protections fall short in many respects of internationally accepted standards.

That is what Senator Bolkus said in 1986, yet here he is today the architect of legislation that takes away the internationally accepted standards to which Australia is a guarantor and a signatory. We need to ensure that Australia's undertaking to uphold the right of free speech is actually put into practice, that we practise what we preach, and that we put into effect what our international obligations are.

The Government set up the Commission so that it could act as a public watchdog as regards public abuses of human rights. That is its charter. It is an independent body charged with the responsibility of protecting the human rights of Australians. In this instance, the Government has conveniently chosen to muzzle the Commission, I suggest, in order to mislead and misinform the public. This calls into question in a very serious, fundamental and important way the direction that the Government is taking.

The documentation that we are asking to have tabled goes far beyond the category of departmental or ministerial information. It contains advice that is crucial not only to the internal politics of our country but also to our standing overseas. That is how important and how crucial this issue is. It contains advice which tackles the issues of freedom of expression and freedom of speech. To use the words of Franklin Roosevelt in 1941:
The world must be founded upon four essential freedoms.

The first of them is freedom of speech and expression, which is tackled by the Government in the legislation before the Parliament. Why do we want this advice? Surely the Parliament has a right to see advice from the Australian Human Rights Commissioner that legislation to ban political advertising is a contravention of our basic democratic right of freedom of expression and speech. To refuse the Australian community access to this information is a crime far beyond even that of the political advertising legislation. Surely, no Minister or government has the right to hide or ignore advice from the Human Rights Commissioner about an infringement of the freedom of speech and expression of Australians. This goes to the very point of calling into question our obligations internationally to meet the guaranteeing and standing up for those international obligations.

Another question is: why now? The issue is important. That is clear beyond doubt. The Human Rights Commissioner's view on this is important. He is the public watchdog on human rights in this country, as established by the Parliament. I have demonstrated clearly how the proposed legislation infringes on the fundamental human rights of Australians. Why should we have this right now? We want this advice now because the matter is to be debated in the House of Representatives on Tuesday week, 28 May, where the guillotine is applying at the moment. The Parliament is expected to debate this important piece of legislation without very important and fundamental advice being made available to the Parliament so that it can judge that legislation.
Senator Powell interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —We are opposed to it. In addition to that, I point out that this matter will be subject to a series of amendments, as Senator Powell has said publicly. Certainly, the advice of the Human Rights Commissioner is fundamentally important to the direction and ultimate result of legislation coming from this Parliament. We will be required to debate this in but a week's time, yet the Government is denying the Parliament advice that is crucial and fundamentally important to the very foundation--
—It is not.
—The honourable senator says it is not, but I say that it is.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Powell interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad Senator Powell has raised this. That is the line from the Government. It is interesting that Senator Powell should be using the Government's defence, which it has used for a couple of days. The Government's defence is that the advice that it got from Mr Burdekin was before the Bill was drawn up. On Tuesday this week, the Minister had a meeting with Mr Burdekin in his office--
—That was after 20 March.

—Exactly, and the point I make is that the advice that was given earlier to the Government over the course of this period and the advice given to the Government subsequent to the Bill being introduced in Parliament has not changed. That is why Mr Burdekin was summoned to the Minister's office on Tuesday night, where they had a very frank exchange of views, and the Human Rights Commissioner has not changed his original advice. Whether that advice was tendered the day before the Bill was introduced or one month before the Bill was introduced is irrelevant. The advice of the Human Rights Commissioner is the same today as it was a month ago. The Government's defence that his advice was based on something other than legislation is totally irrelevant to this argument. The advice is the same today as it was a month ago. Therefore, the advice tendered is the advice that this Parliament ought to have in its possession, and is the advice on which it will make a judgment about this legislation.
—You can make a judgment without having his advice; you have to agree with that.

—Of course one can make a judgment without his advice. My point is that the advice has been tendered. It is highly critical of the Government's approach. The advice of the Human Rights Commissioner has been totally consistent throughout. It has not changed as a result of the legislation being introduced. That advice tendered on whatever day is relevant to this Parliament in making an assessment as to how the passage of this legislation will proceed between the two Houses and what amendments might or might not be acceptable to the two Houses. The point I make is that if in a week's time we are going to have to address this legislation, surely we are entitled to the advice from the public watchdog, the independent statutory authority-the Human Rights Commissioner-and to know what his attitude is. We are not asking for a Cabinet document. It is not a memorandum specifically from one of the officers of the Minister; it concerns advice forwarded over a period of time to the Minister from the Human Rights Commission, the public watchdog, on behalf of all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: That is why this advice is important, why the issue is important, and why it is important to this Parliament to have that advice now so that we can consider it in considering the legislation about to come before the Parliament. The denial of that information to the Parliament, on which it can make a value judgment, is denying the Parliament the opportunity to look at what is clearly important and fundamental advice to the Government on a very important and fundamental piece of legislation.

The Government's only excuse for not presenting that advice-and it went to some length to tell us-was that it did not have to present that advice. I note Senator Ray's comments earlier wherein he said that, if the motion were passed, his advice to the Minister would be not to table it. `It is not enforceable. Go to Crete. Do not worry about it for the next week or 10 days'. That is the advice that Senator Ray is proposing, so from those comments I assume-and I hope that it is not right-that, if the motion happens to be passed by this Senate, then the Government will perhaps accept that advice and not table it. If the Government were to proceed with the course of action suggested by Senator Ray, that would be a very serious matter. This advice demonstrates the concern of the Government about this advice, and how it undermines the thrust of its legislation. Therefore, it does not want to have that advice out now. It does not want its legislation undermined. It does not want the truth out about its legislative proposals.

As a result of that, by all means available to the Government, it is going to attempt to suppress this advice that has been tendered over the past month or two by the Human Rights Commissioner. I commend the motion to the House. I trust the Senate will acknowledge that this issue is fundamentally important to Australia-not only now, but also for our future-and that Mr Burdekin's advice is important. It is his advice as the public watchdog that we should, in my view, be entitled to see. It is important that we have it now because the Government is bringing the legislation on in a week's time and is applying the guillotine in another place to the passage of that legislation. For all those reasons, I trust that the Senate will support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to reiterate the fact that the Government opposes the motion before the chamber. We oppose it on two grounds, the first of which has been substantially canvassed already in this place. It is the long-held view of the Government-both this Government and former governments-that it is untenable for governments to be forced to publicly release advice and other forms of consultation. Already I have referred to Odgers on this issue. We have referred to eminent Prime Ministers-I referred to Sir Robert Menzies and my colleague the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) mentioned Mr Harold Holt-who have also reinforced that attitude. I do not think I need to reiterate that now. The basic point is that the decision is up to government; it is privilege of the Executive to decide what documents should or should not be tabled and that is a position to which I adhere.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to this document or any other document, my view is that, even if the Senate were to pass the motion tonight, I would make an assessment of that document and then make a decision as to whether it should be tabled. It is not up to the Senate to decide-that has been pretty well established. Even in your ruling this evening, Mr Deputy President, you made the point that there is a discretion for the Minister to decide whether to comply; I think those were your words. That reinforces the position I have put forward.

It is even more important in that we are talking about documents which Senator Olsen believes were tendered to the Government before the proposals were formulated. The Bill was not formulated on the date on which the documents that Senator Olsen requests are supposed to have been sent. In fact, the Bill was not formulated until early May. We have had discussions this week with the Human Rights Commissioner. It is part of an ongoing consultative process with him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is a most important debate. We are trying to listen hard to the argument of defence that the Minister is trying to put forward. He is mumbling again; he is impossible to hear. I ask that he speak up so that we can hear the words he is trying hard to enunciate.

—Order! I am finding it difficult to hear the Minister, not because of his articulation, but because of the conversation that is going on on my left. Not only is there conversation going on on my left, there have also been interjections from honourable senators on my left. Senator Olsen was heard in silence. This is an important issue and I expect the Minister to be heard in silence as well.
—I accept what you said about the interjections and about the conversation, but I am, in all seriousness, asking that the Minister speak up. He really is inaudible and he is mumbling.
—I do not agree that he is mumbling, but I assume that the Minister has heard what you have said.

—In responding to that, I suggest to Senator Bishop that if she does have problems, she can get a hearing aid; it will not detract from her physical appearance. We are talking here not only of government advice, but advice that was tendered during the consultative process. The Bill was not formulated at the time that the document that Senator Olsen requests appeared.
—You rude little twit.
—Order! Senator Knowles, that was totally out of order and you will withdraw that remark.
—Are you saying that that is unparliamentary?
—I am.
—I withdraw and I will keep my opinion. You are rude.
—Senator Knowles! You will withdraw that remark and you will withdraw unconditionally.
—I withdraw.

— I do not want to labour this particular point for very long, because as I say, it has been canvassed already. I reiterate the point I made earlier that there are mechanisms for the disclosure of documents. The Senate and Senate committees have deliberated on those mechanisms; freedom of information legislation was the product of that and I suggest that that legislation provides the legal framework for the release of documents. In closing on this point, it is a long-held principle that it is up to the Government to decide what documents are or are not disclosed. In this respect, regardless of the resolution of the Senate, the Government will consider the document in question and decide what to do with it accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: It is rather ironic that the basic principle expressed by Senator Olsen goes to the question of human rights and freedom of speech. It is quite ironic that it comes from the Opposition side of the Parliament. As I have said many times over recent weeks, it has been that side of Parliament which has consistently, in this forum and outside, opposed measures to entrench, either through constitutional amendment or by legislation, the protection of basic individual rights in our society.

I do not have to go through a long record but, for the sake of interest, I go briefly to examples in recent years. In particular, let us look at the body we are talking about tonight, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. This Commission was put in place to implement a covenant signed by the Whitlam Government and ratified by the Fraser Government.

Once in opposition, the coalition lost its interest in supporting human rights. In 1985-86, the Opposition vehemently opposed this Government's attempt through Bill of Rights legislation to entrench the covenant in law. It was this coalition which opposed the creation of the new Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in 1986. The Commission was responsible for monitoring Australia's observance of our obligations under the covenant. Is it not ironic that Opposition senators, who are still committed to abolishing the role of Mr Brian Burdekin, to abolishing the Commission, come in here and look to that Commission-in some sort of fantasy that Senator Olsen seems to be involving himself in-and see it as an arbiter of human rights?

If it is so important in entrenching and protecting human rights in this country, why do Senator Hill and Senator Olsen not change their policy? Why do they not support its existence, its continuation? They have had a policy of opposing it as a creation for a good part of five years and they still have that policy. So they should not come in here with utter hypocrisy and claim that we should entrust our legislative framework to the Human Rights Commissioner when they want to abolish him and his role.

It is not just that. We have tried to entrench human rights through basic freedoms in our Constitution, through constitutional amendment-amendments which were proposed and endorsed by a very broad ranging committee of Australian citizens, including the former Liberal Premier of Victoria, Sir Rupert Hamer. The Constitutional Commission proposed a number of amendments to our Constitution to protect some basic rights: rights to freedom of religion; a right to vote; the right to one vote one value; the right to trial by jury; fair compensation and so on.

Who opposed them? Who opposed them stridently in this place by way of filibuster? Who opposed them out in the electorate? Who led to their defeat in terms of their potential to be enshrined in our Australian Constitution? It was the Opposition. The Opposition's attitude has not changed. The degree of duplicity that has been shown over the years by the Opposition continues. Only last weekend we saw a press statement put out by Senator Olsen, of all people, wishing once again to mislead the Australian public.

What did he say in his press statement? He said two things. The Government's Political Broadcast and Political Disclosures Bill was `a trick' he said. It is not true disclosure because we are not covering our trade union-I think the word is in there somewhere- `mates'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Comrades.
—Comrades. It is very clear that any person with half a brain reading the Bill would see that union donations and union affiliation fees are going to be transparent under the Government's proposals.
—Not affiliation fees.

—In respect of affiliation fees as well the trade union movement annually-and has to-disclosed its donations by way of gifts or affiliation fees to a political party by the mere fact that every year it has to disclose its expenditure and income statements to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The trade union movement has had that obligation for years. Those fees will be even more transparent under this proposal. They have been transparent in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: But what about the other point of trickery? Very much in line with what has been presented tonight, Senator Olsen says-and I must admit, he is a new boy, so he may not have known about this-and I quote:

We are determined to ensure that Senator Robert Ray's statements to the Senate in November 1983 and again on 19th February 1988 when he said, `with regard to Disclosure, there will always be a way round'---

Senator Olsen says that the Opposition will make sure they `do not become law'. The reason why there has been `a way round' the last few years has been the trenchant opposition from the other side. Opposition senators are the ones who rendered ineffective the spot audit provisions in the legislation. As recently as 18 months ago the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters said:

Spot audits on a random basis at the whim of the Commissioner, however, would introduce a further increment of bureaucratic power that would be intolerable to democracy. The purpose of such spot audits,-
and this is a real gem-
as expressed by the Commissioner would be to enable the AEC to say with a clearer conscience and more confidence that `everything appears to be satisfactory'.
What did Opposition senators' comrades say?
This is not sufficient reason to trifle with free, democratic processes.

That is the reason why we have the disclosure legislation that we have now. The Government made it very clear at the start of this process that we recognise and respect the international covenant on civil and political rights. I have also made it very clear from the start that we have had very clear advice from the Attorney-General's Department-our advisers-that we are within the ambits of that covenant.

It is quite easy for the Opposition to quote in here and outside article 19 (2) of that covenant. It is a very specific and general provision. But there is 19 (3). Article 19 (2) provides and guarantees the rights to freedom of expression. This right is not and never has been absolute. When it comes to things like censorship legislation, banning videos, and things as trifling as telephone indexes, it is the Opposition that recognises that there can be an exception on the grounds of public health or morals in that case. Article 19 (3) of the covenant says that we can make exceptions for the protection of national security or of public order. From the start, we have recognised the steps taken--

TALK.START.PARA: —You will find no exception limiting free political speech.
—Our primary concern in this matter has been and always will be, unlike Opposition senators, to prevent potential corruption and undue influence of the political process. Our ban on advertising ---

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: I ask the Minister to withdraw that remark. He said that his intention, the Government's intention, is, unlike mine, to get rid of corruption. He is implying that I have an intention to maintain any existing levels of corruption, which I, quite frankly, would have thought, with what is going on in Western Australia, is a bit of a long bow for the Minister to be drawing. I am offended by it and I ask that he withdraw it, unreservedly.

—I withdraw. The point I was making was that we believe our ban on political advertising is a proportionate and necessary response to these problems. Article 19 is general but it is not absolute and there are quite a number of instances, whether it comes to the airwaves or anywhere else in our society, where the qualifications to that article are spelled out.

SPEECH.PARA: All the advice the Government has received has recognised that steps to prevent corruption or undue influence of the democratic process would fall within the limitation of public order, that being under article 19 (3) of the covenant. There is only one person who actually argues strongly against that and that is `Professor' Olsen, but let me say that the considered view of our advisers is that we fall squarely within that limitation on public order, and we have stated that consistently.

In the second reading speech we stated the Government is satisfied that the proposals are a necessary and proportionate response to the threat of potential corruption and undue influence. We have carefully considered the implications of the proposed restrictions on the right to freedom of expression. Senator Olsen has very gladly in one case pointed out tonight that I was a supporter of legislation ---

TALK.START.PARA: —If you are so sure you are right, why not release the advice?
—Order! I have asked that Senator Bolkus be heard in silence.

—Senator Olsen has pointed out that I was a supporter of legislation in 1986, and I in fact support it now. But I am mature enough to understand that there are qualifications in that covenant and I am also advised, very firmly, that what we are doing is within those qualifications. Let me reiterate: all the advice that we have had has recognised that steps taken to prevent corruption or undue influence of the democratic process would fall within the limitation of public order. So we are satisfied that the ban, for the stated purposes, does not constitute a breach of potential corruption of our obligations under international law.

SPEECH.PARA: There is some cynicism about this particular point-the proportionate and necessary response to the problem. But the threat of corruption and undue influence was demonstrated not only in the report of the Joint Standing Committee but it has been recognised by the Fitzgerald inquiry and by Commissioner Roden of the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption. They have referred to the threat in their reports and I do not have to go through those reports once again to indicate their level of concern.

There are royal commissions currently under way in Tasmania and Western Australia. They are considering related matters. The Saulwick national poll arising out of all that indicated very strongly that 76 per cent of respondents believed political donations were made to buy influence. That is the sort of threat to public order the Government is concerned about and that is the sort of threat we are tackling, and we are tackling that in the only way possible-the only necessary and proportionate response to the problem.

Up to $17m was spent on electronic advertising at the last election. This point should not be missed because it points to the potential threat of corruption and undue influence to our democratic process. We believe that that threat requires an urgent response and we have considered all the options and all the alternatives. We have looked at free time, caps on expenditure and disclosure in itself. Free time and caps on expenditure do have problems. Disclosure on its own does not answer the problem.

Even John Howard, the former Opposition Leader, has made that point-disclosure of its own does not solve the problem. It only addresses one part of the problem. Unless the need for funds is stopped this interrelationship between the corporate sector and government will never be stopped in terms of supplying funds for campaigns.

It is a proportionate response. It is a necessary one. It applies to advertising alone. I do not really have to go on at length on this particular point but what are we talking about? We are talking about advertising. News, current affairs and editorial comment will continue to operate. We are talking about political advertising, a commercial transaction, which members of the Opposition in the report of the Joint Standing Committee on this matter indicated their position on very clearly. They rejected as absurd the assertion that political advertising is socially good. I will not say much more on this. All I will say in conclusion is that we are advised, and we are quite sure, that we are acting within article 19 in its entirety.

In respect of this particular document that has been asked for tonight, whether the motion is passed or not, I will have to make a decision on the merits of that document as to whether I table it or not. What I will say though is that we are talking about, allegedly, a document that goes to the Government's proposal. Commissioner Burdekin has not advised us on the Bill. He received that late last Thursday night. We are having discussions with him, and I anticipate that we will get some constructive proposals from Commissioner Burdekin during the course of those discussions.

When I get advice on the Bill, I will sympathetically consider making that available, but of course I will have to take everything into consideration, including the view of the Senate as it may be expressed, but more particularly the advice of the Commissioner and what is embodied in it. I give the undertaking that when that advice on the Bill is received, as opposed to on the proposal, I will sympathetically consider making that available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have listened to some debate supposedly on a motion put forward by Senator Olsen. Much of it has not been relevant, in my view, to the motion, so I think it is important that we know what we are talking about. Senator Olsen wants the Senate to require the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) to table written advice received from Human Rights Commissioner Burdekin dated 20 March referring to a proposal by the Government which subsequently has come before the Parliament in the form of legislation. That legislation came before the Parliament-it was tabled in the House of Representatives-last Thursday, 9 May.

SPEECH.PARA: I have noted the Minister's remarks both in his answer to the question today put by Senator Olsen and at the end of his response to Senator Olsen's motion just now. The Minister in answer to the question today commented that Commissioner Burdekin had some difficulties with the Government's proposal, and I think we all read in the newspapers that that was the case. The Minister then went on, as he did just now, to say that now that there is legislation, which Commissioner Burdekin has to hand, there are discussions going on and he expects to receive some advice, and that if he does he will consider making that advice available to the Senate.

The first point made by the Minister is one for us to focus on, and that is about the Government's right to make public or not to make public certain documents. I believe that if a government-any government-is to be asked to table documents of advice and to make them public, there needs to be a very strong argument of public interest. Where that is in the public interest, those documents should be made public. Therefore, I listened to Senator Olsen's remarks on that basis. If any government is to be asked under such a blanket standing order as standing order 164 to make documents available, there is a very strong argument of public interest. I believe that when there is advice from an important figure in this discussion, such as Commissioner Burdekin, as I believe there will be, on legislation which we will be considering here, and which will be considered in the House of Representatives prior to that, there could very well be a strong element of public interest in that advice being available to legislators, and through the Senate that might well be able to be the case.

Apart from what the Minister has said and from what one has read in the newspapers that there was some adverse reaction by Commissioner Burdekin to the Government's original proposal, I think we can remember that there was an adverse reaction from a great many people to the Government's original proposal. Indeed, there was an adverse reaction from the Opposition, and the decision has been made to reject the Government's proposal for a blanket ban on all political advertising. There was an adverse reaction on that very point also from my own Party and we, too, have made the decision to oppose a blanket ban on all political advertising.

What we are now facing, as Senator Olsen said, is legislation which the Government has gone ahead with, putting a proposal for a blanket ban on political advertising, even though it knows that neither the Australian Democrats nor the Opposition is prepared to support that legislation. Therefore it knows that that legislation will be amended. It is that legislation and the preparation for amendments which I think is the issue-not necessarily the proposal which was floated in a press release with a couple of pages of attachments by the Minister, which led to the public debate and to the decisions already made by the Opposition and by the Democrats. That has been done. It has gone; it is not relevant.

What is relevant is the Bill that was introduced in the House of Representatives last Thursday night. I submit to the Minister that it is relevant and of interest. Unless he can argue for some reason or other when he does get the advice and information from the Commissioner on the Bill--

TALK.START.PARA: —He has already got it.

—I would suggest that there would be a very strong public interest in ensuring that, when the amendments come forward to his legislation-which as it now stands is opposed by the majority in this place-we should have that advice. I put that as a submission to the Minister. I noted Senator Walters saying that the Minister already has that advice. If he has, it is not the advice that is the subject of this motion. This motion refers to some advice apparently dated 20 March, which is in the relevant period and is about the Government's proposal, not about the Government's legislation.
—It is the same.

—It seems to me that there is not a significant public interest argument which would override the argument that, unless there is such a significant public interest argument, governments should be able to determine which documents of advice should be available and which should not. I am told by interjection, as was the Minister when he was speaking, that the advice is the same. I find it difficult, first, to find whether that is relevant; and, secondly, to understand how Opposition senators can say that some advice is the same as advice which the Minister tells us he has not yet received. I do not see a strong public interest argument. My Party has made up its mind on the blanket ban; the Liberal Party has made up its mind on the blanket ban. What we are now required to do is look at the legislation and decide on amendments. I would value the advice of the Commissioner for Human Rights, if he has a view. I submit to the Minister that that will be very important to the deliberations of the Democrats and to the Senate at large.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In closing the debate, I should like to make one or two points. First, I was disappointed by the response by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), who acknowledged that the motion was in order and acknowledged that the Senate can pass a motion calling upon a Minister to take a course of action but said that he, the Minister, will make a judgment as to whether he wants to comply with that resolution of the Senate. That is tantamount to thumbing one's nose at a house of parliament expressing a point of view as to the course of action that the Minister ought to take.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to Mr Burdekin's advice and whether the advice that he has tendered to the Government over the last month is relevant now that the Bill has been introduced, I reiterate the point that Mr Burdekin offered advice on the Government's proposal. The Government subsequent to that advice introduced legislation. In telephone discussions that I have had with the Human Rights Commissioner this week, he has clearly indicated to me that the advice he has tendered is consistent with the advice he gave the Minister on Tuesday night and is continuing to hold.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you speak to David?
—Did I what?
—I ask that all interjections cease.

—I make the point that in a telephone conversation with me today Mr Burdekin indicated that the advice he has tendered to the Government will be consistent with any subsequent advice that he might be giving to the Government. Therefore, it is consistent; therefore, it has not changed; and therefore, it is relevant because it contains the arguments that I put earlier when supporting the motion as to why this matter is important, why Mr Burdekin's advice is important, and why it is important for that advice to be available to us now. I do not think that the Minister's response deflected from that. In fact, this evening the Minister's response went on to disclosures and my press release. I am rather pleased that he has taken some notice of a press release that I put out. In other words, he went off and drew a total red herring in regard to the motion before the Senate as it relates to the advice given by the Human Rights Commissioner.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister did not have substantive argument or rebuttal, so he used the old ploy of going off on a tangent and being irrelevant. The Minister quoted article 19.3 of the International Covenant. It states:

Nothing in the present Covenant may be interpreted as implying for any State, group or person any right to engage in any activity or perform any act aimed at the destruction of any of the rights and freedoms recognised herein or at their limitation to a greater extent than is provided in the present Covenant.

That is, the Government is proposing to restrict freedom further. Article 19.3 clearly identifies that that cannot be done. I am absolutely sure that Mr Burdekin's advice to the Government said that article 19.3 does not support what the Government is, in fact, putting in place.

A motion such as this is not moved lightly. It is not moved regularly, as clearly demonstrated by the debate that took place earlier in this chamber, which recognises the importance of this issue before the chamber. I just want to re-emphasise the point that if we are expected to debate an issue of such fundamental importance to Australians, the advice that has been put forward ought to be available for Australians to make a value judgment on the Government's direction. The denial of that right is merely to restrict the debate, merely to ensure--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to have your Cabinet debates in the Senate?

—If Minister Collins had been in the chamber earlier, he would recognise that we are not asking for a Cabinet document and we are not asking for advice specifically from the Minister. We are asking for advice that comes from the public watchdog on human rights in this country, an independent body, an independent organisation-the Human Rights Commissioner. That is what we are talking about. Let us get it right. Mr Deputy President, this issue is important. The advice of Mr Burdekin at this time is important because we are talking about the democratic rights of Australians.
