INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter on the adjournment this evening in relation to parliamentary delegations to Australia from other countries. Past practice has been that these delegations are conducted on a bipartisan basis. In fact, when such delegations take place, quite frequently the parliamentary friendship group that associates itself with that particular country hosts a lunch or a dinner. That is also conducted on a bipartisan basis. What happened yesterday, I hope, was just a minor and occasional blip in what is the accepted practice. I certainly hope it is not an indication of how the Government intends to use these delegations for the remainder of its term. I wish to detail my concerns to the Senate in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday a parliamentary delegation from Italy visited Parliament House. In the morning it had a number of discussions. I think it had discussions with the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson; then with the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security, Mr Con Sciacca; then with the shadow Minister for social security, Senator Alston; and then with Senator Patterson who, as a shadow parliamentary secretary, has a particular interest in social security matters.

Social security matters were of particular interest to the Italian delegation. The Australian-Italian parliamentary friendship group hosted a lunch. At that lunch, I was surprised to find myself at a table with a staffer from the office of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security. I was not surprised to be at a table with a staffer, although one wonders whether government staffers are meant to be included in these friendship group luncheons. But that is not a matter I wish to raise. I am not sure at whose largess the particular staffer was there, but that is not a matter which concerns me. What concerns me is that the staffer from Mr Con Sciacca's office leaned across the table and asked a Public Service interpreter from one of the departments-not from the Department of Social Security, I understand-`Well, what did Senator Alston discuss with the delegation this morning?'. That is a disgrace.

If parliamentary delegations cannot come to this place and speak with all parties in confidence-whether or not we all know that the issues raised are social security matters-it is a serious problem. It is a serious problem if the staffers of Ministers and Parliamentary Secretaries are going to sidle up-either at a parliamentary friendship group lunch or in the corridor; I do not care where it happens-to Public Service interpreters and ask, `Well, what did Senator Alston discuss with this delegation?'. That kind of activity puts every delegation that comes to this Parliament on notice that, if it is not talking to the Government, it is not talking in confidence. It is a disastrous situation; it is a deplorable situation. I would be pleased to hear what the Minister, who may be responding tonight, has to say about that.

What was more deplorable was the reply from the interpreter, who was also sitting at the table at which I was seated. There were two interpreters arranged for the delegation, but I am talking about only one of them. I was told that this particular interpreter was not required for all of the meetings. I assume, as I was not at any of them, that was because a good deal of the membership of the Italian delegation was able to speak English. But the interpreter was in the vicinity. In response to the question `What did the delegation discuss with Senator Alston this morning?', the interpreter said words to the effect of, `Well, I was only able to eavesdrop momentarily or for a few minutes'. He then related the subject of one of those discussions.

Those are two instances which represent a serious breach of the bipartisan approach which should be taken to these delegations. I do not give two hoots if the interpreter decided for himself that the particular subject that he related was common knowledge. There may have been lots of others or it may have been the only subject-as I was not there, I do not know-but as I gather, by his remark, that he was able to `eavesdrop' only for a limited period of time, there may have been only one discussion. But it is not up to interpreters to make an assessment of whether a matter is one of common knowledge or not. It is certainly not up to a staffer from Mr Sciacca's office to seek information from an interpreter about what the Opposition has discussed with a foreign delegation. It is just not on.

The fact that this happened at a lunch raises the question: if these friendship groups are to survive, be effective and continue to be conducted on a bipartisan basis, as they have been in the past on all occasions to my knowledge, what is the purpose of having a Parliamentary Secretary's staffer there? I have no objection to an interpreter being present because some members of the delegation who may not speak English may like to have a discussion privately with one of the senators or members.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not baby sitting; they are translators.

—The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support has a small problem. I am talking about interpreters and translators. I said that I have no objection to interpreters or translators-or whatever term the Minister wants to use-being at these lunches because a member of a foreign delegation who may not speak English may wish to have a discussion with a member of this Parliament who may not speak the appropriate foreign language. In such a case the services of the interpreter or translator would be required.

SPEECH.PARA: But the question of staffers from offices is a very serious one. I see no reason why, if Government staffers are there, everyone else should not take their staffers along to these functions. We would all have a very nice party. It is a serious matter, Mr President, and it is one in which you have an interest. I hope that you and the Speaker will raise this matter with Government Ministers, get to the bottom of it and make sure that this sort of thing never happens again. The bipartisan approach to the friendship groups and parliamentary delegations is at risk, and it is a disgrace to this Parliament that we are in that situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I do not know any of the details of the issues that Senator Vanstone has raised tonight. However, I want to make two points. Firstly, the delegation is not an official delegation from the Italian Parliament; it is a committee that is visiting this country. I believe that the Italian Parliament has paid for its members to visit, so this does not fall into the usual category of bilateral delegation visits. I do know that at times the Speaker and I have had serious difficulties in trying to get enough people to attend lunches and official dinners to show courtesy to the visiting delegations, and members from Ministers' staff, my staff, the Speaker's staff and from shadow Ministers' staff have been invited. I do not know of the circumstances to which Senator Vanstone has referred tonight, but I will make inquiries about them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the adjournment debate tonight to raise certain matters relating to the administration of the State of New South Wales-matters which fall within the jurisdiction of the Government of New South Wales and which are relevant to the general election of 25 May. Tonight I wish to discuss the draining of the public purse by the Office of the Premier of New South Wales and to expose the use of polling by the State Government for absolutely blatant political purposes which serve only the interests of the Liberal Party of Australia. A public servant, Mr John Stirton, works in the office of the New South Wales Premier. Previously, he was the prime mover in the now notorious organisation known as Community Polling, an arm of New South Wales Inc., the illicit agency of the New South Wales Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: On 30 June 1988, the New South Wales Premier issued a confidential memorandum to all his Ministers. A copy of that memo has been given to me. It is to all Ministers from the Premier and is dated 30 June 1988 regarding market research and opinion polls. The text reads:
In order to have all information on hand relating to Government Market Research and Opinion Polls, I have asked John Stirton of my office to be responsible for co-ordinating this project.
Please advise your departments and statutory authorities that Mr Stirton should be informed of all proposed research so that a central register can be kept in my office.
The aim of this change is to streamline market research, combine some projects to lower expenditure and improve the current tendering procedures.
Where a Minister is interested in the responses to one or two poll type questions, this can be arranged with John Stirton on a weekly basis.
It is signed `Nick Greiner, MP.' The memorandum's real significance is revealed when the New South Wales Opposition asked for assurances that:
Publicly funded market research is not being used for party political purposes.

The Premier of New South Wales refused to give that assurance. Its significance is further revealed in a letter dated 13 March 1991 from Mr Ken Hooper, Chief of Staff for the Premier of New South Wales, to Mr Bruce Hawker, a policy adviser to the leader of the New South Wales Opposition, Mr Bob Carr. It reads:
Dear Mr Hawker,

I refer to your Freedom of Information request of 30 January seeking access to documentation relating to market research and opinion polling, conducted by or co-ordinated through the Premier's office since April 1988.
Your request has been carefully considered but it has been decided that access should be refused on the grounds that the material will be exempt under Clause 8 of Schedule 1 of the Act.
Yours sincerely,
Ken Hooper,
Chief of Staff

If one looks at clause 8 of schedule 1, one sees that it bears absolutely no relationship to government research. Why on earth could not this material be made freely available? Under further questioning in the New South Wales Legislative Assembly, Mr Greiner admitted to having circulated the memorandum, which I have quoted, and confirmed that the polling was not done by the Liberal Party. If it was not done by the Liberal Party and in the absence of other information from the Premier, the clear inference which may be drawn immediately is that this work was being paid for by the Government for and on behalf of the Liberal Party.

At the time the memorandum was circulated the public was still unaware of the existence of the organisation known as Community Polling. But as we now know in this chamber and beyond, Community Polling had three specific functions: first, to conduct covert fundraising operations for the Liberal Party prior to the 1988 New South Wales elections; secondly, to conduct opinion polling for the Liberals; and, thirdly, to conduct covert funding of dummy Independents whose preferences would flow to the Liberals in the March 1988 election. At that poll, the New South Wales Liberal Party produced a how-to-vote pamphlet that extended preferences in all of the 109 seats. I will return to that point later.

The owners of Community Polling included the former Minister for Education, Dr Terry Metherell, and the abovementioned John Stirton, also at that time an adviser to Mr Greiner. So Mr Greiner's pollster in opposition is now his pollster in government, as indicated by the memorandum. The research is paid for by public money, public dollars, public taxes. It is public waste. The $900m public waste of the Greiner-Murray Government extends to its research program.

The New South Wales Opposition has since attempted to use the totally inadequate New South Wales Freedom of Information Act to establish precisely what market and research and opinion polling Mr Stirton was conducting at taxpayers' expense. I have read the response; it is a complete stone wall.

In March this year the Premier's office refused the request, as detailed in Mr Hooper's correspondence, stating that Mr Stirton's opinion polling was exempted because it was research material. It was research material for what purpose and for whom? What on earth is the secrecy? What is there to conceal? Why can it not be disclosed? In other words, what the Premier of New South Wales said was: `Yes, it is true that polling is ongoing, but the public cannot have the material. The public and the Parliament are not entitled to the material.' He said that he was simply doing opinion polling on behalf of his Ministers, but for what purpose? This case is not disputed; it is confirmed in the Parliament. It is a matter of public record and it is not in doubt. The opinion polling was ongoing.

We also know that Mr Stirton, a public servant, is currently staying with the Premier in five-star comfort and travelling with him in Lear jet circumstances. But the Greiner-Murray Government's misuse of public moneys does not stop there. The company engaged by the Premier to do the Liberal Party's advertising for these elections is none other than Clemengers, a company headed by someone very close to Mr Greiner, Greg Daniels. Mr Daniels previously worked for Campaign Palace, the New South Wales Liberal Party's 1988 campaign advertising agency. The coincidences do not stop there.

In 1988, Campaign Palace donated $18,000 to Mr Stirton's business, Community Polling. This reflects the incestuous nature of Liberal Party Government/Community Polling deals. The tie is very clear. It is unmistakable. Subsequently, Mr Daniels and his new company, Clemengers, picked up some very handy advertising contracts from the Greiner-Murray Government. In fact, Clemengers obtained contracts for Elcom and a $13m State Lotteries account, which includes Lotto, draw lotteries and instant lotteries, to name but two. Elcom, of course, is the most compliant Government business enterprise in New South Wales. Honourable senators will have witnessed some of the recent board appointments.

Another question which demands to be answered is: what tendering went on before these contracts were awarded? What was the process? Why did the tenders go in that particular direction? There is no doubt that Liberal Party polling in the hands of this agency can be used, and indeed has been used, to finetune and target these politically motivated advertisements. Elcom is now totally politicised. Again, that is not in doubt. That is not disputed. The job awarded to the Elcom account was to make political advertisements disguised, or concealed, as legitimate public advertising on behalf of the Greiner-Murray Government.

Could it be that Mr Stirton's opinion polling and market research was tied up with this scam? Is that an unfair question? Was it the basis for the advertisements? Perhaps Mr Greiner will care to deny it. The one simple fact of New South Wales politics now is that we need believe nothing until Nick Greiner denies it. We then know that it is true. The New South Wales Government, to date, will not say anything. It has refused to give any information to the Opposition or to the New South Wales public. In the absence of any further statements from Mr Greiner or Mr Stirton, it is fair to assume the worst.

The Senate may be interested to know that the other company which picked up the bulk of the advertising account of the Greiner-Murray Government was George Patterson, a company well and favourably known to the Federal Liberal Party. It is, of course, the Federal Liberal advertising agency. This company, together with its subsidiaries, now has a $21m advertising contract with the New South Wales Government. As I mentioned, George Patterson, by coincidence, just happens to be the Federal Liberal Party advertising agency. This is incestuous indeed. The master media agency for the New South Wales Greiner-Murray Government is listed as Jamieson House Pty Ltd, a subsidiary of George Patterson-another coincidence. Between January and the first week of April this year, 94 per cent--

TALK.START.PARA: —This sounds like a speech I made two years ago attacking your campaign.
—Except I am doing it much better. Ninety-four per cent of the New South Wales media billings went to either Clemengers or George Patterson. This is extraordinary.
—Disgraceful!

—Senator Aulich is right. It is disgraceful. We have the State Liberal account, the Federal Liberal account and the Greiner-Murray account becoming totally blurred, with public money being poured into their coffers. That 94 per cent figure represents at least $2.5m in actual billings, some $300,000 minimum to the master media agency. In a full year, this would represent a minimum figure of $1m.

SPEECH.PARA: The thing that offends me and a lot of other people most is not the obvious tie between the Federal Liberals and the State Liberals. The tories are entitled to have their advertising agencies. I do not believe that they are entitled to tie them up with the New South Wales Government, which is what they have done. But, in the case of one of the agencies, we are not even talking of an Australian agency. It is a subsidiary of a foreign company. Which foreign company? Saatchi and Saatchi. This is Thatcher's agency, the agency that did so much to strengthen the social fabric of the United Kingdom under Thatcher. We have special favours being awarded and a government tied to special interests. We will see what Mr Greiner says tomorrow. As I say again, we need believe nothing about New South Wales politics until Nick Greiner denies something.

The rorting of the public purse with these overtly political advertisements became so extreme that the New South Wales Auditor-General-not the Labor Opposition; not the media-was forced to write to the head of the Premier's Department, Mr Dick Humphry. I have a copy of Mr Humphry's letter of 21 February to the New South Wales Auditor-General, Mr Robson. It states in part:

I refer to your letter of 24th January, 1991 drawing my attention to the need for the Government to have regard to advertising which may be considered as promoting the incumbent Government during periods leading up to the State elections . . .

It is interesting that Mr Humphry took a full month to reply to the Auditor-General. During that time, the Greiner-Murray Government's paid political advertising, disguised as Government advertising, continued unabated. Indeed, it continued right up to the calling of the general election. In fact, just a week ago the New South Wales Minister for Police used the internal police network, which is used for operational police matters, to promote Liberal Party propaganda. Perhaps this is not surprising, given Ted Pickering's record.

The facts are clear. Mr Stirton was a key figure in Liberal Party opinion polling, before the election of the Greiner-Murray Government, in the organisation known as Community Polling. He continued in that role when he became a public servant-and at taxpayers' expense. He continues his role in Liberal Party politics tonight.

There is an unnaturally close relationship between the polling activities of Community Polling and the blatantly political government advertising campaigns conducted by Clemengers and George Patterson. Note the financial ties that we can see all the way through this web of interlocking relationships between Clemengers, Pattersons and Community Polling. Now Clemengers have the New South Wales Liberal Party advertising account. This whole thing would be intolerable in private enterprise. It ought not to be tolerated in the State of New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Bishop, I remind honourable senators that the Premier of New South Wales should be referred to as Mr Greiner or Mr Nick Greiner, as you please. The Police Minister should be referred to as Mr Pickering. If we can use proper titles it will make debate ever so much better in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite interesting that Senator Loosley has just dropped in from Kathmandu. He has popped in to give us a little chat on his concern about what has been going on in New South Wales. While he has been away in Kathmandu, he has missed all the lovely juicy-what a shame; Senator Loosley is not going to stay. I am sure that other people will be quite interested in listening. Let us see what Senator Loosely has had to say.

SPEECH.PARA: One cannot help but feel that it was but a pathetic attempt to allay what must have been to him the devastating effect of the Burkegate expose which has been going on while he has been in Kathmandu. Not only that, but he has been away while we have seen the unemployment figures come in showing that only New South Wales has employment rates that are growing; while we have seen Victoria slip more into the mire financially; while we have seen the State Bank of South Australia lead the plummet of South Australia into oblivion; and while we have seen the murky mire in Western Australia become murkier and murkier.

Senator Loosley has missed the contortions of Senator Evans and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) trying to work out ways that they can give money to Mr Burke. Indeed, as I pointed out earlier today, they finally fixed up a way to give him that lump sum and in a way in which he can attract a lesser tax rate on it. Altogether, he has missed a whole lot of things that have been going on. Not only that, but he missed the wondrous bringing down of the report of the Resource Assessment Commission, and because he was not here he missed all the questions that were asked during the Estimates hearings concerning that Commission. In particular, he missed the questions that Senator O'Chee asked concerning the community attitudes survey conducted by the Resource Assessment Commission. Surprise, surprise, if one looks at this questionnaire, which had a bar code on it-and people who did not respond were sent a follow-up letter-one sees on page 4 in question A.6 nice, important statements, including the following:
Income and wealth should be redistributed towards ordinary working people.
Private industry should be allowed to keep more of its profits.
How nice of Senator Loosley to come back! A.6 continues:
It is possible for a modern society to run effectively WITHOUT the profit motive.
It contains further similar statements. Then we go on to question A.7:
In political matters, generally speaking, do you usually think of yourself as closer to any particular party-the Liberal Party, ALP, National Party, or what?
Then we get a rating:
Closer to the Liberal Party-1
Closer to the Labor Party (ALP)-2
Closer to the National (Country) Party-3
Closer to the Australian Democrats-4
If the answer is `Other', we gets a five. Then the survey asks in question A.8:
Would you call yourself a very strong, fairly strong or not very strong supporter of that party?

Then we get a rating of one, two or three. The extraordinary thing about that very vital information-which is clearly the business of the Resource Assessment Commission, and absolutely necessary for any work it will do!-is that the Commission then published a report entitled Forest and Timber Inquiry Consultancy Series. But guess what? There is not one syllable in it about political parties-about how closely one was to the political party, how one felt about the political party or, indeed, whether one thought that income and wealth should be redistributed to ordinary working people. So one asks: where did it go?

Furthermore, I go one step further and recall an inquiry before the Joint Committee of Public Accounts where we dealt with the question of the number of awarded accounts given to Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls Pty Ltd (ANOP). That is Mr Rod Cameron's company-we remember him, do we not? He used to be the first best friend of Mr Loosley, as he then was. But Mr Cameron and Mr Loosley had a falling out because they had a different view about the way in which ANOP served the Labor Party.

But not to worry: when we had a Public Accounts Committee hearing we had question upon question being asked and witnesses come and testify about the number of awards that were made to ANOP to do research for various Government departments, and-surprise, surprise!-we did not get so much as a sniff of a report. We did not even get a print-out and neither did the Department. Furthermore, we did not even see the questions that were asked. At least with the Resource Assessment Commission we have seen the questions, we have seen the report and we have seen the lack of information being published.

But in the other area we did not see the questions and we did not see the print-outs. Neither did the departments, because we asked them the question. Furthermore, we did not even see answers published anywhere. So I said during Senator Loosley's speech that we were getting very near the old analogy of pots calling kettles black. I said that he was looking remarkably kettle-like.

TALK.START.PARA: —He should have stayed in Kathmandu.
—Indeed, perhaps he should have stayed in Kathmandu. But one wonders, I suppose, why it was that the Labor Party wanted him to be in Kathmandu.
—They did not want Hawke at the launch.

—That is the point. The Party even organised the launch on a day when the Prime Minister could not possibly be there. It was very nice that at the Liberal Party launch we were able to have a Federal leader whom we respected and were pleased to welcome and to hear speak. Dr Hewson made a very fine speech indeed. But coming back to the sorts of things that Senator Loosley has been--
—Coming back to them. You haven't even started on them.

—Give me time, Minister. It was nice of Senator Loosley to drop by and attempt to drop a bucket, because I have distinct recollections of the John Singleton agency being awarded the Buy Australia campaign. If my memory serves me correctly, there was a little committee called the Publications Committee which vets, for and on behalf of this Government, all advertising contracts which are awarded. I think the main person who sits on that Committee is one Senator Graham Richardson. I happen to recall that we had a long debate in this chamber about the fact that the tender process went out and a recommendation was made by a committee established to evaluate the submissions made. The recommendation did not happen to include Mr Singleton. So, guess what? This time it was Senator Richardson who intervened in the tender process. He instructed the Committee to kindly reconsider the people who had applied. The person who was then admitted was none other than Mr John Singleton, who was ultimately awarded the contract, which was worth, I think, $2m at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: Now we have this whole sort of episode being perpetuated with Senator Bolkus intervening in other sorts of tenders. As we have seen, Senator Richardson was able to do it, so I suppose that Senator Bolkus thought the precedent had been set. So I hear the hollow words coming from Senator Loosley, who had his own brush with things that were difficult in New South Wales: I hear the pious words fall from the lips of an apparatchik of the Labor Party who is part and parcel of the push to have advertising banned so that we will no longer be able to have the words of political parties and independent people heard in the political process. And guess what? We are going to have the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, headed up by Mr Peter Westerway, determine what can go to air. So the question of what departments have to say is going to become much more relevant. Someone has just dropped on my desk a nice little press release, too; it is an important one. I think we would all be enlightened by the additional information here. It is put out by my good friend and colleague Senator Kemp, who said--

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't have any friends or colleagues.
—Indeed, I have, Minister. I am pleased to be able to read from this splendid press release headed `Taxpayer gives more than unions to the ACTU'. It starts off by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government probably provides more money to the ACTU than does the union movement.
In the current financial year the ACTU will receive almost $4 million-
that is, $4m cash-
from the taxpayer-more than the likely fees paid by its affiliated unions.
The latest ACTU accounts available (for 1987) show that union affiliation fees totalled $2.5 million.
The ACTU has received over $11.6 million in government grants-
let us hear that again: $11.6m cash-
since the Hawke Government came to office in 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a boofhead, Senator.
—Some of the comments coming from my right are becoming a bit hard to ignore.
—They would probably like a share of the $11.6m.
—They'll probably get it.
—They probably will; they have to pay their debts somehow. The release continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Many of the major Government departments have made grants to the ACTU-the major contributors are the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Industrial Relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Incorporate it in Hansard.

—I think we have to hear it, Minister. It is not every day that we read, and are enlightened to know, that this Federal Government-this Government headed by Mr Hawke whose first best friend is now Mr Burke, whom he has gone through contortions to protect and give money to-has also given out $11.6m in cash to the trade unions. The news release goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: The huge amount of money paid to the ACTU's foreign aid arm . . . gives the ACTU affectively an opportunity to run its own foreign policy.
Never mind a paltry advertisement or two; it can run a whole foreign policy. It can go overseas and intervene in other nations. The release states:
Money has been given to such questionable causes as the African National Congress.
This is a splendid press release from Senator Kemp. It points out:
The Government has given the ACTU $70,000 through the Department of Industrial Relations to assist the amalgamation of prosperous waterside unions.

That is the Minister's part of the world. The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) has been helping them enormously. I know he promised to resign if he did not get it right, but, really, to pay $70,000 to try to stop himself resigning is a bit rich. They are taxpayers' dollars. The report continues:
The ACTU President Martin Ferguson--
Senator Collins interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Collins!
—If I am going to be provoked I will respond.
—If you do, I will respond to you, Senator Collins. Could we cool it for a while?
—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. The release states:

SPEECH.PARA: The ACTU President Martin Ferguson recently said that the ACTU was ``part and parcel of the government''.
Clearly it is-it was given $11.6m in cash and $70,000 to fix up the Minister's mates on the waterside. The press release continues:
Senator Kemp said it was unacceptable to use taxpayer funds for the Labor Government to fund the activities of its partner in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —And so will the people of New South Wales.

—Indeed they will. So we come back to the fascinating concept that this Government, which wants to ban the right of everybody else to speak, is busily syphoning off the funds of the taxpayer to its mates in the ACTU who claim to be `part and parcel of the government' so that they can propagate the Government's messages for, and on, its behalf and deny other Australian citizens the right to speak. As I said throughout Senator Loosley's speech: more and more, the pot is looking black like the kettle.
—Just about finished, Bronwyn?

—I do not know, Minister, I think we might have something else to say. The Minister did promise to resign if he could not get it right, and we have just found $70,000 to try to help him. The Minister is not showing gratitude.
—Who do you think you are, Senator?
—Come off it!
—Pathetic.

—`Pathetic' is the right term. Pathetic was the attempted attack on the only State government which is seen to be running an effective State, and the people of New South Wales know it. `Pathetic' is the right epithet to describe that poor attack that Senator Loosley managed to give honourable senators after he dropped in from Kathmandu.
—Sit down.

—Oh dear, Senator Faulkner. I have told Senator Faulkner over the past couple of days that he really ought to be home helping out his good lady wife. She does need his help. John Singleton, to whom the Australian Labor Party paid all that money earlier, is now working for Dawn Fraser. He is working against Senator Loosley's wife; he is not working for the ALP candidate this time; he is working for Dawn Fraser, and he has made a judgment about the ALP as well. All the money that members of the Labor Party tried to siphon off in order to buy favours and so on, and all the taxpayers' money which they used improperly has not helped Senator Loosley particularly in the seat of Port Jackson. Never mind, Senator Loosley can go home tomorrow, to pitch in and help. I repeat: I would use again the word of the Minister-this is a `pathetic' attempt by a Minister who has had his own brush with difficulties in the State of New South Wales, but in fact--
—Who is she talking about-you?
—Yes, he is the one.
—He's the Minister?
—No, Senator Collins is the Minister who was talking about pathetic things.
—I have had a brush with New South Wales?
—No, Senator Loosley had the brush with New South Wales--
—And Brian Burke.

—Yes, and Brian Burke. Of course, Senator Loosley did not tell us how he managed to spend all that money raised in Western Australia and New South Wales for that campaign. We have yet to get to the bottom of the method by which the money from Connell and the like of those other lads-the ones who went to the lunch when members opposite discussed the gold tax-was transferred to New South Wales.
—He was the State Secretary when Burke was handing over the money.
—Indeed he was; he is the guy who was spending it. We have yet to hear that tale. It was nice of Senator Loosley to pop back from Kathmandu.
—That is the fifth time. It is getting a bit weary.

—Well, it was a wearisome journey over there in Nepal; it was a wearisome time. As I said, he did not have time to catch up on all the things that were going on, but when he got a report he tried a little diversionary tactic by trying to say that New South Wales somehow is suffering the plight of the other ruined Labor States. New South Wales is the only State with an economic future; it is the only State which is economically sound and has sound management. I have outlined for the chamber the manner in which the Resource Assessment Commission's forest and timber inquiry sought its information. I would be most interested to see whether in the future the Minister could inform us who got that information about party political affiliations and what was done with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel rather sorry for Senator Loosley. He was sent in here to try to save a sinking ship and he was told to talk about opinion polling. Little did Senator Loosley know that we on this side of the chamber already had a substantial amount of information about opinion polling.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Bishop said, that information was the Resource Assessment Commission (RAC) community attitude survey on forests and the timber inquiry. Senator Loosley is disappearing again; I suppose he is going to see whether his press release got a run. When I put questions to the departmental officers in Estimates Committee A, they did not even know about the survey in question. They had to take all the questions on notice. I would like to read from the answer those officers provided to Estimates Committee A on my question on notice. It says:

Political beliefs, (Questions A.7 and A.8) are a significant component of social and cultural values and are important in setting an historical context to the development of attitudes to the environment in Australia. Inclusion of the questions on political beliefs also permitted comparisons with surveys on environmental issues conducted previously in Australia and overseas which use similar or identical phraseology.
Let us just take that portion of the answer and pull it apart bit by bit, because I am going to enjoy this, as I am sure everybody on this side of the chamber will as well.

It says that political beliefs are a significant component of social and cultural values. Well, if they are a significant component of social and cultural values, why are details not given in the report? It is very simple. They are just too significant a component of social and cultural values to be put in the report because they will be kept by the Resource Assessment Commission. The RAC reports to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet. I will get back to that later. However, if political beliefs are so significant, one would have expected to find details in the report, yet they do not appear. It further states:
Inclusion of the questions on political beliefs also permitted comparisons with surveys . . . overseas . . .

Why was the comparison to be made? It was not for the purposes of the Resource Assessment Commission or for the purposes of the public, whose dollars funded this shoddy little exercise. The comparison was to be permitted for the purposes of the Labor Party, the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Prime Minister, Bob Hawke. That is why those questions were put in there and why the information was withheld.

Yet, in the adjournment debate tonight, Senator Loosley had the audacity, or perhaps the naivety, to try this shoddy little political stunt. Little did he know, of course, that we on this side of the Senate had the arguments and the answers to throw back at him. Senator Loosley so infringes the customs and traditions of this place that he did not have the courtesy and good manners to remain in the chamber to hear the reply to his speech. That is the sort of attitude that Senator Loosley has towards this chamber and towards the Parliament in general. I believe that Senator Loosley ought to abide by the traditions and customs of the Senate and stay in the chamber to hear what is said in reply. But he does not do that, and it is because he is not interested.
I now turn to the questions themselves, and I would invite any honourable senator in the chamber to show me the link between the following five statements and forests:
Income . . . should be redistributed towards ordinary working people.
More money should be spent on reducing poverty.
Most of the unemployed just don't want to work.
I cannot find any link with forests in relation to those statements. Further:
The trade unions in this country have too much power.
I might agree with that, but I cannot find any link with forests. Now comes the fifth chance for the Minister and the other senator present on that side of the chamber to find a link with forests:
Trade unions are necessary to protect the workers.

However, I cannot find any link with forests there. I could run through all the parts of A.6 in the survey, but I shall not do so. The references I have made are sufficient to show that this questionnaire was nothing but a sham on the part of the Government and the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet-and remember, it answers to Mr Hawke, the temporary leader of the ALP. Only his department and the Resource Assessment Commission have the answers to this survey.

TALK.START.PARA: —Paid for by the taxpayers.

—Yes, as Senator Knowles says, it was all paid for by the taxpayers. Senator Bishop has already referred to question A.7. It asked whether people felt themselves closer to the Liberal Party, the Labor Party, the National Party, the Australian Democrats, or others. Question A.8 asked how strongly they felt that affiliation. I suspect that the results of the survey must have been alarmingly disappointing for Prime Minister Hawke. Given the enormous plunge in the popularity polls currently being experienced by the Labor Party and honourable senators opposite, I think the Prime Minister would have felt that the response to question A.7 was alarmingly disappointing.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, we can go through and find other questions in this survey. I will take just a random sample. Question D.8.c asked people for whom they worked. It asked whether they were self-employed, private company, business employee and so on. Question D.9 is very interesting also because it ties in with Questions A.6, A.7 and A.8. Question D.9 asked whether people belonged to a trade union or a staff association. They can answer yes or no to those questions. As I said, there is a very good link between questions A.6, A.7, A.8 and D.9, but I cannot find the link between any of them and the forests.

As I said, this displays what a sham this survey was. What I find particularly disturbing is that the copies that were distributed to respondents, unlike the copy which I have with me tonight, had a bar code on the back. The answer to my question on notice was as follows:
Each questionnaire was bar coded to allow follow up of non-respondents.
I am going to be very fair to the Government here, and give it a free kick. The answer continued as follows:
This is normal practice in mail surveys to ensure the highest possible response. Cross-referencing of the bar coding to addressees was destroyed by DATACOL after each questionnaire was received.

Let us take that on face value. Let us assume, for the time being, that that was destroyed. That does not stop my constituent's fear that personal political beliefs would be kept and made available to the Government, the Australian Labor Party and any of their friends. That is a very real fear. I do not care what is said in answer to one of my questions. For me, the fear and perception of my constituent are the most important things. I think that this was a disgraceful effort. My constituent received not one, but a number, of follow up letters which she thought were of a threatening nature. Of course, this is how the Resource Assessment Commission and the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, and Prime Minister Hawke and his friends on the other side of the chamber get their information. It is funded by the taxpayer and uses methods that many respondents find intimidatory and offensive.

When Senator Loosley came in here and delivered his speech it was not for the real purpose of making a speech, but, I am sure, merely for the purpose of ensuringthat it appeared in Hansard so that he could cover himself with regard to the press release which he undoubtedly put out some time beforehand. We see that Senator Loosley and the so-called gentlemen senators who sit opposite have very little reason to come into this chamber and pontificate. I am sure that Senator Collins will get up and try to run some of the more useless arguments that he has been running about political parties on this side of the chamber. He has been running them for a while and they have not been terribly successful. No doubt, he will try it again tonight.

However, the comment I make is that every time a Government senator tries that sort of argument, it sounds less and less convincing. As the enormity of the losses in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia mount up, it sounds less and less convincing. As the enormity of the financial impropriety in Western Australia mounts up, it sounds less and less convincing. When Senator Loosley came into the chamber tonight to try his shoddy election stunt in this Federal Parliament, it sounded even less convincing than anything else.

All I would say is that I really do feel sorry for Senator Loosley. He has just come back from Kathmandu, no doubt having learned a lot from his trip. I saw a report in the paper which said that he had found out a lot about election rigging and about the stealing of ballot boxes. No doubt that is something he might want to bear in mind at a future date. But I say that Senator Loosley should not come into this chamber and try this sort of stunt. It displays a contempt for the Senate, a contempt for the chamber and a contempt for the procedures of this place. His whole attitude and his speech this evening have been indicative of that. I think Senator Loosley has done himself no credit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the Minister, I just mention that a great deal of Senator O'Chee's speech was technically out of order, because he was anticipating debate in the committee stage of the Appropriation Bills. I ask him to look at that in future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond briefly to Senator Vanstone's comments tonight. I have been an officer of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association (CPA) for most of the 15 years I have been in parliament. I listened with great care to what Senator Vanstone had to say tonight about the incident concerning the parliamentary delegation. I am rising to speak tonight only because Senator Vanstone indicated in her address that she wanted me to respond. That is the only reason I am doing so because the President has in fact covered this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I was aware that the delegation that came out here from Italy was not actually a formal, official Italian delegation; not that that makes any difference at all to the concerns Senator Vanstone raised. The only point I want to make is that, if the conversation that Senator Vanstone reported took place, it was most unfortunate.

I have been overseas only twice in 15 years in politics, which must be some sort of a record. They were both CPA trips; one trip was to Africa and the other to the Isle of Man. I enjoyed those trips immensely because of the great courtesy-and any honourable senator who has ever been on a CPA delegation will know what I am talking about-that was shown to us as visitors by parliamentarians in those countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —This wasn't a CPA delegation.

—The point I am responding to specifically-and although the President has covered it, I want to say it myself-is Senator Vanstone's concerns about staffers attending these functions. I speak in defence of the staffers, because as Vice-President of the Northern Territory branch of the CPA, I have requested staffers to attend functions twice this year on my behalf. At times we have great difficulty in relation to delegations, particularly in the dry season, the winter. Many delegations which visit the Northern Territory want to visit Kakadu National Park and to be shown around Darwin and so on. With a total membership of only 25, the CPA in Darwin often finds it difficult to extend to those people the proper courtesies that most parliamentarians want to extend.

SPEECH.PARA: A multitude of delegations come to Canberra; a week does not pass without that happening. It is occasionally embarrassing that at the functions that are put on-we need to make some sort of a show-we often cannot get members of parliament to attend because of their busy schedules.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was the staff rather than the interpreter.

—l absolutely agree with that. I am sure that this matter will be investigated by the President who, I know, is particularly concerned about matters like this. If the comment that was referred to was made, it was entirely inappropriate and unfortunate.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply want to say that I am grateful to the members of my staff who, as a matter of courtesy, twice this year have on my behalf attended functions held for delegations from overseas, when I could not attend. They have extended the courtesies that need to be extended by members of parliament to those delegations. I am personally grateful to those members of staff who do that. But I make the obvious point-and I hope it is taken-that members of staff who assist in providing those courtesies should be sensible enough to realise that they should behave courteously at these functions which they are attending on behalf of the members of parliament. I have no doubt that the President will make inquiries about the particular function that Senator Vanstone referred to in order to ensure that if the incident did happen, it does not happen again.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.34 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 12 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How often are the Average Staffing Levels (ASL) reallocated to Offices of the Commonwealth Employment Service (OCES) on the basis of new estimates for the demand for CES services.
(2) What precisely were each of the variables used in the formula the last time ASLs were reallocated among OCES.
(3) What were the relative weightings assigned to each variable used in the formula the last time the formula was used to allocate ASLs.
(4) When was the last time ASLs were reallocated on the basis of the formula.
(5) When will ASLs again be allocated on the basis of the formula.
(6) When was the last time the variables (as opposed to their weightings) were changed.
(7) If the variables have been changed, which variables were added and which were dropped from the formula.
(8) What input, if any, does the Department of Finance have in determining the allocation of ASLs amongst the CES.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The ASL for the CES is reviewed twice yearly; at Budget time and in January as part of the additional estimates process.
(2) The variables used to determine the staffing distribution are as follows:
* self service enquiries
* registrations of jobseekers
* referrals to notified vacancies
* vacancies notified
* labour market programs approvals
* numbers of labour market programs parti- cipants in training
* average applicants awaiting placement (a quarterly average)
* number of OCES
(3) Three separate regressions were used to determine the workload portion of the model, and their values are as follows:
Jobseeker Servicing Regression
Coefficients:
* self service enquiries 0.01456
* registrations 0.0492627
* referrals 0.0449148
Constant 88.945484
Employer Servicing Regression
Vacancies notified Coefficient 0.1332643
Constant 258.65492
Labour Market Programs Regression
Coefficients:
* labour market programs approvals 0.2688402
* numbers of labour market programs parti- cipants in training 1.5024089
Constant 30.589442
The Management portion of the CES staffing system (also called the `whole of office' regression formula) has the following variable values:
Jobseeker Servicing Staffdays Coefficient 1.3835305
Employer Servicing Staffdays Coefficient 1.3574088
Labour Market Programs Staffdays Coefficient 1.9371123
Whole of Office Constant-69.10719
(4) The mid year review at January 1991 was the last reallocation of CES ASL.

(5) The current staffing formula is being reviewed by the three parties to the CES staffing agreement (DEET, PSU and DoF), with a view to a new formula being implemented for the 1991-92 Budget. The next allocation of ASL will be at Budget time.
(6) The variables for the current staffing formula, which has operated since 1985-86, have not changed.
(7) See answer to 6.
(8) None.
